review_title: So so place to work at....if hired from another bank with high salary already
job_title: Equity Middle-Office Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros:
WF's securities trading unit is a pretty relaxed and friendly environment.  Everyone is really nice and the floor doesn't have any of the east coast uptight attitude.  You can definitely learn a lot if you take the time to pursue the information.

Even though the company is pretty big, each division is very close-knit so you get to interact and communicate with a lot of people.

There are a lot of volunteering opportunities as well for employees to take advantage of.
cons:
Salary at WF is a joke.  If you're moving up WF internally, your salary will never be as high as the other banks.  We're talking base pay of roughly 50%-75% of the other BB banks out there. Bonus payouts are also pretty much non-existent.  They always have restrictions for salary increases, so the best bet is to already have a pretty high salary from another company, and then enter the WF workforce.

Also, upward movement here is pretty slow too.  They do a lot of sideways moving, but it's hard to move up unless you schmooze (a lot) with the right people.

pros: I enjoy the people I work with as well as the customers that come to my particular branch (I can't say the same for other branches that I've worked at for a few days to help them out). Also, my managers are knowledgeable and pleasant to work with. They will help you when you need help and work with you when you ask for time off (I've worked for other branches when they needed extra help and the managers weren't nearly as pleasant to work with).
cons:
You feel like a sales work horse. For the amount of money that you get paid and what Wells Fargo expects of you is not fair at all. They're really cheap when it comes to raises. Whether you're a stellar performer or just average...The pay is the same and you can forget about raises. Also you get micro managed a lot...Constantly asking if you've sold anything yet.

There's a huge turnover rate at this company. I've seen so many tellers and bankers leave Well Fargo for the short time that I've been with the company. The sales pressure is a bit too much for the pay that they are given.

pros: If you are not a person that is looking for cutting edge technology and a fast paced environment then you would fit right into Wells Fargo. This is a very siloed environment and crossing department lines is frowned upon. This is a sliders dream job if you want to do one thing with no concept of what is going on with the overall company or division you are in. Modern day assembly line factory work. What is put in front of you is all that is expected.
cons: For a true technocrat Wells Fargo is a nightmarre. Innovation and individuality are frwoned upon. There is a culture of ensuring that there is no transparency between teams and departments. Experience and expertise are not valued the status quo is welcome at all times so many bright and ambitious ideas are never mentioned. Poor skills are enhanced in the culture unless this is your life long goal. Frustrating in knowing a difference can be made but not wanted, desired or needed due to the volume of customers. A very boring and poorly regimented environment where everyone leaves promptly at 5pm.

pros: benefits/PTO that's where it ends.
cons: Micromanaged to death by someone who probably previously managed a bed, bath and beyond. Unrealistic sales goals, where unless in some of the biggest markets, require unethical behavior to meet. angry customers all the time because you make them sign up for 2-3 checking and savings accts. Sub par products, no better feeling than shoving a credit card with 22% interest down someone's throat. High turnover, everyone working with me had been there less than a year, same with people before them.If you have a college degree or are an older person with just a bit of self respect I would run for the door. O I forget, Don't plan on waiving any fees even when the bank is at fault, because your expected to keep 93% of fees or it comes out of your bonus, which doesn't equal out to much more than pretzels and cheese after three months.

job_title: Bank Officer in San Francisco, CA
pros: There are none I can think of and I'm only writing this to fill in the 20 word minimum
cons:
I could take all day in jotting down what is wrong with  Wells Fargo. Do a quick Google search on their sales practices and how much trouble the company has found itself with local and federal authorities. Managers train employees how to lie to customers in order to achieve ridiculous sales goals. I resisted unethical practices, but then found myself in the cross-hairs of queen-bee syndrome female branch managers. Unfortunately, carrying my FINRA licenses while working at Wells Fargo proved  to be disastrous. Like so many before me, Wells Fargo tacked a disclosure on my U4 for "opening a bank account without a business purpose." I could laugh at this. Every single employee engaged in this behavior. I was approached about it only because my Ex called the 1-800 number and made up a story about a bank account getting opened without her permission. That's all it took. Because of this U4 disclosure I've found it almost impossible to find work at respectable financial institutions. I'm in the midst of contacting attorneys to get the disclosure expunged. 
Avoid this company at all costs. I know desperate times call for desperate measures. If you've been out of work for months and have an opportunity at this "bank," take it, but look for something else immediately. You will not be happy, unless you find a position in the back-office. Stay away from branch level employment. 
You've been warned.

When corrective action is taken it often is directed at the whole team, which allows those who really need to improve to slide under the radar of corrective action. There are also restrictive practices in place when an employee seeks to make a major career jump.

pros: Working for a large and stable company...and that's where it ends.
cons: Upward mobility completely sucks if you're in retail.  Managers will promise you a raise if you hit your numbers but then they just keep finding another excuse not to promote you. job_title: Personal Banker I in Seattle, WA
pros:
-Easy way into sales
-Patience and political cunning can lead to a lucrative career as Private Banker or Business Banker
-1 month training program fully paid
cons:
-Unrealistic sales goals. Good look even meeting the minimum sales goals tier. Constantly switching up compensation to minimize number of people that get paid. 
-You will witness people commit felonies regularly. Signing people up for credit cards without consent, opening and closing accounts without disclosing to customers (to hit sales goals), lying to people about closing accounts. 
-Customers treat you terribly at times
-Coworkers can be great, but there's a severe lack of professionalism. Comments on personal appearance, brazen sexual harassment. 
-Don't kid yourself, this is a retail job like working at Macy's or Starbucks. Expect commiserate compensation and treatment. 
-You are required to do a 20 minute interview with every person that you sit down with, probing about their financial situation. "How much do you make? Any new debts? Going on vacation? Let me open you a vacation checking, savings and debit card. And an online-purchase checking, savings, and debit card!" This last part was so disgustingly rampant. You are exploiting your customers. 
-Avoid at all costs - work at a credit union or any other entry-level sales job.

review_title: Teller, Personal Banker, licensed Personal Banker
pros:
Solid place to work. Good benefits: flexible PTO, 401K matching 6%. 
I have been lucky to work with a few great managers and have made lasting friendships with other team members.
The training is pretty good and I have experienced an excellent culture of team members supporting and coaching each other.
cons:
There can be a lot of personal drama depending on your team and manager.
Upper management and the people in corporate are completely disconnected from how life in the branch is and make decisions that don’t make sense for real life.
Lots of time is wasted on useless and extremely repetitive meetings.
It can be difficult to move up if you don’t have a manager who is interested in supporting you. It is definitely a ‘who you know’ culture when it comes to opportunities.
Career paths outside of the retail level are not clear and can be difficult to figure out. Managers typically only know the paths inside the retail branch (banker, business banker, licensing, management) and have no idea how to help team members move on other than the retail level.
Despite the change in culture away from sales there is still sales pressure which can be frustrating.
Consistently not having enough people to cover on the service and platform side despite being told the branch is overstaffed based on FTE.

review_title: Challenging and rewarding, but standardized to the point of hurting both employees and customers.
job_title: Customer Sales and Service Representative in Marquette, MI
pros:
- Excellent career opportunities; in my experience, upper management prefers to promote internally rather than hire from outside. 
- Good benefits, such as 401(k) matching up to 6%, tuition reimbursement, health insurance (including dental and vision), and stock purchase plans.
- In my experience, the work environment was very pleasant and accepting.
- Aside from call nights, work was over at 6pm every day, so I never felt overworked or that I had to juggle my work and my life.
cons:
- Compensation is not as competitive as other banks, base pay and sales bonuses both.
- My biggest issue was with Wells Fargo's obsession with standardizing everything. They want all their retail staff to be the same person, and I can say from my experience that customers do not appreciate how obvious it is that the "personal touch" has been lost.
- Too many reports. Solution Acceptance Rate, Sales Proxy, New DDAs, Rolling Fund Rate, Cross-Sell Ratio, Daily Solutions, WOW Service Scores, and Partner Referrals - I had to go over every one of these reports for every customer I interacted with. Needless to say, it took me away from doing my actual job.

review_title: Not bad, but better when it was Wachovia
job_title: Licensed Banker in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: There certainly was some truth to the phrase "banker's hours."  The benefits provided by Wells Fargo and Wachovia were fantastic.  New full time employees automatically had 19 days of PTO, but there were no sick days so you would have to use PTO time.  There is a very good level of friendship overall.  You'll never get along with everyone you work with; however, 90% of the employees at the retail level got along very well.
cons: The toughest thing to deal with was the incentive compensation plan.  For individuals hired under Wells Fargo and not Wachovia the incentive and base salary levels may be acceptable; however, for those that were originally Wachovia retail employees there was a considerable drop in bonus levels.  Also, it could be region specific, but the expectations and goals went through the roof beginning in 2011.  The metrics that each person was gauged on made it nearly impossible to reach incentives.  Also, for an internal promotion the salary increases were so negligible that it nearly made no sense to work towards a promotion.

pros: For a part-time teller position, the benefits were exceptional.  I think it's great experience to work at a bank, regardless of where you end up in your career.  The customer service experience is very good.
cons: I was there during the transition from Wachovia to Wells Fargo (I left before it officially changed over).  Employee morale was very low, and there was a general sense that we all had to be pushy sales people in order for management to think we were doing a good job.  I don't blame the management, as I know their managers were just doing the same thing to them.  I felt like I was selling people useless checking accounts that they were going to constantly overdraft and pay fees on..... very rarely did I feel like I had actually helped someone with their finances by getting them to open an account etc.  When you can't get behind the product, it's really hard to sell...

review_title: Experience and years of service mean nothing.
job_title: Senior Loan Closing Specialist IV in Clackamas, OR
pros: Solid relationships built with peers based on understanding, empathy and mutual respect.
cons: Experience/Seniority are not valued.  No personal life. Advancement is rare. Abuse is tolerated. Stress levels high.  Atmosphere is somber.

review_title: Very rewarding depending on your manager and your attitude
job_title: Personal Banker I in San Diego, CA
pros: At Wells Fargo there is plenty of positions one can explore on their career path. The growth can be very quick depending how motivated an individual is and how they go about attaining their sales goal. The compensation gets very robust as you climb your way up the latter. Hours are decent with it mostly being a 9 to 6 job with only a couple of call nights for a hour sprined in here and there. Over all I say it is a very good place to work.
cons: Wells Fargo gets a bad rap as a stressful, sales driven company which for the most part, well is true....sort off. There are many individuals in leader ship that don't know how to coach properly in order to get the most out of their employees. I've seen managers demand productivity and threaten corrective action which in itself causes team members to become disengaged and disgruntled especially newer employees that don't know what to expect.  To be fair that's not an issue limited to Wells Fargo alone but I can only speak from my experience.

job_title: Mortgage Loan Officer in Portland, OR
pros: The health insurance is ok . When they close loans the can get them done quick .
cons: Pay is terrible unless your a regional manager , their are a lot of lifers their stuck thinking that they will move up some day into management or ladder ., Overall pay sucks , points paid out for closing loans is below poverty level . Now that wells is really big in cross sale they will have some young manager fire you quick which only did the job for a few years and is wet behind the ears for sure .  I don't recommend this company at all unless your in a very high level of management your only a number and very disposable .. You can end up working here for a longtime and if you have a sit down call center job you will walk out 1 pounds heavier then you did when you walked in .

pros: Benefits and Pay, and I had one Manager that I will respect forever because she was professional and a very hard worker (she was also the only manager that was treated poorly by upper management).
cons: Out of 5 managers, I had one that was professional and reliable. After sales goals ended, co workers did not want to take care of customers and if they did payed no attention to detail and did not care. about the quality of work.  Managers had unprofessional relationships with employees and had no sense of confidentiality nor were they or any others held accountable for their actions. District managers and Regional managers turned a blind eye and no one was trustworthy. I have never worked with or for such entitled and unprofessional colleagues.  Empty promises were made and Wells Fargo does not deserve to employ good employees, hence the high turnover rate. Employees either stay because they are too lazy to leave (and therefor are a good fit for Wells)  and good ones stay because the pay is so great.  They don't care about their employees and they certainly don't care about their customers.  Money talks and after that, they could care less. What a waste of time and effort!

Political senior management

pros: #19 in the Fortune 500 list. Reputable and huge establishment, excellent on your resume. There are many positions within the bank that you can cross train and transfer to. Every team member are qualified to take advantage of the tuition reimbursement program, $5000/year is not much but its free money. Matching 401k up to 6% of your salary. 23 days of paid personal time off/per year (if you are hired before December 2008), 18 days of paid personal time off/per year (if hired after December 2008). The company gives free shares of its stock when it does well. Stability and job security (Except in retail and sales positions).
cons: The pay is not that high in comparison to other major banks. The company employs over 200k, everyone is a statistic. Your recognition is very objective. Everything is calculated by your numbers. Annual raises are usually between 1% - 2.5%, this is only an inflation raise. Conservative company and not very competitive. Seniority is a big thing in the company culture, the more years you have the more privilege you have, the downside to that is that not everyone is productive. The young talents are discouraged because they are not recognized.

review_title: Tough sales enviroment but rewarding career to those who work hard and have the taste for competition.
pros:
-A lot of development from training and coaching that you can bring into any other job.
-Very fast upward movement. (I've been promoted twice in 2 years with a skip over position in one of those promotions).
-Incentive pay outs.
-Benifits are good: Medical, Dental & Vision Insurance, 6% Matching 401k, Stock options.
-Paid Time Off.
cons:
-Sales environment is NOT for everyone, or every personality type.
-A lot of turnaround of employees due to transfers, promotions, and quitting.
-Incentive pay not as good as other banks.
-May have to work longer work days and overtime with no pay, and may have to cancel PTO due to business need. Expect to weigh Life VS Work at times.
-There could be politics or favoritism involved with promotions, VERY competitive work environment.

pros: Great benefits, fun team of people to work with, management from the branch...district...and state level will take in interest in all of their employees. If you want it bad enough, you can start as a teller and become a branch manager within in few years, I've seen it done. You can literally go from making $25k a year to $55k+ if you show you're interested enough and willing to follow their steps.
cons: Though upward mobility is encouraged and easy at the branch level, challenging to get to the next tier of the profession. Politics are very real in the corporate world, if you know the right people, you can get to where you want to be. The downside is if you're more qualified than someone who is liked more, you may not get the job. This company is also INCREDIBLY sales oriented. The branch I worked for had good ethics and were honest to their customers. Other branches (especially in larger areas that have higher goals) have been unethical and misleading to their customers. Use your right judgement, if you don't like how your branch is running, don't necessarily quit...just consider finding another branch.

job_title: Sales Support in West Des Moines, IA
pros: Once we got into the new building the atmosphere was great, for me it was probably because the campus was new.
cons: I was taking medication for anxiety that one of the side effects was doing things without thinking. I worked for the sales support team in 2009 and they were talking about cutting our pay, I got mad and said some things on facebook that got me fired, it was probably more the title of the post that got me fired. At no time did anyone ask me what was going on and I didn't even realize I posted it, they just took me in a room and told me I was done and I was escorted to the door. Had someone told me it was there I would have re worded the title or even taken it down. It appears now the team I was on has been dispersed anyway but I am not proud of what happened and sometimes I wish I could go back, but as a result I have been black listed.

review_title: There's better out there as far as banking jobs
pros: Decent benefits package but everything has a catch: up to 6% 401k match but you have to work there for a year before WF contributes, 18 days of pto to start but that's for vacation and sick time, up to $5k tuition reimbursement but they prorate it differently than most other employers.
cons: Pay below market so do your research and negotiate, especially if you're a woman. I saw way more men being promoted faster than women so where you start will matter. Also, the yearly pay increases are very little. They will pay you as low as they can get away with. In my case, the workload was heavy and the people I supported demanding/unappreciative. Basically, if you work in a support roll, you will be treated as "the help." The management structure I was under had many kinks to work out. I didn't see my career going anywhere despite the fact that I'm very career oriented and hard working.  Also, the HR department is terrible. It's an 800 number, of course. Good luck getting any help from them.

pros: Nice people. Busy all the time
cons: Sales goals. Audit was stressful period

job_title: Lead Teller in San Diego, CA
pros: Cool place to work at.
cons: Not enough pay and growth

pros: nice relaxed team, friendly and welcoming
cons: not much room for progression.

review_title: FREE THINKERS LOOK ELSEWHERE.......MINDLESS DROIDS APPLY!
pros: They're not laying people off. That's it! To work here you must like working for people who have no grip on reality and can't be honest with their boss because they have to be a yes-man so they don't get fired.
cons:
will only get ahead with a yes-man mentality and completely sellout your personal beliefts and agree to be brainwashed. management was groomed from within...these aren't people who went to good colleges and majored in management let alone have an MBA. they were good salespeople...and even though that doesn't equate to managing well....they got job.

total micro-management!!!  you would think they'd know that happy employees are better employees....but they just drag you down with all the conference calls and tracking charts and then ask why you don't hit goals (ps.....about .1 to 1% of employees are hitting the "goals"). management is a bunch of kiss-arses who only got ahead by breeding more like them. this is how companies like countrywide went down.....management not listening to the people at ground level!!

review_title: They like widget sales and many checking accounts per household
pros:
This company is always moving and things change on a continuum. 
Many opportunities for advancement.
cons:
The Scottsdale Market for Wells Fargo is unfortunate. They are caught up in upselling to the nth degree of consumer and business products. For a single customer, they would offer a direct deposit checking account, an on-line banking checking account, a travel checking account. They think that the more checking accounts one person or business had, the better. BEWARE of the month of January... they expect you to open many accounts for your friends and family. My branch manager was also of the office for weeks... Didn't have proper support of management. 

Caution: If you're doing well, you can compensated via your bonus. If you're not doing ok, you'll get written up.  If something bad happens, it's your fault and management didn't know about it. 

Caution No2:  This place has become a very micromanaging company. Not only did the manger have a morning, afternoon, and evening checkin with the district manger. You'll get your over the shoulder check in as well.

review_title: Company Great, Branch management not so much
pros: The company seems to be all about the employees and doing the "right" thing for customers. They offer a lot of development opportunities, benefits, and support for their own employees. Very quick upward mobility, if you consistently exceed your sales and customer experience goals. This company has a belief of training and retaining their "best" people. Customer satisfaction surveys keeps the employees engaged and be mindful of their customer relations skills.
cons: Banking is not for everyone. The base pay for their positions is lower than Chase's and Citibank. The incentive pay for WF heavily relies on customer satisfaction surveys (5 or nothing) and sales goals. The sales goals are so aggressive, that it leads the employees to turn to unethical practices to reach them, while the management turns a blind eye to these said practices. The managers even sometimes teach them these practices, but when someone gets caught, they immediately abandon them.

job_title: Licensed Personal Banker in San Francisco, CA
pros: I been with WFB for almost nine years. It is a lot to learn from your daily work, every day there is something new.
cons: The sales goal and customer service rating is unrealistic, all numbers game. However, when I took the job, I have to do what the company requires. The management is pushing us every day, no matter how good was your last performance. If you argue that the goal is too hard to achieve, the manager will threaten you with words as "termination, insubordination, formal warning, and no bonus even though u achieve the bonus level." Managers always play favoritism, if she/he didn't like you, no matter how good is your performance, you will not get promoted to the next level. In WFB rules are set, but not carry about by the managers. Every managers have their own set of rules, and sometimes those rules are conflict with the company rules. When you complain it to the HR department, no one cares, and when it suppose to be anonymous, sorry your manager will find out who was the person that file the complain. I will not recommend anyone to work for this company for their long turn career.

pros: The Bank has a great culture of inclusion, terrific values, nationwide footprint, and the rank in file is generally caring and committed to doing a good job the right way.
cons:
Mid to upper management frequently talks about the values of the company and how important the rank and file are to the success of the Bank. However, management rarely practices the values they preach; they could care less about their employees as all that matters is the job getting done and who does it matters very little.
The company is so big that they leverage this so that they can pay less than market salaries and yearly raises are never more than 2%. Also, career development is almost non-existent and I saw very little promoting from within.
Health insurance is also bottom of the barrel.

review_title: Some managers care, others really don't
pros: Work life balance is good. I have worked with great team members and have been able to build my customer service skills. It's a good job to start out especially working through college for the paycheck and experience.
cons: Some bad management and even more terrible ones. There are branch managers who were apart of the sales scandal and act like those sales goals are coming back. They constantly degrade, but don't help you with your growth or assist with building a plan to help you reach the next position. They want to take credit for the success their team members make in the branch, but haven't done anything to reach those goals. Constantly getting threatened to be written up for something minor, because they can no longer threaten to fire over not cross selling enough. 8 was never great for the account holders who have a below to mid average income. WF says there's no pressure to sale products, but threaten to close and shut down branches for not generating enough revenue. The health insurance is terrible and the best compensation really just goes to BM and DM.

pros: There were not alot of pros
cons: Not good for long-term growth

job_title: RB Branch Manager in Delray Beach, FL
pros: The Health benefits are somewhat decent
cons: Senior Leadership is tainted! Fear based management.

pros: Company advancement, thorough training, compensation
cons: All about numbers and sales

pros: Insurance, 401k, Modern Day "Banker Hours"
cons:
Ever since the LA Times and New York Times articles have come out, there has been a push now instead of solutions, its all about how the tellers phrase their questions to customers, they are being told how to speak, yet we can't say its scripting.  But when it comes down to it, its 100% still product pushing, Service Managers are the target of the week, since the ways to get solutions have gone down, the Service Managers are expected to "ride" or "get on" the tellers for more and more handoffs.  The tellers are now miserable, as well as the Service Managers.  
Service Managers are required to do 2 observations per teller per day, to go over "strengths, and opportunities" Then the Service Manager's observation is critiqued with the Branch Manager.  Its definitely not a "culture of caring" anymore. It depends on your Branch Manager weather you get any positive reinforcement since the District Managers are genuinely only interested in sales but they thinly veil it as "behaviors". There is a distinct disconnect from the Region Ideas down to the Branch level. It is a caustic environment in the branches and no one seems to care. PTO for the entire branch is controlled by the District Manager because they don't think a branch can handle their own pto schedule.

pros: None. I would say the pay but the company actively tries to keep you down.
cons: Low pay, no room for growth, intense pressure from every supervisor on up to procure sales.

review_title: A good job to have for college
pros: It was great to experience the positive attitude and great coworker environment at Wells Fargo. The job is looked highly upon, and as a Teller you really learn how to talk to new people, find mutual interests, and influence them. This has helped me already, both in being more inquisitive and assertive. Great for a job part-time job, and they even pay tuition reimbursement for part-timers after six months.
cons: This is stymied by the fact that compensation is below average (compared to other entry-level Teller positions at local banks) and that you're really pushed to sell. Even though we were told to be careful (I worked there in 2010) to not get people into bad situations, our 'helping' the customers always seemed a bit wrong. Sure, if you transfer your credit card balances to our credit card, you might not have to pay interest for six months ... but you can believe that we will sure profit after those six months.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: 401(k) match, profit sharing, standard banking hours, good insurance
cons: If you work at Wells Fargo, you are under extreme pressure to meet daily, monthly, quarterly, and annual sales goals. Do not think for one second they care about you as a person. You are a number in a numbers game. You are expected meet your sales goals and if not you are not promotable and not worth their time. many employees game to meet their goals. Every keystroke you make is on report and you will hear about it. Opening a checking account is not enough. You need to open four or more products per customer at minimum with a cross sell goal of eight. The people that get promoted in this company typically have less experience and knowledge, but have met their sales goals or exceeded them. Being good at your job here does not get you ahead. You can be a star performer, but it's all about who you know.

pros: Great way to start off a sales career.  If you are willing to work hard, and quickly build an honest, and trustworthy portfolio, you can move up the ladder, but please note that this is rarely done, and only highly ambitious, smart, hard-working people can succeed this way.
cons: Right from the beginning you are pushed and shoved to sell products to all your relatives/friends, and the demand to produce numbers is whispered in your ear at least 10 times a day.  If you are not a hustler, you will not survive. The environment is toxic, which is governed by an 80s sales approach.  Get in, get trained, get a customer base, network, and get out.  Turn over rate is ridiculous! People do not last. Management is constantly reminding you that there are other candidates eager to apply, which there are.  You never feel "safe", you might be praised one day and fired the next!

job_title: Senior Personal Banker in Washington, DC
pros: Plenty of press and brand recognition.
cons: A terrible company. Everything is about the bottom dollar, just jam clients into accounts, 5 conference calls a day about sales goals, every hour and 45 min wanting to know where you were on your goal and what you were going to do to exceed it? Telling Manager on your sales spreadsheet how many accounts, loans, "sticky products" you've managed to convince people to get.

review_title: A great company that has some drawbacks...
pros:
Excellent benefits.
Many locations, and ease of transfer if you move.
Friendly, motivated coworkers.
Good incentive compensation, and team-oriented goals.
Many opportunities for promotion in a very wide variety of fields within the company.
cons:
Very high pressure to perform: Wells Fargo rates employees in the retail stores based on only two significant factors - Sales and service. If you aren't selling as much as you can every day, you will be cut, guaranteed.

Constant transfers: Wells Fargo transfers its employees to different branches compulsively. In the time I worked there, I was transferred once, the two managers at the two branches I worked were transferred, and multiple other bankers and tellers were transferred. Needless to say, you will not likely build a close relationship with most of your coworkers due to this. Regular customers also recognize this problem, and are lax to get to know you.

High pressure sales atmosphere: Very high pressure to meet daily, monthly and quarterly sales goals. The pressure is such enough that you may likely encounter questionable ethical situations. If you don't have a strong moral compass, you can easily get sucked in. Don't.

job_title: Personal Banker in San Antonio, TX
pros:
Pay is top in the market!
Your can use your PTO for just about anything you can think of.
Locations are just about at every corner.
cons:
Ethics are HORRIBLE! sure the pay is great, but you have to sacrifice your soul to get there.
they say the have an ethics line and that anything will be reported and that they follow federal regulations and are for the customer...but thats a total piece of caca.
they will bend rules and put people into accts just to get there fees. and they will encourage it! but as soon as a customer reports you then its your butt, not the managers who pretty much made you do it or your job would be put on the line. EVEN THOUGH, in the end...your job will still somehow still be put on the line. 
IF YOU HAVE GOOD ETHICS AND STRONG MORALS, THIS IS THE WRONG COMPANY
if you want great pay and don't care what you have to do to a person's financials, this is perfect.

review_title: Very sales-oriented, but overall not terrible.
pros: Good pay, great paid time off, promoted within company to deserving employees. If you are good at sales, they have decent incentives as well. Plus, it helps to get you from job to job. You can start applying for promotions after 6 months in your current position. In a year's time, I had already jumped 2 spots.
cons: WF has very high sales goals, for each individual, not just the company total. The goals are the same for each job family in each store, no matter the traffic. In a very high-traffic location, sales seem to come on their own. This drives the goals up even higher. But in a slower part of town, employees can get written up for not meeting the same goals even though it is almost impossible without unethically forcing products onto customers.

job_title: Service Manager II in Beaumont, TX
pros: Able to work with great people that are wanting to advance in their careers.
cons: HOURS, PAY, SALES PUSHING and not being able to spend anytime with my family due to work

review_title: Great company, not so great employees
job_title: Loan Document Specialist in Charlotte, NC
pros: Benefits and pay scale are amongst the top in the market. They do look after their employees...almost to a fault.
cons: They are not afraid to work you a ton! Many employees are in such a hurry to advance that they are too willing to step on your neck to get ahead. I'm a competitive person, but some of my fellow co-workers were over the top. Unwilling to help those that are new, and only help out if it benefits them in some way. Also, for being the biggest company in the market, their software leaves something to be desired. I remember having to fill out "thanks a million" requests to people just to get them to do a flood review for me, (otherwise they wouldn't do them for a day or so.) How about just do your job??

pros: Good pay, good benefits, overall good corporate culture and company outlook. Most processes were very organized, well defined and managed. There didn't seem to be any lack of budget money for equipment or headcount, which always makes things easier.
cons: The technology umbrella of teams was not a hospitable environment. Most people seemed to care more about their job security and making themselves look good rather than helping out a new employee. This included peers up through the few levels of management I dealt with. The management structure was also very confusing and seemed unnecessary in some departments. There was a distinct lack of work-life balance and the lightly hinted at after hours work from the interview became multiple nights per week with some weekends (weekends were never mentioned). With a low end estimate on average overtime I was making less per hour than my previous job, so I got out ASAP. It also turned out I had a newer manager that was terrible at managing people, but I can't hold that against the company too much.

pros: Management, supervisors, leads. I was lucky to have manager night shift,probably best I've ever had.great benefits, 401k,bonus,lots paid time you can't use it unless your take occurance. Positive,HR is great opportunity
cons: The metrics, someyes its hard working under these kinds of pressure. Seems leads,coaches,suervisors (not all)/quite a few, sit around a just talk all night after the bid guy is gone.want good cust survey,sales,quality sometimes it won't happen 3mins with customer has issue. Hold time is 30/mins.I think if they stopped pushing employees and customers with sales I believe the good old fashioned help and care the customers wouldn't need to be sold. The hours,impossible to get help with schedule change or even take the time to talk to anyone. My manager and lead made up for all of this though.

review_title: Strong Company, Action Not Always Equal to Words
pros: Financially stable, customer focused, good base pay and benefits. Flexible scheduling to attend to items outside work when necessary.
cons:
Continuously states that senior management believes that people are the key competitive to the business, but then take actions that do not coincide with those statements. Case in point, profit sharing contributions. If the team members truly are the most important asset of the bank, wouldn't a contribution of more than 1% be more reflective of that value? The trend is a continuous decline from 4%, 3%, 2%,1%, and 1% for the past 5 years all while the bank earns record profits of well over $5 BILLION / qtr.

This behavior combined with a non-stop focus on cost cutting makes it feel like we're working at a small, community bank, rather than one of the world's largest and most profitable banks.

Finally, the expectation that we should always be available to the needs of the business, even late nights and weekends makes for a poor work / life balance.

review_title: How to truly treat employees as assets is a topic that top executives need to learn
pros: Wells Fargo has a culture to get things done - as a Product Manager, you can secure funding for initiatives, move forward with projects, and deploy value added products/services quickly.
cons: The organization structure, and # of business managers managing the same product or service makes it almost possible to shine for ambitious, capable, and "exceeding" employees. Young business managers may find there's no place to move up, or even be assigned with a handful of meaningful tasks each year. The company treats corporate employees (especially those that are not based in San Francisco) like assembly line workers. Our floor hasn't been renovated for more than 10 years, with dirty carpet, awful looking cubes, and crowded space - all of which can create a very negative working environment. Recently company even cut the cost by getting rid of colored printers. We don't even have dish detergent at the break room.  Really?  Wells Fargo?

job_title: Financial Advisor in Newport News, VA
pros: Despite recent negative news from bank channel, the senior management of WFA is top quality. They truly have a "put client first" attitude. My job, working with clients all day long, is highly rewarding. I've enjoyed working with the same clients for over 15 years, getting to know their families.
cons: Downside would be the ever growing regulatory requirements that makes being productive more difficult and complicated. But I believe WFA has responded with tools and technology to make it as easy as possible, but that said, it's still challenging.

pros:
Benefits. 4 month paid paternity or maternity. I get over 30 plus days paid off a year. Made good money and they invest in training for sure. 

Seems like they are trying to get better I think.
cons:
Definitely don’t pay as much per loan as other companies. 

-middle management seems like a waste of a salary

-processing issues with loans. Lose clients because of lack of communication or process delays

-lots of micro management even for top producers

-everything is an email. No real conversation or healthy confrontation 

-do things to make people quit so they don’t have to give them severance. (Middle manager). Can’t say this is indicative for the whole company. 

-no real positions to advance to in mortgage sales

-been losing market share because of stagnant innovation

-seem content to lose market share for now. Give you corporate reasons that don’t make sense.

job_title: Phone Banker II in El Monte, CA
pros: Great training that will help you go far in banking
cons: Lots of discrimination and favoritism. Lots of sexually harrassment known by management. Men make bets on  which new hire they can take down first. Again management is aware of this. Have to kiss butt or be personal friends to get a chance regardless of your work ethic. Pressure to sale to customers but they like to call it financial help to avoid getting in trouble by the government. Management will try to fire you if you get on their nerves or challenge them. New hires get paid more than workers who been there for years. You wont get more than $.50 cent raise a year regardless of how good performance is. Customers tend to survey the bank when they get asked to do survey on reps and even when managers listens to call and find rep did a great job the rep will still get disciplined. This will result in a bad performance metrix. Get in trouble for going to the restroom to much.  Not enough time to pump if breastfeeding. A lot of people scared to speak up on serious issues due to not being considered for promotion or being treated unfairly.

review_title: Wells Fargo retail banking is not for those with business degrees.
pros: If your a college student and need a part-time job with good benefits, being a teller is a good position for you.
cons: I just graduated from college with a finance degree in May and cannot apply for another job within the company until I fulfill one calender year in my current teller position. So now I have to look outside the company for a job. There is no way I can survive on my own on a tellers salary. I explained this to management and they wont budge. I am the only one in my branch with a college degree and it makes me feel worthless working as a teller. I recently interviewed for a analyst position for an insurance company and was treated with much more respect and worth.

job_title: Consumer Loan Underwriter/Loan Processor in Birmingham, AL
pros: Steady employment as long as work is available. I would not suggest this to anyone I know.
cons: The entire organization is unorganized and the people who are in upper management seem to be the problem. Technology releases are sent out without testing and cause problems in more than one program. The people making business decisions do not put any thought behind what they are doing - for example - The Birmingham 3-Step HARP processing site, that has proven success over the past 4 years, was closed and all of the work was transferred to another site. As an underwriter in the refinance program I was able to see the level of understanding in the process between the employees who were replaced in Birmingham, and the understanding of the processors in Iowa. This was a terrible business decision and I am sure the person who was in charge of this should not be in their position as most management who make terrible decisions. Most of the management within the corporation do not deserve their positions and in general do not care about their jobs, they are sitting back collecting money with job security through diversity.

review_title: Great place to work if you love sales
pros: Wells Fargo provides decent hourly wages but makes it worth it with excellent sales and customer service incentives. Hours are always the same and you are always off by 6pm and off on Sundays because of bank hours. They like to promote from within so you have plenty of opportunity to grow within the company.
cons: If you are not the best sales person, you will have a really rough time with managers harassing you about sales and quotas everyday. A big part of your performance is based on randomly conducted customer service reviews, which unless you receive absolutely perfect scores on, can lead to extensive coaching and a negative impact on the whole branch. You could have a perfect interaction with a customer and still receive zero for the review if that customer chooses to put a 4/5 for one of the categories. During my time with the company I worked for two branches and experienced shortages of employees at both which meant time off was difficult to come by. I also noticed that there was quite a bit of office politics and favoritism going on in each which greatly affected promotions and my overall confidence in the company.

review_title: It should come as no surprise
job_title: Personal Banker II – Registered in McLean, VA
pros: They do like to promote from within, albeit at a lower pay scale than what they pay outside people to come in for but since turnover is abundant (see below) there are opportunities to be promoted.
cons: This is place that only cares about sales numbers. Nobody cares how you make your sales goals as long as you make them. I've worked in aggressive sales environments and this place takes the cake. They push ethics but promote the opposite, at the end of the day you have to do what you have to do to hit your numbers otherwise you will be pressured and treated poorly by your manager until you quit or they can find a way to get rid of you.  Google the lawsuits against the company by employees and believe that hype, this place is horrendous.

job_title: Business Intelligence Manager in Des Moines, IA
pros: Great pay and great benefits. Culture is great and full of team players.  Wells Fargo encourages your personal development and growth, which I really liked.  They also encouraged you to seek new opportunities within the company as you developed so could be where you would add the most value to the company
cons: 20% of the people do 80% of the work but the annual compensation doesn't reflect this.  Slow to address performance issues up and down the chain of command.

job_title: Claims Analyst in West Des Moines, IA
pros: The benefits package is very competitive, they offer 18 days PTO, 2 personal holidays, all national/bank holidays, 16 hours of volunteer service time, and 16 weeks 100% paid parental leave for primary caregivers after the addition to a family, including adoption.
cons: This company does not care about the financial well being of their employees or customers. All of their calculated moves following the major fiascos in the last 2 years have been to save face for the executives and shareholders. Employees face constant stress due to the quick pace of change rollouts and are not compensated to reflect their hard work. The "culture of caring" and "raise your hand" initiatives are just empty promises to do better while just a ploy to line the pockets of those at the top. There are limited positions for growth and movement which magnifies the feeling of being stuck in a dead end/thankless job. This is not a company to make a career at, though their benefits package is good, there is much to be desired from the mismanagement of this company and its goals.

job_title: Vice President in San Francisco, CA
pros:
1. Competitive Benefits
2. Excellent 401k matching plan (6% plus 1% annual profit sharing).
3. Highly competitive salary - provided you are able to meet or exceed your sales goals.
4. Great name to have on your resume.
5. Credit Management Training Program is a career accelerator for bankers with only 2-3 years of work experience.
cons:
1. The Credit culture is very conservative and it is difficult to do deals that would otherwise be easier to do at other large banks.
2. Wells Fargo has a very difficult reputation in the market place due to the well publicized scandals that are emerging frequently .
3. Sales goals are very aggressive and are NOT limited only to the retail side of the bank.
4. If you are unable to meet your revenue goals, you will be treated like a second class citizen and your bonus will suffer. 
5. The bank has a “do more with less” mentality right now due to expense management initiatives. As a result, a lot of employees are working increasingly longer hours and are charged to do tasks outside of their job description but still expected to meet their sales goals.
6. Lots of cost cutting which means entire groups/departments are getting disbanded.

pros: Good people to work with and good benefits are at the top of the list followed by work life balance.  Work from your home is also allowed.  Training opportunities are good to very good
cons: To much talent is wasted where individuals are limited to their silos.  Poor management and far to much dependence on Indian and other offshore workers.  To much software development  is done by offshore workers.  Very little direction from management but due to a “lead yourself “ practice.  Far to much political correctness.  Career advancement is difficult within your organization and only possible by applying for other roles within the company.  Only career path for senior technologists is to go into management

review_title: Not a good company to work for
job_title: Loan Administration V in San Francisco, CA
pros: well known employer with decent medical and PTO time
cons: Low ethics, only care about $, have little care for employee well being

job_title: Licensed Personal Banker II in Denver, CO
pros:
Flexible, opportunities for advancement, great benefits, growing and well established brand/company.

There are tons of different career paths within Wells Fargo and many different ways to advance. The top performers move up quickly while the employees who aren't 100% committed find other gainful employment.  

It is a fast paced, ever changing environment. It is hard to stay bored when you focus on the work in front of you. It is a 9am to 6pm job, with Saturdays included.
cons:
Heavy emphasis on daily sales, tedious micromanagement. 

Our branch is "under the microscope", so-to-speak, and that microscope focuses down. It is no exaggeration to state that our sales goals are asked about hourly. "Where are you at? (in terms of sales numbers) What are you doing to hit/exceed your goals? What do you have planned for the next day, 5 days, week? etc." 

All of these are great questions, but when they are asked no less than 5 times a day, they lose their effectiveness very quickly. Motivation turns to derisive sarcasm and an apprehension to walk near management in fear of being frisked verbally.

review_title: Micromanaged environment so you're just a number
pros: PTO, Bonuses (if you can reach the high goals to get them), Benefits
cons:
You're just a number when you work in retail banking. Your day consists of squeezing sales out of every customer regardless if they need the product or not. You are taught to drink the "corporate" kool-aid. This means if you express dissatisfaction with your environment, you are viewed as negative instead of opinionated. Expressing yourself typically ends on deaf ears. This is typical in company of this size.

Your manager's manager's manager drives ridiculous sales goals down your throat on a regular basis. 

The turnover is so high in this position that it's not even funny. Talk to former WF employees and you'll hear some of the same. The robots that still work here don't know anything outside of WF jargon that doesn't even make sense.

review_title: CSR in a Mortgage Call Center
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Frederick, MD
pros: The pay was not that bad.
cons: Every minute of your day is scheduled, including when you can use the bathroom.  Everything you do is monitored.  While the position claims to be about customer service, the most important thing to mgmt is that you cross-sell completely unrelated banking products.  The sales goals are set so high that most employees lie constantly to customers in order to meet them.  Every mistake and shortfall will be reviewed by several supervisors in "coaching sessions."  Overtime is mandatory every week because despite constant hiring the turnover rate of employees is too high to keep any of the call centers properly staffed.  You show up in the morning and some of your coworkers are just gone, and no one speaks about it ever.  The doublespeak is Orwellian, and you will witness unethical and illegal practices on a daily basis.  This place will crush your spirit and demand that you have zero ethics, all while treating you like a child.

review_title: Not a good experience but I think it depends on Store
pros: Good and affordable health benefits, Paid Holidays, Good hours.
cons: Wells is a big Company therefore they don't know who their managers really are or what really goes on in the branches. Teller Manager I was working with tried to do some unethical things, I refused and went down hill after that. Store manager was informed about issue and since the teller manager had been there for years she practically told me I was lying. After I told her I would tell Human Resources about it so they can fix the issue, she finally decided to believe me and talk to teller manager(which stepped down to lead teller ). I felt very uncomfortable after that, I only lasted 6 months with the company for that reason and this is the company I have lasted the least amount of time with. In my past jobs I have lasted 2 years and 4 years, kinda wish I would have told HR about the problem but I wasn't sure if they were going to dismiss me like the store manager did.

review_title: I loved working for this company.
job_title: Personal Banker I in Mesa, AZ
pros: Excellent employee benefits! It feels great to work for a company that has made a very respectable name for itself.
cons: Caution - If you do not like intense sales pressure you would not enjoy working on the retail side of wells fargo. This is at times a "con" because too much sales pressure can lead to an unethical work environment and culture.

job_title: Credit Risk Analytics Consultant in Des Moines, IA
pros: My team had a great work/life balance and very flexible schedules but it really depends on your job and manager.  I would rate the pay as above average for newer employees.
cons: Good pay early on but can easily "cap out" and feel like your career is a lame duck.  Much of the work is extremely tedious, we can spend months to fulfill a request from internal auditors because they really don't know what they want you to do, just keep wanting to see it done differently.

pros:
There are a few good hard-working people.
There are interesting things about the banking industry.
I know not to bank there.
cons:
Do not rock the boat culture.
Which translates into very little, if any accountability.

Managers have a great ability to completely ignore problems dealing with personnel.
Which sounds exagerrated, but multiple managers did nothing about a contractor that slept most of every day for 18 months.

Have never witnessed so many people so completely comfortable doing absolutely nothing.  
First place I was physically unable to work because of all of the continual outside distractions.
Witnessed a contractor get hired full-time after he had spent the previous months doing mostly nothing but having other people over to talk.

Worked with another manager that had no clear goals, but would continually send multiple people off in circles.
Extremely, and usually unnecessarily so, difficult work, where I was going 100 MPH every second of every day.

Very questionable methods of analyzing results.
Continually found major problems with processes and data that should have been taken care of long ago, but were not even considered.

Gave notice and offered up to 8 weeks to help in transition.
Contract was ended the following day, contrary to previous conversation I had with manager.
Apparently this is common.

Some managers could use some people skills. 
Most everyone is mostly concerned with their own comfort.
Zero consideration for conditions for contractors.

No sir.  I didn't like it.

pros: Networking opportunities with the wealthy. You meet the who's who and find great opportunities for yourself. Talk, talk, talk yourself to a better career. That is exactly what I did! I used this platform to mingle and network with those that I would not have ordinarily had the chance to. You meet the high ranking executives at fortune 500 companies and more! Use this as a stepping stone to something better.
cons: WF focuses on sales more than customer service. They have no clue what ttue financial success and freedom truly is. They believe offering CC and loans equates "helping their customers succeed financially". Delusional sales goals. Unrealistic expectations on Teller and Banker side. Unfair business practices. LOW, LOW pay even in Management rolls. They ate constant giving away money but not giving decent raises.  YOU CANNOT feed your family here as a teller or lead teller.  Impossible without state benefits. My family has need surviving off food pantries for the 4yrs I have been here.  Finally after networking with my wealthiest customers, I landed a 6 figure income doing rewarding work!

pros: The management keeps in constant communication with you. They try to make it a fun work environment by using games and prizes for sales competitions. Over all the management is pretty nice.
cons:
If you work here be prepared to be cussed out several times a day!

The downside is the customers. The people who are calling in about their account information are 80% of the time very rude and treat you like CRAP!  Either they are very uneducated about banking and blame you personally for their mistakes even though you have no control over what happened to their account. On the other hand the are very educated in banking, or at least they so, and believe there is no possible way they made a mistake or could have possibly forgotten to record something. It wouldn't be so bad if the customers didn't personally take it out on you.

review_title: Great bank but has a ways to go to be more customer focused
pros: Wells is focused on being the best bank it can be.  It sets high standards for itself and its employees and their work.  It continues to work through the merger with Wachovia and is trying to be sure that its taking the best examples from both cultures to make a new culture. It does care about its employees.
cons: Like all banks its heavily regulated and is dominated by legal, compliance and other departments who are watching risk and exposure.  We want our banks to be stable, however depending on the department you are in (eg marketing, internet), you might find this stifling as you try to get to parity with the outside world.  In addition the culture is heavily product focused and branch driven so the needs of the customer sometimes get lost.

review_title: Very stressful work place because of the Micromanagement!
pros: Based on my experience, I think that helping people from different backgrounds is the only positive part.
cons: The micromanagement by uneducated managers is very stressful. It made me hate the job and quit after few months. I hated the "one on one" meeting because the managers that I worked with used it to criticize every little thing I do rather than giving positive feedback. I suffered and cried a lot during the few months that I worked there since I am not used to be treated badly. The mangers that I worked with only had high school diplomas! they had no idea about neither being good mangers nor about treating their team well through a healthy management.

pros:
1. Pay is Good. 
2. Infrastructure
3. Cabs
4. Canteen
cons:
Many, Lets start with History little bit,when it started in Hyderabad, they hired people like cattle, from XYZ companies and now they are in Management posts and would never retire from here.
Now what this means
1. They formed a big team [ Called Leadership Team & LOB Heads ] and they create new roles for themselves and create new initiatives for their career growths and who works for that ? Team Members.
2. At Hyderabad they all talk in local languages even in meetings, so if you don't know local language you are in catch22.
3. Some Managers have GirlsFobia so there are many "All Boys" teams.
4. Politics & Lack of Transparency is the factor why many & many people are Leaving.
5. Good works [Development] are given to Contractors and Support lies with full time employees.
6. People are self acclaimed leaders here, without knowing technologies they become Architects and when projects fails blame game starts and they fire at lower levels.
7. Too much fun activities and that too by same people who are arrogant like hell.
8. My Dad's time technologies are used. Mainframes
9. Managers They don't utter a work in front of US teams and consider them as vendor as many of them came from Indian Service Companies so expect Micro Management, Time Tracking and peeping into your monitor while they pass

pros: They make sure that you take your 15 minute breaks and 30 minute lunch. 3weeks paid time off for sick leave or vacation. The co workers are pretty nice because everyone is going through the same nightmare.
cons: This was the worst job I ever had. Extremely high stress. Customers yell at you. You have to keep your average time per call under 5 minutes. So if you get a long call because someone has a difficult problem then you have to try to cut time off the rest of the calls to stay under the time benchmark. They have a quality assurance team that reviews your phone call and if you make a mistake you get written up. Mistakes can be something as simple as how you phrase something. It gets really dicey when you have a customer yelling at you and you're on the call too long so then your supervisor is yelling at you too. You're powerless because you can't hang up on the customer or be rude so you have to just put up with being yelled at continually from both sides. There are a multitude of metrics that you have to meet. Supervisors are really intense on those metrics because their bonuses are based on that.

job_title: Personal Banker in San Francisco, CA
pros: The job is fairly simple, no real financial skills or know how necessary.  If you have a past sales experience job is fairly easy to get and they are always hiring due to high turn over.
cons: All that matters to them is sales.  When you are hired they tell you it is about customer service but don't be fooled, all they care about are new accounts.  Don't expect to get a day off in January.  Vacation days are blocked the entire month for everyone working at a branch.  In order to do well you need to avoid customers who need help and concentrate on new accounts.  If you take a job in a low income area you will never make your loan goals because Wells Fargo will not approve any of the loan applications.

review_title: Most disgusting company I've ever worked for in my 30 years of working!!!
pros: My favorite part of working for this company was a comination of the day I gave notice, six weeks later I left and never had to go back.
cons: Employees are replaceable, disrespected, not trained well, underpaid, the list is immeasurable!!!  By far, the WORST company I've ever DEALT with and WORKED for.   I would rather be homeless than to ever work for them again!!!  I had one day of training, and then one week of a "trainer" on location.  I can't tell you how many "I don't know the answer to that one" replies I got from this so called trainer.  That's insane.  SO many customers closed their accounts after we merged because they were disgusted.  I do NOT blame them at all.  Insurance is awful and they manipulate the incentive pay system to their favor so you'll never get bonus. I saw them in action and it's ridiculous.  Don't work for this terrible company !!!

review_title: you better sell if you want to work there
pros: I liked the people I work with. Other than that, I can't say a whole lot of good things about Wells
cons: Managers act like they are your friend and want to help you and then one day, they pull you in the office and tell you that you're on an informal warning for not meeting sales goals. Then it's a formal warning and then termination. Many have been terminated for failing to meet sales goals. Of course they don't like when you use the word "sales", they claim it is "finding solutions for our customers". No, it's tricking them into getting additional products and services whether they need them or not and if you don't get the sale, it's always your fault. "You should have asked more probing questions" or "you should have given them more benefits" is what you'll get from managers. There is no objection that can't be overcome if you just say the right words. It never crossed their mind that the customer is just not interested. It's a shame. Wells Fargo has the potential to be a great place to work.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Hilton Head Island, SC
pros: This is one of the leaders in the Banking industry.  You will have the ability to relocate to almost any state in the country.
cons: This is a "what have you done for me today environment".  There is constant pressure for sales numbers!  The customer nor the employee are valued.  There is a lot of turn over.  They churn and burn.

job_title: IT Senior Manager in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Work with some really smart people.
cons:
Travel for conferences is non-existent unless you are at a senior level.
Although online training programs are decent the education and development budget is very limited for a company this size.  
LOTs or politics and behind the scenes conversations that completely contradict good collaboration and partnership.
Barriers and red tape between groups make it difficult to negotiate deliverables and contribute to delays.  For example - sometimes it can take more than 4-8 weeks to get a single lower environment vm turned over to an app team.
Too many promises to IT employees that cannot be delivered on. 
Antiquated IT procurement delivery systems and processes in dire need of streamlining yet funding get's cut year after year to do so. 
ALWAYS watch your back.  Very, very, very few people you can trust that are not gunning for your job or aiming to blame you or someone else for their own inefficiencies. 
Management says one thing - does another. Example: Need to cut down on travel expense this year so they scratch everyone's travel (except) management.  They continue to jet-set domestically and globally at a ridiculous pace.

job_title: Solutions/Digital Advisor in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Good starting place if you don’t have any financial experience. 
Solid training program to get series 7 & series 66 licenses.
Access to 401k, profit sharing, 6% match.
cons:
Low pay.
Mediocre- & Micro- management.
Much of your time will be wasted on unproductive meetings, huddles, and town halls.
Minimal financial and investment education.
Cubicle work environment.
High turnover (I was there for almost 3 years and I’d say 65% of the employees were out the door within a year not because of firings but because they realized the job sucked and they just had to get out).
This is by know means a financial advising job. It’s more of a client servicing role that gives you the ability to recommend high costing investment products to clients after you take care of their many service tasks.
Also many of our clients are extremely low income so there is limited opportunity for financial guidance and they are often very difficult to work with.

job_title: Strategic Sourcing Consultant in Concord, CA
pros: Good base pay and bonus structure. I received LTI bonus for several years, but this is not offered to everyone. Offices everywhere, so you have plenty of choices where to work, and they are in the middle of a real estate restack so the office furniture and meeting facilities are current in most buildings. Technology is decent. Computers are replaced approximately every 3 years. Lots of job and career options once you get your foot in the door. Benefits are decent. Employee rates and discounts on bank accounts, credit cards and loans.
cons: Emerging telecommute policy is confusing & punishes employees who are not in the office 5 days per week. Company is huge, so there are plenty of bad managers out there. I had one for 8 years that broke promises over and over. - that's why I left. Pace of life is very frenetic. Morale was fairly low when I left, and that was before the 10% workforce reductions were announced.

pros: Not much honestly.  Given so many companies are just as bad, WF is not alone.
cons:
Where to begin.

Countless certification classes have to be taken, and I mean countless!  Most have nothing to do with your job.  They are long and mind-numbing.

Apparently WF tellers have to be told how to be ethical...sad.  Perhaps HR should do their job.

Speaking of HR, I don’t know if we even have an HR department.  Well, unless you count the Diversity personnel.  What do they do exactly????

Don’t expect anyone to be helpful.

Don’t expect documentation.

Don’t expect training.

Expect a lot of temps...I mean contractors.  And don’t expect them to have good hygiene.  I would be shocked if one of them washed their hands in the restroom.

Expect every IT request to take forever and don’t expect it to be easy.  

Very old school mentality.  People cling to the past and fear job security.

If you have the misfortune of working in IT...you’ll know what I’m talking about.  The Operations Center takes business casual to a whole new level.  I didn’t realize stained sweatpants were business casual.

Take the job if you enjoy the cons...there are plenty.

review_title: Great Company just a few people issues
pros: I work in Technology and I am very pleased with the level of competency of the Technical staff and it shows in their abitliy to manage the bank products. I think it is great that they have not offshored the "Help Desk" to another country. It is really great when you can get help locally and they can understand the language. I worked for another bank and they offshored to India, and the technical help desk was not good.
cons: There seems to be an ethical issue at Wells Fargo. I have noticed that some people like to make a big issue of ethics, or calling attention to something when you may have made a mistake. I'm all for ethics, I just think there are ways of dealing with issues without blasting someone and making a federal issue of not "dotting your i". I wonder if making an issue of ethics makes a person look like they are ethical?

review_title: Once a proud company, now nothing more than a corporate monster.
job_title: Personal Banker II in Atlanta, GA
pros: The only reason I can think to work for this company is the benefits package.  They offer everything under the sun and most is pretty affordable.
cons: The thing you have to keep in mind going to work as a "banker" is that you're not a "banker".  Goals are so high that ethics has long since left and the company is being absolutely robbed by its employees.  Management could care less about those that are cheating the system because they just want to keep their jobs.  The bank doesn't care about its employees or especially its customers.  Employees are pressured to push things that people don't need based on whatever flavor of the week that management wants to look good about.  The environment is so stressful and micromanaged that many employees are having health issues, and management does not care, they just push harder.  When the economy gets better the turnover will be astronomical as I don't know of a happy co-worker....anywhere.

review_title: Good place to work.....but with limitations.
job_title: Registered Brokerage Associate in Mountain View, CA
pros: More autonomy on investment side than bank side. Constant stream of leads from banking customer base. Generally very nice people to work with, regardless of the line of business. Conservative posture in lending and banking has made Wells very strong through tough economy. Wells avoided most of the risky business of other financial institutions. Warren Buffet is major shareholder :-) The majority of clients are very nice and feel a strong attachment to Wells.
cons: No opportunities for advancement currently from an associate role to an advisor role unless you have significant prior sales experience or perhaps a book of business to bring in from another firm, otherwise you have to get lucky and get the nod from an established financial advisor to come on as a partner. Don't feel there is any real career path planning for associates. It's easy to get burned out after a while since the work that is done every day is mostly servicing accounts, so it gets a bit monotonous.

review_title: WORSE COMPANY I HAVE EVER WORKED FOR!
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Benefits:medical,dental,401k match is 6%, get to meet interesting customers.
cons:
Pay, horrible management, very sales driven to the point where you are asked to have family and friends "help" you by opening accounts, a company that puts on a show for you your first week, and then after that, it's all downhill. A lot of unethical activity goes on in Wells Fargo and if you think your job is horrible, go work for Wells Fargo. Never again will you complain about your job. Very unprofessional company, they fired me and in order to prevent me from getting unemployment they claimed I quit, luckily I had the letter from my manager showing that she indeed did fire me. Commission paid out every quarter unlike Chase which is end of every month. They do this to make sure that by time quarter hits, you don't get paid because you will not meet the minimum requirements. 

Lots of sales pressure. They will pressure you to pressure your family and friends, and by the time you leave that place, I guarantee you, you will have a lot of people hate you and never want to speak to you.

review_title: Endless products & services for customers, endless coaching for team members
pros: Great medical, dental, vision benefits and paid time off. Comfortable working environment. Lots of product information available on their system. You get to know regular customers and they feel comfortable and even bring their family and friends in with them.
cons: Alot of sales "scenarios" presented without a lot of system training to help you succeed quickly. The need to multi-task in my head, get it right every time, sell, and make it all look effortless! Must memorize & use 5 sentences plus use customer name 5x, give compliment, inspect negotiables, see bank account standing, watch my & customer's body language, keep engaged conversation going the entire time, greet waiting customers & those walking in, watch for memos and most of all, offer the solution and offer the sit down with a banker or introduce them to one for future follow up. The pay is very low.

review_title: My branch is GREAT! Yet it still has flaws b/c of corporate.
pros:
1. I get paid holodays.
2. I get PTO as a part time employee.
3. My branch is family.
4. I get to eat dum dum lollipops all day.
5. Management doesn't choose favorites.
cons:
1. High pressure for sales.
2. Who manages lead tellers coming to work on time and owning up to it?
3. Dress code for guys isn't as casual as girls.
4. Bonus isn't that much.
5. Doesn't let you get a second job if you need one to pay bills... To elaborate more on this, working 25 hours as a teller simply isn't cutting it for me to pay bills. I asked if I could change my availability from 8:00-6:30 to 8:00-5:30. I was told that they could not honor it because I was hired based on the fact that I had full availability(I would understand if it weren't for the fact that people who needed to go to school could change availability, yet I need more money to support my family and I can't!?!?!?). That is what I'm TRULY disappointed about.

job_title: Full Time Teller in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Great hours (40+hour weeks), great way to learn customer service, sales, and bank products.
cons: The out of balance drawers, everyone has to stay 1-2hours to find the problem. The sales driven aspect of WF is aweful, you have to make a daily quota and if you don't, management holds it against you. They push sales on customers even after customers say " no" 3 or more times. They try to make people feel like they need products that they really don't need, try to apply for the product and then 90% of people don't get approved anyways, unless they have tons of money. The up selling is pointless. Management would tell us why we were there and if we couldnt make our sales...we didn't deserve our jobs. They didn't want to work with me to take time off to go to mandatory doctor appointments, and when I was blacking out they told a coworker that they could not get me a chair to rest. Horrible management. I couldn't wait to get out. Way too much stress.

pros:
Benefits - 401k, PTO, Health/Dental, Parental Leave
Training + Resources available
cons:
Not re-hiring positions when someone leaves - spreading the weight of the extra work over everyone, fine for a while - but I fear it's now the new norm. Quite a few people already burned out.
Settlements - I now find myself hesitating a bit to tell people where I work.

pros: Despite recent scandals, it is surprisingly a good company. If you are interested in Denver job market - it is one of the best.
