It is a large company, so different departments would deliver different levels of employee satisfaction. Management is generally caring and listens to the employees. Lots of opportunity for growth and development. Many people work for WF for years. Those are brilliant, smart and friendly people. You can make good friends here and develop productive relationships. Laid-back environment even despite many hourly positions. Good work and life balance.  It is a good choice to start your career and learn.
cons: There are serious, however. Pay is the biggest one. Like in all other banks, the pay is low and it may take time to get an adequate raise. Health benefits aren't very good either. There three choices of health benefits, but they are all expensive. Every once in a while you will get to communicate with people who are a wonderful mix of stupidity and laziness. No, these people cannot be fixed and they don't learn. Fortunately, there are only a handful of these people  and you don't hear from them every day.

pros: Nothing is good about this place
cons: Everything. Management is only worried about themselves and VERY sexist.

job_title: Personal Banker II in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Great benefits and Time off.
cons: Unorganized, staffed by incompetant people. Goals are ridiculous and unattainable. Not sure how some managers are where they are. The district I work in has all minority management. You need ZERO educationt to work it this position. There idea of sales is quite comical. I don't see selling a customer a second or third checking accout as being useful to the client, only useful to company goals. Whatever happen to bringing in NEW money to the bank? They only focus on getting as many new checking accounts. That is it, that is this companies whole sales strategy. They push the bankers about branch goals, which we don't see a dime for. Training was atrocious, and I am ill prepared for the job, learning everything on the fly. They tell you in training, that what you are learing just touches the tip of the iceberg, you can call the back office to get all your answers. I learned about 5% of what I need to know for this job on a daily basis. Last, but not least, this is a sales position that is CAPPED. For the most part, you cannot make more than about $75000 in this position.

pros: Benefits, PTO, a consistent, predictable schedule and clear career paths are probably the biggest pros of working with Wells Fargo.
cons:
Working with Wells Fargo comes with many, many cons - at least in my experience. Turnover at the branch in which I worked was extremely high and management at that particular store was way sub-standard. Expect to be harassed about your sales goals (even if you're meeting your numbers) and forced to speak to your customers in a disingenuous manner.

Tellers are also the busiest people in the store, yet are paid the least. Every single teller that I worked with had a college-level degree - we were consistently ignored when applying for corporate-level jobs at Wells Fargo, but reassured that we were the most important people in the branch. 

If you're okay with drinking the Kool-Aid, you'll make it at Wells. I've noticed that those who don't necessarily think independently make it rather far with the company.

job_title: Online Customer Service Representative in Richmond, VA
pros: Benefits are the only positive thing about this place.
cons:
Out of about 40+ calls a day, you get maybe one nice person a week. I can almost deal with that but I can't deal with being yelled at, while I'm on the phone by everyone around me, managers constantly tell you that you aren't doing as well as others. Then while you're on the phone, you're getting emails about how much you suck. Even when your sales and times are above where they want them to e they still tell you that's not good enough. Their goals are absolutely ludicrous. They want conversations to be 3min or less but you need to fix the problem and sell the customer a ton of stuff they probably don't need (while their mad at something that is probably their own doing).
As far as coworkers, you may find a few cool ones but it's like high school. People are mean and caddy to each other. 
When start out your hours suck. They say the pay is based off of experience but I made $2 less an hour than someone who used to be a hospice nurse. I at least used to be a receptionist and a manager.

review_title: Unethical, demeaning, used car sales lot type environment
job_title: Sales Manager in North Charleston, SC
pros: I have to list at least five words for pros
cons: There are no upsides to working for this financial institution. Upper management manages through fear. Sell or heads will roll, we don't care how you do it just do it! 4 and 5 sales calls a day early morning (630am) workshops to teach you how to call customers and scare them into an "appointment" at the branch. Praying on elderly with high dollars in there accounts and moving their funds to 6 year CDs because it gives them PROXY they NEED proxy. Issuing credit cards and lines of credit to people unknowingly. "Sign here we are upgrading your debit card to a card that gives you points". Well you are thinking "just report it" yes did that and guess what NOW YOURE on the chopping block and being harassed and mistreated and being forced to stay until 8pm pulling reports. Upper management doesn't care about anything but their incentive check. Tellers and bankers are in their cars at lunch "when they get a lunch" crying because the environment is so bad.

pros: No night shifts, no sundays. That's it!! This is the worst company to work for. You will hate your life of you work here.
cons: Everything is a con! It is the most stressful job ever! They focus only on sales! They do not care about the customer at all. They give you ridiculous sales goals and You have to do whatever it takes or they are on you all day. They make you go to businesses and talk to the employees to get accounts from them. You're supposed to have 16 businesses that generate you accounts regularly. If you don't have any sales for the day, they treat you as if you didnt work. MICROMANAGEMENT!! They do observations on you, watching every single word that comes out of your mouth when you're with a customer. You have to fill out pointless "needs assessments" for each customer explaining their financial needs, even if they just want to replace their debit card. Do not work here. Every banker wants to kill themselves. You never get a pay raise and bonuses are extremely hard to hit, and if you do they are like 300 dlls every 3 months. You are not a personal banker, you are just a pushy salesman. Meetings every morning and every afternoon to yell at you for not meeting sales for the day. DO NOT WORK HERE! YOU WILL REGRET IT AND HATE YOUR LIFE!

pros:
Excellent incentive program
CORE (WF origination system) is better than many in the industry,very streamlined, they are constantly looking for ways to make it better from employees, but also breaks everytime its updated.
cons:
-Overworked, if you prove yourself you can end up taking on alot of responsibility. Which is great to gain experience, but when review time comes they will say things like , upper management doesn't want us to give out 5's and rarely 4's so we have given you a 3. ( For someone who was a top 5 producer within the company this is unacceptable.) They also gave a 1% raise.
Along with putting too much on their closers' plates, they added customer communication along with a having a pipeline of 100+ loans.
Working to get settlement statements from title companies in an appropriate time is very hit and miss,  while also remaining in constant communication with internal partners.  The company relies on it's closers heavily to complete transactions , and put the bow on top of transactions but they end up with too much on their plate to provide that experience.

review_title: A decent company to work for if you can look past the terrible management.
job_title: Personal Banker I in Keizer, OR
pros: The company is easy to move up in if you're on your upper managements good side. Its become a rather relaxed environment since sales goals were eliminated.
cons: Incredibly tight control throughout the chain of command leaves you feeling like you are being babied and walked hand in hand through your job and through customer interactions. A lack of focus on the individual employee is seen throughout the company and noticeably in the performance review criteria. Individual goals and bonuses have been all but removed from the structure, leaving the largest percentage of your bonuses in the hands of the entire team, which would be great if management kept employees accountable when it comes to doing their job well and being friendly.

review_title: Very good place to work, with real human capital approach towards employees--they do many things right
pros:
Non-branch salaries are very good for most positions; competitive bonus structure, if bonus eligible
Truly walk their talk in terms of mission, values, promotion from within, professional development
Very collegial atmosphere; genuine collaboration and commitment from most workers
Excellent benefits 
Excellent communications--top notch internal web sites, frequent news briefs
Strong Performance Appraisal system, including Talent Inventory for higher levels of management and skip-level interviews on annual basis
cons:
Not always easy to push through the "done that before" mentality, as so many employees have been with the organization for more than 15 years
Not as open to innovation as might benefit them long-term
At times, put senior executives in positions where they have no background and do not insist on training them to accommodate the "rotation" approach and ensure appropriate professional mentoring for the people under those executives who do have the experience
Long bottle-neck of middle-management; hard to break through to senior levels in terms of promotions

pros:
The day I was hired my direct supervisor told me a story,  He had asked his interviewer what was the best advantage of Wells Fargo.  The hiring manager when into a long description of the many paths available to employees since WF was such as huge company and offered so many different channels.   After hearing that answer he asked what was the worst thing about WF;  the answer started with you know WF is a huge company...
Your experience could be great, or not so great, depending on your skills, experience and expectations.
Wells Fargo is the elephant in the room of most industries it participates in,  some great advantages, some draw backs.  Certainly the person you report to will set the weather!  Be advised that can change very quickly!  Read "built to last"   and " good to great"  you will learn a lot about Wells Fargo.
cons: Good Benefits; and compensation in the sales arena.  If you are in management, they pay very well, but know you will earn every dollar.  Hugh expectations for results!

review_title: Stable company trying to find its way after a big growth spurt
pros:
Very stable - it's not uncommon to see people walking down the hall with 10, 15, or even 20+ years of experience. The benefits such as 401k matching and paid time off (especially for those "lifers") is competitive. 

Very diverse working environment and inclusive.
cons:
After a big growth spurt, the company is trying to simplify- that's a plus once it can be done - however, it means that right now it is bulky, full of confusing and slow process. Things move slow here, and those looking to make significant progress will be frustrated. 

While pay for performance is their mantra, in my experience I've hardly found that to be the case. In many instances I've see where they aren't ready to pay people what their worth till they have another offer and are already out the door.

pros: Great benefits, 401k, tuition reimbursement opportunities, & bank holidays. I worked at Wells in college. The money isn't great at all but as a student, it is nice to have benefits and tuition reimbursement opportunity. Wells did pay for 2 semesters of my business classes.
cons: I can only speak from the Retail Banking side but it's horrible!!! Management is forced to "make numbers" which transcend down to entry level employees. You are replaceable. The Big Banks only care about receiving and retaining customers. There are absolutely ridiculous sales goals management expects tellers and personal bankers to make. They will make you staf after business hours and cold call customers for sales. It should be illegal. Now it is different in each geographical market. I was a loyal employee who was looking to move up within the company after I obtained my bachelors in Business, but the company gave me NO opportunity to transition. The company should focus on keeping those loyal employees happy.

pros: After 12 years with Wells Fargo Bank,  I can appreciate the great company reputation and above-average benefit plan.
cons: It used to be a great company to work for, but now it's all about doing "less with more".  Our goals haven't changed, but our staffing is down 25%.  The annual (and sometimes semi-annual) rounds of layoff get tiring since there is always an ax hanging over your head.  10 years ago, you knew you had job security if you were a solid performer.  Not any more: HR people who never met you  - and often don't consult with your manager - made layoff decisions based on cost and geography. Morale and productivity are suffering.  Combine that with outdated systems/software, and it's hard to get your job done.  Now, it's all about cost cutting and meeting shareholder goals.

review_title: Be a trooper with very high tolerance for BS
pros: Overall, it’s a good company to work for with lots of opportunities to explore and gain experience. If you are a brown nosed and know how to take advantage of others, this is a place for you to advance in career.
cons: Pay starts low. Raise is less than the change in pocket. Over promised. under delivered. Overworked. Underpaid. Very unforgiving audit requirements to cut incentives. Manager levels + are the only groups who have life-work balance. Management’s attitude is “everyone of you is replaceable. We can always find someone to do a 3 men job”. A lot of seniors left because they’ve tried to stop the BS and make a change but with no support from the company. It’s all about looking good on the surface. Employees can’t even be honest on the Gallup survey or any survey for that matter afraid they will be targeted.

job_title: Senior Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros:
- Allows for remote work.
- Good people peppered here and there.
- If you don't really care about doing a great job and providing excellent service, but are good at optics and tolerating low standards, you can go very far.
cons:
- So lacking in organization as to challenge the very definition of chaos itself.
- Business processes that are somehow overly complex and yet still containing gaping holes.
- In house developed or heavily customized IT tools that don't function correctly or sometimes not at all.
- No consensus on tools. So several ticketing/monitoring/tracking/documentation systems in use by teams that interface on support.
- Constant re-orgs.
- Due to the previous bullet points, many many employees have just given up on trying to follow processes and end up glomming on to anyone who will reply to email, even if the request isn't the responding party's responsibility.
- Hyper secure environment but poorly implemented so as to cause serious overhead on even simple tasks
- Machiavellian level internal politics and nepotism/tribalism.
- Systemic institutionalization. Most employees are split between people who have adapted to the chaos and let it kill their soul. They are most adept at dodging work.
- Low pay to management expectation ratio.
- Being set up to fail is SOP. Not because they want you to but because, due to the above, success is rarely possible to any great degree.

pros: none they have no pros they're evil
cons: they're awful evil everything about them is wrong unethical thefts

pros: Good benefits; it can be fun to work here.  There are promotional opportunities but ONLY if you hit the unrealistic sales and WOW goals.
cons: Unrealistic emphasis on WOW scores:  all 5s or you fail.  As a branch, you can miss 6 surveys and make the minimum goal.  If you don't hit bronze, you get no payout.  Sales goals went up 20% in one year.  There's no adjustment for volume:  if you see 100 customers a day or 20 customers a day, your sales goals are the same.  The pressure is incredible leading to many employees putting in referrals that are unethical by the company's standard.  Everyone looks the other way if your sales goals are hit.  "Doing what's right for the customer" is a joke.

review_title: The Worst Company in the US
pros: To survive and to have insurance
cons: Too much sales pressure  (every hour sales results required by DM/upper management) or in other words tellers and personal bankers(PB) are COMPELLED for the sales. If PBs cannot complete their day's quota, they cannot leave the branch unless they make appointments over the phone for next day(s). Tellers are compelled by Service Managers (in charge of Teller-line) to fill out all Deposit Slips, Counter withdrawal slips(counter checks) etc for ALL the customers (whether they are young and can do on their own or for other customers who chat on the phone  or chew chewing gums standing there) in the name of OUTSTANDING CUSTOMER SERVICE OR GOING OUT OF THE WAY TO SERVE CUSTOMERS.    This company might be best among top 100 US companies but only for upper management employees and not for Tellers and Personal Bankers. New Tellers have been given raise after the recent survey but old tellers get same rate or even less than the New Tellers current rate and they face more challenges and responsibilities than new tellers. Nobody is happy with this company.

review_title: This employer will literally suck the life right out of you
job_title: Personal Banker II – Registered in Houston, TX
pros:
In comparison to other banks there are some perks.
•. Competitive salary
•. Stellar training program
•. Competitive benefits
cons:
This organization from the top down are indifferent to employee work and life balance.  The turnover rate must be around 80%.  

•. Too many hours and days worked with little consistency for a decent work life balance.
•. Their risk management in Houston pursues modern day witch hunts so be absolutely certain that you document well because chances are that you may have to frequently justify your actions.  Their Houston internal investigator is a small person with a huge ego and an arrogance that leaves you wondering what her under the surface issues really are.  
•.  Cookie cutter atmosphere.  Has some good concepts but gets bogged down on theory rather than results.  Call nights and call weekends are a joke.  Work the clients that walk in or drive in rather than getting hung up on ignoring live bodies so you can document that you phoned 30 people, contacted 4 and set one appointment.  You have managers that cannot effectively lead or manage this process.

review_title: Run Over By The Stage Coach
job_title: Branch Manager III in Houston, TX
pros: I would have to say the # 1 Pro to having worked at Wells Fargo would be it would make working anywhere else seem better. Its the one time in which the "grass is always greener..." slogan is actually true. To be fair I think that the disconnect with has occurred somewhere between San Francisco and Houston Retail.
cons: The cons are MANY and they start right at the top of the Houston Autocratic Hypocritical Retail Sales Beast Machine. The out of this world unrealistic expectations placed on and disparaging treatment delivered to the Houston Region employees is despicable and dare I say, illegal. Look no further than the mass terminations in Los Angeles or even in Houston due to massive sales pressure.

review_title: Strong, well-regarded company but be prepared to do your job on a committee
pros: I have been with Wells Fargo for 12 years and overall it is a fantastic company to work for.  John Stumpf is a great CEO and continues to keep the company on a strong yet steady course.  Across the organization there is a commitment to team members' and their development.  Many roles have bonuses included in compensation.  I have learned a ton while working there.
cons: Because it is a huge organization, you will lose the ability to do your job without consulting a committee.  Everything is process driven, but the processes are not effective at getting work done.  It is embarrassing how long it takes and how expense it is to get things done.  Granted, the company has undergone several mergers, but it is just slow.  The company is undergoing centralization of many administrative roles (legal, compliance, PR, marketing, etc) so we expect head count reductions in the coming months.

pros: Strong company, great brand, endless career opportunities and lots of great people to work with.
cons: This department is in transition and has had a huge influx of loans added to the pipelines of all the current employees. The incentive program has been slashed and for high performers this can equate to a 50%+ cut in compensation (which is huge!). The job can be rewarding when working to help the customers in your pipeline but since the amount of customers has grown dramatically it is very difficult to spend the time you need to in order to provide the best possible service. Most of the day is spent taking incoming calls from the customers of other specialists which has really turned the department into a call center. Its a demanding job but if you can last a year, you will be able to transfer to just about any department within Wells Fargo.

review_title: Room for growth, but a great deal of stress
job_title: Store Manager I in Bath, PA
pros:
~Unlimited room for growth based on performance (both lateral and horizontal movement); I had three promotions within just over a year with the company
~Competitive performance-based incentive structure with potential to earn up to an additional 20-25K a year in bonuses
~An unparalleled number of resources, training opportunities, and partners within the company to help problem-solve and progress within the company
~6% 401K match and profit sharing
~Paid holidays and a generous amount of paid time off (I currently receive 18 paid days off a year and have been with the company just under 3 years)
cons:
~Emphasis on sales goals places a great deal of pressure on team members. Some team members have done  unethical behaviors to meet high goals and meet incentive
~The better you perform, the higher your goals raise
~Wells Fargo recently took away most of our reports to measure performance, but did not lower goals. 
~Inability to take ownership or solve many issues because of the number of departments- frustrating for customers and team members

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Carlsbad, NM
pros: Benefits especially health insurance are wonderful, dental, 401k, life, enroll dependents. Chances to move up if you play the local game and fit in well. Overall the bank promotes diversity and is very inclusive which is refreshing! Very generous PTO especially for first year compared to other banks and companies.
cons: Lack of effective manager to mentor you to move forward with the bank. Constant turnover. Very number focused in terms of sales and customer service scores so often the valued customer gets lost in the shuffle. New policies and new rules negatively impact the customer experience which leads to lower scores on customer service surveys. This does hurt morale and upset employees who really do care about their jobs. Management is seriously micro-managed. Pay lower than other banks in the area. Hard to get significant raises.

review_title: Premier banker 4 years with the company
pros: Liberal PTO days, 4 weeks. Good benefits 401K matches 6%. Regular work hours rarely any overtime required. Average pay.
cons: Everything you read in the news is true. Managers pushed products. Blamed it on bankers and denied any involvement even though managers reviewed EVERY account opened. Type in WF mid session review on you tube. Poor recruitment,  most anyone can qualify for banker position. They spend a year or 2 as banker and then promoted to branch mgrs. So many incompetent branch mgrs for the most part. Most have no college education. As a licensed producer, its difficult at times trying to partner and work with managers who are not top talent to say the least. New compensation plan pays way below industry peers. The only incentive left is .23 basis points paid on investments. Obliviously all the bad press and lawsuits make it difficult at times to build trust with customers.

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Tempe, AZ
pros: Wonderful teammates, slick origination system, great benefits, accepting workplace.
cons: Empty promises from management, unattainable customer loyalty goals, lack of response to employee feedback. Also soft phone system needs updated.

job_title: Registered Client Associate in San Francisco, CA
pros: I can't think of anything good to say about this company.
cons:
The advisor I worked with was dishonest, abused discretion and charged excessive fees and commissions. When I approached management with my concerns, I was initially dismissed. I returned to management 10 months later as I observed the advisor putting the firm at risk and lacking sound judgement. The managers went on the defensive, they criticized me and targeted me for any infraction (i.e. accused me of lying on my timecard). I returned to work after PTO and found that they'd replaced me and moved my desk to the other side of the office. But no one told me -
 the manager avoided me. I was being punished for bringing a concern to management, through the proper channels.  I met with HR several times, they were incredibly apologetic and the advisor was subsequently fired due to his malpractice. It was awfully stressful and I decided to resign when it was all said and done. It's clear that speaking up and whistleblowing are not appreciated in this firm - even though this is what we're trained to do. The WFA division is separate from the retail bank but the culture and corruption is pervasive. Do not take a job with WFA if you can help it!

review_title: Old Company and Old Strategies create New Troubles
pros: If you want a good work life balance, this is the company for you.  I have plenty of coworkers who chose this company because they know they won't be worked too hard, and will only be asked to perfect the current processes.
cons: Company keeps making it into headlines for the wrong reasons.  Because we're so old-minded, our strategies are less effective, requiring our managers to find "creative ways" to catch up to competitors.

job_title: Senior Analyst in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Alot of responsibility in a short period
cons: Leadership abysmal, Decentralized teams lack collaboration, Desktop technology poor

review_title: Don't bank here, don't work here
pros: Easy entrance to the financial field, with the right sucking up one can get ahead if you have moral flexibility to swindle people.  If you don't have education and don't thrive in a meritocracy it is a place where you can truly succeed and fly up the ranks.  People can rise from entry level teller to management despite lack of management experience or economic knowledge.  Very pro-minority as they value diversity over skill.  This place will give you a thicker skin in sales, if you can sell online banking and debit cards to 90 year olds you're apt to succeed.
cons: Unfair business practices, management suggesting immoral practices, poorly trained and educated staff, extreme pressure to put extreme pressure on customers despite their best interests, subpar products that one is expected to push, repeated unethical and questionable business practices, managers who are uneducated, and uninformed, lack of concern for the best interests of the customers or employees.  They fail to prune out employees that have been popped for violating policy, and punish those that follow it.  Employees are encouraged to endlessly harass customers into products they don't need.  This company embodies the peter principal, and rewards their most morally deficient employees.

review_title: This job will steal your soul.
pros: Health insurance, 401K, amount of paid vacation ( although you can't take more than one week off at a time).
cons: Micromanagement by threat, unrelenting sales pressure that causes employees to convince customers to open accounts that they don't need just so they can meet their daily sales 'goals', blistering emails every hour about your to the moment sales numbers. Gaming is a huge problem within this company so be prepared to relax your ethics if you want to reach your sales 'goals'. No time to do paperwork or research for customers, or follow up on needs and questions so customer service is a sham. Management only cares how many bank products you sold to a customer and how much money you brought in with a loan. Absolutely. Nothing. Else.

review_title: Not a good job at all
pros: My co workers were awesome and the hiring process was very quick.
cons: All that management cares about is sales. The "conversations" we are required to have with customers is too scripted. They care so much about sales that we have to push products and services that the customer does actually need. I quit because I felt this was immoral. Pushing a Line of Credit to someone who already has $10000 of credit card debt is immoral, you're enabling people to be more in debt, instead of encouraging them to be financially stable. Management is nice, but they are pushing the tellers to hit outrageous goals that the company is forcing the branch to reach.

job_title: Trade Service Representative IV in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
-Somewhat flexible work schedule.
-Laptop with two monitors.
-Workload allows for work done at your leisure.
-Management does not micromanage.
-Recognition for hard work.
cons:
-Majority of team members have 20+ years with the company which makes taking vacation quite a hassle. (You start with 2 weeks where everyone else has 4-5 weeks with seniority)
-Team members are not motivated for improvement projects/goals and/or meetings.
-Main trade application is always being updated without regard for effects it has on all departments. 
-IT business consultants do not speak English well and are so monotone in conference calls that it will take quite a keen ear to understand what's being said.
-Management states they would like to promote from within but otherwise chose to hire an individual from an entirely different continent which seemingly does not possess the skills for the job.
-The kicker here...no funds allocated to have a Christmas party or anything to really make employees feel appreciated.

job_title: Home Preservation Specialist in San Antonio, TX
pros: None at all that I can recall
cons: Bad work culture , shady

job_title: Licensed Personal Banker -registerd in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Great Benefits and 401k plan
Vacation good but, goodluck on getting to use it!!
cons:
Company does not value family time
company does not respect schedules and at last minute or hours before it is time to leave for the day they will tell you to stay for  a call night or conference call.
Sales goals are set way to high.  Even if you exceed their expectations, don't expect to be paid more than 300.00 a quarter in bonus.
It takes a lot of work to make it to over the 100% but don't expect the compensation you received when you were Wachovia.. Not there anymore.
Focused on sales and not the customer!!

job_title: Senior Registered Client Associate in Boston, NY
pros: I have a paycheck and benefits
cons: This company does not care about the Client Associates, they are loading us with so much paperwork that we do not have time to help our FA's or clients.  They don't want to hear what we have to say, there is no training available for CA's and the pay is terrible.  It is really sad when a person coming into this company today will make more base pay than someone with over 10+ years experience.

job_title: Customer Service and Sales Representative in Lincoln, NE
pros: Many opportunities await you at Wells Fargo if you are hired and are able to put up with their corporate policies and culture. Training is phenomenal. I will keep the skills I've learned here with me for the rest of my life. The products and services are unmatched.
cons: The company I learned about in training isn't the same company I worked for. There's more to banking than checking accounts and "solutions," but that's really all that matters at the end of the day. You can do what's right for the customer, but if that doesn't result in numbers, then we have a problem. 3 checking accounts and 15 solutions (or sales) one day doesn't matter when you only get 4 solutions the next. Expect lots of scripting here, ridiculous stipulations to work around to keep accounts free for customers, and lots of stress.

job_title: Personal Banker II in Oakland, CA
pros: Big name, good benefits and a good training program.
cons: poor management, poor inner politics & inner communications across the board. Majority of the people do not care who you are or what your role is...just want you to be a robot and produce obscene numbers to hit obscene (not reachable) goals. Employees are treated poorly and without regard to how hard they work.

pros: Great co-workers, good pay (again, management has a lot of discretion here), good benefits and good PTO.
cons: Your work is always in question; have to note and explain everything you do. Very important to maintain a friend relationship with your manager and theirs (no matter how fake this may require you to be). The manager and their supervisor are the only ones that can make the difference in fighting the "qc" department. Many colleagues were stripped of their authority when no one would help them with the auditors. Bottom line; keep copies of everything and ask coworkers if they've received the same feedback as there was serious inconsistencies. To advance, you must make noise, to the point of being annoying, until they follow through on their promises.

pros: I worked in the centralized area of Wells Fargo for 1.5 years.  The benefits offered are good and coworkers are awesome.
cons: Their systems are very difficult to learn.  When I left they had 5 different platforms for completing loan applications and minor nuances to the loan application meant that certain systems could not be used.  A great deal of time is spent figuring out the systems and it is a major bottleneck in the process.  As a result, employees are constantly missing deadlines for closings.  Customers are constantly angry with you and your customer service scores, which impact your compensation suffer.

job_title: Senior Registered Client Associate in Sacramento, CA
pros: Good benefits, vacation time, 401k matching and psp, improved software, and most of all the clients are great to work with, which is why I still work here!
cons: Working conditions/expectations have become out of whack over the past few years as they have taken away the permanent staff in the branch lobby, which means the CA's are now required to rotate to cover the position on a daily basis; in our location it accounts for almost 40% of our day when everyone is there, even worse when vacation time is being taken and/or your FA is out of the office. Not to mention that the duties that used to be done by the now eliminated cage staff and now being done by the CA's, They is very disruptive to the daily flow, especially when your priority should be providing top notch customer service and being available to service your clients without continuous distractions.

review_title: This position implemented change. The change could be product/program specific, to change of systems. Travel 75%-90%.
pros: Great benefits and good pay for the position.  Able to keep all your travel points (Hotel, airline, & car rental) for personal use.  Has a lot of learning segments available to you to be better at your position.
cons: A lot of hiring of people because they know the hiring managers, and not because of their skill set.  Layoff's seem to be quarterly & across all business lines.  Position title changed three times in a year & a half.  A few months you're salary with a bonus option, next you're hourly with OT no bonus.  Very closed group that is not open to new people joining.  Be prepared to be looked down upon & poorly treated by most people on your team, including management.

review_title: Good company.. But not a place to learn AT ALL.
pros:
* Really good infrastructure. 
* Mostly a laid back environment. 
* Good work life balance. 
* Good enough employee benefits.
* Good salary benefits.
cons:
* Please never EVER go if you plan to learn new technologies or you are well aware that you're not the first to join a particular team/project. This is not a place to really learn new technologies & grow your career. You'll only be given bit-parts and if you're well versed in your field and you feel that as an extreme for you to learn, then surely you can join this company I was one of them, who wanted to have better exposure in terms of technology and I'd to quit after a short tenure.

* Company culture is changing. Management is not really lenient and there are people keeping tabs on your time in and time out.

* You have an option to move from the project that you're put into. But it depends on your relationship with your manager. From what I have seen, it takes an average of 3.5 - 4.5 years to get a project change.

pros:

1. Good Work life balance
2. Free transportation
3. Internet reimbursement (over and above your CTC)
4. Good environment
5. Only for female employees for 2 kids (upto 5 yrs) upto Rs 8000 are given for daycare

7. Additional 4 annual leaves on completion of 4 years
8. Excellent infrastructure

cons:

8. 90 days notice period
9. Very few people got functional business knowledge

pros: Security is not that strict in concerns of PHI or SCI
cons: With have history in servicing mortgages already working for this company I was psyched. However like a previous review states this company is mainly structured for SALES.There were many blanketed answers after I asked more than once if this was a sales position.So after training the only feed back you mainly will get is that your sales or service solutions quota needs to be at a certain %.Not customer service,or even policy being done appropriately.In fact this company does not have a specified department for pay off or escrow and home preservation.This is the only company I came across as of yet that is as big as it is that puts all the work on skill 2+ to get yelled at because they don't want to fit training in to put a queue in structure for advanced or complex inquires for those areas but can put aside "case time" for people to be off the phone .Scheduling is no better seems like we constantly being advised that are in a very high step with calls holding because 15 people are all on a break at the same time resulting in mandatory overtime to clear out holding calls.

review_title: Unrelenting, stressful work load in some departments
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-good benefits, including severance packages, especially when you've worked at the company for more than 10 years.
-had good experiences working with team members from other departments; people are willing to help one another.
cons:
-definitely can sense a change in culture within the company since the housing crisis and feels like management expects everyone to work more hours for the same pay. It feels like every department is incorporating metrics to prove itself even when the metrics don't mean a thing; department management just wants a number to present to senior management.
-just switched to a new department and the work load is relentless and stressful. Spoke to several others who had previously worked in the department and they expressed the same exact feelings (they left the department within 2 years). Other than the managers, few people seem to stick around in this department.

pros: Generous PTO, health insurance  benefits
cons: High turnover.  Low morale.  Narrow focus on 'metrics'. New hires are  very young with no experience, OTJ training thrown to the wolves.  Seasoned administrators are overlooked for promotion.  Most team leads are 30 or younger.   Lots of chatter and socializing creating distractions among the cubicles.   Dress code is hoodies, shorts, flip flops, cellphones. Managers will not acknowledge problem areas. Managers distracted by projects. Unable to approach managers outside weekly meetings.  Inconsistent direction. Policies change constantly .  Communication from management is lacking,  reliance on each other for news.  No acknowledgement from management for accomplishments. Apparent favoritism.   Focus on risk issues yet risk managers non responsive on  many issues.  Difficult to get answers.  Staff is held financially responsible for errors which create loss for bank, result in deductions from annual bonus.   Account fees are rarely correct, and involve several layers of review for remediation . Tight clique of managers w upper management.   Unreasonable work load and additional accounts coming our way. Client surveys reveal much discontent and create additional work.  No clerical support available.   Redundant procedures making job a grind.   Stepping stone position for most.

pros:
Excellent benefits
401K is great
health plans are good not super but very good
Good work locations

I feel that Wells Fargo gives you alot of opportunities to make what you want out of a career. I have gone from both the business side to the development/IT side and the company was very supportive of my moves. The work life balance is great in most groups and the work from home options are really helpful if you have the cable guy coming.
cons:
red tape - getting access to certain systems

raise/pay/bonuses - The only way to get a decent raise is to get a new job in a different department and you have to fight hard for every single cent. Some groups are super stingy with bonuses as well. 

retention of key employees - some really good employees who came in as entry level leave because the raise/pay scale has them paid hideously below market; so a simple market rate adjustment even in excess of the normal max percent increases would help

pros: unlimited overtime in phone banker coach position, discount on some services such as mobile phone bills, free or discounted services like money orders, team member bank accounts, stop payments,
cons: underpaid, overworked, minimal perks, strict when it comes to what lengthy company mandatory dialogue, horrible & depressing workplace setting, getting graded on how client's feel about Wells Fargo's brand and it's products, policies/regulations, and performance as a whole instead of your performance and services rendered to the client affected bonus pay outs, extreme time limit per call that make it exceedingly difficult to address client needs especially in a difficult/complex situation and/or difficult customer and if you exceed your time limit it decreases your bonus, being screamed at, cussed out, insulted, or just dealing with rude customers because they are incompetent individuals who can't do simple addition or subtraction or angry at Wells Fargo in general .  Cross sell, cross sell, cross sell on every call even if a client doesn't want or need any additional services in order to preserve your job and keep your bonus that make up for the slave labor pay.

job_title: Senior Business Process Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros:
A very open and easy going environment.  Every one is very congenial and friendly for the most part.  HR processes and protocols are very well defined.  The company seems to be relatively fair
in the way they address salary and bonus.
cons: Wells Fargo does not seem to have a strong leadership or strategic direction, which make the work environment a little chaotic, not unusual for the Financial Services Industry, but they seem to be a little below par.  Roles and responsibilities are not very well defined, allowing overlap, inefficiency and creating potential ownership conflict.  In my experience the performance management process is not very specific for each employee and it work against distinguishing individual achievement.  For the most part, Wells Fargo is not a rapid promotion company and does not seem to have a strong culture of meritocracy.

review_title: This job is terrible, not-funny joke
job_title: Teller At Wells Fargo in Reading, PA
pros: Benefits apply to even part-timers. Paid time off. Day-to-day activities aren't hard once you get used to them. Regular hours, though if youre part time they probably won't allow you to be unavailable for any amount of them. A lot of opportunity to move up, if you do EXACTLY what they prescribe you do.
cons: Almost everything. High pressure to sell products. Numbers matter more than anything. It ruins customer experience, which we are supposed to place above all else. Totally see-through 'visions and values' as a company.  Intense micro management from incompetent managers. They only want to you to hit your goals so that they can look good to their managers and move up. They don't offer any real coaching. Constant issues with understaffing. High turnover. They offer you plenty of benefits in hopes that that will outweigh how awful the job is. Overall lack of support, lack of training, broken promises, unanswered questions. Frequent calloffs, especially by management. This job caused me so much stress and anxiety. I am not a salesperson.

pros: Started out to be a great company to work for. Found lots of people that really enjoyed working with others to try and find a way to make banking easier and save money. I felt like my career was what ever I wanted until I became a Buddy Banker for the California conversion. When I let management know about the inappropriate sales going on they said that is how they did it in Cali and my hopes for advancement stalled.
cons: As you know the pressure was on. I stayed out of the line of fire by being at a smaller branch but culture became a "Boiler Room" culture and all they were out for was what did you do for me today.

review_title: A good place to work, depends on you
pros:
Everyone you work with wants you to succeed and advance and grow in the company.  Good starting pay and a lot of PTO that grows a lot the longer you stay with them.  There are like 14 paid bank holidays per year plus paid sick days and ample PTO. This helps your work/life balance a lot especially in the long run when a few years down the road you get weeks of PTO/year.

You go through training, and get immense support from everyone around you when you first start.  You don't have to have a lot of experience, just motivation to work.  Team building is strong here.

Constant learning and development and support from everyone around you. You learn a lot. It gets repetitive though but if you do your job well you won't hear it.

Clear advancement paths that you are pushed to go for.
cons:
Depends on how busy of a branch you are working in, it can be fast paced at times.

Management reinforces things a lot which gets redundant, but only because they are pressured by their superiors to do so.  

Repetitive lessons  and spiel's.

review_title: Good place to learn, don’t get stuck though
job_title: Service Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great way to pick up skills for entry-level workers, good benefits, lots of learning resources, decent pto, thorough training
cons: Retail banking career path is misleading and lengthy if you’re looking for a job at corporate headquarters.  May take you years of developing completely unrelated skills for the company to start moving you towards your actual goal.  By then, a decade later, you will be halfway into your career, with no relevant skills to your goal.... not ideal. Not to mention, the goal posts move... a lot. Also, BMs and DMs explicitly care more about what you can do for them and their district, rather than what they can do to develop their talent.  End up hemorrhaging their best employees constantly as a result.

review_title: Great place to work, especially in the Digital organization
job_title: Vice President Digital Consultant V/Digital Product Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great culture in Digital. Positive atmosphere and leaders that seem to care and respect employees and partners. May not pay the best in the industry, esp for similar roles in tech sector but does hire and retain lots of seasoned, highly capable employees and contractors. Proud of leadership's focus on doing what's right for the customer now in all areas and looking at technology and more automation to help rebuild trust and transparency.
cons: Lots of reorganizations but not uncommon for large banking institutions. Understaffed in key areas limiting ability to grow and support many businesses that depend on Digital. Lots  of bureaucracy, especially in heightened risk and control environment. Salary for seasoned employees is not competitive with the marketplace....once you've been hired in, it is very hard to increase pay vs new hires.

job_title: Product Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Benefits vacation insurance bonus salaries
cons: Manager toxic environment fighting within the dept

review_title: I loved working at the Wells Fargo Advisors headquarters in St. Louis.  Excellent culture, benefits and boss.
job_title: Internal Biz Dev Consult in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Wells really cared about my work/life balance.  My departments worked well with little supervision.  In other words, the boss was not hovering over us on a regular basis.  
Great Salary
Easy work - call center for mutual funds
Great work environment
cons: Constant corporate changes.  Departments were always being merged.  Downsizing happened often.  When I came aboard, the company was just about to complete one merger and then another occurred.  The job was good but I hated it when an employee or two would leave the department and management would not replace them.  Due to promotions and transfers, our department shrank from about 15 people to 10.  Guess what? Management put in a hiring freeze and our workload increased with no additional compensation.  In the end, after the freeze, the employees were never replaced.

job_title: Loan Servicing Specialist III in Raleigh, NC
pros: Mon-fri 8am-5pm no weekends great benefits great co-workers
cons: Wells Fargo HR does not help employees anything you tell HR in confidence is reported back to your manager. HR tells you Everything is up to managers discretion so basically  if a manager doesn't like you they will and can treat you differently then someone they do like. Foreclosure Production liaisons Pay is terrible for the responsibilities you are in charge of. MIcromanagement is a very big issue. There a huge disconnect between managers and employees treated like the bottom of the barrel when employees know more than the managers. Department is all about numbers that is all the managers care about. Other departments raises are extremely higher than the production department raises are .1 percent whic is very insulting

review_title: Very corporate, rewarding, and frustrating . The people are held back from reach potential.
pros: The work benefits are great, healthcare, legal, investing, parental leave is 16 weeks for the primary parent, 4 weeks for the secondary parent. Plenty of career opportunities once an employee.
cons: The training the company requires doesn’t apply to 60% of the employees within company. Zero training for current role. It’s very corporate. A lot of re-org, it’s common to have multiple managers within 2-3 years. No commission for employees that are not sales but are required to work with customers and provide products to customers. You will never reach bonus potential due the companies compliance issues.

review_title: Not a great place to work.
pros: The pay, The hours, The incentives.
cons: As a loan processor the training was not long enough or detailed enough.  Also there are too many loans for each loan processor to manage.  It was impossible to give true customer service you are give goals of 17 loans per month yet have over 70 loans to manage.  The turnover rate is extremely high.  It is a high school environment at best with little room for career advancement.

job_title: Phone Banker II in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Easy to get a job because they are so desperate to maintain staff levels. Good 401k and stock purchasing options. Good health care. Regular overtime available. 24/7 shift options.
cons: Actually achieving the ability to get paid out on your "cash bonus" is crazy hard, Every possible  dis-qualifier they can think of is used so you never see a cent of the profit that you make for the company in sales of new products and services. Not meeting your stats means you will never be able to leave yoru current position within the company. Those that do get move to management, however just because you can sell, doesn't mean they are good managers or trainers.

review_title: Strong company but used to be even stronger.
pros: Good benefits, lots of opportunity for driven team members with a work ethic at lower levels.  Brand recognition, stability, a lot of resources to help you do your job.
cons: As you climb you will find the environment for more political and inflexible.  Titanic egos with limited ability to admit others may have a better way, show up with greater frequency.  Many decisions are made absent sound logic or logic not communicated to the teams.  Salary compression from lack of reasonable merit raises is a factor the longer you stay as well.

pros: There is definitely upward mobility and the opportunity to prove yourself and be rewarded but in house hirings will pay you minimum for maximum talent. Having said that, you will learn the necessary skills and knowledge to move forward and be successful anywhere else.
cons: Excessive goals once met and surpassed increase goals by amount surpassed becoming the norm and expectation, forcing employees to find less than favorable means to either keep up or be put on corrective action. A capable individual is no longer enough if the quota is not only met but surpassed.

review_title: Depends on the cards that you're dealt (or in this case, the Branch/DM/AP that you're dealt)
pros:
- Extremely pro-ethics (despite the media coverage lately)
- Wonderful culture (OneWellsFargo)
- Great training (before you are actually customer/team facing)
- Open door policy to speak up if you see something wrong 
- Promote from within before they seek outsiders
cons:
- Little work/life balance
- Glass ceiling (if you area woman, be prepared to be paid less than your male counterparts for the same job)
- Too "HR" friendly (sometimes, team members are kept in their jobs even if they are bringing down the rest of the team/mistreating employees just because it is too "hard to prove" despite documentation/time/date in which it occurred)
- Long work hours (though most team members are hourly, the branches are open until 6 on weekdays and 2 on Saturdays, leaving little time with friends/family)

review_title: Company is circling the drain, stay far, far away...
job_title: Licensed Personal Banker in Richmond, VA
pros: Company will invest in you personally if you desire to move up.  The company paid for me to get my licensing done.  Great benefits, 401k matching up to 6% after one year.
cons: Antiquated business model in general.  Company seems to have gotten too big for it's own good.  Many different areas of the company make it complicated to ultimately help the customer at the branch level.  Banking in general is moving away from the physical location of the branch itself, many things, even for bankers, need to be called in on, and the back office usually is not informative, knowledgeable, or helpful enough to solve the issue in a timely manner.   Most people hired by the company are sub-par or entry-level work force members.  Very high turnover rate.  Company is trying hard to bounce back from pending lawsuits and aggressive sales tactics.  Company seems to be on the way out within a few years.   Company is downsizing, most branches very short-staffed.  Money can be made as a financial advisor, but at least 5 years are needed in order to work with the advisory team.

job_title: Client Services Manager in Tacoma, WA
pros: Being part of a great team, feeling accomplished, working with great clients, benefits, pay and PTO.
cons: The lies that management continues to spew and the thankless work they demand daily, without truly caring about anything but the $$$.  Words are spoken about how much the company cares, but I truly believe proud founder, Henry Wells is turning in disgust in his grave at what has become of his good name and the company he built.  Shame on those people that have broke the spirit of so many loyal employees and clients with the deceit and fraud of recent years.   No good can possibly come of merely changing a media campaign.  I had hoped to retire after spending 21+ years of dedicated work, but instead was given a pink slip along with 1,200 of my fellow team members.  For those of a certain age, being laid off but not old enough to retire, Wells Fargo didn't care, only that it saves them money to pay their fines levied by the US Government for crimes against their customers.

pros: Some people I worked with really did care and wanted to do the right thing.
cons: My boss and her bosses were political, inept, and ran a fear based team. 3 weeks into starting at this job, I was told (in not so many words) that I need to do what I am told or will not be around. From that point onwards, everything thing was done to put me in my place (bad reviews, constant complaints of the finest things, back stabbing etc.). I was scared about losing my job and complained to HR Advisors. 1 week after my complaint, I was let go by my inept boss.  What a joke of a culture and so much for we listen to our employees concerns seriously.

pros: Wells Fargo has GREAT benefits. Excellent medical and dental, plus a lot of aid for families. The training program is also very extensive and leaves you feeling competent. Even if you've never been in the financial world, 3 months at Wells Fargo you will feel very comfortable. WF is big enough to be able to offer further employment opportunities in almost every field and the ties within the company are very valuable.
cons: The hourly pay does not always seem fair compared to other financials. The teller position is certainly used as a stepping stone to other jobs that do have much fairer compensation. Although the pay isn't great, even the tellers enjoy the great benefit packages which can offset some of the disatisfaction with pay. Also, a teller is asked to do a lot beyond his or her job description. Another con is dealing with a public that can often be very harsh on "Big Banks" like WF.

job_title: Client Services Associate in Salem, OR
pros: Very good base of clientele, top notch systems, platforms, educational resources, opportunity for advancement and really good people to work with.  Company is more financially sound than most institutions and is VERY diversified (Warren Buffet owns 10% of its stock).
cons: Be prepared for possible animosity between legacy Wachovia team members vs. Wells Fargo.  Wells Fargo is very efficient in right-sizing without incurring large expenses to do so.  This is a very bottom-line oriented company that looks for a 15% return on investment regarding anything it does.  That means if sharpening a pencil doesn't return 15% to the bottom line, then don't do it.  Large disconnect between the cultural philosophies of the "old Wachovians" and Wells Fargo.  Wachovia was much more "customer centric" and customer loyalty driven but did a very poor job of enforcing policies and procedures, which is part of the reason it was assimilated.

review_title: Good for some, not for most
pros:
-Benefits to full time and part time employees
-401k company match
-Tuition Reimbursement up to $5000/year for full time employees
-Relatively Flexible with Scheduling
-Lots of room to grow career
cons:
-Petty office politics play major role in decision making
-Completely unethical in terms of sales techniques
-Very stingy in annual raises as well as raises for promotions
-Consistently making sales goals harder every year and lowering total bonus payout

review_title: It is what you make of it. The sky is the limit with Wells Fargo.... Store Manager III
pros: Staffing Model is generous in a Wells Fargo Store, no skimping on employees as other banks have gone to. The opportunities are limitless with top performers and supportive management. As a team member you will have all the tools needed to be successful as well as easy to use state of the art banking systems. Salarys are above most other bank mid points. Benefits are very inviting, and Incentive opportunities are excellent. OVERALL GREAT COMPANY!
cons: Every day is a Focus day when it comes to sales. Goals are AGGRESSIVE! Do not come to Wells Fargo in the retail bank and expect an easy job. Customer Service scores operate on a Gallup 1 - 5 Scale and even 1 question resulting in a 4 will cause a 0% survey, goals based at 85% Perfect surveys are difficult to reach. Top performers are praised as were low performers are managed right out!

pros: Wells Fargo apparently has the top rated training in the retail banking industry. That makes it easy to be considered an asset for any other bank in the area. Benefits are GREAT, big company means theres somewhere to go if you can stomach working in the retail division.
cons: Retail Banking. That should be enough to steer anyone away. My initial experience was great, but I had no idea what type of sh*t storm I was getting in to. There is no plan. none. Every week we implement a new system, or a new way of tracking sales, or theres a new reason why we didn't hit a certain number of checking accounts. Oh. My. God. Don't get me started about checking account sales. "You're working on a $100,000 line of credit? Well, did you get an appointment for a checking account?" That pretty much sums up my first couple months at Wells Fargo.

pros: they match 401K up to 6%, some tuition reimbursement, bank is national so you can find employment in other states, If you get a manager who sees potential they may recommend you for the Wells Fargo programs that are available.
cons: Poor upper and lower level management. Leadership used to come to our site repeatedly and not acknowledge anyone but the individuals they were meeting with. Manager's don't care about you or take the time to learn your team's process but push goals and targets constantly. We are constantly receiving changes thru email and you are supposed to remember them all. Some jobs have incentives and better annual increases then others based on where you work in the bank and that should be across the board. There are no Holiday celebrations or acknowledgements depending on who your manager is or what department you are in, while other groups in the company are given these perks. Several people from our building have died from heartaches from our building since I have been there and have left in ambulances from work.

pros: Wells Fargo treats its team members with respect and throughout the employment lifecycle, provides growth opportunities, coaching and mentoring.  In my 15 years there I’ve had managers that care about me as an employee, care about my professional development and care about the customers, despite the recent news on sales practices,   It is a fairly flat organization giving people the opportunity to show their value at all levels of management.  They truly believe and show it through actions that team members are Wells Fargo’s competitive advantage.   I’ve had a lot of jobs in my life and I’ve never worked with a smarter, more innovative and caring company. It may be hard to believe given how the media presents the company, but I absolutely love working for Wells Fargo.
cons: Because it’s so big, and it takes so long to do things like equipment or systems upgrades, it can feel feel like we are lagging  behind other companies.

pros: i can't think of any
cons: management, environment, all around horrible

review_title: Great company to work for but a poor manager could cause headaches.
pros: Wonderful co-workers who are genuinely interested in satisfying customer both external and internal. The benefits are very generous with regard to time off, health. People frequently thanked you for doing the job right. Flexible work hours. Overall I highly recommend getting a job there, just be certain to get insight on your potential manager.
cons: It depends on the department you work in and the immediate managers. I did not have the benefit of a manager with leadership talent and capabilities. That was evidenced by their lack of promotion and the extremely high employee turnover in the department. Sometimes you get stuck but over overwhelmingly from my interactions with other departments, others did not experience these issues. I would have definitely stayed with Wells had there been other exercisable opportunities to move laterally. Cycling through contractors to catch up on the backlog is another issue.

review_title: Work work work no pay no recognition increasing sales numbers
pros: The company offers great benefits such as 24 days PTO (after 3 years of service) great insurance matching 6% for 401K.
cons: The past year this place has become a nightmare! They keep raising our sales numbers and forgetting that customers are extremely hesitant to out their money in banks. We have horrible rates and yet we are forced to keep pushing products on customers. It is very hard to get credit approved which makes sales that much harder. They consistently bark at us to make sure that we are not gaming to get sales and in the same breath we are asked to do things that are completely unethical. As soon as I get another job offer I am out of here and I have been a very happy employee for 5 years.

pros: good benefits and good locations to work at, if in California.
cons: pay structure..dont get paid for what your worth..rather than how much management wants to pull the wool over your eyes.  Management structuring is horrible, people who are not qualified to manage or lead ever are somehow promoted to high level status. Branches are run like sweat shops and banker/cssr's/tellers are required to do everything but sell there soul on a daily basis.  The requirements to work there are that you sell people things they dont need and shouldnt have, car salesman have a bad rap.  But when its in perspective Bankers at Wells are told to be a million more times pushier than the local used car salesman.  Could be a great company to work for then again isnt that the same for all of them...!

review_title: The Most Boring Position You Will Ever Have
pros:
Comprehensive Training- Lasted approx 2 weeks
Seemed to be flexible with scheduling
Friendly Co-Workers
Helpful Co-Workers
Good sense of community within workplace
cons:
This position is basically an obnoxious greeter who stands up front that none of the customers want to talk to.

You literally stand for 8 hours a day asking people what they're doing at the bank today. Of course they don't want to talk to you!!

Lots of pressure to meet your "sales quota", even though you're not a banker or a teller. You are still expected to perform by providing the bankers and tellers with a set number of referrals each quarter. 

Should do away with the position if they haven't already. Customers don't like it!!!

review_title: Wells Fargo is the oldest Financial Institution in the USA.
pros: Team members working together, online platform for customers and team members, benefits package and compensation, working for the customer mentality.
cons: Too many higher ups that implement policies and procedures that are not practiced by the people who implement them which causes a disconnect in communication and working for the client mentality.

review_title: micro managed, treated very poorly and unfair
job_title: Personal Banker I in Tampa, FL
pros: They are good with promoting within the company, good paid time off.
cons: Since the merger with wachovia wells fargo has gotten steadily worse, i used to love my job but they have started micro managing you so horribly to the point where they lock up your screen and your manager has to review what you have done before you can process opening accounts, making you feel like you aren't competent to make good decisions, they really have gotten to big for their own good, you will have to constantly deal with customer problems and issues where it becomes unbearable because most of the time it was not your fault yet people are just so upset they will scream at you. They have started to take away your credit for accounts if they are opened under certain circumstances so trying to make sure you reach your goals is becoming impossible. the people there usually are decent but i have run into times where the mangers are such horrible people to be leaders its discussing and you really don't have much of a resource because if you call human resources get ready for everything you do to be scrutinized. overall since wells fargo took over wachovia there hasn't been anything but changes to make life difficult for employees and customers.

pros: its not a bad company they treat you nicely and with respect, they are always giving you recognition for every little thing you do, where I work, coworkers care for each other, is a very friendly work environment. so that's what makes me like my job. I learned how to be more aggressive which I really really like the most about the job. it helped me a lot.
cons: pay is alright if you are a college student and live with parents  and have no bills to pay and have no intention to move out independently. But in my case the pay and my bills I cant save money because is not enough for my intended goals.

review_title: Good company to work for if you don't have onsite aspirations!!!
pros:
Employee friendly culture and policy.
Good people to work with.
You can retire from this company if you want
 There are people which seriously following this; especially managers.
Fun@work.
Wells Fargo brand value will be good for your CV.
Ideas and efforts are getting recognized.
cons:
No onsite opportunity at all. They will make this expectations clear at the time of joining.
If you dare to ask for any onsite opportunity they will convince you that Wells Fargo is not a transport company.
Salary is good when you join this company. Half yearly increments are terrible. If you stay in this company for more that 3-4 years then world will be ahead of you in terms of salary.
They have fix duration for offering role change. No matter whatever you do you will not get promoted to next role before that duration.
80% support work.

job_title: Marketing Professional in San Francisco, CA
pros: As a contracor, only "pro" is paycheck...and the fact that 98,% of the people on the floor I was on are out the door by 5 p.m. They pay decently (everything through recruiting agencies...). Having said this, the woman I reported to us probably the sweetest person I've worked for in 15 years....
cons: Contactors get no benefits...but some companies try to make you feel part of the company. NOT WFB! NO one spoke. Ever. Employees rarely spoke to each other except on conf calls. Say "hi" to someone and people view you with suspicion.Ecen o. The coffee room-- DEAD SILENCE.  I've worked dozens of places o. Contract before -- including Wells...but only BofA's UX group  years ago was weirder. Most days I did NOTHING -- which could be. "Ori"...except you're blocked from accessing personal website, sending or receiving attachments and get pio-up warnings when you logon to many (non creepy) sites. But this understandable for such a highly regulated industry. Just, why do they hire someone to just sit there for weeks?

review_title: No room to grow // lack of leadership
pros: Had some great coworkers. Business credit cards  rather then using your own and then getting reimbursed.  Ability to volunteer with the community.... IF you can get the time approved.
cons: If the producer you are working with does not bring in more business there is no movement for you or anyone on your team. If there is limited number of producers, you cannot switch teams either. WFIS wants you to do the work, without the title or salary.  Per my manager, you must work in the position for at least a year AND a position needs to be available before you get promoted into that title and salary increase. Manager also wants the floor to sound like a library. Started to create a horrible work environment.  A lot of red tape due to being owned by a bank.

pros:
diversity
6 weeks of training
Paid holidays
cons:
bad management 
Crappy schedule 
Poor pay

review_title: Wells Fargo treats employees as widgets.
pros: Some excellent and very helpful people work at Wells Fargo at the lower levels. The will go out of their way to help you understand what needs to be done. In fact I got a call from one of them telling me a bit about what had been happening in the background. Told me not to take it too hard as it probably was just some budgetary thing from on high.
cons:
Somewhat squirrelly and arbitrary I was told by a couple of others who were nice enough to talk with me.

They tend to treat people as plug in widgets with no concern for employee morale. They tend to hire and fire, especially contractors without thinking about the people. Rarely if ever give a reason for letting someone go. Almost no communication up and down the food chain. You can get moved from one group to another and not know it until later. Team leads are not told much about what the reasons are for the actions of upper management and often are not even told when a team member is being released.

review_title: Lack of respect and communication only by email from District Mgmt
job_title: Personal Banker I in Oakwood, GA
pros: Lots of room to grow and advance your career. Generous time off allowances. Clean work environment. Stable company.
cons:
Where to begin, Pay was too low and incentives/bonus are a kick in the head even if qualify for it.
Dist Mgr and up are only email reachable and the micro mgmt is ridiculous. The reporting by peers to Mgmt is unethical everyone lies about there numbers hourly/daily/weekly and monthly hoping for walk in traffic to meet those numbers. The leads they expect you to call are crap unless you have all the senority then you get the top leads. Make sure you work in a branch with 3 or less bankers anymore and its a Shark Tank. If you like being threatened then work in the Gainesville,GA market.
Make the base pay the same as the rest of Metro Atlanta. Two-three exits down from Oakwood in Buford/Sugar Hill the base pay for the same job was $6000/yr more. I found that out a few weeks after I started.

review_title: Most Bipolar Management Ever but Great Learning Experience for First Job Out of College
pros: 20 Days PTO plus bank holidays are really nice. Great coworkers and depending on your manager, great support from them. Feels good that most of the time you get to help customers with there finances. Great learning experience on how to interact with customers. There is a saying that if you can survive a year at Wells Fargo, you can survive anywhere.
cons: Unrealistic sales goals that causes even the most ethical banker to turn to the dark side to make a living. Unrealistic customer satisfaction survey that causes paranoia in branches. Upper management is out of touch on what is really going on in the workplace. Slow upward mobility which seems only shady bankers gets to move up. Very low morale in stores due to unrealistic expectations

review_title: I was sold a fool's dream
pros:
The co-workers are nice. After 3 years you get an extra week of vacation.
If you can meet you quarterly goals the bonuses can be nice.
You get almost every major holiday off. 
Great job if you don't mind trying to sell to every person you see.
cons: The turnover is high. At one location, I had 3 different service managers in a 12 month period. I've worked with over 35 tellers in 4 years and just as many bankers. There is a great deal of stress in making your quarterly sales goals, and even if you make them, there is little chance for promotion because I work in an area with very few branches. Tellers are only hired at 20 hours a week, and even though they're promised 40 hours a weeks when hired, many have not seen that come to fruition. If you're not a sales person, it's not the job for you.

job_title: Phone Banker I in Columbia, SC
pros: Excellent Company to work with. I have been employed for a month this company offers more than great pay and a cool job. WF also offers opportunities of growth and development they help you learn the true meaning of finances and what it means to invest and save money there are free counsel opportunities for employers and the list goes on anyone that works for WF there is no reason they should not be financially successful. The learning and development training truly prepares you for your job and all the class time is 100% relevent to the job itself I encourage anyone that has a strong back ground in customer service  that is looking for an opportunity where growth and advancement is realistic within a work place to be a part of WF.
cons: Honestly every job/position has its cons, however WF rewards its employers for dedicated team members so the position and people you work with totally out weighs any bad day as well my review is targeted to everyday people such as myself that are just doing their best in being successful in the coming future. :)

review_title: Heavy Sales Culture, But Friendly People
pros:
Decent Pay for a teller when you take the bonus into consideration.
They provide 401k.
Tuition reimbursement.
I enjoyed the people I worked with, I know Wells has a reputation for a heavy sales culture but I was lucky and had two awesome managers. They were by far some of the best managers I've ever had, they were friendly, engaging, and most importantly supportive. However, not everyone is as lucky as me, so when you're at that interview make sure you get a good gauge of the manager. Don't be afraid to ask, how the atmosphere at the branch is.
cons:
Sales!!!!! This company never lowered a sales quota when I worked for them, every quarter is was increased regardless of if customers needed our products. We now see the consequences of such aggressive sales tactics, public disgust. I hope
Wells learns from this and creates an environment that takes care of their customers and doesn't take advantage of them day after day.

pros: No sales goals.... for now. PTO/Vacation time and paid holidays off. They recently added a few more paid holidays to pur 2018 calender, which is awesome. That's about it.
cons: Good luck trying to advance and move up if you're not, for lack of a better term, an a** kisser.
