Management acts as if they care about your advancement, but in turn will literally give positions to "favorite " employees... when sales goals left, quality work went with it. If you aren't best friends with your manager, you'll be stuck in your position .  Recruiters reach out to managers about employees who are looking to post out, so if your manager doesnt want to let you go.... you wont go anywhere. So while you think you're moving in the right direction, someone is always there to knock you back down.  The pay could be better.  Saturday hours.

pros: Training was good but wasn't followed in branches
cons: Everything else pretty much a con.

review_title: Wells Fargo is not for me!
job_title: Store Manager in Las Vegas, NV
pros: They were flexible with my work schedule and it made my personal life easier to manage.  They offer a decent benefits package that included 401k and stock options.  It is a bank, so you do get every holiday off and if you are fortunate to work in a traditional branch rather than an in-store you could even get weekends off.  The work itself is not very difficult but because of the economy and the way the overall market is right now, you  may have a tough time achieving your sales goals which will bring more pressure from Senior Management becasue they have deadlines to meet as well.
cons: Management is not very organized, they believe more in quantity rather than quality when it comes to sales.  They hold way to many meetings about things you are doing wrong rather than ways to improve current situations.  I believe that management is too self involved with thier own sales goals to see that keeping and training your best people will lead to stronger sales and a happier work environment.  I believe that Wells Fargo Nevada is to blame rather than Wells Fargo Company.  The leadership in Nevada is very poor and is run by people who in my opinion are store managers at best.

review_title: The Saddest Day of My Life
pros: I still have a job in an economy that has double digit unemployment.
cons: The paid holidays that we were given at Wachovia were reduced to 8. They took away our 10 day family care time (in addition to regular PTO). The tuition reimbursement does not cover anything other than the actual tuition; Wachovia paid everything, books, fees & tuition.  Additionally, they only pay for a very small amount of pre-approved classes.  I am mid-way through classes that they will not pay for. The health insurance is certainly cheaper, but, much more inferior. We now have to pay 20% of everything!!  Many of us had titles with Wachovia, they took those away too. Every day it seems as though they are taking away something else from us. This is not an organization geared for the professional.

review_title: Great room for advancement lower salaries at the branch level!
job_title: Personal Banker I in Venice, FL
pros: Benefits are great, many opportunities to advance your career, very stable company, WF seems to guide employees to advance to the next level and have plans to assist in doing so.
cons: Goals are a tough reach, certain branches are favored because of higher foot traffic and same goals are expected of those in a considerably slower branch. Some weeks bankers are telemarketers with scheduled "call nights" that are long drawn out sessions of calling customers who have been called by every other department in WF. Low starting salary. If a simple test is failed that is given to the whole branch all bonus opportunities are tossed for each individual! Mandatory Saturday's following each holiday because there is eight hours that WF doesn't have to pay overtime.

review_title: I've thoroughly enjoyed working there as I've met alot of great people and I've been able to build my skill set.
job_title: Customer Service and Sales Representative in New York, NY
pros: There's no shortage of great people that I've met whilst working there. Eventhough I've gotten promoted to another store, I'm still in contact with most of my co-workers who I worked with at my previous location.  Depending on your store's location, the potential exists to make good extra money through their compensation plan; higher volume stores will be goal mines for business.  Altogether, I think their banking system is incredibly advanced so it makes the work of the retail banking staff much easier.
cons: Overall, the company itself has many great things to offer as they are a full service financial institution.  However, as they are so new to the NY market there are definite challenges as far as sales are concerned because they're competing with so many other banks that already dominate the marketplace.  Also, with some of the recent changes to the compensation plan, getting compensated has a number of technicalities and it can sometimes be challenging to understand the complexities of the plan.

review_title: It was okay- very sales based
pros: I was lucky enough to have incredibly friendly and supportive upper management and coworkers. The wells fargo orientation definitely helped me with learning new skill sets that I still employ in my day to day work!
cons: Being a teller at wells fargo was entirely sales based. If you made your sales and had excellent customer service, you did well. I was lucky enough to do well but it was tough constantly having to sell accounts to people that I know didn't necessarily need them; I guess that's a problem for working for a big bad bank corporation, right? There was also a lot of pressure on management to reach sales goals which was putting a lot of strain on our branch.

review_title: Was  A Great Company but Lost 'People First' Focus
pros: Good pay, rock-solid marketing, theoretically good opportunity for advancement
cons: Very poor treatment of lower level employees, HR department completely out of touch with business needs, Company and management very clearly value profit more than people and will keep toxic employees who support given regime, but quickly dump hard working employees focused on building strong and controlled core business.  Unfortunately for Wells Fargo, this is not limited to one or two business lines but rather is a way of doing business and will, in the end, leave too many 'yes' people in place at the expense of a strong culture of control and people-first.  While Wells should be a great employer for advancement, it is surprisingly poor from an HR perspective.  HR policies will not allow employees to grow into new positions or career paths unless they have direct experience.  This focus on pedigree over competence will eventually weaken the company.  Sadly, this isn't unique to Wells Fargo, but certainly more pronounced than at other companies.

pros: Ok Pay and good benefits. Most supervisors were nice.
cons: You have a lot of training, but after the training is finished you're practically thrown in like a fish without water. It's a very difficult job and they expect you to have perfect numbers all of the time. They get very frustrated if you can't deesculate a call even if the caller was livid to begin with. Treatment was unfair sometimes. No very supportive towards workers who have anxiety problems. Are told to "suck it up" constantly and always get a "talking to" if you're away from the desk too long after a bad phone call. I know you're getting paid to do a job, but some people can't handle being screamed at and being called every horrid name under the sun for a half hour and be able to let it go after two minutes.

pros: The job I hold has some stability.
cons: Horrible, top-down management. No meaningful engagement with employees. The compensation plan is stone age unless you are at the executive level. If you enjoy being driven year after year to provide more with less support from the company then this job is for you. The company wide raises are capped at 2%, which means that if you are one of the lucky ones that get an actual cost of living wage of 4%, then someone else has had their raise cut by 2%. The healthcare is, again, sub-par. The deductible for the HSA Silver account is $5000. The gold plan is $3000. Given that the IRS limit is just a little more than $3000 good luck trying to save anything for the future with these bare bones plans. But hey, the last two years they have provided 1% profit sharing to their "Most Valuable Asset" (smirk), their team members. I generally try to avoid teams that are actively out to screw their team mates, but of necessity and seniority find this a distasteful arrangement to make a living.

review_title: Wells Fargo Advisors WBS/branch based advisor
job_title: Financial Advisor in San Francisco, CA
pros: Referrals and they have tuition reimbursement
cons: This is by far the worst company on the planet. I worked in the branch as an FA and they take 12.5% on refereed business from a licensed banker, why? I have no idea probably to pad the earnings. Everything you get is from referred business so if you’re on a 25% pay grid they take half of your earnings. If you do a trade under 100k they take 90% of the commission so if it’s referred to you, you actually pay them to write business under 100k. I did 35k in revenue one month and after they took all their deduction I ended up owing them 600 dollars... unbelievable. Do not work here for any reason you will be penniless and desolate to get out. Oh and another kicker it’s the most unethical company on the planet (I know big shocker). I’d have bankers telling me which investment a prospect wanted to do without me even speaking to them. If you take a job with them after reading this then you deserve the pain they’re going to give you.

review_title: Layoffs!! Poor Management!! Poor Decisions!! Poor Managers!!
pros: Once upon a time it was a good company
cons:
They'll hire web developers after one  year, u tell them you're outdated, you're not good at machine learning, big data and screw them up, insult them like slaves. 
No proper promotion policies. 
Ever changing polices on hikes, promotions.
All the real benefits are being stripped off.
Clueless managers who don't know anything about what's happening on top level.. 
Already dissolved few Lobs and layed off many managers! 
Introducing silly things like dress code relaxation and project it as employee benefit 😂. College kids also won't join you for this stuff..
Technology Managers with very poor understanding on modern programming and delivery models most of them coded decade back.

Technology managers are the sin of this company!!!

job_title: Registered Personal Banker in Dallas, TX
pros: Wells Fargo is a very enclusive work evironment. They will pay up to $5000 per year for higher education as long as it is toward a Business degree or Business advancement. Wells Fargo matches in their 401K of 6% up to 100% of your salary; and gives 20 Paid Time Off when you first get hired.
cons: Wells Fargo is a very sales oriented environment. I dont recommend this company if anyone is timid of asking lots of financial questions to people. They are considered a "widget" based company to where they want everyone to have checking, savings, debit card, credit card, rewards, online banking, mortgage, investment accts......after a while, the "widget" driven environment gets old. Their bonus structure is capped, so if an employee has a great quarter in sales and does 200% above goal, then the max payout is $5500.....which is not alot in the "sales" world.

pros:
You don't have to work nights or Sundays.
You get a bonus every quarter as long as you make sales goals.
cons: The pay and small quarterly bonus is not worth the stress of the high sales goals. The managers are constantly breathing down your neck to find (or make up) sales for customers even when nothing is needed. Even after you finally meet your sales goals for the quarter, you are still constantly lectured to get more and more or you are just not good enough. Plus every month you get these tedious and time consuming assignments that you must complete while trying to deal with customers in the meantime. Honestly, if I didn't have to worry about the stressful sales, and just worry about customer service, it wouldn't be a bad job. When I go to the bank, I don't want to be asked about getting a savings account or if I have insurance every single time. I just want to do my transaction and get out.

review_title: Working here has been one helluva roller coaster ride.
pros: Ok benefits package, paid time off, hour lunches, voluntary time off if call volume is low. May meet some great friends.
cons: Too many supervisors that do not communicate with each other. Favoritizim from upper management. No room for advancement unless you personally know the hiring supervisors. Advancements based on likeability over actual skills needed to do the job. Management does not listen. People don't say anything for fear they will lose their job. If you want to work here don't go through temp service. If a person that gets hired directly come in the door making what they want  you will get at least 2 dollars less and have to work twice as hard if you want to get hired on coming from a temp service.

review_title: Great job for those who like working in a very structured environment
pros: Great benefits, 2 weeks paid vacation at start of employment, many opportunities to advance to other positions and promotions. Wells Fargo always likes to promote from within. As one of the largest corporate companies in the USA and abroad, there are many different types of employment opportunies opening up all the time. Great for long term employment. Lots of recognition.
cons: Must have a very flexible schedule and easily adapt to change. Changes at Wells Fargo can happen overnight. Very structured environment. As a phone banker, you must meet sales goals, while maintaining passing levels of schedule adherance, average handle time, quality assurance, and more. Failure to pass any of them will result in NO QUARTERLY BONUS CHECK. Lots of pressure to sell, sell, sell!!!

pros: What Wells Fargo does best is that they have excellent training and set rules and plenty of staffing in most departments in the retail banking division. Well established and opportunity for growth if you know the right people and exceed all aspects of your role at Wells Fargo, especially the sales role.
cons: Wells Fargo has excessively high/un-achievable sales goals in the teller role. Management threatens you constantly and the Micro-managing that goes on at each "store" makes you want to go home and cry every day. I hated working for this company in the end. I felt like I was selling sunglasses to customers everyday and they already have 20 sunglasses as it is. Customers could see we were depressed and no longer happen with what happened from the merger from Wachovia (a great company) to this high sales driven company.

job_title: Credit Card Phone Banker, Personal Banker, Teller in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Pretty good benefits compared to other companies, get to meet new ppl everyday, educated a bit in the banking world, met some of the best coworkers
cons: Sales at whatever cost . I honesty wish I had the chance to instead of quitting maybe just switch to a department that didn't have any sales goals. Managers will literally let anything slide just to get an acct, loan, partners, etc...,even if it's unethical and defeats sales integrity. I worked in two different branches but also have friends who worked in other branches as well and it was the same everywhere, everybody IS/WAS gaming and not because most want to anyway, but because they HAVE due to the insane sales goals. It's really unfortunate to the customers because they would leave w. Services or products they didn't know they signed up for or didn't need and I honestly think that Wells Fargo doesn't reward their employees enough for the good work we did. Their prizes and incentives are a joke :/

pros: I worked as a teller while I was a full time student, so I appreciated that they were willing to work with my schedule to some degree. Their training program is boring but once you get through that and get to know the people you work with it's not half bad. Hours are consistent and considering the job, it actually pays fairly well.
cons: While some people were nice, the drama that took place in the work environment was ridiculous to say the least. Also, if you are a natural born seller, this is the worst job for you. They want you to read a script to almost every customer, which because you have so many regulars, they end up getting angry with you.Lastly, when I first started out the management was great, but corporate cleaned house and brought in management that became notorious for playing favorites. In the end, myself and several others left because of the shift.

pros: Great training and career advancement; for example I've only been with the company for less than a year and I've advanced to personal banker with in time from a teller. Buys lunches occasionally this is very rare. Awesome benefits out the gate such as Time off and Health and Life insurance. 401K's and assistance with schooling. Awesome career advancement to this is a driving factor with their culture.
cons: Pay could be better it seems that Wells Fargo is the lowest paying retail banking in the industry as a personal banker I would like to see an increase in what we see at take home. The bonuses are a joke too. with High sales pressure and the small pay out it gets to be a little crushing with little rewards. Oh and don't forget those "Amazing" benefits are supposed to make up for the lack in pay and compensation.

pros: Nice co-workers, and management. Yes, there are sick days, and some vacations like everywhere else 21 days a year or so.
cons: Very pushy sales, very stressful, the stress is not worth the salary, most of the time it can become too boring to work at the bank, depending which branch. If it's a busy branch, it can become too crazy to work (they expect you to sell more), if the branch is not crowded, then it's just boring because there are no customers and you can't like read something or browse the web. At times, you just think you cannot handle this any more, and after you leave, you don't want EVER to go back to sales positions, but may be it's just because of the bank experience. Selling accounts is pretty annoying, if you like to sell something nobody really needs, then go ahead and try. Everyone has accounts already either at this bank or somewhere else, all you do is annoy customers each time they walk in. That's how I felt (not when you just chat with them but when you really offer them a product a.k.a. extra accounts). Good luck!

review_title: Entry-level bank and not for top performers
job_title: Customer Assistance Specialist CAS in Chandler, AZ
pros: Hours, night differential 4 hours after 4pm in 1 work day. 2 volunteer days, 401k 5% match, benefits are same as any other. Carry over unpaid sick days. Team members all support each other seeing that upper management does not (same enemy mentality). Room for lateral moves advancement not so much since pay is capped out at 10%.
cons: Was hired in at lower pay rate because I was told a 2k monthly bonus was possible.  Within months the bonus was taken away with no compensation. Who does that? ? WF does and no one cared what the employees thought. Managers response was if you dont like it leave. Every is on some type of written warning. Expectations are so unrealistic even for top reps. Bust your butt for free or to have them question how you do it in a negative way. This place/company is a joke. I have yet to find 1 person who likes it. Been going downward spiral since middle of 2015. Sad to be a part of this sinking ship. Love my customers though.

pros: The pay is competitive. insurance is very good and not too expensive. Customers will be the highlight of your day! This is a great company with good intentions and a potential to be great, but their management teams kill all hopes.
cons:
Management hassles you to no avail and try to coach you on a daily basis. 
The turn over rate for the company is astonishing! I worked for them for 6 years and saw a total of 4 branches, 8 branch managers, 6 service managers, and about 40 or so Co workers. At one branch I was at everyone was let go and only 3 people were left. The first time I left a branch was because of HR issues, the second was for a promotion to a lead teller, the third I actually left the company for another job and quickly realized I needed to come back. The position at my old branch had been filled so I had to apply else where.

review_title: The pros directly link to cons
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Des Moines, IA
pros: Care for employees and for customers, despite recent bad press. Basically well-run, despite recent bad press. Good opportunities, despite recent bad press...but then there is the bad press...
cons: The bad press related to account opening was terrible but not as bad as the response. No one should be surprised given the sales pressures but what was surprising was the ill-prepared, bumbling testimony of John Stumpf (could not state when he first heard or when the Board first heard - not a surprise question so utterly ridiculous not to be able to answer) under whom the sales practices began before becoming CEO in 2007 and the consequence-free retirement of Carrie Tolstedt. I went from a former senior employee who was proud to have worked at Wells to one who was embarrassed. This insider integrity lapse needs to end.

review_title: Commercial Distribution Finance Desires A lot to learn about diversity and inclusion
pros: Household name, stability, and some of the ethical people who make your time their enjoyable
cons: The environment created at the line of business Well Fargo acquired from GE Capital known as Commercial Distribution Finance proved to be unhealthy in just 2 months into my experience. Particularly, the Program Services department displayed weird, cultish behavior. This line of business despised having been acquired by Wells  Fargo, and did not uphold the company values. Their idea of diversity & inclusion is contracting a bunch of African Americans, making them prove themselves before hired on as employees and treating them subpar (actions & behaviors) meanwhile. Family members and friends are hired on, and favored creating an unethical, unhealthy, and cult-like environment with limited opportunities for others. Being a true orange personality with a level of confidence, zeal, and creativity, this was not the environment for me. Be aware of employment agency, Insight Global who works with this division/department. Both will insult your intelligence, lie to you to reel you in, and preserve a bigger salaries for their friends & family. The starting salary for the Program Associate position is  laughable unless you are truly entry level in your career.

job_title: Technical Project Coordinator in Des Moines, IA
pros: Great PTO Allotment 20 days. Plus 10 holidays and 2 personal holidays. They encourage upward mobility and the bettering of one's self.  If one is inclined to do so it is encouraged and the tools are given to do it.  I am glad I have medical coverage through my husband though as it seems a bit expensive for basic coverage.  I do get my dental and vision through them as it was cheaper than my husband's offerings.  They have an up to 6% 401 k match which is really good.
cons: Sometimes there is too much micromanagement from Top Down.  It makes things a little stressful from time to time, but understandable since government regulations have to be followed.  Not too many con's since this job is typically not customer facing.  or out customers are other employees.

job_title: Teller At Wells Fargo in San Antonio, TX
pros: Teamwork for work at branch
cons: Pay is not what is should be

review_title: Good company, terrible mgmt style and mistreatment of employees
pros: Excellend company, classy, and good organization structure.
cons: Repetitiveness; not really being able to take on new challenges, questionable management.  Dissatisfaction with the way they handled a very important personal situation.  There is a huge conflict of interest within the entire company.  "Financial" is the consumer finance division of Wells, their primary product is sub-prime refinancial/lending.  However the consumer finance division also offers auto secured lending and unsecured lines of credit.  The problem is Financial offers higher rates on the secured and unsecured lending products, you solicit these products to existing Wells customer to offer diversified products, but some if not most these existing customers have similar products already at much much lower rates.  So how can the same company offer similar products, to existing consumers, at a higher cost?!  How would take a line of credit from Financial @ 18%-24%, when they can call the Wells Bank in South Dakota via phone, or internet and obtain the same product for a 4-13% rate?  You competing for consumers within the same parent company which the biggest competitor ironically!

review_title: A good company to work for if you like sales with very little compensation for the sales made.
pros: This is a good company that is changing fast. You usually work with pretty cool people that are outgoing  and want to get along. The benefits are nice and so is the 401k which is 6% after the first year. You can move up quickly like in all jobs if you kiss butt and succeed at your position. You can actually promote yourself rather quickly if you want. Your manager makes a huge difference, so hopefully you get a good one.
cons: The companies goals have changed a lot and almost seem unethical, with a business model that doesn't seem to hold strong over the long run. You are pushed extremely hard and the compensation for your sales is very sad and almost embrassing. If you want to do great sales you must contribute to the recession. Your main goal is to get a checking account.

review_title: Wells Fargo is definitely one of the best places to work!
job_title: Business Process Consultant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: I have worked for a number for Fortune 500 companies, and I have to say Wells Fargo is the best for their benefits, diversity, employee care, etc.  When I first started with Wells Fargo back in 2005, I received five weeks of vacation starting day one.  I believe that is down now to just under five weeks with the merger of Wachovia, but still better than most companies.  Also, they allow me to work 100% remotely for the position I am in as a Business Process Consultant.  As mentioned above, Wells Fargo is also strong with their diversity.  Every year they participate in the Twin Cities Gay Pride Parade with over 100 team members walking in the parade.  Their GLBT employee resource group meets monthly and is actively supporting their GLBT team members.
cons: The medical benefits over the past couple of years have become less attractive due to healthcare cost.  However, given the state of healthcare, I can understand the necessity for the change.

review_title: Wells Fargo Salt Lake City  is TERRIBLE!!!
job_title: Phone Banker in Salt Lake City
pros: If I could give no stars, I would. The only pro is the competitive hourly wage.
cons: Favoritism, nepitism, micromanagment, unrealistic sales goals, lack of sales integrity, unprofessionalism, stressful.

pros: Decent pay, holiday pay, PTO, 100% match 401k at 6% contribuition. They are a bank. A financial institution. The benefits are there. But you definately have to work for them. I love my job itself. Helping people reach financial stability and control and a better understanding of credit management, but in my current district, I don't feel valued at all.
cons: Sales, sales, sales. They are very agressive and demanding when it comes to numbers. You may have a 9-5 shift but they don't warn you about call nights and madatory phone meetings. Management has its nose in the air and are completely close minded to both your needs as an employee and the true needs of the customer.

pros: Easy, not much stress now that sales goals are gone
cons: HIGHLY political organization. It was pretty astonishing how much face time with the higher ups matter even for smaller promotions. Very slow to promote unless you use personal relationships to get ahead. And the cherry on top, even though sales goals are no longer paid via bonus, people are still being promoted by opening additional accounts that customers don't want or pushing credit without disclosing all of the fees involved. After months of being yelled by customers for my coworkers actions (opening accounts the customer didn't want, not disclosing fees, or other such issues), I finally had enough. My advice to anyone seriously considering this role is to prepare yourself to either break ethical barriers or know that you will be in the role you were hired into for a long time.

review_title: Honestly, an awful place to work
pros: Flexibility with hours, that is literally it.
cons:
I feel the need to be completely honest here before another poor post grad kid with a masters in finance is sucked in to this place. It's a boring, data entry job. You are doing the same task over and over again, some are easier than others but overall you are doing the same one thing for 8 hours a day. Management is so beyond removed. You will have either a micromanaging fly for a manager or a completly checked out manager who knows how boring the work here is. There is no room for growth or skill development other than excel. 
You can do literally a whole day without seeing anyone in your team, division, or department. You are busy for 2 weeks then have absolutely, literally, nothing to do for another 2 weeks.

job_title: Credit Manager in White Plains, NY
pros: Excellent company as far as resources; this ensured great benefits, training, etc.  Learned a lot about the banking/credit industry from my time with the company.  Comprehensive 401K plan that was highly recommended by co-workers, unfortunately my brief period (Less than 1 year) with the company didn't provide much experience with the plan.  Employees were recognized/congratulated by management for meeting monthly/yearly sales goals.
cons: Constantly on the phone!  Information sharing amongst employees was scarce.  Working for a company like Wells Fargo during the "credit crunch" one would assume that more education would be provided for employees, especially sales members considering that information/knowledge is vital to selling.  I was also extremely disappointed with the compensation packages offered to employees.  It often felt as though this was an environment of "what have you done for me lately" but then again that's the sales industry in a nutshell.  Required sales targets were unreasonable considering the lack of compensation provided for meeting these quotas.  Products provided customers with little to no finance stability/relief, just perpetuated a struggling economy.

review_title: Great Place to work with strong initial trianing
pros:
For someone coming in off the street, Wells Fargo has kept up with AG Edwards' old training program.  It is a very successful at getting you past the Series 7 and 66 exams. With the training time spent in St. Louis, a new FA Trainee comes to the branch ready to run.
Personally, my experiences working with Mgmt were exeptional.  My Branch Manager was far from a micro-manager.  He trusts his FA's to do what is needed for success.  Work life balance was great and each FA is given the utmost respect.
cons: One of the things I struggled with didn't really have to do with the company but rather their marketing philosophy.  Like all broker dealers, Wells wants you so shoot for people with high net worth and investable assets.  Personally, I feel that leaves about 90% of all Americans out of the loop.  If you market to that group, you can make up the difference in volume quite easily b/c you are working with a segment of the population that is pretty much ignored by traditional investment brokerages.

pros: There are not many good things to say about this company.  The best thing this company offers is a good dental package.
cons:
Where would someone start in order to explain the lack of care this company has for its customers.  The entire philosophy is centered around shoving basic bank products down a customers throat, so when they eventually do get sick and tired of the company, the customer has too many products to just take their money and walk.  
Yes, dear Wells Fargo customers...They want your direct deposit, your debit cards, your first born ... because they will screw up and you will find it to much of a pain to withdraw your assets and move them to a decent bank, where the smile on the bankers face is not a false one.   
How many checking accounts can one person have?  Ask a Wells Fargo Banker and the answer is going to be something along the lines of " how many points do I get for selling one".  
The branches are called STORES!  I think that explains it all. 
I wont be a banker for much longer, I am finding it hard to look at myself in the mirror and accepting that I am apart of this.  
Filthy Company at Best

review_title: Busy, understaffed and all about the 'social game' versus getting results and work done
pros:
The benefits are excellent
Many locations so you can find one near you and not have a long commute
Peers that are great to work with
cons:
Pay is lower than equivalent jobs outside of Wells Fargo
They are more concerned about the "social game" than getting great results and getting work done
Difficult to get approved for reimbursement of outside work-related education.  This is a benefit that they offer. 
Severely understaffed in many departments
Lack of organized training - most is side-by-side, on-the-job training

review_title: The pay is better than other non-banks, but there is no professional growth
pros: The pay is better than similar jobs in other industry in the area.  There is a lot of work autonomy.  I enjoyed working with my peers of the same level.
cons: Promotion not based on performance; and there is little chance of promotion.  There was little guidance and training of company systems at on-boarding, or any other time.  Wells Fargo is not a place where the management wants to challenge it's employees with offering process improvements.  There was no real guidance on what annual goals are or what bonuses will be if one outperforms goals.  Bonuses were given out like a Christmas party mystery gift with no rationale as to how the bonus amount was derived at.  Also, if someone quit or was fired there was no notice sent out the "so and so" was no longer at the company and designating what person was know handling the departed's workload.  I know that is like the behavior at a lot of large corporations these days, but it doesn't make it right.

pros: large company that appears to have a stable foundation.  good brand name, strong volunteer/corporate giving presence.  good staff on the floor supporting the goals of the company.
cons: Managers seem to ruin the environment.    somehow the leadership continues to get in the way of the success of the company.  constant rah rah in what a great company we are but no really employee support, no giving back to the employees, benefits get worse each year, no raises and constant reorganization.

review_title: Awful, dated technology, policies, and procedures. Corporate has no idea what retail is really like. Training is a lie.
pros: Bank holidays. 1 hour lunch break
cons: Everything else about the company, pay, job duties, training, interview, management, corporate, etc. The sales goals are not realistic thus you are pushed by store managers to deceive customers and push products they don't need/will cause problems for them. Customers are definitely taken advantage of especially when they are having financial troubles. Upper management/corporate is delusional and so old fashioned they have no idea what retail is actually like now. They are also so fake and disturbingly peppy, I wanted to vomit or scream listening to them speak. Very frustrating. Don't even get me started on how pathetic the software and banking systems are...I could design a better program using my iPhone. The interview and training process is even more disconnected from what the workplace is actually like. HR is living in a dream that is their training manual and does not prepare you at all for what the job is actually like. Pay is lower than other banks to top it all off. I could go on for days about how disappointed and horrified I was working here for 8 months. Everything is about sales numbers, who cares about customer service or proper bank protocol. Disgusting and unethical.

review_title: If you like asking 100 questions per customer and be accurate and fast and kind and genuine and sell products and Etc...
pros: Sundays off and good training before you start at store/branch.
cons:
Low pay, poor benefits, and standing in one spot all day.  Store Manager was great but in the office all the time.  The Manager on the teller line broke all the rules they trained you for.  She was a backstabber and was starting arguments on the floor with tellers and bankers in front of customers.  Lied to customers and did not have your back.  Computer software is unfriendly and seemed out of date and did not maneuver smoothly.  Late hours because drive thru open till 6 and still have to balance and close up.
Working Saturdays and Christmas eve are not necessary waste of payroll it was quiet.  Customers want you to hurry and cheat the system because always in a hurry or it never used to take this long before.  Sorry ....your only cashing a check from another bank for $15,000 why would I ask for your drivers license how silly of me????? You should scream at me.  I deserve it.  GET OVER YOURSELVES.

pros: Leaving at the end of the day.  The pay, but from what I hear, BOA is better on that front. There's no amount of money to get me to work for either one.
cons: Cant belive some people actually like this place- they must be new to the workforce.  There is no leadership or  communication. Unfriendly and uncaring environment overall.  And CHEAP!  This company has more money than God but they can't provide employees with hot water in the  break room .. or hot water, nevermind napkins, utensils or straws. Toilet seats look like they were salvaged from a bus depot!

review_title: Amazing! GREAT pay, GREAT benefits and I truly feel VALUED!!!
job_title: Research/Remediation Analyst in Des Moines, IA
pros: I worked for WF for 7 years and left to search out other opportunities.  I came back in 2016.  Since I've been back, Tim Sloan has become CEO and things have changed DRAMATICALLY-- the benefits (which were great before) have only gotten better,  the culture of the company is improving by leaps and bounds.  Yes, we've had some definite challenges to face, but there's been a huge effort by Senior Leadership to face those challenges head-on.  I am a true believer of this bank... a loyal customer...and extremely proud to be a team member of Wells Fargo.
cons: Our senior leaders and front line supervisors are wonderful.  However, there is A LOT of "middle management"  which needs to be trimmed down or they need to be more in sync with our senior leaders.

pros: The company has a good culture. There are a lot of virtuous individuals who work here.
cons:
They don't hire from within at pace near to turnover. A lot of skilled people move on because the job doesn't pay enough. The management blames turnover on why raises are so low. This line of business obtained World Class service ranking this last year and the account managers had to deal with a catastrophic error in our software for nearly a week before resolution. Yet raises were tiny for everyone. 

For the last year I achieved all of the things that I could within my postion. There is nothing else for me to learn, and yet my manager isn't trying to move me into another position in the company. I was forced to reapply to my own job and I lost it in a reorg. This company doesn't care about my development, and would rather keep me stuck training in new hires than actually want to retain me.

pros: I've been able to be part of several different areas of the bank and had opportunities to learn and grow.  The managers I've worked with are dedicated and want to see you succeed.  This is a performance based business.  When you succeed you are rewarded.  When you are not meeting minimum standards, as with any company, it is brought to your attention.  This sometimes can be perceived as a need to be pushy with customers.  I do not see it that way.  I'm able to meet my goals by helping customers to be financially sucessful.
cons: The financial compensation is inconsistant. I work with someone at my same location that is currently making 13,000 more than I am.  I've got more seniority and better past and present performance.  What is that all about?  I've asked for raises.  I've shown my manager how I've benefited our company and still nothing.  I'm ready to find something new.

review_title: Wouldn't Wish It Upon My Worst Enemy
job_title: Personal Banker I in Plymouth Meeting, PA
pros: Name Recognition and good place to get your foot in the door, paid time off is normally easy to get
cons: I have never worked at a worse place in my life.  This company is horrible.  Everyone hates their job.  They give you unrealistic expectations and then punish you by forcing you to come in on saturdays and make cold calls when you don't hit your goals.  Advancement in the company in nonexistent.  It's true that if you are good at your job you will never get promoted because losing you would make the manager's job more difficult.  Such a petty environment.  No one really cares about the customer, only jamming as many products down their throats as you can.  Everyday gets worse.  Senior management is SO FAR out of touch with reality.  They punish you and make you stay late just about every day til 7pm.  They seriously treat everyone like a child.  PA/DEL area is a horrible place to work, don't let them trick you into thinking that they value you as an employee!  Hands down worst place i have ever had to work.

review_title: Great people, middle management could be better
job_title: Business Systems Consultant in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
You get to work with great people - one bad apple in every group, but 99% of people are extremely professional and smart yet laid back. 
On the job training in every position - people have very varied backgrounds, and as long as you are eager and able to learn, they will train you. They do want you to advance.
Great benefits
Good, strong company values, they really promote community involvement and volunteering.
cons:
Varies vastly by department - some people LOVE the company and have been there for decades, while people in other departments, though hardworking and brilliant, are unfortunately not treated well by middle management and are very dissatisfied. Nearly everyone in my former department is looking to leave.
Pay somewhat lower than other companies; allegedly that's mediated by excellent benefits package, but it's up to you to decide whether it's worth it.
A lot of the same issues as any other company - lots of promises, not always delivered.

review_title: ehhh, not as good as I thought
pros: OK pay, good benefits, hours; sundays off (stand alone branch)
cons: EXTREMELY difficult to hit sales goals if you're at a branch with high value customers/clientele; customer service reps have an upper hands because they have teller experience and have banker duties and have goals to hit so of course they won't pass sales off to PERSONAL BANKERS; the sales goals are a bit on the ridiculous end when you don't have a full 8 hours to be able to interact with customers; saturdays are you get out at 4 unless you have to cold call…until 530. lot of politics, favoritism, etc…if you start in the middle of a quarter, you will be expected to perform at an experienced bankers level, full quarter or not. commissions get paid out every THREE MONTHS with a cap.

review_title: A reputable company that has a great corporate vision, but it doesn't always translate onto the retail sales floor
job_title: Licensed Personal Banker in Palo Alto, CA
pros: Energetic retail sales environment, diverse work environment, potential for growth throughout different departments, well-known company in the industry, numerous locations
cons: Incentive compensation plan is not great, high turnover in the retail sales sector, favoritism exists, some personal bankers are out for their own personal agendas, salary not enough to compensate for the stress brought upon by unreasonable sales goals

pros: Wells Fargo is a great company to work for. They promote a lot within the company so there is a lot of growth involved. As a teller, a lot of incentives come a long with the job, they even take us to concerts! Without a doubt a great company to work for that has a lot of great benefits as well.
cons: As a teller you are expected to sell sell sell. Now I am a great pitcher when it comes to selling products but sometimes even if it doesn't benefit the customer they still want you to sell the customer something and that doesn't always sit well with me. Also you deal with a lot of cash so there are a lot of rules and regulations to abide by and that can be very stressful at times.

pros:
Benefits (Medical, Dental, Vision, 401k with 6% match after 1 year that is fully vested, stock purchase plan).
Easy to move between branches and positions if you do your job, word travels fast good or bad.
Pay is average but with licensing it bumps up nicely.
cons:
Very political, many great employees get passed over for the ones that managers like, know outside of work, are attracted to, ect.. definitely need to kiss up to move up environment.
How your career and quality of work environment will be is based upon your manager, if they are terrible at their job and everyone knows it, they can still ruin your career if they don’t like you for personal reasons. 
Can be cold environment, my mother had a stroke and I was told I couldn’t leave work because I was needed, with 3 other bankers on, though Manager left daily for littlest things like their teenage child was hungry and they had to get them food.

pros:
*The firm will help you advance in your career if you show proper initiative and are friends with the right people (just plan to leave after you have progressed far enough in your career to land a more respectable position)
*The firm encourages community support
*If you don't have initiative or talent you can still stay for a very long time; many mediocre employees who don't want to work hard and, essentially, just want a paycheck (a pro if you are mediocre)
cons:
*Terrible pay/total compensation compared to industry standards for similar positions (they even did away with the last bit of somewhat redeeming benefits after the Wells/Wachovia "merger")
*Poor communication between senior management and employees
*Too much "decision by committee," nothing gets done efficiently or in a timely manner (and sometimes not even thoughtfully)
*Essentially, a fund firm with some decent funds that wants to be one of the top asset managers without having many of the proper employee/compensation metrics in place
*See Pro #3 above

pros: Overall a great company to work. The benefits are great and the PTO is good as well. Many areas of the company really care about their employees.
cons: The area that deal with sales is a rat race. The focus has been taken off of what is best for the customer to what we think the customer should have. It no longer matters about the employees family because the hours are extended and when a location is short staffed they all have to work longer hours until it is staffed. My bankers were working 50+ hours just to cover the extended hours when we were short. Sales are company wide and no matter how slow a location is, they have to get the same amount of sales that the bankers do in very busy areas.

pros:
*Actually having a job
*Benefits
*Pay - although its not the best, its certainly not the worst either
*Ease of job function - Brainless work. 
*No Micro-Managing
cons:
*Pay - Yes, i listed it above, but its also not what it should be for someone with this much experience
*Ease of job function - Again, yes i listed it above, however it is too easy. I like a challenge and i feel like a 5 year old. 
*Management - my direct area of managers could use some brush ups on their skills
*hours - They are horrible! Hands down, horrible!!
*the atmosphere - management doesnt encourage team building. They dont want employees up talking to eachother. We are expected to sit in our cubes and not move, not talk, just work. Sound like something else you know? (hint, think of bars and bright orange jumpsuits)

review_title: I have gone from Teller to Banker to Assistant Manager and now to BBS in less than 3 years and you can too.
job_title: Business Banking Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros: Upward mobility potential is high and management works with you to ensure that you're on track to achieving the next promotion.
cons: Unrealistic goals and very "widget" oriented selling. Community banking (retail) management has misguided what banks should focus on and oftentimes prefer that you get 15 debit cards ordered rather than a new private bank client because it's so much of a numbers game for solutions.

review_title: They are an ok company if you like being a robot.  Think ...Stepford Wives
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: A steady job.  Decent pay.  Excellent benefits.
cons:
The corporation is so Ozzie & Harriet phony it's sickening.  They brainwash very well here.  Heavily bureacratic, there is NO sense of creativity or individuality (though, they try to brainwash you into thinking so).  Think "1984" here.  Because of the bureacracy, it is very very difficult to get any real work accomplished.  The culture is heavily laden in processes and procedures that has its workers chasing their tails creating more nebulous tasks for themselves (and others).

So, if you are a results-oriented person who thrives on getting anything meaningful done - you will slowly languish here.

pros: Okay pay and hours, if you're good at sales, you'll be good at the job.  You're sometimes able to really help customers.  There is a chance for commission if you're good at sales, the extra money is nice.
cons:
Sales- never enough. 
Gallup Surveys- not absolutely perfect is bad, even when the customer is unhappy with the company but you did a great job.
To me, the company seems to take advantage of people who have very little income.  For example- they offer credit cards with little/no incentive for the customer to pay it back for 6 months to a year and a half, and then when the customer the bank offers them debt consolidation loans while leaving the card open. (This is more of an industry issue than a specific company issue.)

review_title: Stressful, poor management, "like an abusive spouse"
pros:
-Reliable pay
-Decent commission (if you manage to even qualify for it)
-Co-workers can be great, but most are cold and cannot wait to tattle on you for anything and everything
-Lots of locations in the DMV area, easy to transfer
cons:
-The pay. To go from teller to banker, you get a $1-2 raise, and triple the work. Incentive is nice, but tricky to get.
-Stress city. Managers expect you to do 150% everyday, and the day you do only 90%, you get chewed out for 30 minutes.
-The entire incentive of a manger's paycheck is based on how many products are pushed onto customers. Often times, you are asked to do what is best for the branch or district, NOT whats best for the customers. Bankers typically succeed by doing unethical and questionable activities, and managers promote this by looking the other way and enjoying the benefits of a good paycheck.

review_title: Great place to develop skills and build life long relationships.
pros: It's a great place to start a career and really grow.  If you are a hard worker and can be easily coached it's easy to move up in the company and get promoted.  The training programs are great it's both in a virtual training classes and face to face classes as well. You learn a lot of great skills that can be used outside of work as well.
cons: If you are a hard worker it's easy to get sucked into working so many hours especially if you are salaried or when overtime doesn't matter.  This makes it difficult to have a work-life balance because work becomes your life and then it starts feeling like a routine that you may get bored of after a while. So make sure to take breaks, have days off, and use PTO once in a while.

review_title: Definitely worth working here, Lots of room for career advancement.
job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Santa Clara, CA
pros:
*
Co-Workwers- Wells seems to hire cool down    to earth people. I got along with everyone.
*
Training- Excellent training provided. Training guides are always available for reference.
*
Benefits- Management is very helpful I'm helping you decide on health insurance, 401K matching, Tuition reimbursement, excellent benefits.
*
Career Advancement- They definitely look to promote from within if you put forth an honest effort. This fact alone makes them worth working for.
cons:
*
Sales Pressure- it is pretty rough here. If you can't produce you will be chastised and transferred from branch to branch until you end up in an in-store. You will be expected to hound customers to open accounts, fill out loan apps, you will be standing behind tellers trying to weasel customers to your desk to give them a solution they don't need. Retail banking, it comes with the territory
*
Pay- kind of low but not the worst.

pros: The company pays well and has a great benefits, including the bonuses that one can expect from a financial services company.  There is also a remote-friendly (telecommuting) culture in place for many jobs.
cons:
If you're a technical person that likes to move fast and solve problems, this probably isn't the place for you.  The bureaucracy is everywhere and frequently unnecessary.  It slows everything to a crawl.

Management doesn't seem to care if you get stuck doing paperwork instead of your actual job.  Often they prefer to hire a vendor to make a "quick" fix that isn't quick OR a fix.

There's a whole lot of inertia in a company this size.  As in, "that's the way we've always done it".  It doesn't matter if there are new/better/more efficient ways to do things, you'll be battling processes/groups/employees that have been in place for years doing certain things one way.

job_title: Personal Banker II – Registered in Baltimore, MD
pros: Wells Fargo is a nationwide company which provides the opportunity to transfer if you need to.   There are also a lot of positions available in different fields if you don't like your current role.
cons: Wells Fargo does not value the relatiosnhip of a customer.   They want the registered, senior bankers to focus on free checking accounts, debit cards and savings accounts.  There is no difference in compensation for the level of money you bring to the bank (i.e. $100 pays the same as $1mm).  Wells no longer values experience or ability, they only want a body in every office to sell products, not relationships.  Wachovia had a great model and the customers loved it.  Unfortunately, Wells will not approve many credit applications nor do they pay competitive interest rates.  There are no benefits to offer the customers anymore.  With no products or loans to offer, poor focus during the merger and low wages, Wells Fargo is just not a place to advance your banking career.

job_title: Customer Service Representative II in Lubbock, TX
pros: Benefits. PTO. Great co-workers. The pay is also good. The call center Is nice and clean.
cons: Sales pressure even in customer service queue.  Management literally will stand behind you telling you what to offer the customer.

review_title: I worked in several different departments
pros: I met some nice co-workers and also some not very nice co-workers. The on-site cafeteria was great in the Frederick, MD. office -- except it closed too early. You can transfer to other divisions within well fargo - but IF you are have a call center job - I feel sorry for you - you will be treated like total garbage.
cons: Wow, where should i start? It was all around the absolute WORST company I have ever worked for.  Managers are HORRIBLE overall.  If you are even 5 seconds late getting back from bread, some will walk over to your desk, slam their fist down on your desk and literally SCREAM AT YOU - "YOU ARE 5 SECONDS LATE!"  There is NO pleasing these people!  They will say and do things that are horrendous. Such as the manager I had who said he didn't like our teams number and he wanted a letter from each of us by the end of the day telling him why we thought we should keep our jobs. Everyone was a nervous wreck under this man's "Leadership"  I dreaded going to work every day - it was THAT kind of job.

review_title: Like the people, but the company is terrible.
pros: Parts of the benefits package, mainly the 401k with 6% match and option for board to increase that by 1-4% each year based on earnings but they never do more than 1%. PTO can grow rather quickly as tenure increases. Health package is at best adequate.
cons:
Constantly hear negative news about your company... hard to defend. 
Little growth or development opportunities.
Currently going through an expense safe exercise called EE2020 that is a disaster for morale.
Everything from senior management is lip service. They call team members a competitive advantage but they do not value people that way. Merit increases are low so if you don’t start with a good base salary then you will soon be looking for a new role to increase your pay. 
Disappointing that with all of the corporate tax savings the bank receives that none of it goes to the employees... instead they use it for stock buy backs and ship jobs overseas. It is probably the next negative headline for the bank.

review_title: Wells Fargo great place to work!
job_title: Technical Project Manager in Scottsdale, AZ
pros: The benefits and pay are amazing.  Where else can you get 4-5 WEEKS off immediately upon hire?  They definitely are concerned about their employees and spend the resources to ensure they are keeping up with our needs and concerns.  The network and virtualization enables me to work from home a few days a week, which helps with fuel costs and pollution.  In addition, Wells Fargo reinvests in the communities that it serves with a strong commitment.  We are regularly encouraged to volunteer and contribute to community programs and I know that Wells Fargo sponsors many of those programs financially as well.
cons: It's such a large company that we can sometimes lose sight of the customer's real needs and how we're helping them.  We often repeat functions throughout the company and follow different processes making it hard to communicate between groups.

review_title: Wells Fargo: Someday, You'll Move Up... Someday.
pros: The banking and loan options for employees are really good.  There were several good options for medical care, as well as optional dental and vision coverage.  Also, the company has pretty advanced technologies for managing customer accounts and identification, making a teller job easier than many other places.  However, this makes many elderly customers uneasy, causing complaints.  This will probably be the case in many customer-service jobs though.
cons: The management team I had was very passive and lacking in ways to motivate their employees.  Giving away prizes (e.g. baseball tickets) is great, but when management gives you insanely unrealistic goals, who cares?  The training was extensive, but many employees, myself included, get thrown to the wolves, waiting months before attending a teller class.  This is a bank, where people manage money, especially cash.  Training should be the number one priority upon hiring a teller.  This is NOT always the case at Wells Fargo.

review_title: Making your numbers honestly is difficult, Stessful, Nothing To Be Proud Of
pros:
Pay, Expectations are Clear, Job Growth, Relocation is Possible Because of the Numerous Locations

 It's  good pay if you don't have a degree, it's decent pay if you're a history major, and if you have a business degree from a good college, it's insulting.
cons:
Job Security, Benefits, Ethics, Unrealistic Expectations, Work Environment 
There's going to be a lot of stress and not the good stress that pushes you to do your best but the stress that any day you could loose your job.

review_title: I am so glad to have a job but I want a career.
pros: A stable place to work, great colleagues, and good hours.  The attendance policy is fair.  You are also allowed to earn extra funds for your medical benefit plan.  They offer great discounts on cell phone service.
cons: The salary could be a lot better.  Some of the departments have a low morale. Applying for other positions and getting an interview is very hard.  I looked around and notice people that are not even qualified in positions that you know you are qualified for.  It is 'who you know' and not 'what you know' to get ahead.

review_title: Does not do what is right for the customer...
pros: Wells Fargo pays fairly decent and the majority of the people you work with are nice. You get holidays off and a good amount of vacation time.
cons: Sales comes first no matter what! The customer could be in a situation where they should not be sold a product an you are forced to always offer something. They push sales down your throat constantly. They do customer service surveys to which if you get below a five on any of the questions you now get in trouble which some of those things are beyond your control. A very repetitive work environment.

review_title: Don't really care about people, only the money.
pros: Teach you to set goals, daily, monthly, quarterly. Train you on sales.
cons: The main focus everyday was how many "solutions" you could get. This is adding a credit card, insurance, open a new account etc. This is why they are always trying to get you to sign-up for something whenever you come in.  I quit after 6 months and even though I was number 2 in the district for sales and I quit after the quarter was finished and only the week before the bonus was supposed to be paid, I was not paid my bonus. I was a Personal Banker and enjoyed helping people and offering products that I felt would be benificial to them. I didn't like feeling I "Had" to get them to sign-up because I hadn't met my quota for the day. When I gave my 2 weeks notice they offered me higher pay to stay, so it wasn't because of my job performance that I was not paid what was owed me.

review_title: Employees & the facility at my location was not at the bar, but the senior managers and policies were decent
job_title: Business Systems Consultant in Chester, PA
pros:
In situations you  can count on the senior management to make the right decision
Great benefit packages - Five weeks of vacations
Great growth potentials:  They promote a lot of people to vice president position
Great and mature company policies
cons:
My job is busy and routine and not very interesting
Their IT system is pretty fragmented due to frequent merges, therefore added unnecessary troubles
My facility/group did not attract the employees  as good as the policies and the senior management should
The expanded facility was not at the optimal condition, the noise and shaking bothered me a lot, otherwise I'll stay there longer and give you four stars

review_title: Thought I would be there forever, turned out to be the worst experience of my life.
pros: The benefits are the only good thing this company has going for them. I started with Wachovia and it was great, after Wells Fargo took over, it became a nightmare.
cons: Everything about Wells Fargo sucks. Money is all they care about and they don't value their employees. They push sales....BAD. Even if a customer has every product we offer, you're expected to do more. I'm sorry, but I'm not going to beat people down, especially regular customers I see often, every week. I understand having sales goals, but their goals are very unrealistic and if you don't meet them, upper management beats you down. It becomes way too much and I just couldn't deal anymore. It's not a happy place to work. It's high stress and continuous pressure.

review_title: The company sets you up for success. However, the management is a toss-up.
pros: The benefits are absolutely wonderful. As a part time teller I make 11.33 an hour plus bonuses and have dental and vision that is unheard of. The company gives you all of the tools you need to succeed and really do work on advancing you through the company as long as you're putting in the effort.
cons: The management at my branch is terrible. They have very negative energy and are horrible at making you feel good about the things that you do well. They are very good at making you feel bad about small mistakes and discrediting the hard work that you do. However, the district manager is AMAZING and many of the surrounding managers that I've gotten to work with are wonderful people. I just got stuck at a branch with bitter and egotistical management.

review_title: Every single moment of your day, you will be micromanaged
job_title: Personal Banker I in San Diego, CA
pros: Good PTO , looks good on CV, Good training. If you are in college and looking for a part time job it is better to work as a teller for wells fargo rather than working for a coffee shop.
cons: Working for a wells fargo branch is no different than working for a car dealer. All they expect from you is to sell. As long as you bring good numbers you are good, if your numbers are below than expected you will be threatened with losing your job. They tell how much they care about their customers but it was not what I observed while working there. Also you can expect more drama in a wells fargo branch than a reality tv show. I also always felt that even the branches in the same market were "secretly(!)" hostile to each other. so if you are good employee expect people to observe you more carefully until they catch a mistake that they can use against you.

pros: Good work environment. Comprehensive training programs. Employees have access to all the tools they need right at their fingertips to learn whatever they want to learn.
cons:
Micro-management to the extreme.  Managers forced to lurk around corners and eavesdrop to complete daily laser forms.  
Very high pressure to produce "solutions" whether the customer needs it or not. Mgr's encourage employees to break the rules to get solutions. The "mid-session reviews" which are a good idea in theory get to be a joke. 
Required to have 4+ appointments per day on the calender...so we were encouraged to make up fake appts to fill calender. Very counterproductive.  
Virtual training is ineffective. If you go to work there, don't let them put you through virtual training (demand a classroom setting if possible) and work in a branch that is relatively new and not in a saturated market....it'll be much easier to get solutions if you are in an untapped market.

job_title: Collector 2- Home Mortgage in West Des Moines, IA
pros: They pay you a lot of money and have great benefits. Start out with 4 weeks of PTO time. You can transfer anywhere in the company. The pros out weight the cons. I have worked for wells 3 times and this place rocks.
cons: Too big to really connect with employees all the time. Big Egos with some management. Things can sometimes be micro managed. They really need to listen to the people on the front line more.

review_title: An exercise in patience and unfulfilled promises.
pros: The company is a nationwide bank which is growing still. A good place to seek employment if one is comfortable with interacting with people and demanding sales expectations based on a quantity basis more so than quality (in terms of actual profit). Very different than Wachovia.
cons: The previously stated demanding sales is not for everyone. There is a pressure to achieve referrals bordering upon nagging. My experience has been that the personality types who lend themselves to retail banking at WF tend to have poor leadership/teamwork abilities. To be fair, there are some great examples of the opposite. Overall, I would forewarn the appeal of growth within the company may not be as apparent as it is made to you.

review_title: Wells Fargo is a great employer
job_title: Applications SYSTEMS ENGINEER in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Good pay within IT - this varies for other careers, great benefits, strong career development opportunities, flexible working conditions, a commitment to diversity, some openness to new ideas and approaches, emphases in required training on ethical and sensitive customer service and on regulatory compliance, nice cubicles, convenient locations, some working from home where jobs allow it. A good employer with a few issues.
cons: The strong focus on sensitivity, while important, can morph into a subtle marginalization of outliers and does not preclude office politics. Also, as in any enterprise change takes time, which can be great for managed evolution but may not sit well with anyone craving the quicker fix. More generally, seeing the forest through countless old, tall trees can be very difficult.

pros: Health benefit, coworkers, and some customers. Your regulars really make your day better. Bonus pay out when you do meet your sales goal
cons: Impossible sales goals. I was a teller in Mansfield, tx for a couple of years in college. They trained us that gaming and illegal practice to get sales are  bad but they keep raising sales goals every year. Having high number sales goals forces people to do illegal act to meet their goals. One senior teller and banker at my bank literally commit gaming every day but management did not do anything because she was top producer in sales. I followed the rules and get put in drive through every shift. Everybody knows you hardly get sales from drive through. Fast forward to 2016, cfpb fined wf for illegal practice of employees opening checking accounts. Well, go figured. I was a teller in college but now I'm an internal auditor. I'm very familiar with frauds and regulations. You have to tell managers to implement controls to keep the company from getting in trouble with regulation agencies

job_title: HMC in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Benefits were decent.  The 401k match was very good.  I had great friendships and worked with good people for the most part
cons: Where do I start, this place is a hot mess.  I  was there over five years and watched the mortgage division self destruct. Horrible management starting from very top. Micromanaged, threatened with write ups and firing every meeting. I was a top producer but felt very disposable  Huge turnover and managers were not available  always in meetings.  Bringing in inexperienced loan officers who don't know what they are doing.  Moving things to call centers. Only mortgage company controlled by fulfillment  worthless processors and underwriters.  The pay is the worst in the industry.  They deduct everything and I worked with many loan officers with 2nd jobs

pros:
Everyone is so friendly; all of my team members have gone out of their way to make me feel welcome! 
Management always make you feel noticed/appreciated. 
They approach mistakes with a solution rather than automatically reprimanding you.
Awesome benefits (for full time AND part time!!) on top of great pay and discounts on all kinds of stuff. 
Open minded company that genuinely works toward the benefit of the customers and growth of employees rather than toward a monetary goal.
Private anonymous counseling over the phone for personal life issues, depression, anxiety, loss, trouble at work or school, etc.
Lots of paid time off!
I could go on, and on, and on. I haven't been working here long yet, but I already feel I made an excellent decision when I decided to work for this company.
cons:
So far from what I've seen/learned and heard from co workers, 

There's a little heavy reading involved. 

You will have to be focused; you're working with very sensitive information and mistakes equal legal trouble/fees.

pros: If you do not like to work, then join Wells. If you are dexterous in buttering people, then join. Free cab services.
cons:
1) new Bangalore building is bad. You would feel as if you are working in open dining area. 
2) Recognition and hikes are negligible. It is not performance oriented but how well you can butter the manager. 
3) conservative bank, no career growth, no new technology learning
4) very unprofessional managers. They bad mouth team members they don't like to other team members. 
5) there is no transparency between US team and indian team. Indian team slogs while US team goes for long walks, doctor appointments etc.
6) Telegu biased managers. Hyderabad team gets more preference. Sometimes meeting happens in Telegu. 
7) no team lunches, no activities inside the team. Most of all no acknowledgement of your hard work (you can forget about appreciation) if you don't butter people up.

review_title: There's an air of change and not for the better
pros:
Fortune 500 company 
Fellow coworkers who care about the company and are hardworking
cons:
Leadership and management that expects you to work 24/7...a just get it done attitude or leave if you're unhappy. (I left because I was unhappy!)
Ever since the housing crisis, the company is looking for metrics on everything. Every department seems to have to have something quantitative to report to management who then reports it to leadership. It doesn't matter if it makes sense or not or if the numbers mean anything - they just need a number.
No entry level job openings.

review_title: If you are a sheep, this is the perfect job for you
pros: If you are willing to work very hard, play the sales game and not rock the boat, you will be fairly compensated and praised.  The pay is steady, the benefits are nice and the security of the job is there for you.  If you are a sheep, don't like to think for yourself and are willing to play the game just as the man wants you to play it, you will do very well indeed.
cons: If you are an original thinker or one who questions authority, this is not the place for you.  It's a very political environment.  It's an environment dedicated to sales under the guise of customer service.  This is true for all banks, not just this one.

review_title: Don't do it, don't do it, and... don't do it
pros: You get benefits after a certain amount of time, plus the ability to earn money at the end of every quarter based on sales
cons: Sales goals are unrealistic for both tellers and bankers.  Always aiming sky high, which means a never ending roller coaster of praise and disappointment.  Company doesn't believe in the "law of averages", where you're just going to have bad days.  You're expected to reach your goals, no matter what kind of traffic comes in the door, even if you're a slow branch.  It's great for bankers if you're in a high traffic area, since you're get a terrific payout and job advancement.  If you're in a slower location, GOOD LUCK.  Branches are a revolving door of tellers and bankers.  In 18 months, there were 16 people that left... all from quitting, none from advancement.

review_title: The only measure of your competence is your row on an Excel spreadsheet.
job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Charlotte, NC
pros: Nice facility at CIC. Very good benefits. Name of company carries weight and is viewed as respectable. Best simulation of the movie Office Space in town!
cons: You're expendable and it is well known across the site. Extremely low moral and general feeling of despair. Incredibly disorganized. Terribly communication.

job_title: Inbound Sales Specialist in Charlotte, NC
pros: Positive Fun Culture, Customer-Centric, Training, Opportunity, Personal Financial Health Education, 401k Matching. The positives definitely outweigh the negatives.
cons: Working for a company's sales department that is constantly in the news for sales practice scandals. The contact centers are completely reformed and have a focus on relationship management instead of sales. However,  the news outlets make Wells Fargo seem like Public Enemy #1, and it is hard to admit who you work for when there is negative press on a monthly basis. Also, I started right before the big sales practices scandal broke and Wells Fargo is taking a very long time to figure out how sales commission is going to work since they no longer evaluate sales metrics. So pay has not been very competitive without it but it should be improving mid 2018.

review_title: Good company to work for however you are underpaid and hard to move up after the lawsuits
job_title: Licensed Personal Banker II in McLean, VA
pros: Good benefits, health, vision, dental and life insurance. Also short and long term disability. Legal insurance. If you have a good manager life is so easy and as long as you do what you are supposed to do you will have no problem.
cons:
In almost 6 years I have worked under 6 different managers, 2 of them were fired. Every time you have a new manager you have to start all over by proving yourself to the new manager to get promoted. 
Hard to get out of retail banking once you are there and if you do well, they’ll milk you. 
Sometimes, some of the employees have no common sense, makes you wonder how they got hired 
Low bonuses and your bonus depends on the overall preference of the team, so if %90 of the team does well and the %10 doesn’t then everyone’s pay takes a hit

job_title: Bank Teller in San Diego, CA
pros: They give you the opportunity to work a lot of hours and weekends if you'd like. The salary is competitive. They teach you how to do your job well and if ever there are concerns you are able to ask questions.
cons: They do not care if you want to grow with the company, its all about numbers, and when your manager sees you're doing great at numbers they most likely will want you to stay in that position. They make it seem like its ok to take your allotted time off but then take it out on you in your schedule when you return. The managers do not seem experienced emotionally, someone may have been in their position for years but it doesn't mean they are mature enough to handle that position.

review_title: Overall, very intense, as you adhered to policy completely (with changes frequently)& adapt to changes you will be fine
pros: Unlimited overtime if that is what you want. My dept. Mandatory overtime, which can lead to bigger bonuses if you are a perfectionist in your job. Decent benefits. Hours somewhat flexible.
cons: Sometimes mandatory overtime can reak havoc on your family life. Promotions were all political, so the job postings were all an excercise in futility. If you were really good at your job, you were not promoted, if there was a race of a gender that needed to be filled, of course that was looked upon first. Rules changed like the wind, just depened who you were or who you knew.

review_title: Fun environment for those attending college
job_title: Teller/Lead Teller in San Diego, CA
pros:
