Good benefits. For the most part, very collaborative. Flexible hours for tellers/lead tellers. Great growth opportunity if you want to stay with the company! I made a lot of good friends while working at Wells Fargo and also learned to handle my finances. 

The company does provide great tools for those who want to grow and succeed with them.
cons:
VERY VERY UNETHICAL BANKERS. They will do whatever to close the sale. Why would an 80 year old who barely speaks any English be sold on a Credit Card!? The managers usually pretend to not see these thins and allow for unethical practices. 

The sales pressure is horrible. The managers will make you (at least they did while I was there) bring in accounts from your friends and family quite often. 

There is a lot of office romance, drama, and "high-school" issues going around (i worked in multiple branches) . Do not be surprised if an Assistant manager is trying to sleep with a teller that is 5+ years younger or if 2 bankers are hooking up when they are both married.

pros: Good hours, good bonuses, good potential to grow within the company.
cons: Your performance is not based off of what you are actually doing. Your performance is based off of random customer surveys. This is based off of what the customer perceives/feels during their transaction. Because, as a teller, you're the face of the company. If something that is going on that the customer is upset about, even if it's not your fault, and you can't control it, they will blame you. Which, this is the same in any company. However, if this customer gets surveyed, you can bet anything they will give you a poor rating, regardless of your excellent service. If this happens, you are reprimanded/punished. This happens even when you don't get a perfect score, (say you get a couple 4s instead of 5s).

pros: Ability to see and learn many products, support while learning is ok, benefits are great! Ability to make good connections.
cons:
Want a promotion? Better be one of mgmts " yes men" and favorites. 90% of the time they promote only friends. 

Want a raise? Get a 4 or higher on your annual review, that should get you .25 an hour more. 

Working towards a new certification and you earn it? Great! Be ready for influx of work with little support and no pay increase. 

Team members bullying each other is standard practice. 

 No perks for senior team members vs newer team members 

Have a issue that needs to be addressed? Don't go to mgmt- they will twist it on you. 

Favoritism runs rampant

Long work hours, high stress environment

review_title: boy did I get suckered into this one!
job_title: Personal Banker I in Irving, TX
pros: Salary comes with the job, fairly decent fall back for sales folks
cons: Focus is on number of products, not what is right - I understand sales goals, but don't ask me what I am doing every second of the day just because it is the first day of the quarter.  YES I know sales is my job, goodness knows I need the paycheck, let me get my sea legs before you make me feel like I am walking the plank!

review_title: Smart people in a mature industry
pros: Sharp, hard working team members; conservative bank which has served them well over the past few years, a lot of different areas which provide opportunities to learn, people who sincerely want to do right by the customer and who deliver their best effort.
cons: Very bureaucratic, death by meetings, very complex, highly matrixed business model - often not very effective. So much effort is put into meetings, powerpoint decks, buy-in (from an ever-expanding group of stakeholders) etc., it's a shame to see such talent wasted. Understandable that an organization of it's size and regulatory visibility needs to move cautiously, but like many big companies it takes forever to implement any meaningful change.

review_title: Perfect job for business students in college
pros: Depending on your service manager as a teller, it is very easy to balance a work schedule with your school schedule.  You are recognized for your accomplishments and rewarded by bonuses which is great for people who really know how to sell and give good customer service.  You always know what is expected of you and what the goals are on a daily basis which eliminates any confusion on what needs to be done on that particular day.
cons: The sales goal has continually grown each year by nearly 20% which is very reflective on what the bank is trying to accomplish in the fact that they want as many accounts and relationships as possible at almost any cost.  You are constantly pressured to hit sales numbers throughout the day by your managers which is reflective usually on your district manager who in turn will feel the heat by his superiors.

review_title: As up and down as it gets.
job_title: Personal Banker in Rock Hill, SC
pros: Steady paycheck thats pretty high for an entry-level sales job. typical 9-5 job, you know your hours and you know what your getting into. Excellent backroom support so you don't feel like an idiot in front of your customer. It's a company where people are given great opportunity to move, aside from if your a teller, its a little tougher to move up from there. something I noticed.
cons: They treat you by the way your numbers look. If your numbers are poor then your treated pretty poorly. If your numbers are good then you get treated really well. Commission pay and structure really is pretty poor. I was formerly wachovia. Wachovia is great because they care for the customer. Wells Fargo cares for the company only. They draw a fine line between what's ethical and what's not. I had a harder time selling Wells fargo bc I didn't believe in their product and benefit to the customer as much.

job_title: Registered Investment Sales Representative in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Very competitive salary and benefits
Excellent customer service 
High ratings by our clients
Community service and volunteering available
cons:
Diversity is poor, as a minority with MBA I didn't receive growth opportunities 
Top Management may support diversity but the message gets lost by middle management
Extended working hours shifts bid quarterly base on production stack doesn't offer a good life-working balance
Against international Business, there is not appetite for global business.  Recently divested from Latin America operations, a lot of inefficiencies servicing international clients.  Very bad experience finding a position to replace my role supporting our International Business Development

review_title: Terrible, worked there almost a decade definitely going downhill- FAST
pros: Benefits package would be the  best reason to work here. If you are making minimum wage they start tellers at 10$ per hour with benefits if you work a minimum of 17 hours a week.
cons: Do not care about their people- they preach "PACA" people as a competitive advantage but certainly do not live this motto. Career opportunity is horrid, can be the top performer in a region for years and is not enough for promotions, have to threaten to quit to get a raise to what they are hiring people at your job currently. Yearly raise is usually pennies for all employees non-management. District and Regional leadership are on conference calls and meetings so often they have lost complete touch of the in branch experience and customer experience. This company has still not released its list of foreclosures to the public in lieu of losing stock value.

review_title: If you want experience this is a great place but don't expect to make a mint.
job_title: Licensed Personal Banker in Brandon, FL
pros: Good benefits, great people (most of the time), lots of vacation time.
cons: Pay is HORRIBLE, Bonuses are basically non-existent and they are quarterly. You can go to Chase make similar pay but get paid monthly bonuses that will range 1-2k plus. or you can go to 5/3rd and make great salary and a bit of a bonus but either way both are better than Wells Fargo. Not sure if "Jump into Jan" is still on but sooooo much shady stuff happens when employees are basically forced to hussle family into opening accts even though they may have banked somewhere for 30 years. Do you really think they will use the Wells Fargo account? Also your only as good as yesterday. You can meet your goal for the month in 2 weeks and they still bust on you for more.

review_title: Person Banker Position has almost a 90% turn over in my region due to unrealistic sales goals.
pros: Great benefits and profitable company
cons: If you work in a sales position especially in retail you must perform in the top 10% to keep your job.

pros: Great company overall.  Been with Wells Fargo over 10 years, planning to stay for the duration.  Past experience with other large financial institutions such as BofA, Chase, Edward Jones...etc... WF comes on top for me.   However, experience with Wells Fargo varies drastically between business lines...  So, choose wisely!
cons: Sales culture is exactly what you would expect in a successful company...that is not the issue...  too many individuals placed in mid/senior level positions have driven parts of the sales groups to the ground with poor leadership.  Specifically, many mid/senior level managers seem to draw inspiration from the movie  "boiler room"

job_title: Personal Banker I in Washington, DC
pros: I worked for The bank when it was still pre-merger and was Wachovia. Then on Managers were motivational, lead by example and were good mentors. despite the challenge of the job it created a positive vibe in the workplace which resulted to efficiency.
cons: I believe when it became Wells Fargo the bar was set higher sending the new store managers to breath under their own team's neck. The micromanagement was terrible. I saw my co-employees fall out one by one. the air around the store was just not ideal anymore coupled with the stress of the job. customers who had relationships with older employees were pissed to see they had to deal with new ones again. Relationship banking was not their forte.

review_title: My experience at Wells Fargo has helped me grow and begin to pursue my career.
pros: Wells Fargo offers a family oriented work environment through the employees. It is nice to know that when I show up to work, people care about me and care what is going on in my life. I think that Wells Fargo has a very thorough training process and it helped me gain the knowledge I needed for everyday work. Without the company values this company would not be the same company it is today. Wells Fargo stays true to their word and I believe that is what makes them so successful.
cons: Some challenges of working at Wells Fargo would be meeting daily/weekly/quarterly goals. I think that it can be tough if you have a bad day of sales to bounce back but at the same time the next day could be 100 times better then the previous day.

pros: I think its pretty clear what the company expects of you and theirs really not much to the customer service as long as you have some common sense. Also for the amount we get paid to deal with simple issues is a good start with bonuses and pay increases every so often. Being proud to say you work for a reputable company. The individuals we work with are great people!
cons: No mater the pay you might get irritated, its still a job that requires a little more effort at times the pressure trickles down to certain individuals. I don't see my position moving up.Also management sometimes acts like they care about their teams however the feeling of  being on a team has disappeared. I would say their is a lack of moral threw the team members. Oh also everyone complaints about the Wells Fargo 10 pounds so stay fit people!!

pros: Benefits, my team, and the people.
cons: Leadership: you either have a great leader or a horrible one. Over my 11+ years I had over 11 leaders. There were only 3 who truly cared for their people and not just the bottom line or their incentive and bonus. My most recent manager decided after 11+ years of being a high performer she wasn’t going to pay my bonus. This is in line with why I left. It was clear she had something against me and retaliated by pulling the bonus out of the system.

pros:
- Vast amount of career development opportunities due to the number of businesses.
- Good place to start your career and learn financial services inside and out. 
- Positive change happening inside the organization to create a better bank for the future.
cons:
- Worked in several lines of business within Wealth and Asset Management. Culture was toxic in every office. Coworkers, managers, directors all looking to move jobs (internally/externally) which destroyed the morale of my teams. Was very difficult to enjoy the workload when your leaders are focused on getting out rather than creating positive change within the business. During my 4 year tenure at the firm I’ve had 11 managers due to the high turnover. 
- Low pay; constantly trying to nickel and dime their prospective hires. 
- Very segmented businesses; makes it difficult for clients to work with us (improving, but still difficult)

review_title: Wells Fargo - A company to be proud of.
job_title: Commercial Banking Relationship Manager in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Wells Fargo invests a lot in its employees and has several structured, organized training programs, classes, etc. that help with professional development.  The overall benefits package is very competitive.  Wells Fargo is a well-run organization and it's easy to be proud to work for a company that is led by the types of people that are in senior management.  Furthermore, the company has the resources, product lines, etc. to provide virtually all the financial solutions a customer would need, which I feel gives it a competitive advantage over many other banks, which gives me little desire to work for someone else in the field I'm in.
cons: It's a very large organization, and as such, can feel like a large buearacracy at times.

review_title: Great company name with bad pay and worse local management
job_title: Loan Officer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The name is very strong and respected.  Easy to promote your business through using the branding.  Access to multiple marketing campaigns although it takes forever to get corporate approval.
cons: Pay.  While they are competitive with other banks, the 35 bps per file means you have to close $1mm plus each month in order to make a living.  Much less than the broker down the road who can make 150 bps per file easily.  Underwriting is incredibly slow!  At one point they REQUIRED 60 day locks while the rest of the open market was closing in 4 weeks.  Now I hear they are at 30-45 day minimum and the rest of the market is at about 3 weeks.  Local management seems to have been tenured and isn't looked at when production in the branches seems to be dropping.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Atlanta, GA
pros: 401k match is great at 6% .  PTO and vacation days are great. Benefits are great as well and it is easy to move up within the company because they tend to hire mostly from within.
cons: Pressure from upper management is unrealistic. You need to have two checking acct appts at a minimum per day and in the Cherokee county district 3 credit card apps per day. Also, expectation is often unrealistic and you can't just expect to work here and sit in your office or desk and expect to get sales. The compensation bonuses are like 1000 max per quarter IF you go way above your quota which the way the market is, not a lot of ppl are hitting it. As a banker, don't expect to be offered more than 15.10 an hour and that is with experience. Turnover rate is absolutely appalling.

review_title: A brand does not do the work, people do. Value the people.
job_title: Inbound Sales Specialist in El Monte, CA
pros: The prestige that comes from working at Wells Fargo. You don't have to commit to a career. Phone bank is temp to short term, no longer has a perspective of a long term career position.
cons: Those that control resources like time off the phone for development to become a well rounded banker also minimize time off the phone to put pressure and stress on some of the employees. The job is tough plus extra stress and frustration can make it difficult to achieve goals. This and other practices are Invisible to those who don't know where to look for these business practices. It takes several years working at the phone bank to see this but who lasts longer than a few months or couple of years anymore. Recruiters also pick out entry level opposed to seasoned candidates for the phone bank and branch.

pros: I loved my co-workers and working with customers. I did very well here, had repeat regular customers, and constantly had high sales in the district. However, the politics and management of this company made me want to rip my hair out and was why I ultimately left and pursued other opportunities.
cons: Unethical sales- company puts pressure to sell customers on what they (often times) don't want or need, all while job security is on the line if sales aren't enough. This resulted in frustration as we tried to provide the customer service that is right and decent, yet having to try and compromise customer service by pushing sales, often times when it isn't in the best interest of the customer.

pros: The actual work of a teller was enjoyable. Easy job, just a lot of responsibility since you're dealing with peoples' money. Most of the people I worked with were helpful, friendly, and professional--I can't say that'd be the same for every branch, but I'm sure it holds up across the board considering how much they drill professionalism into you.
cons: Tons of pressure to "sell" accounts. There was always a banker looking over your shoulder when there was a customer, and trying to see if they could upgrade their accounts. Made customers very uncomfortable. Shady, shady stuff going on on the Banker's side. Always trying to open accounts for people who did not want them, just to receive quarterly bonuses (TONS of pressure from management). This was before light was shed on Wells Fargo on the news--bad work ethics have been present for a long time.

pros: Sundays off was about the only pro
cons:
-Expect you to be sales sharks and harass customers
-Managers told employees to lie to customers to get them to open new products
-Quotas were way too high which promoted dishonest business
-Not customer oriented, company only cares about sales
-If you have a moral compass you may not want to work here
-Manager yelled at employees during meeting due to not meeting quotas which is very unprofessional
-Was personally attacked in front of employees in a meeting for disagreeing with dishonest practices
-LOW WAGES, lower than other teller positions at other banks & credit unions
-Had to stay late, come in early many times. You can't expect to just work your schedule.
-Worked over 40 hrs many weeks & still unable to make a self sustainable living

review_title: Corporate Level Roles Better Than Line of Business Roles
pros: Wells is a large company, with all of the good and bad things that go along with that status. It has many opportunities, pay range is very good, responsibilities are well defined, management is generally engaged and focused on team member satisfaction.
cons: Wells is a large organization. Things move at a glacial pace, until the glacial melt happens, then it's a rush of change, often without much apparent thought as to the downstream impacts of that change. Opportunities sometimes seem as if they are "reserved" for close friends and colleagues of those who are hiring for those positions.

review_title: Wells Fargo is not the best, but not the worst place to work.
pros: The team environment is great, and their are a lot of fantastic people who work for wells fargo.  They have detailed ways to disseminate important information throughout the company which is really important for a big organization.  The benefits package is competitive.
cons: The sales goals are horrible, you can help many people in a day (and take care of a lot of problems) but if you didn't hit your numbers you failed. I feel guilty if I leave for an hour for lunch and asking for time off that I earned (almost like I am asking a favor).

review_title: Sales Position disguised as Customer Service
job_title: Phone Banker in El Monte, CA
pros: if you want overtime there is plenty of it, health care provided but expensive, bonus are given
cons: unethical practice, the only thing that matters to this company is SALES SALES SALES!! my boss told me "your not servicing the customer if your not referring a product" wtf! we are forced to shove pricey products down the throats of these literally poor people for the expansion of this conglomerate, but they dont put it in those words, most bankers have to game every call just to make the outrageous numbers,  the bonuses are not worth all the stress of the day, not enough information is given to bankers for debit card issues, bankers on the branch level dont explain to customers the extremely structured and complex way to manage their accounts to avoid service fees, QA is stupid... i know im going on and on but i just HATE retail banking and im only doing this till i graduate in the fall....

review_title: Senior Bias, poor communication, intolerable treatment
job_title: Entry Level Teller in Deland, FL
pros: There is little to think of as fair or balanced.  I was mistreated the minute I hit the working environment.  I was senior to all employees age wise; many dirty tricks occurred.  For example, I was NOT allowed to take a restroom break for five hours.  I was Left off of employee rosters for company functions, deliberately.  Not communicated to about the way things were done, no protocol, never given a key for a my cash drawer to keep, daily I had to wait for the Service Manager to find time to give me a key.  Yet others had their's, it was a concentrated effort to force my departure.  One time the Vault was short $10K, I was not told there was a problem.  Luckily, due to a fluke it was found... long story, great ending.  Rules were selectively enforced, lies were told, and tricks played. The Lunatics were running the Asylum!
cons: See above, it was a nightmare to work there, I needed the money to pay my rent. I felt abandoned...

review_title: The Ritz-Carlt0n of Call Centers, but still a Call Center
pros: great benefits, great co-workers, newly remodeled floor for the Call Center, and management is good about monthly one-on-one meetings to discuss performance.
cons: I'm convinced that any type of Service role in a Call Center is pretty bad.  I cannot really speak for other parts of the company, but I personally hated working in the brokerage Call Center.  You have to clock out to get a drink of water or go to the bathroom and that time counts against your numbers.

job_title: Loan Verification Analyst in San Antonio, TX
pros: Company benefits and work schedule.
cons:
For all the programs they offer to build your resume, train, advance... none of them are beneficial in any relative sense. It feels more like they are checking to boxes to show they are trying. Management in my department is strife with nepotism and advancement has a ceiling. Mangers are too young and inexperienced, do not have people management skills and basically look out for themselves. I believe this comes from not hiring the best person for the position. 

Corporate level clearly is not connected to the working level of their company. The expectations and requirements serve as punitive outcomes rather than excelling. 

Raises are an insult to the real cost of living; six cents at the beginning of the year.  The maximum salary for this position is $45,000 - I am not even close to that.

review_title: Great company to work for if you're a competitive person who enjoys sales
job_title: Personal Banker I in Lincoln, NE
pros:
1. Great Benefits
2. Competitive company
3. One of America's Great Companies
4. Receive incentives for sales
5. Depending on management, Awesome!

Wells Fargo is a great company that has opportunities abound, the company is so solid I am proud to say that I work for Wells Fargo.
cons: The only con that I can think of is that people who are not competitive or strive to be the best, like myself, may not love this job as much as me. The constant talk of sales may wear on some, but if you approach it as providing solutions to your customers, like we are doing, then it's a cakewalk.

review_title: Good ideas, but lack of follow-through to fully support staff
pros: The employee benefits package was a plus, primarily because of the range of insurance choices and the company 401k  match.
cons:
The beginning of my time at WF was a wonderful experience.  It felt like the company really cared about both employees and customers.  However, the atmosphere and morale of the district where I worked declined horribly in the 5 years I was there due to major increases in sales pressure.

I've also heard repeatedly that other banks in this area pay better, which is another consideration.  And in the meantime, I saw promises of promotions and raises go unfulfilled for multiple co-workers.  Follow-through was very poor in this area.

review_title: Mostly positive, not perfect but they let you know what is expected
job_title: Internal Support Customer Service Representative in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Very organized and maybe to organized which sometimes makes it hard to locate needed information quickly. Very precise and detail in providing instructions and the work process is simple
cons: Maybe not as family friendly as Wachovia in some of the benefits offered but I do like the fact they offer HSA to everyone not just Wachovia execs. They will terminate you without hesitation for those not performing to their high standards. That is actually a pro but as employees we dont always view it that way. You will not be doing someone elses work and carrying their load. They tend to pay less then what Wachovia offered and wachovia was known to be under paying but they are fair to their employees and expect the employee to perform since they are being paid to deliver service and results

review_title: Ethically Challenging, character defining and rewarding.
pros: The best thing is the benefits and ability to promote if you work hard. My retirement plan is pretty good and ok health insurance and PTO. The pay is also decent.
cons: You compete with people who have less concern about ethically correct so you have to work harder. It is nearly impossible to be blessed enough to land in a district where the DM is ethical and respectable.  When you do- it is the best place to work! but a majority of the time you will land in someone district who cares more about their ICP then doing the right thing and it becomes very challenging- especially when you are so committed to the core values of the company as well as your own career.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in San Diego, CA
pros: Enjoyed the benefits of forming part of a great organization where there is lots of room to grow. Enjoyed the benefits (medical, dental, vision, life, etc) along with the good number of PTO and Holidays observed. The pay was good as well. Compensation was great in the time that I worked there.
cons: It is a high stress environment where sales goals are high and are expected. Jump in to January was brutal; but if you are task oriented and self motivated you will get there. You have to be very consistent in your practices and effective at you job. KNOWLEDGEABLE is the key.

job_title: Customer Service and Sales Representative in Orange, CA
pros: A-W-E-S-O-M-E benefits! 18 vacation/sick days, 6% match 401k after first year and great health insurance benefits. They pay for tuition as well for both part time and full time employees.  Lots of room to grow, many different avenues for growth.  They train really well. My manager was understanding and willing to work with my school schedule as well and he didn't micro manage either. You can bonus huge if you meet goals.  Huge emphasis on customer service.
cons: The sales goals are a bit out there, especially for branches that are only busy due to business deposits.  It felt like if the management only liked people who were meeting sales goals.  Once you started to dip, they started to like you a bit less.  Lots of call nights, I was working about 45 hours/week. I liked my manager but he was very negative and always just pointed flaws.  I think if the management was better, I would have stayed longer.

job_title: Store Manager III in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Ability to move up quickly if you do well. Most of us started off as tellers and moved up to store managers within 4-10 years of being with the bank. I started as a teller earning $11 per hour and ended as a manager with $70,000 plus compensation.
cons: No work life balance. You have to work late everyday and increasingly they want you to work Saturdays. Whenever the bank is open you are expected to be there, in addition to early morning meetings that your manager will require you to both host and attend. Your district manager will also turn over almost annually, making it difficult to build a relationship with a manager.

job_title: Phone Banker I in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Fantastic benefits and great people to work with, most of the time. Pto is nice and the 6%401k match is good too.
cons: At the call center it's very strict as far as being on the phone all the time to 'help' the customers. It would've been fantastic as long as helping was all we did, but in reality you have people grilling you every second to refer products to the customer which even that is okay, but then they say to overcome the customers objections saying well this is why it's good for you. But in the six weeks of training all they talk about is how we're here for the customers. I don't believe pushing customers for things they clearly didn't want like personal loans and things that can ruin them, and being forced to ask about them when the customers are crying in the phone is very service like. That I didn't like.

pros: Full Time Opportunity Base Pay + Commission Eligible but very low pennies for a lot of work. 30k a year job. Paid Time off. You can get promoted every year but you don't get a big raise and its virtually same position tougher sales goals but bigger commissions. Great for AA professional.
cons: Manager always micro manages you. Expects to constantly be on the phone calling and soliciting your customers regardless if customer doesn't need service. Expected to have business suites which are costly yet only getting paid about 950$ every 2 weeks after taxes. 80 hours. No overtime which sucks because it could really help employees who are willing to work harder earn more money. Very stressful job and a lot is expected but little is done to actually help you beside push there worthless products such as IRA's, Savings account, Credit Cards, and anything that helps them make more money and putting customers in risky financial positions.

job_title: Online Customer Service Representative in Concord, CA
pros: The money is very good, hours are flexible, and co workers are good.
cons: When I was originally hired for this position they advise me that they do required sales go to be met. Then, they advise me that its just a referral and that he didn't require any sales. Well, let me tell what the position actually consist of. You normally take about 80 calls per day. The calls are back to back. You are required to maintain a Low talking time which is 6 minutes. The goal is to meet at least 45 percent referral rate and 8% transfer calls to the sales department. After you take a call you must have solve the issue in a timely manner than ask if the member if you can sale something to them. If the customer agrees then you try to sale a credit or loan if you can. They rate every single detail that you do. Every single detail. They monitor you like a hawk.

pros: Decent pay & health insurance.   Opportunities to advance. Technology sometimes innovative, depending on the project. Many projects follow waterfall model with good documentation up front -- some of the best I've seen.  Romantic Old West history.
cons: More technology was glued together with chewing gum than bank would admit. Many hairbrained projects dragged on for months, years...then got deleted, wasting the lives of humans. Egomaniacal, ivory tower managers were common. In many instances, managers passed off workers' ideas as their own in order to look smart & get ahead. Many managers were political and scheming -- gotta watch your own back, and take their promises with grain of salt.  If you read the news, you know WF has been publicly caught swindling customers, which affects employee morale... If you don't want to work for a company now perceived by many as unethical, look elsewhere.

review_title: Good opportunities if you follow their framework
job_title: Strategy Consultant in New York, NY
pros: Good people, very good work-life balance with lots of community engagement opportunities, most folks stay for 5+ years
cons: The brand reputation is still "not good enough" following the scandals and employees aren't happy with their annual raises while EVP's continue to enjoy the lifestyle of $7M+ houses in California and tout "strategic alignment". Opportunities for advancement are limited and it takes a LONG time to go through the HR cycle. Many issues are based on the fact that many folks come from the small rural banks that WF bought a few decades ago. Those folks now have tenure and decision-making power, but may not have the global experience or mindset for innovation.  Initiatives take years (decades?) to complete. Some processes are very antiquated because the bank is so big. Basically you may need to drink the WF Kool-Aid to grow professionally, and that may come at a cost to your own timeline.

review_title: One of the better places I've worked
job_title: Wells Fargo Bank in Kirkland, WA
pros: Lots of paid time off, great company culture, and lots of training/coaching if you want it. Company also promotes from within and regularly checks in with you to see what your goals are with the company. Management will work with you to help reach those goals. Pretty good worklife balance, you work your 40 hours and very, very rarely overtime. Company actively doesn't want it. When on paid time off, management never reaches out in regards to work and you don't take work home if you're not management.
cons:
Likely due to past scandals, policy changes at a very rapid pace. It feels like you constantly have to check to see what the new changes are and calling the back office can give mixed results. Coaching can become overbearing if you're not used to it.

Sales goals technically eliminated, but it's still ultimately a sales job. This isn't so much a con, but different managers will have different expectations for this aspect of the job.

review_title: Relieve the stress from good bankers by letting them do what they do best
pros: close to home, fun work and great respect in the community. interesting information in the  banking business. career opportunites abound for us in victoria. communication within the local management is great. pay is fair and we know we are worth more and can probibly get more if we move to another bank but we continue to stay because the company offers a lot to us. employee morale in the victoria banks is low but varied among managers.
cons: their manditory use of customer worksheets and morale between branches is at it's worse. it's almost like you are in a reality show and competing in individual challenges and not as a team. the goals are reasonable and can be obtained if more mentoring between bankers was utilized and not forced use of the caw sheet.

review_title: Wells Fargo is an excellent workplace for IT professionals looking for a team environment.
pros:
Team atmosphere
Professionalism of teammates
Outstanding Management
Fairness
Opportunity for advancement
Good amount of PTO
Opporttunity to telecommute when appropriate
cons:
Night time deployments
Constant multitasking
Very Fast Paced Environment
Constant Change
Health Plan has changed to HSA or FSA model

review_title: While It Has It's Ups, It Has A Lot Of Downsides...
pros:
I work in the Home Equity Service part of Wells Fargo, and there are indeed some good things about it:
- friendly people
- great benefits
- plenty of opportunities to be recognized
- room for advancement (see Cons)
cons:
- tremendous sales pressure
- minimum standards are often brutal
- focus is more on sales rather than customer service
- job gets extremely repetitive after a while
- home equity is pretty darn slow compared to some other departments (note - to some, this may be a pro... get used to reading a lot of books and magazines)

All this being said, I would recommend this job, again, if you are a consummate salesman/woman.  Although it says Customer Care on the box, it is a SALES job.  Know that going in, and you'll be fine.

review_title: I do enjoy my job and position at Wells Fargo
job_title: Service Manager in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: The company has been around since the 1800's so they are definitely doing something right. The career potential is there if you put your mind and talents out there to succeed and grow. The benefits are nice with 401k (with some matching), medical (with family and domestic partnership coverages), dental, vision, and paid vacation/sick time. My particular goal is to remain in my position because I am comfortable and the job is ever-changing. I've recommended friends to work here and they've been hired...and they are also satisfied with their employment.
cons: The company is, most definitely, sales driven.  This is not something really to be viewed as a "con" per-say, however, the company boasts about being customer service oriented, however, sales is the number one priority. Where this becomes a "con" is that the pressure for sales is so high (especially in the branches) it can cause staff to do unethical practices and managers to threaten staff members with termination if some of the unrealistic goals are not met.

pros: I work as an underwriter in Charlotte, NC. People are nice, i learn a lot on the job. Good work life balance.
cons: The pay is a total joke. Making 40K after being in finance for 15 years. Basically you are on the hook for every mistake you make, government can sue you etc.... They gave us an 800 pages of binder about credit policy....Training is great, but there is so much to cover. You have to bring your own pens to work. If you want to have a coffee you better have a quarter on you, because Wells Fargo does not pay for your coffee, so we can pay our CEO 20Million. if you wanna make money look somewhere else.oh one more thing you have no 401k for a year. They even send you an 80 pages benefits description about it. Healthcare benefits are laughable, best plan has 3K deductables. Really? Yes that`s what you get. They hire people from Best Buy and Verizon with no finance background. Why did i go to college?

review_title: Unethical sales and very high pressured sales goals.
pros: Flexible hours, good dress code, happy customers, account fee structure makes it easy for customers to waive fee.
cons: Wow I have lots of cons. You are way overworked for your pay and they give you extremely high sales goals. Your manager and district manager will pressure you every morning to hit your daily solutions like you are supposed to have six to seven accounts by 10 am. You will work very hard and be promised a promotion but never get it. The bonus incentive is a joke. It's only 200-3000 per quarter and the 3000 payout is only if you are like number one in sales for the state. It's really a waste of your effort. Management is useless and not there to help you succeed. They will take customers and steal sales.  Also managers will train you to open accounts without customers permission just to hit sales numbers.

review_title: Dead end department - Home Preservation Specialist I
job_title: Home Preservation Specialist I in San Antonio, TX
pros: Benefits but that goes with any job. Great vacation time given!
cons: The standard given to the employee is to modify 14+ loans a month, this includes: goverment modifications, short sales, and deed in lieu. If no of those work then at least you a decision of no modifcation granted which counts to your decision goal monthly of 10+ loans. There are other goals to meet which go into a matrix. The training given is beyond poor, it does not help you once you are on the floor. You actually learn how to do your job on the floor (but they give you a 3 month period to learn, this job takes 1 yr to get the hang of w/out help) but you are lucky IF the tenured teammates you have on your team will provide assistance. You will work past your shift and not get paid overtime because the dept does not have the allowance for OT.

review_title: Go into a Wells Fargo Branch only if you really need a job, great coworkers but you'll hate the job like nothing else.
pros: Salary is ok, it pays the bills. Coworkers are great, friendly and supportive. Great company with potential. Room to grow if you really like sales and being somewhat of a pest with some clients to chase down business.
cons: The micromanaging, the pressure to know where you'll go and get accounts because the branch is doing poorly. They want you to shove products to clients throats when they don't need them. They make you open and close accounts for clients to get sales credit when you clearly dont have to put clients through that. Not illegal, but unethical practices to get accounts and meet sales quotas.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Irvine, CA
pros: Stable company, profit sharing in your 401K, 401K 6% match, fully vested after 3 years, they are ALWAYS hiring, their goals are attainable once you've been there about 9 months
cons: Pay is not very good if you are good in sales.  Even if you hit all of the goals and maximize your pay, it is low for the amount of work you will put in. very poor training (although it lasts a long time 1-month or more), poor management at the branch level (many are kids and have minimal knowledge of banking, finance, or lending).  Extreme micro-management and very high turnover.  I have seen many unethical "sales" in my time here, including products that were not discussed with customers, as well as outright lies about products.  They base their goals on number of accounts instead of deposits, so bankers will talk people into opening multiple un-needed accounts that they will later get fees on.

job_title: Home Preservation Specialist in Des Moines, IA
pros: It is a central hub for many different departments pertaining to Home Mortgages.  Great place to cut your teeth on the mortgage industry.  It’s always changing, and co-workers are always helpful in helping with work related questions, and insight.
cons: Work Load is unrealistic, department is shrinking as mortgage sector is resolved and less home owners need help.  Federal Government has put some unrealistic guidelines that has Wells Fargo documenting aspects of the process out of fear of litigation from the home owner, or the government themselves.  CFPB is the OSHA of the banking industry.

pros: Wells Fargo is an amazing place to work. The benefits they provide are excellent. Not only bonuses for reaching certain sales goals, but plenty others. I have an on call attorney, dental, vision, health insurance, retirement, paid time off, holidays, paid volunteer hours and much more. I have an amazing team that loves and supports one another, attainable sales goals, coaching that promotes growth personally and in business and professionalism, access to tons of financial tools to help people and myself and my family as well. Also the transferability of the job is excellent in terms of the overall credibility of working with such a company. It is easy to move up in this company and your hard work is always appreciated, celebrated and rewarded. Great place to work.
cons: If you are not use to being coached, this job will be difficult for you at first. This job has a system of constant coaching and mentoring. They have  specific way they want things to be done, and  will follow you every step of the way for you to achieve that.

review_title: Decent job, extremely hard to move within
pros:
Work life benefits are not bad you do have the support of a giant HR department in case you have an issue like scheduling days off, health benefits, HSA, 401k support, ect. 
Giant company with lots of opportunities
cons:
Very hard to move laterally. Since Wells Fargo relies heavily on Contract to hire roles for most of it's roles it makes it hard to move laterally in the company. 
Here is my breakdown on why the contract to hire model is a very very poor tool for Wells Fargo. 

1) Most Staffing agencies will ignore your resume or not work with you because that is considered poaching

2) Those same staffing companies will in turn hire outside talent that are generally not familiar with Wells Fargo software, policies, or have experience.

3) Existing employees are never given the opportunity to move laterally since the roles they want are being filled by staffing companies so they in turn get frustrated and quit.

review_title: wells fargo is a good company to work for
job_title: Customer Services Representative IV in Chandler, AZ
pros: they will pay for college, the benefits are great, i have see a big increase in my 401k. if you are unhappy with one department . im sure you can find a better department that will better suit your needs. i started in sales and ended up in the fraud department which is a non sales department.
cons: pay level isnt as high as other banks. start giving bonus to non sales departments. I dont believe just because we dont make money for the bank we should get bonuses, our fraud department saves the bank millions a year. thatshould be looked at to. if they do that i think that the turn rate would drop and employees would stay

review_title: I love being a teller, but I need to move up already!
pros: My co-workers are the best! Meeting my sales are extremly easy because I literally offer products to every customer that actually needs it, and not just to sell. If you really want to help your customer, your sales will come easy!! I have never gamed in my life, which makes me proud of my sales because I got all of them fair and square and I am usually in the top 10 of my whole region. My salary is good and they are flexiable with school. The benefits are amazing! They pay for my tuition!
cons: This only concerns my branch and maybe alot more other branches, but my manager seems to favor the lead tellers. It bugs me but not to the extent that I will make a huge deal about it. My branch won't promote anyone yet, and I am ready to move up.

pros: Good benefits and decent compensation.  The work isn't too difficult.  There is a certain amount of freedom granted (ability to prioritize and perform work how I want to, as long as the goals are met).
cons: It's just too big.  There is no way to be recognized for advancement when there is virtually no face-to-face contact with management.  The work itself can be brain-numbingly repetitive.  On this particular project we've been averaging 50-60 hours per week for over a year, and as a thank you, given a bag of jelly beans and told that we can't let up, we'll need to keep working just as hard.

review_title: Your job is as stressful as your manager makes it.
job_title: Business Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: There is opportunity for career growth if you are extremely dedicated and have exceptional people skills.   This particular position is much better than the personal banker I position.  The base salary is much better, and the quarterly bonuses are considerably better.  And the bonuses are a lot easier to hit as a Business Specialist as opposed to even a Personal Banker II position.  In my opinion this is one of the best positions within the wells fargo retail bank.
cons: Management feels like the best way to get the most out of their employees is to give them unrealistic goals in hopes that when their sales staff fall short the numbers will then meet the actual sales quotas.  Also, any position in the retail bank is hardcore sales.  What makes it most difficult is that there are daily sales quotas.  So when you have a great sales day, it is immediately forgotten the following day.

job_title: Wealth Relationship Manager in Charlotte, NC
pros: Overall good benefits for Health and Retirement.  For the most Wachovia / Weels Fargo was a good place for work / life balance.  Giving in Communities and support of employees contributing in their communities was encouraged.  Salary and Incentive Compensation was fair although demanding and could be punishing if you miss "one" piece of the puzzle.
cons: Sometimes management is so disconnected from Line Employees that they have lost touch.  Decisions are made in towers and big cities without taking a good look at frontline and differing markets.  Missing "one" piece of the incentive matrix could punish an otherwise tellar production year or quarter.

review_title: Desk job w/out opportunites to grow
pros: 40 hrs week.  tuition reimbursement. good amount of vacation/sick. benefits are ok. very structured environment with very casual work attire standards.
cons: Way too many managers and most w/out skills to manage effectively. Almost no advancement availability-mostly latteral job transfer. They tell you that classes etc are available-in fact they make a big show of it-then you cannot get the time off your duties to take them and you are only allowed to take the class during your work schedule. Favourites of the management are well known. Policies and procedures subject to change daily-without notification except when you are told that you are wrong. Overall a very hard place to work. Lots of employee disengagement. Very big corporate environment. Employees are often left feeling like they are only #s in a cubile and fed only corporate bs.

review_title: It's great if you are driven!  It's not if you are a follower.
job_title: Premier Banker in Los Angeles, CA
pros: This company will give you everything that you want if you are good.  This is not a job for the weak at heart.  You have to be able to do whats best for both customer and company.  Sometimes Management will guide you to focus on driving measurable business to meet their goals.  Do them a favor and meet those goals and you will be loved!  If you are driven, ethical and have strong relationship management skills, then the possibilities are endless.  The name is great so when people come see you, it's for a reason.
cons: Managers of different stores are all somewhat different.  Some focus on measurable statistics that are instant i.e. solutions.  If your not getting them, then you are coached.  Sometimes managers will turn the other way while business takes place.  Brokerage is scattered with other wirehouses/RIA's having a competitive advantage.

review_title: Company is only worried about gouging and profiteering!!
pros: Got to learn first hand how banks really operate and after I did I got to tell them I quit.
cons:
- All this company is worried about is confusing people so they can collect fees.
(good example - Oh you need to open two checking accounts and two savings accounts because one will be your everyday group of accounts and the other group will protect you from fraud. In reality they know you will never use the accounts properly and this will allow them to charge you all kinds of fees).
- Be prepared to be a part time telemarketer.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Charlotte, NC
pros: It is a good company. Good benefits and there is a lot of room to move to a new job or move to a leadership position. My manager and team lead were great. They were very supportive, and I believe I got lucky with my manager. Pay is good.

pros: Its a good company and I enjoyed working here until 2017 .Good medical benefits. Salary was good too.
cons: After 2017  the work conditions were org changes and working conditions were really stressful.Managers expectations are not documented and they don't have any bar to measure your performance.However they only makeup their mind as to what would satisfy them as you being a good performing employee.They fire you in a  beautiful way when they don't need you.They will put you on PIP and comment that they will help you in getting better, making you feel that they are with you and you will benefit out of it however they won't even have courtsey to give you their feedback so you can get better.I heard my senior manager saying that if manager doesn't like you they find ways to take you out.If you have zero tolerance to politics please don't join WF in today's day and time.

pros: They still have a few good people.  Used to be an amazing culture and place to work.
cons:
Scandals, bullying, downward envy and cover-ups from the top down.  Budget cuts are laying people off or squeezing the life out of those left standing.
I went there at 23 with pink hair and a clean bill of health.  I left at 35 with PTSD, Major Depressive Disorder, and a general anxiety disorder that continues to haunt me.

The company is on the being of collapse.  

I reported Disability Discrimination and Retaliation from my direct manager to her managers on 15+ occasions over 11 weeks until I finally had to undergo medical leave for severe mental health conditions.  I began reporting Retaliation began 34 weeks ago.  I opened a case with HR 21 weeks ago.  The investigation has gone on since May with no action taking other than relieve my manager of her duties.  The company refuses to take accountability for their actions.  I left specifically because of my manager’s behavior and her managers covering unit up.

pros: Good benefits and salary is competitive, that's it.
cons: You dont know true micro-management unless you've worked at Wells Fargo.  Everything we do is analyzed to death to the point that it becomes counterproductuve.  The sales process is also way too long with all of the paperwork we need to complete and the fact that we actually need approval to open each account, which is ridiculous.  Wells has taken away all of the responsibility we used to have and treats us like children.   Also, clients are becoming annoyed now that we try to sell them something every time they step into the bank.  With all of this, sales goals are absolutely absurd.  They are so astronomical that its laughable.  All the company cares about is your sales numbers, period.  They could care less about the employee, and it is very frustrating to work there anmd deal with this.  Very tough bank to work for!

review_title: WF claims they care about customers, but they only care about sales
pros: Good benefits, OK pay, somewhat flexible schedule.
cons: It's all about sales. It's more important to sell checking accounts than to balance your drawer at the end of the day. Sales goals are ridiculous, and the job title should be "Sales Representative," not "Teller." The job description when I applied was very misleading, and during my interviews I was told about certain "goals" we have, which basically are mandatory quotas. If your branch is slow, oh well, you do whatever it takes to make your numbers. I had a manager call an ex-boyfriend to see if he would open up an account to meet our checking account goal for the day. Managers also play favorites with the tellers, and if you're on their good side it doesn't matter if you don't sell to the customers. They also pay crap for what they expect of you. When I was hired the HR rep told me that they love their tellers because they are the "face of the company." For some odd reason they like to pay the face of their company $10.67/hr and the bonuses are far-fetched.

job_title: Licensed Personal Banker II/Brokerage Associate in Greenville, SC
pros: Benefits are good. Paid Time Off and Holidays are great. Helping clients with financial questions on banking, credit, investments, and insurance.
cons: This is a sales position, period. A licensed banker is expected to open a certain number and type of products every day. Very shotgun sales goals: you need everything all the time. You need to have a certain number of dials, contacts, and appointments each day. You will be micromanaged closely even if you're a top performer - there is a manager's report for everything you do/should've done. Very in the minute culture: it does not matter what you did yesterday or last week, what did you do right now? If you're driven you can try to make their incentive/bonus payouts quarterly - by that point you could probably be a financial advisor in your own office elsewhere.

pros: plenty of career development programs and room for growth.  base salary is top of the line in banking industry.

review_title: After Wachovia Merger, Wells Fargo leaders screw over employees
job_title: Business Banking Sales in Shoreview, MN
pros: Health Insurance, friendly collegues, 1 month off out of 11 months

They recruit talent and pay them well, then cut the bonuses.  The pressure was unhealthy.   I lost my respect for them.  I spoke highly of them.  They are ruining the lives of many hard working people that want to support their families.  It seems like they care more about shareholders than employees.  They implemented a customer satisfaction survey.  IF you got 4 4 4 4 4 out of 5 5 5 5 5 they consider that a failed call and took your whole quarterly bonus.  They call it KDM  scoring.  I call that Keep Da Money.   Greed is killing our society

pros: Very good pay! Friendly team members! My service manager sucked, but the store manager was awesome! Great benefits.
cons: Crazy sale goals ! It felt like I had to harrass every person that walked through the door! They wanted us to click the green button with every customer and talked to them about what they don't have even if they already bank with us! review_title: Well Run - but not for super stars

review_title: Wonderful, Helpful Employee Environment Throughout WF

I really wish that I  could return and work there again.

review_title: Behind the curtain is a real mess

review_title: Good bank, good people, trying earnestly to regain its tarnished reputation
job_title: Senior Vice President in San Francisco, CA
pros: Right after the financial crisis of 2008, Wells Fargo was considered "the best" of the big banks, with its reputation and customer service seen as better than its key competitors. In 2016 unfortunately, there were negative sales practices that came to light; this had a significant negative impact on the bank's reputation, its team members, and its business. Because of this, the bank has really tried to do an extensive audit of its practices, incorporate all necessary controls, and make customers whole. These actions continue until today, so most of the bank's initiatives are still geared toward's fixing what is wrong. The company has struggled with costs, process improvement, driving consumer growth, and corresponding lack of morale among its employees. I think the company's core is good, and is sincerely trying to improve. It has, and will take more time for it to regain a positive reputation among customers.
cons: It will take time to win back customers' trust. Most of the initiatives are not around marketing but risk mitigation and process controls

review_title: No flexability and room to grow..
job_title: Senior Business Banking Specialist in Atlanta, GA

Your direct manager will say to business leaders what they want to hear but will restrict you from doing what you were hired to do.

Not clear on incentive payouts. Continuing to change payout structure and not sharing what numbers are above average, average, below average.

review_title: Merchant Services is poorly managed.  Stay away if you know what's good for you.

review_title: Wells Fargo training grounds for the used car salesman

review_title: Okay job if you can stick it out
pros: Plenty of room for advancement and is known for their training. If you want to leave and go to another bank, having Wells Fargo on your resume looks very good. Benefits are pretty good. cons: The selling environment is almost predatory on customers. I have seen several people come in with multiple checking accounts and savings accounts where they were being charged monthly fees. Also, the selling environment is very intense especially for tellers. They put a lot of pressure on you to hit and exceed quarterly goals. review_title: The Good, The Bad, and the Ugly

cons: Sales goals are fairly difficult depending on store. Management wants you to rush people out the door if it's not a sale. treat them like cattle

review_title: Great potential for growth. Stick and no carrot retail culture.

review_title: Field Leadership struggles to live the Vision and Values on the Retail side.

The gap between the Wells Fargo that non-retail employees experience and the one that retail employees experience.  
Micro-management and endless conference calls.  There are conference calls about the conference calls that we are going to have after we have our conference calls... It is ridiculous.
The Pay is a joke.  They are paying peanuts compared to the job expectations.

review_title: Lotsa praise,  lotsa trinkets, low pay

Wells Fargo really does care about your training while you are being introduced into the banking world, they have one of the most comprehensive and extensive training courses you can find all crammed into a few weeks. They also really focus on customer interaction, if you enjoy working on a face to face interaction with customers daily this will be a good fit for you.
If you are good with sales you can expect to be recommended for a banker position after a year as a teller (or less if you are really good at sales)
cons: Wells Fargo places a great deal of focus on reaching sales goals and making quarter deadlines. At times I felt that they placed unneeded accounts on individuals merely to make a sale.

pros: Pay is OK. It really is a Hit or Miss with the people you end up working with.
cons: Hard to move up. This is a company based on who you know instead of what you know, your contributions to the company do not help, and they don't promote promotions within the Branch. I believe you shouldn't have to consistently interview if your trying to move/transfer to another branch or If your trying to move up within your Branch, only if it is a completely differnt job title your trying to take on should you have to interview.  Like I said, it's a who's who that takes you further than your abilities that you have shown to Leadership. Sales as well, they just keep changing the name of the game but it's still SALES and Conversation Starters. All. The. Time.

pros: There is not a single pro about this company everything is horrible.
cons: Not being able to start the position I was hired to do due to Wells Fargo rescinding the position at the very last second of the start date.

review_title: Pay is ok, but don't expect any appreciation!
pros: For the most part the group I work in is very team oriented. Of all the managers in my department I do have the best one. There have been a lot of upgrades and automations and management has worked hard to keep every position on the floor and ensured that no one was laid off.
cons: Absolutely NO recognition for anything. Management believes it’s up to your co-workers to acknowledge and reward your hard work instead of them, which makes for low morale. In my department there is a lot of favoritism by the managers and they make it extremely obvious. Upper management is extremely unapproachable. I once got in trouble for asking for help and quickly found out that the "open door" policy was quickly shut on me. There is a lot of office politics.

review_title: Great position for college-students or people who love sales!
job_title: Customer Service Representative III in San Bernardino, CA
pros: The best reasons to work for Wells Fargo Home Mortgage as an inbound customer service representative include: flexible scheduling, great benefits, great hours including weekends off or some Saturday morning work, a team-oriented environment.
cons: Working in a call-center environment is certainly not just for anyone; it is very demanding and can be quite stressful.  Employees are expected to perform at standards that are barely attainable, and the company tends to value sales over service.  Some employees seemed to move up too quickly because of networking and personal connections while others were left at lower level positions for years.  The turnover rate was enormous, and there were always new faces in the office.  Certain employees seem exempt from performance expectations based on personal connections within the office.

review_title: good benefits; don't have to work too hard.
job_title: Web Developer in San Francisco, CA
pros: The company has very good benefits, competitive compensation and stability.  Many people choose to retire here.  I was given regular promotions, though did find it hard to for to find the 'next step' when wanting to make a career jump to management.   My first manager there was great, but when he left, my department went downhill.   So, it really depends on the department/management whether you will have a good or bad experience.
cons: I was in technology, but the main business is banking therefore, it was not so cutting edge for a technology professional.  Due to this, the dot commers were making much more money, but we had the job stability which was a tradeoff.  In addition, many times your employees were not the brightest or 'A' gamers.   Mediocrity rules the roost there which is good because then it was relatively easy to be a star.

review_title: What you say can and will be used against you
pros:
They offer good benefits
You can gain experience in banking and sales.  If you are good at sales, they will like you.
If you like or need structure, this may work for you.
cons: Focus on numbers and quotas, not best interest of customer.  Very sales driven, quota wins over integrity every time.   In general, employees are not very broadly educated.  Seem to promote those who say yes and terminate those who question authority or rules that don't make sense to follow.  Everything is repeated to leadership as information is power .  Oddly enough, non professional behavior by leadership is ignored, even when harassment is evident.

review_title: Great way to get through college.
pros:
Good compensation for sales performance once you reach a certain threshold for sales numbers.
Tuition reimbursement if you do not have grants or scholarships.
cons:
If you cannot make the sales, life can be extremely stressful. 
Wells Fargo is also a little more aggressive with their hours of operation, do not expect regular banking days - you will be open when other banks are closed.

review_title: It has been an overall bad experience that has strengthened my resolve to go back to school and enhance my education .
job_title: Register Personal Banker in Spring, TX
pros: Good Benefits.  Great Technology. Thats about it.
cons: Poor internal support. Very punitive environment to work in with constant micro management and unfair treatment and expectation towards bankers. Not only is there no work life balance, but I am just not certain that this company (at least the retail side) has ever heard of such a concept. They support an environment that harbors negativity by being condescending and downright disrespectful to bankers and don't even think about asking for time off. Its like pulling teeth. Incidentally, managers take all the time off they want and a certain manager is always leaving the branch to go attend to her personal business and disappears for about 2 hrs often.

pros: Rarely will you find yourself working more than 40 hours . Able to visit nearby business to recruit accounts for  commission while being paid for your salary.
cons: It is nearly impossible to make commission. You are not given any power. For example, you need to ask for permission to open checking account, savings accounts or any other accounts . You must see your manager to get these items in which he then question you about the whole conversation you had with the client to make sure "no sales opportunities were missed". You are required to fill out a form about the client, which is not a quick process, and you are rated by how much of the form you fill out and for how many people. As for growth opportunity , As a Personal Banker 1 you need to work your butt off , and still not make commission, to be picked by the a higher executive to choose to pay to get your series 55 and 57 to get promoted to personal banker 2 for about five thousand extra dollars . Oh I forgot the best part , people don't trust banks nowadays so of course your going to have a facade of rude customers!

review_title: Love the work, hate the coworkers
pros: Great company, pay is decent, they hire entry level. I love how quickly you can advance within the company. You're always growing into new, better positions, and pay gets better and better as you go up in the ranks. I was hired in one state but had to move to another due to a family emergency, and went through the whole hiring process in the next state... I was hired in both states within a 2-week window, so their hiring process can be SUPER quick.
cons: They hire entry level, LOTS of gossip and drama with little done by management. Some district managers act like if you're a teller, you're the bottom of the food chain and they want nothing to do with you. A different district manager was planning when we'd go out for a girls day together during my interview with her.

pros: Great room for advancement. If you are great with customers and love to sale, you will do great. If you don't have customer services skills and don't like to sale, don't waste your time. This company is a great company to work for but they are sales and customer orientated.
cons: Depending on the district you may be placed, you may have an amazing management staff or the worst. If you don't meet your sales goals (may I say they are ridiculous, how many accounts can someone really open?) you will be placed on a warning and quickly pushed out.

review_title: Cronyism and sexism at the top; notes from the glass ceiling will be my book about my experience
pros: Great culture of customer service, leadership development. So close and yet so far. Cracks in the glass ceiling but no real breakthroughs.  Women who support and promote other women are not in leadership roles.
cons: Hypocrisy regarding opportunities for women at the top.  I felt seriously discriminated against at the most senior levels of the company. The Minnesota old boys network trumped equality of opportunity for women. I was young and believe that good work and fairness would result in opportunity.  I learned a lot about sexism and betrayal at this company. I hope that my nieces will not have to experience similar work environments in their lifetimes.

job_title: Branch Manager II in Atlanta, GA
pros: Clients are great. Gain valuable experience. You can use this experience to get a similar job at another financial institution because they know you can sell products.
cons: Its a miserable existence having to sell unneeded products to customers just so you won't be told you are horrid at your job. The conference calls are a job. 3 a day not counting the one off credit, affluent, or small business call. You don't have time to do your job. Leadership is clueless and they hide behind the "Vision and Values" claiming that they want us to sell so much to help our clients. The first week of each month you have to do 150-200% to plan and they call it quick start. This breeds cheating and holding back products, but the leadership is ok with it unless you get caught.

review_title: Goal-driven sometimes fun place to work
job_title: Licensed Personal Banker II in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
Good salaries
Good benefits and PTO
Strong company/brand
Lots of products to help clients with
Customers are usually friendly and like banking with WF
Decent employees (though there are always unethical people you will run into)
cons:
Daily goals are expected but they keep taking away what we get sales credit for.
They are also very much trying to be service oriented and not sales oriented but they expect you to hit your daily goals. Dichotomy. 
District Managers are tough on managers, very high expectations.
Segmentation. Certain bankers are supposed to get certain products but many of the goals are overlapping and it can create a "every man for himself" atmosphere. 
Can be cut-throat between bankers.

pros: I don't work with retail, so I can't speak for their line of business, but from my experience in Corporate Trust Services, Wells provides team members with a generous amount of paid time off from day 1. They provide two paid days for team members to volunteer for a cause of their choice. The pay is OK, but they really sweeten the deal with all of the additional benefits. If you are a hard worker, you can probably bet on steady yearly promotions.
cons: The work can be tedious and the entry level pay is too low to attract quality candidates. The beuracracy involved with promotions is also a bummer-- the minimum amount of time you must spend in a position before you can apply to new positions is 6 months, and that's only if it's approved by your manager. Otherwise, you must wait a year before applying to other positions.

pros: Local management outstanding. The products offered are among the best in the industry.
cons: The bank gets the lion's share of the perks. All other LOBs are treated like second rate citizens. FA hurdles are increased each year and the salary increases for staff are typically less than 3% annually. People coming into a position will often make more than 15 year veterans. High turnover in operations causes issues with the quality and consistency of back office support. Cutbacks at the branch levels increase workload on an already reduced staff. They offer limited medical benefits, with high deductible HRA/HSA plans only offered in my area. We pay $5700 out of pocket before anything is paid. Opportunities for advancement are minimal unless you're near St. Louis.

review_title: Said differently, Done differently, Written differently !
pros: middle managers  write memos and attend conference calls
cons: a dress code from the 80’s

review_title: Wells Fargo:  A great place to bank, a better place to work
pros: I like the fact that Wells Fargo is very innovative in products and services to offer their customers and the Vision and Values that has been adopted for both the customers and team members.  The upper management that i have had the opportunity to work for within Wells Fargo, allows the Store Managers to run their "store" or banking center in a way that they would run their own business.  The good side to that is if you have an effective manager it works and of course the opposite holds true.  This says so much about the opportunity to learn and grow with such an awesome company.
cons: The goals for the stores should be based on the current market they serve and not just an increase of the previous year.  If you work here, you'll understand what I mean!

pros:
I get 20 days off
I met some friends at work
I like riding BART to work
My job is pretty good and easy
I get free coffey
I have my own cubicle
I love San Francsico
I can watch the internet at work
I get paid every other Friday ($794.31)
My girlfriend got me my job, her dad is a banker
cons:
My boss yells at us a lot and makes us feel bad
The company is too nit picky
The company seems to hire a lot of people that are not good fits
A lot of people can't get along with each other and Wells Fargo seems to promote that.  
Wells Fargo pays the lowest salary of any company in the Bay Area
I am a stellar performer and only got 2% raise
Wells Fargo management gets bonuses and doesn't share with workers
Wells Fargo makes all workers volunteer and give money to charities and takes credit and tax breaks.  
Wells Fargo got big bailout and never paid it back

review_title: Expectations for Success can compromise quality of service.
pros: Great medical and other benefits. The people I worked with on the branch level were great and very supportive in a high pressure environment.
cons: High pressure for numbers.  Management constantly states mission and values of Wells Fargo and then demands high numbers which are very difficult to achieve in certain markets.  It seems like upper management can justify their actions with "do what's best for the customer" and then pressure you for high numbers which means pushing customers towards products that might not necessarily need or benefit from.

pros: Wells Fargo is a company that demands a lot from their employees, but gives back even more to those who are willing to grow and succeed. There is a very strong sales culture but it goes hand in hand with an emphasis on doing what is right for the customer. Most new employees let fear of sales get in the way of that and do not succeed at first. A poor attitude and weak performance are a quick way to get "promoted to customer. " However, a willingness to try new things and grow has seen many of us promoted multiple times a year for several years.
cons: The teller and banker positions are used to test what someone is made of. They are typically a stepping stone and the key is getting promoted to a more specialized role as soon as you can. Lean on management to prepare you as it can be hard to hit your sales numbers when you are new.

review_title: The best co-workers. The worst job.
job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Montreal, QC
pros:
The schedule is your average 9-5 with short hours on saturdays (alternating)
The customers are great.
The employees make coming to work bearable.
cons:
Sometimes painfully slow.

Always calling customers for sales (Cold calls are common)

SALES pressure is insanity. They will make you sell checking and savings accounts, credit cards, lines of credit, home equity... etc Regardless of need, want, or AGE.

If the customer shows and slight interest, and the manager is desperate, the product will be pushed and made to be opened. This company does not have its customers best interest at heart. They are hungry for numbers.

Will make you stay late several times a week if branch goals are not met.

Upper management.

Customers get fed up with sales calls.

Customers feel afraid to come into the branch for fear of being bombarded by "sales people"
aka Personal Bankers.

Extremely stressful if you work in slow branch with high goals.

job_title: Personal Banker I in San Francisco, CA
pros: yeah, if you want a steady job 40 hrs/ week, 401k, benefits, Wells Fargo offers that here. But so does every other company in the bay area.
cons: To move ahead in your job, you have to do some shady things to upwell the customer. Things I've seen: bankers telling customers that they're signing up for a 'rewards card' and not a credit card to meet sales, forcing the customer to open both checking and savings when they verbally said no, and sending multiple debit cards. Lately  corporate has been cracking down on this, but bankers still find a way to be shady.
