Also, work environment is very much like high school politics, there's no way you're going to get promoted if they don't like you. When I worked here, management made it seem like I wouldn't find another company that could be as flexible as they were as to scheduling PTO/ or working around my schedule, and would emphasize that there were no jobs in the job market.

pros: Full-Time paid training for two weeks in a virtual classroom. Employees are fun, really down to earth and hang out a lot after work. Employees are really helpful and look out for one another like family. Company is great for sales and goal oriented people. There is great potential to advance, and Bankers are usually available to help you position a Solution that you aren't comfortable with. Base pay there starting off isn't bad either.
cons: Constant changing of schedule, even at the last minute without making sure its okay with you first. They only care about how many Solutions you got for the day, and if you clicked on that green button or not. Really stressful unless you're really sales driven. Its hard to push something on customers that you know they won't benefit from, or after its already been offered a hundred times before to them. Not really friendly schedulewise for someone going to school as well.

pros: Good Pay in comparison to other financial institutions, good first impression w/fun and relaxed training program that makes you think you will be helping people make their financial dreams come true, lot's of initial company swag
cons: Fun training program, good first impression of company.  Once you are out of training and in the real world - one might think you were hired to be a sleazy used car salesman.  Super high pressure sales, ridiculous "solutions" quotas that you are expected to meet with a "do what you have to do" mind set - If you are a Wells Fargo customer - ever wonder why you have a checking account for bills, a checking account for grocery spending, a checking account for dog food purchases, a checking account for vacation spending.  You think it's to help you budget?  Nope, it's because we needed more "solutions" for the day.  It's tough to keep up with all your account numbers and minimum balances in each account to offset the monthly service charge huh?

review_title: Overall, great company but high sales goals
job_title: Personal Banker I in Montreal, QC
pros: Great benefits, good people/coworkers, nice culture. I learned a lot of really great skills including customer service skills, multi-tasking, sales experience. But you do get bonuses every quarter, recognition for your performance, paid days off (even if part-time), and even better....tuition reimbursement!
cons: Not going to lie... the sales goals are pretty high. So, I felt as if there were high expectations of me. The environment can be intimidating for this reason. Also, I had a bad experience because of the branch/ manager I was located at. But, then I moved to a different branch and was much happier. So, I would suggest finding a branch that has a culture that fits you.

review_title: This company is great to its employees!
pros: I'm not that far into my tenure with the company, but so far it's been an amazing experience. The flexibility and time off offered makes the work-home life balance extremely easy. The environment is professional and structured well.
cons: The current distrust that most consumers have towards the company, at this time, make things difficult. Right now, there's high scrutiny from the public eye on the company as a whole which can make it hard to tell someone where I'm employed because of the recent settlement. Executives have been very open with their plans to rebuild trust amongst our consumers, but we're only at a starting point with those actions so that distrust and reaction from consumers feels unsettling.

review_title: The Advisory division is not the Bank division even though Glass door makes me choose the bank
job_title: Senior Vice President of Investments in Plano, TX
pros: Wells Fargo Advisors is a fantastic place to work as an advisor. They give us a lot of support to help our practice and take care of all the due diligence, etc so I can have faith that the investments we use have been vetted.  They have a very strong compliance division, which protects the clients, and they are strong financially, which means they don't have to take on risks.
cons: When part of such a large corporation there will always be someone who does something wrong somewhere. Unfortunately that catches the eye of the news and even though it is in a different division, people assume that it infects the whole company.

review_title: I did not believe all the bad reviews prior to working here
job_title: Phone Banker in El Monte, CA
pros:
Great Pay
Good Benefits
room for advancement
cons:
Even Though There is no more Sales.
the pressure and micro managing is still there. Supervisors and Leads breathing down your neck. Out of the 15 people i began training there only 5 are still there after only one year because they could not take it.
The Team Leads sometimes guess when they assist you. even though you get a wrong answer from a lead you will be the one to blame for giving wrong information. I though i was there to help customers, while questioning answers i was given to say to customers i was told to not try and help customers too much.
know i know why we are getting too many lawsuits and people leaving us.
i wish corporate would look into this deep down. They have really good customer service employees that are pressured to just  rush customers through calls instead of really assisting them.

job_title: WIM Retirement Services in Charlotte, NC
pros: Some nice people around the office to engage with.
cons: There’s no career movement at Wells Fargo unless you know someone. The only jobs you will have an opportunity to are going to pay you WAY WAY less than other financial institutions for that specific job. Be prepared if you seek career advancement in Wells Fargo to only be offered 1500-2500 more when taking on a NEW position...which if you don’t know that’s a horrible pay increase.  When looking at the pay for jobs Wells Fargo will NEVER pay you the high point and the hiring manager will only hire you around 80-85% of the value of the mid point. So that means you’re going to make 15-20% less than most people who do your same job at a different company. There’s a reason why the company is all over the news for bad reasons...it’s because It’s not a good company.

review_title: No work, only plain politics in CLT..dont join
pros:
Not much work
Good for Telugu people 
Good infrastructure, young crowd to pass your time
A lot of extra curricular events
cons:
Management is unprofessional and full of junk leaders and managers. Be careful about servicing team and its leader, he is worst person . Only his family and friends can grow here.
Technical people will become handicap in 2-3 years and can only think of saving their job at any cost.
There is no clear direction and no guarantee that you will work on what you are hired for.
All accolades and awards for reserved for people who act well and are manager's favorites.
Architects, SAs are namesake and no proper roles defined. 
Technology managers are super powers in India and can stoop to any level of politics to safe guard their jobs.

review_title: Lots of organisational changes happening around, no clarity regarding the changes
pros:
- Technical people/ Developers are favored in every way whether it is compensation, promotions or hikes.
- Organisation is slowly adapting Agile, so scope for people who are well-versed in Agile.
- Internal Job Postings are good if you want to change role withing org, provided you have good contacts.
cons:
- Very laid back and conservative in terms of adapting new technology and methodologies
- Roles like Business Analyst and Quality Analysts which are not so technical are not respected at all and every now and then even the managers openly say that these roles are not required.
- Hikes/ Promotions for BA and QA roles are not good.
- Unfair management, favoritism
- learning culture not there. Managers' approval required if you want to reimburse any certification cost which shouldn't be the case.
- Too much power in the hands of managers

review_title: A Choice for A Long Career:  Miles of Possibilites
pros:
Its vision and values
Its track record 
Its commitment to diversity

Because of these things,  team  members can be assured that they are working in a company where what they do really matters to the customers that they serve as well as to tthe bottom line.  Additionally, they can be confident that Wells Fargo really is committed to People as a Competitive Advantage.  

Especially in these turbulent times a company like Wells with its nearly matchless track record of performance and history combined with strong and caring leadership at the top is a great place to start a career or to continue a career.
cons:
It's a complicated structure, so collaboration skills are essential.  This is no place for lone rangers.
Expectations are high, even in difficult economic environments, so you have to stay committed to do well.

pros: Benefits package was pretty decent. The opportunity to grow is there, but it's seems that favorites play a big roll. I also watched one person that was top in sales continued to be turned down for different positions. Theory is that he is carrying the stores numbers, and store management doesn't want to lose him.
cons: Pay scale is terrible and commissions is a joke. They only pay out quarterly, which turns a top level gold payout into about 300 bucks per month. There is also a commissions cap for tellers which I also find to be a terrible idea.

pros: Upwardly mobile; they prefer their management to come up from the teller line (not upper mgmt though, they are still stamped out with an MBA from How To Wear A Business Suit University),  and they pay better than any other bank in the state, as far as base salary.
cons:
Benefits packages, the PPO is available but prohibitively expensive, so most are on and HRA or HSA plan.  
Relentless in solicitation of customers for 3rd and 4th checking accounts as well as widget products like online banking, bill pay and debit card overdraft service

review_title: Training was great then came the actual job, Sell or Die
job_title: Customer Sales and Service Representative in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Good benefits
Nice and sociable co-workers who hated their jobs but refused to leave.
Interesting clients
cons:
Inconsistent work schedule(random call nights, without being told in advance.  If you have kids or enjoy family time, not the place for you)
Jump into January (I was required to open up 20 new checking accounts on day one, I was encouraged to take new account forms to Christmas dinner to sign up family members with Lames Fargo)
Poor middle managers(managers used to pace the office if we weren't hitting our sales goals by noon, harassment by managers to be a "gold performer" or be fired, everyone customer that came to our desks were expected to sign up for another Wells Fargo product, for ex. credit card, identity theft protection, a savings or checking account)

job_title: CONSUMER LOAN UNDERWRITER in Raleigh, NC
pros: Very large company, so there are usually a larger number of job openings.
cons:
- Benefits are expensive and there are still high out of pocket expensive for services covered by insurance. 
- Incentive plans are altered all the time and not to the benefit of the employee. My incentive plan was altered and no one in my 2,000 person department has seen incentive pay since. 
- Seem not to care about employee loyalty. 
- Disorganized. No "clear" guidelines for work within departments. Everything is left to individual interpretation. 
- Want employees to work Saturdays even though there is not a large enough work load to warrant the extra day.

review_title: QA Automation Engineer Selenium...a bad place to work
job_title: QA Automation Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros: one of the worst place for a QA Selenium Automation Engineer to work for as a  contractor...!!!
cons: contractors are taken for granted and high level of micro managing exists! no work life balance and can be hard  for non-telugu speaking people to work in the automation team..!there are few telugu speaking full timers whose only aim is to make the life of contractors hell by squeezing out the best out of them ! Highly  unprofessional Team Leads and Managers who are not at all technically qualified for their role!

job_title: Loan Servicing Specialist V in Boston, MA
pros: A lot of opportunities if you are considered "in" or part of the FAP (Financial Analyst Program). If you are not part of either of these it is very tough to advance. Many jobs throughout the country which allow you to transfer / relocate if needed. Good work/ life balance
cons: As mentioned above, need to be "in" in order to go anywhere. As a member of Operations, you are treated like an idiot and looked down upon by many other areas or groups. Tough to advance from the Operations world. A lot of egos and personalities to work with. If in Operations/ a Loan Servicing Specialist you are treated as children at times ("I told you to do it so do it."

pros:
The bank has been extremely well positioned to take advantage of its size and with new leadership might finally fulfill its potential.

Allen Parker (interim CEO) seems to be doing his best and hopefully the new CEO will be able to change the culture at the bank.
cons:
Current senior management is lacking.  There is a lot of talk about "People as a Competitive Advantage", but little true follow through.  

Additionally, the hard driving sales culture still exists with leadership being all sales or former sales.  Management seem to be enamored with the sales persons skills at selling and buy in far to easily to the slick talking team members.

Additionally, I see the most truthful, honest, and dedicated people either leaving or being pushed out.

review_title: Good pay and benefits but little career growth opportunity
pros: The company offers decent salary compensation relative to the individual's position and experience.  The benefits offered are excellent and cover everything from 401K, legal services, child care, etc.
cons: Depending on the division you are in, you might find yourself stuck in neutral with your career.  Few individuals were ever promoted (and none of the IT division I was in) and little is done to encourage employees to work toward promotion.  Because it is a bank change is glacially slow and you cannot expect to utilize the latest technologies, but can expect to use far outdated technologies that will be of little benefit to you if you choose to leave.  The workplace environment is often extremely parochial and even childishly petty.  Comments and behavior are often at a high school level which you will have to either accept or withdraw from in order to survive long term.

review_title: This is a great stepping-stone position for future college business majors.
pros: This is one of the most ethical retail banks there is. They have a great company history and it's influence reaches into almost every conceivable sector of finance, i.e. retail banking, commercial banking, brokerage services, estate planning, etc...
cons: The quickest way to get promoted is not necessarily being the most knowledgeable about your line of business, but getting "solutions." This can be rather aggravating when you see someone getting a promotion because they lack any moral standards and push products onto anyone they can.

pros:
- Worked with some very professional people while there.
- Stable technical infrastructure.
- Challenging projects.
cons:
- Timelines sometimes ignored when very strong evidence to push back was presented from a Technical perspective.  Later it came back to bite.
- A clear separation between contractors and FTE's appeared after purchase of Wachovia. Contractors were sometimes placed away, other side of a room or floor, from FTE team members that they once sat beside.  Practice decreased the value of a cohesive work environment.
- 18 Month Rule: After 18th months of contracting...so long for 6 mths. They loose a lot of knowledge capital as well as critical project time to onboard and have new contractor up to speed.

pros: Great people, team members truly work together on behalf of the customer. The management team is accessible, down to earth and, for the most part, willing to listen. Team members stay for a long time, there is little movement at the staff level (but lost of turn over at the retail level).
cons: Systems can be antiquated, middle management can often be a barrier. Run it Like You Own It culture can be difficult to navigate on behalf of the customer.  Very risk averse. Not a lot of openness to new ideas, unless they are vetted for months. At the same time, open to GOOD ideas that show instant value, just difficult to get implemented. Lots of fiefdoms across the organization, can take years to build relationships that matter.

review_title: Great Vision, bad execution, rampant unethical behavior
pros: Unmatched capabilities  to provide customer solutions.  Wells Fargo has more products and service than most companies across all product groups.  Awesome vision and values that makes it easy to get behind and they embrace technology. Decent benefits although they have diminished in recent years.
cons: Vision is not embraced at the store level.  There is rampant unethical behavior even though there are serious consequences in place.  Management looks the other way most of the time.  Get your numbers however you can.  Those that speak up tend to be outsiders and are perceived as disengaged.  Partner business groups do not meet the same service standards as the retail bank and there is a poor wealth management program in place.  Only 1/10 stores has someone to talk to about investments.

pros: The PMO does a good job of allocating the proper resources for all the IT related projects. There is a team effort and very minimal need for "red tape" since all the processes are well defined.
cons: The on-boarding process was not very smooth, it took well over a month to gain all the required software and access needed to be able to actually work. There is also a slow pace at adapting to newer technologies due to legacy systems, lack of technical expertise, and the overall size of the enterprise. The former leadership from the east coast management team is lacking integrity. I had a great opportunity, but because of political "red tape" the team lead who was formerly a Wachovia employee seemed to be very self-absorbed and thought he knew everything. I was actually warned about him, needless to say I stopped the interview and left the company.

review_title: Good Place to Work... IF You Love Sales!
pros: Once you're in, the job is generally stable. There is a low turnover rate and people generally stay for a couple years. The pay is good, benefits are great. The company tries to increase employee morale through rallies, public recognition, certificates and awards, etc. Scheduling is organized. You get holidays and Sundays off and receive PTO. They prefer to promote from within, but promotions typically only come to those that are consistently good with sales.
cons: You NEED to love sales to work here. Wells Fargo will go to all lengths to get sales -- they say they're ethical but they are not. The sales goals are extremely high, to the point where it becomes unattainable. Everyone - including the branch manager at my store - lies to the customers, opens accounts over the phone, or resorts to other unethical means to reach the goals.

pros: decent pay, nice coworkers, room for advancement
cons: Decent pay because you are going to be asked to jump through many small hoops to push production limits and despite your best efforts, you will be constantly harrassed by management who is being constantly harassed by their management to harass you to produce despite the fact that customers make their own choices without really considering WF sales goals…Nice coworkers but their so stressed you really don't get to know who they really are besides someone who is looking for other employment… and their's always room for advancement because as soon as you make management you are eventually not going to make the impossible difference being requested from area management and will be forced to move on or hate your life.  13 District managers in 12 years…speaks for itself.

review_title: Service Manager - lots of pros but some significant cons as well
pros:
- Lots of opportunities for advancement. 
- Company truly cares about its customers.
- You can make lateral moves on your own accord so there is the opportunity for variety.
- Benefit packages are diverse and better than other banks.
- Good district managers.
- Opportunities to work varied hours.
- Adequate training.
cons:
- Very sales oriented.
- Advancement rate depends on manager.
- Lots of drama/office politics.
- HR cares more about protecting the company's reputation than taking care of employee issues.
- Annual pay raises are comparable to the industry standard (3%) but are still minimal. Meaningful raises only result from promotion.
- Customer service surveys only considered passing if you receive all top scores. 
- Once you become lead teller/service manager on the retail side, you sometimes work immense amounts of overtime and take your work home with you. My job at Wells Fargo consumed my entire life even when I was "off" work.

pros: Working as a Teller gave me some great leadership and customer relations skills. I was able to work with customers to ensure I met each of their needs and find ways to improve their financial services.
cons: Wells Fargo is a very heavily competitive environment that requires you to sell their products without being able to name them. For example, if I identified that a parent could setup a checking account for their teen, I would have to sell the value of the checking account to them without being able to directly say, "would you like to open a checking account for your teen." While I understood the logic behind this, I often felt that my abilities to work with a customer were limited due to the fact that I could not say the names of products. This, combined with a highly competitive environment, paved the way for a somewhat stressful work environment.

pros: The benefits are like no other in time off and medical and all they offer. There are discounts for everything. The pay is good. There are branches everywhere so you can transfer anywhere you can get hired. Wells Fargo is always in the breaking edge of technology and banking. The brand is strong and people recognize Wels Fargo.
cons: It's a corporation and it runs like a corporation. It's not community. They are more concerned about the bottom line than they are about the team members who help them reach their goals. The sales quotas are too high and the sales are their number one goal over and above the customers. Raises are hard to come by unless you apply for and get a promotion, it's only cost of living raises other than that.  It looks like the have huge opportunity, but actually getting that break is nearly impossible.

job_title: Phone Banker II in Shoreview, MN
pros:
-Good benefits 
-You can make a lot of money if cold, cross-selling is your thing. 
-If you don't care about putting people in more debt that they already are, of selling unnecessary loans, credit cards, etc; this job is for you.
cons:
-Cross-selling is emphasized and is the core of your call. 
-you have to request time off by weeks, and that is not guaranteed to be approved. if not approved, you have to chase people down to get them to switch with you. 
-managers don't care about you, their employee turn over rate is staggering. There are about 2 10-15 people classes going on each month to fill in the spots of those that quit. 
-They lure you into the position with 2 weeks of paid training where you basically sit and do theory work. They throw you out in the phones after and typically, you quit. 
-Growth is VERY limited. They sell you on the idea that they will help you get anywhere inside the company to get you motivated. They host events, feed you, etc, just to get you motivated. There is no growth past the coaching team or phone bank management, for anything else you need some sort of education.

job_title: Business Systems Consultant in Bethlehem, PA
pros:
Best place  I ever worked for multiple reasons:
   1: Reviews were fair and objective
   2. Many opportunities to achieve goals and rewarded for projects done.
   3. Salary was fair for the position.
   4. Best Vacation/PTO benefit I ever had in my career to date.

I was far removed from upper management levels and in my opinion I have never held and higher opinion of a CEO then John Stumpf. He was by far the BEST CEO/Chairman I have ever heard as he was a very good people person having Town Halls through out the country speaking and answering questions of concerns by all/any "Team Member". Never referred to anyone as an employee but a "Team Member". It is sad that he had to take the fall for the recent problems at Wells.
cons: No Cons that can be controlled by Wells.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Walnut Creek, CA
pros:
Usually 9am - 6pm, off on Sundays!  
I really have not much to say in terms of pros. The job is very similar to working in a retail department store or a car dealership. It may seem somewhat better since you don't have to keep folding clothes or live only off of commission. But have no doubt, you will be fired if you don't produce above and beyond expectations. You may enjoy the environment if you are an unethical, hustler (as long as you cover your tracks).
cons: Very little room to grow! The bonuses are hard to come by and they are not even worth the effort. Constant pressure to sell, sell, sell! If you reach your goals, they simply raise them almost immediately. Don't expect an annual raise! They don't care or take care of their employees or their customers. Gaming, unethical practices and scamming employees and customers is imbedded in WF's DNA. Don't go there unless you are desperate!

review_title: corrupt managers and a system that protects them
pros: hard working, friendly, dedicated people; there are some good departments and teams;    decent benefits
cons: unethical management practices; dishonest managers; punishing employees for ethical behavior; questionable hiring practices; no accountable by managers; good people are worked  hard and then quickly shown the door; status quo is strongly enforced and the worst of the worst managers are protected;

pros: The team members.  My team members and in some cases direct managers were awesome.  We had great camraderie and they made the workday that much better.  Initially there was good incentive to make pretty good money but with more layers of compliance, watering down of commission, and re-orgs no longer.
cons: Your viewed as a number to them.  You'll get 10 email blasts on smiling executives pitching some BS but nothing tangible to your role usually.  Commissions and incentives have been WAY more difficult to achieve then when I started 6 years ago.  Inept and disconnected management.  The real problem is a lack of obtainable success (financial and career advancement) to each front line sales rep  in their role.  This company is way out of touch

pros:
1. Great Benefit
2. Excellent Work Life Balance
3. Good Policies especially for women employees
4. Emphasis on Risk Management
cons:
1. Too Slow to get things done, they are so laid back because all projects are internal. 
2. None of the standard constraints in the project are really a constraint, for eg: if there is a shortage of funds, create a CR, Give your business Justification and you will be funded in the next cycle :).. because of this there is no room for creativity, you try to cut costs, the sr leadership will shoot it down
3. Too slow to adapt to new technology, they live in their bubble knowing that they are one the biggest banks and practically think nothing can bring them down

pros: experience, technology, benefits, PTO, stable bank.  best looking ugly bank out there
cons: Where do i begin.  i have been with Wells Fargo now for 10 years...teller, banker, FA.   all they care about is numbers..sales, sales sales.  and i doesnt matter how you get them.  Every bank client should get 2 checking accounts, 5 debit cards, online, etc.  Its all about how many widgets you sold today.  As an advisor, same thing.  How many structured products you sold today.  Sell wealthbuilder funds, more insurance.  At the end of the day, its sad.  WFC was a good place to have a career but now its just turnover city.  Get your experience, find out what you like to do and then GET OUT!!!

review_title: I would not recommend working for this company.
pros: Originally, the part I liked best about working there was the freedom, but then new management came in completely changed the atmosphere.
cons: My immediate manager was great as well as most the people I worked with, the next levels of management were incompetent.  You were paid on a draw so when there was a bad month it immediately put you in the hole for the next month.  There was very little support for gaining new business.  You were responsible for coming up with your own leads.

review_title: Good place to work, unfair "favoritism" rather then performance promotions
pros: Great vacation amd 401k plans. Pay is low compared to other banks, nut they are flexible for college students.
cons: Not much room to grow. Even if you deserve a promotion, the position will likely have many other employees in line for one manager position. The theme of Wells Fargo when I started was "Help the customer succeed financially". Now its sell products and make profit for the company and try to get customers to sign up to allow $35 fees. They need to get back to what made them number 1. They are wearing even the senior bankers, and will likely gain a horrible reputation from employees within the next 5 years. They push and push and push sales, and increase goals every quarter.

review_title: If consultant is stationed in a busy branch, the probability of success at WFHM is increased substantially.
job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Long Beach, CA
pros:
Technology is at its finest.  Wells Fargo's data management systems are the most current.  A bit complicated at first, but once you get it, works very well to support your business development efforts.
Senior Management keeps employees abreast of the most recent changes to laws and industry regulations.  Implements changes quickly.
Competitive products, and rates and fees.  Good reputation with many realtors, and other industry-related affiliates.
Regular training is provided to maintain employee's skillset and industry knowledge.
cons: Many First-Time Homebuyer Programs not fully supported by Wells Fargo Home Mortgage. WFHM will often "overwrite" the Programs' guidelines with it's own restrictions, making it difficult for borrowers to qualify.

review_title: Wells has gone from Great to barely good
pros:
Good people to work with
Paid training
401k match of company stock
Limited but few opportunities 
Group health insurance through your own funded health savings account
cons: Most client facing positions have very aggressive sales goals with limited or no support to service clients. You will sacrifice time and vacation to meet goals trying to do servicing/ maintenance especially as through cost saving measures workloads have doubled  Unfortunately good work isn't rewarded but many times the unethical sales practices are encouraged. Pay raises are minimal or non existent  once you reach a mid-point while mid and senior managers enjoy stock options and percentage increases double or triple the minions

pros: Pay is more decent then other major banks; decent 401k and vacation time to start
cons: You have to plan all that great vacation time ahead a year on a calendar so if something comes  up you want to do later, your screwed. Or if someone has the week you want. The sales pressure is horrible and management definately plays favorites. How far you get has a lot to do with how much butt you kiss. I know some tellers have gotten as far as they have b/c they have bankers bring them slips saying they "referred them" so go ahead and put it in the system. Raises are non existent and if you are in a branch with immature people it makes the job so much worse. You can complain to HR but nothing comes of it. Record everything that happens people!

review_title: Ups and Downs, but Mostly Downs
job_title: Teller, Lead Teller, Banker in San Diego, CA
pros:
Opportunity for advancement
Paid Time Off
Paid Holidays
cons:
SALES! This company is far too concerned with sales. It makes a bad customer experience when tellers and bankers are constantly pushing for new products. It is also a very stressful environment. It is very hard to find a branch with good management, most managers seem to only care about themselves and don't know how to handle the stressful sales goals, They are also claiming to be moving towards "quality not quantity" but they never lowered the sales goals and it is impossible to reach the goals without talking customers into products that might go against your own ethics.
This extremely stressful environment causes a high turnover rate in branches which is difficult for team members and customers to deal with,

pros: Diverse work environment, Learning Environment
cons: Up-Ward Mobility (even with given education/experience - Hiring managers hire on the basis of "liking" a person rather than from qualifications)

pros: Consistent hours, federally observed holidays, fully laid out expectations, paid vacation. Decent benefits and health insurance.
cons: Too much sales pushing, sometimes what is in the best interest of the customer is forgotten  because employees are trying to "make the sale". I worked in an what they call an "in store" branch, which means the branch was in a grocery store. We saw the same customers all the time and thus it made it difficult to always push new products and meet sales quotas as we were held to the same standards as stand alone branches that were in higher foot traffic area, i.e. a branch in the city or in the middle of a college town.

pros: Was really a great experience as a young person starting out. I really loved upper management, super understanding and willing to work with you and tried to make the environment super fun.
cons: Less understanding about my school schedule so it ended up putting a lot of stress on my position and felt like I didn't get the respect I felt was appropriate for an employee. Upper management also played favorites and some talking about you behind your back situations. Honestly these things are just so generic I think these are very common issues in the work place.

job_title: Loan Adjuster (Freddie Mac Default Liquidations) in Fort Mill, SC
pros: Despite pay, company offers insurance options, PTO, and 401k for non-contract employees. The Fort Mill location also has a nice cafeteria with decently priced meals which makes eating in Ft Mill easy.
cons: Management in Freddie Mac department was everything you'd fear in working for a bank. Layoffs are the norm and you're told to spin it positively to the public while cutting jobs for an insanely rich companies and CEOs who are setting records for bonuses. Departments are staffed so short that customer service is impossible and management couldn't care less about that fact. They do, however, fear the CFPB like crazy and your entire job is to churn out loan decisions without getting on compliance reports. This would be an easy task were it not for the gross understaffing that is the norm. The place is all profit and no focus on customers or employee quality of life. Id flip burgers before going back. Not even joking.

review_title: Overall a very positive experience over the last 14 years
job_title: Digital Marketing Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros: There is a lot of opportunity to move around the organization. While culture and management style can vary from one business line/department to the next, overall my experience has been positive in terms of life/work balance and investment in team memeber development. Although the company is now nationwide and going international, because headquarters are based in San Francisco, there is a relatively relaxed culture overall. I do feel that overall, getting the job done is valued more than worrying about dress code and hours at the office.
cons: Due to the sheer size of this company, innitiatives and projects tend to move very slowly. As a marketing professional you should know that it is a sales driven organization so that a lot of your work will be dependent on their buy-in. While a lot of money and resources are invested in technology that supports information security, Wells Fargo is lagging behind in terms of tools and resources that support team members getting their job done.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: The majority of my fellow corporate team members are very nice to work with. In general there seems to be a high priority on creating a harmonious work environment. A lot of corporate team members have the flexibility to work from home. The workload is typically very manageable and doesn't require any evenings or weekends. Benefits are pretty solid, even if not exceptional. There are also many opportunities to move to new roles within the company.
cons: There is a large amount of bureaucracy and process which can reduce efficiency. There's a lot of contractors who seem to work at Wells Fargo for years, but have to take months-long breaks. Some lower managers impact the culture by behaving questionably and amateurly; it's something that I think wouldn't fly at most companies I've worked at previously. There also can be heavy micromanagement in a way that's unhelpful and actually interferes with my job.

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Tempe, AZ
pros:
-You can work independently while trusted to be professional and earn new business.
-If you work for a good manager your time here will be great, if not you'll burn out pretty quickly. 
-Pay is decent while rates are low. 
-Working behind a trusted brand makes selling pretty easy.
cons:
-The independent work you're doing will be watched extremely closely. It borders the line of micromanaging with the constant pressure from reports showing you exactly what you're worth to the company. 
-The increasing level of compliance bs they are cramming down your throat will make you want to consider other options, frequently.
-It's an uphill battle trying to fight your own company to get things done.

review_title: Worst job I have ever held
job_title: Mortgage Servicing Specialist in Frederick, MD
pros: Potlucks, training was fun and made it seem like they cared. They really do not care at all about you though.
cons: As soon as I left the training environment my job did a 180 flip. It went from "we care so much about you, you are the reason Wells Fargo thrives" to "shut up, do not give your input, take calls, don't even think of getting up" I have never been so micromanaged in my life. I was miserable. They have over 500 procedures that they expect you to have memorized in less than 2 months (mind you the procedures constantly change) not only that, but I couldn't even go to the bathroom. They have a system for tracking you in which if you even decide to breathe differently they know. I got pulled into my managers office because I took 2 unscheduled breaks less then five minutes each to go to the bathroom, in one week and they told me I was away from the phones to much. Are you kidding me?! They are all about quota and numbers. No wonder they had that scandal. They pressure you way to much.

review_title: Tout Mentoring but Do Not Promote
job_title: Systems Support Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: Commensurate pay, 401k options, bonuses, Flex Time, work from home options. You can end up with an awesome tight nit team to work with.
cons: Technology Sr Management promotes “hire inexperienced people and train them up!” But then flat denies any promotion requests regardless of employee merit. Only options are to wait for an opening at a higher level than you are then apply for it along with everyone else.  Promoting someone to fill that open slot is not allowed. That doesn’t fit with the mantra of keeping talent in-house. MAJOR org shift is happening with a business strategy and  location strategy rollout. Expectation is that there will be zero to minimal Work From Home by Q1 2022. Cost cutting measure are being heavily implemented to curtail any remote work. Adopting AGILE methodology to all aspects of Organization.

review_title: Got a good salary but no increases in 3 years
pros: Team members are supportive and salary is good for the work which is required.  End users are very happy with my work and the support that I provide to them.
cons: The managers do provide consistent feedback.  They tend to focus on anything negative and fail to provide acknowledgement of successes on a regular basis. Some managers want you to know everything about every tool in use by the team even though you have not received any training or have been exposed to the tool.

review_title: OK to work there, not many promotions though.
pros: Very big employer, lots of things for network engineer to do. There are many areas one can focus on. However, if one is in a particular group then you will not hear anything from the other groups.
cons: Promotions are hard to come by. Seems like a very young cadre of people are in charge. Engineers are not promoted into management, thus management has no clue when it comes to making decisons or doing change post-mortem. There is a HUGE divide between management and the workers. Where you come into the company is where you will stay generally. So don't accept a low level job just to get in. You will be stuck there forever.

pros: My store manager is too amazing and is the main reason I stay with the company. She is very very rare. Within less than two years of working here I have doubled my salary and have been promoted 2 times (teller to lead teller to personal banker)
cons: The banking aspect of Wells Fargo seems way too greedy for sales and solutions. I have heard non-retail Wells Fargo is amazing and strive to uphold the visions and values of the company but sadly I cannot say this is true for the retail banking. Sales, appointments, DCOS, funded accounts and whatever topic the district manager is feeling that day Are your focus... Not customers. I try to balance sales and customer service which has lead to 7 consecutive WOW surveys and low sales.

review_title: Wells Fargo is a great company to work for with awesome health & financial benefits
pros: 401k match dollar for dollar up to 6% of your base salary.  401k has Roth IRA option.  Health benefits include vision, dental, & full physical body wellness with coaching options on better health.  Employer availability in various parts of the country.
cons: Maneuverability is about who you know and not what you know.  Definitely a friend helping friends along company.  Once you are in an area of work, it is extremely difficult to move in other areas of the bank.  Education means very little to the company even though they have tuition reimbursement up to 5k a year and some jobs see certain degrees "as a plus" (does very little for job placement).

job_title: Marketing Program Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
I work with a lot of very smart and motivated people. The culture is that of a team, it's very collaborative, and people are generally trying to do the right thing for the customers and the business without letting their own agendas cloud their judgment. 
Also, good work/life balance.
cons: Sometimes not easy to move up. People stay a while. Business is always trying to do more with less.  A company this big has a lot of controls in place for internet usage etc and it can feel very big brother-like sometimes.

pros: Great PTO, Good hours, Awesome team to work with became a family. Great company values. Decent job security
cons: Do not value their employees, Favoritism, No bilingual compensation, Store managers do not care for employees. Company values are not portrayed in stores. Not enough pay. Nothing is ever good enough, even if you are top in sales. KDM/Service surveys are ridiculous! You can have excellent customer service, but because someone else messed up, you get hammered with a bad score. Very hypocrite upper management. Overwork their employees by having them skip lunches on a 10 hr shift. Customers are not their priority, Sales are! Management shops online and gossips while the place is falling apart. Wait time was ridiculous because of their "Click2Staff" scheduling! Over 9 tellers employed and the place worked on 3-4 while lines were out the door.

review_title: Retail Bank at it's best, love the people...if not a sales person, the stores&call centers are definitely not for you!
pros:
Legacy Wachovia culture (when you can find it!)
Amazing people to work with. Worked in multiple branches in seven year span in couple states-always felt like home!
I had PHENOMENAL STORE MANAGERS! 
Benefits
Work/life balance 
Learning and development
The customers (well, most of them)
Helping people
Internal promoting
cons: Pay could be better but pretty competitive with other retail banks. Wells Fargo merger did change culture drastically-sales, sales, sales! That's the business though. If you love people, banking, and SELLING, you'll love it! If you want to keep your job, hit your numbers and earn them ethically! (This is not a con :)

pros: Competitive salary for the market. Diverse company. Long history of this company.
cons: Everything!!! Sales culture is so deviant that large numbers of employees are selling product to customers who never asked for them just in order to meet sales quotas. Ethics is very strange word in WF world. Even if non ethical behavior is reported nothing is done to be prevented. Numbers are most important to management. Customers can insult employees on daily basis and nothing will be done to prevent future insults. Customer is always right as long as they can sell them something. Management is way to busy in maintaining sales goals and excessive conference calls every day that there is no interest in team members development. This kind of sales push mentality goes up from store managers to executives. Sell, sell, sell. Otherwise you are doomed and they will storm onto you like wasps. No mater if you are doing your job honestly and with great customer service if you are not selling you are outbound.

review_title: Not What It Used To Be
pros: Highly developed infrastructure with all the associated large company resources, great career pathing opportunities, good benefits
cons: Decline in leadership quality and culture, inability to manage change effectively, focus on people as a competitive advantage is dead

review_title: Things started out great and I loved working here, but it didn't take long for management corruption to mess it up.
job_title: Information Security Analyst in Winston-Salem, NC
pros: Very desirable schedule from 8am - 5pm and you'll make some very good friends here.
cons: By far the most incompetent and corrupt management team I've ever had the misfortune to work for.

review_title: You be the judge... but be careful!
job_title: Financial Crimes Specialist in Homewood, AL
pros: Good benefit package, flexible work hours, and good pay.
cons: Management and team leads are horrible and will go no further than Wells Fargo because the crap they pull will not be acceptable at any other bank/company. Also, the managers & team leads, do look out for each other, so if another manager and/or team leader does not care for you, they will go out of their way to make sure you lose your job. Working for this company is very cut throat, so go to work only to do your job and go home. Lastly, make sure you have a "plan B" because Wells Fargo is the kingdom of lay offs.

job_title: Database Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: Collaborative work environment that crosses business lines and company divisions and allows sharing of best practices from those who have already laid groundwork.  This minimizes the need to "recreate the wheel" when building similar internal  structures or products being considered by other functional groups within the bank but outside that immediate banking group.
cons: Standardization of bank policy for all employee functions, as well as HR rules and regulations by publishing "cookie cutter" procedure manuals throughout all banking groups.  Exceptions are deemed as unacceptable and limits each groups' specific work environments which often need some variations in policy to function effectively.

review_title: Wells Fargo Business Payroll Services is the Worst Place to Work.
pros: 401K and PTO.   Good place to meet friends.
cons:
The managers favor certain employees.  The managers only provide a 1% raise if that every year.  Upper management is always stressing out the regular managers.  Our managers treat us like we are kids.  They would rather serve us Snicker Bars than provide opportunities for career advancement.  

More Cons include that my manager would always stay in their Cubicle any only felt the need to speak to people during team meetings. 

Management sees its employees as pigs in a trough.  They only care about numbers and this is why this company and division is a total joke!

review_title: Overall - a very good company to work for.
job_title: Research/Remediation Specialist in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: Great Benefits!  Good people, lots of opportunities and there are tools to help you grow as an employee if you choose to use them.
cons: So many rules and they are interpreted or enforced differently depending on where you are and who your manager is.  Many of the jobs are production like - there isn't enough diversity in the work.  If you are on the phones - you are always on the phones.

pros: This is one of the best place to work with. Attractive salary, good leadership, good appraisal, Very transparent management.
cons: I have to mention about the supporting service like transport team in Chennai. They exactly work like any  Indian govt department. They are least bothered about employees for whom they are hired! They always comes up with new policies, which will have negative effect on us. Free transport is one of the attractive offers WF is giving. But because of mis management of that department, employees are forced to make own arrangement. Company is spending huge money to give benefit to us as most of  folks works on US working hours. But because of unfair policies, people started to bring own vehicles and travelling back to home in odd hours, which not only risks their lives and increases pollution!

pros: Wells Fargo offers great benefits and usually you can move up within a year if you're good with your sales. Prepare to kiss ass though, if your branch manager or district manager doesn't like you, even if they just heard rumors about you, you will never be promoted. Incentives are pretty good and you can use your PTO whenever you (or your manager) wants.
cons: Accounts may be hard to sell if you're a banker because the bank focuses on the number of accounts a customer has, the more the better, instead of focusing on one account that the customer can manage well without getting fees for not using it. Another thing, a lot of favoritism going on and cliques. In-store hours are long.

pros: There is room for advancement; they hire within the company instead of looking for those outside, to fill the position. Paid time off is great; if you need time off, and request it within a reasonable time; you'll most likely get it off.
cons: Very stressful environment if you don't make your sales. This job is very sales driven. Doesn't matter if you can multi-task, do your job properly; if you don't make your sales, you're fired. Benefits used to be great; but now are bad. Certain districts require you to be a banker first before you can advance to any other position. Pay isn't all that great. Raises are poor. Sometimes communication is poor.

review_title: Great Place for Wonderful Work life Balance, Job Security and good Compensation
pros: Great facilities, Job Security, Work life Balance, Lot of Events happens throughout the year, No Work pressure, very cool...
cons: Not many to say. But for the employees to grow in their careers Technically, Training programs are just not enough. We need the kind of work where we can apply the skills we learned. What i mean to say is the kind of work we do in offshore[india offices] is not  skillful/Technical. If someone always wants to learn more technical skills by work, we simply can't as the job we do is not too technical/challenging.

review_title: Slave -5 on scale but couldn't select
pros: I can't honestly think of one.  Decent lunch area that constantly smelled of curry from the IT department next door
cons: Never worked with more rude conceited arrogant coworkers in my life.  I was assigned a mentor who was never around when I needed help.  Luckily I found one guy who would help when he could.  Management was clueless from director to sales managers.  None of them and I mean none had any insurance experience.  They came over from the phone bank.  By far the worst job I ever had in my life, constantly thought about jumping out the window every 15 minutes.  I REPEAT DO NOT TAKE THIS JOB IF ITS THE LAST JOB ON EARTH, you'll be happier homeless.

review_title: Best for laid back guys who can stay till their retirement ; passionate techies will move on!
pros:
1. Very good work life balance
2. Relatively less amount of work even though the trend is slowly changing towards firms like Cognizant and Infosys.
3. Takes good care of employees( again, moving to the cost cutting mode).
4. On par compensation with the market.
5. Learn as much as possible while you are here. There is a very big scope to learn banking concepts and even technology innovation. This organization supports learning programs very well.
cons:
1. Manager is the monarch. Everything is solely dependent on the manager - he/she can promote you or terminate you just like that
2. No transparency. Nepotism/favoritism plays a huge part in career progress.
3. Promotions / performance review are simply not transparent and not fair.

pros:
Wells Fargo offers a competetive benefits and 401k package. I have every holiday, nights, and weekends off.
The company itself has great values.
cons: There is not much room for growth within the company as a Client Associate. This position assists Financial Advisors in operational duties and they prefer you to stay in this position. During the interview process I was asked numerous times if I would be interested in getting my series 7. I viewed this certification as an oppotunity for growth. However, once hired the series 7 has not been brought up once. Also, the office dynamic makes it hard to "fit in" at my location.  I currently make 15.38 per hour which is decent pay considering my responsibilities. However, in comparision to the pay of Financial Advisors and the Branch manager, my salary is small. I have been here a year and have not received a raise or the opporunity to take the series 7 which would increase my pay. I plan on leaving the company within the next year.

job_title: Merchant Service Business Sales Consultant in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Independent, work from where ever you like, set your own schedule, typical corporate benefits, compensation for gas.
cons: Very number driven company, they hire a lot of young people to save money, they only care about money and accounts, long hours, pay isn't what they say it is - they lie at the beginning what you will make but is so far-fetched. You are expected you to work during vacation and PTO time but they "don't say it". Very stressful work environment. Goals are unattainable, you can be in the top half or quarter of your peers and you will still get written up even if you are 1 account away or .1% away from your goal. They make you use your own car but the compensation for gas and mileage is not enough. It barely covers gas. The average employment for this job is less than one year.

job_title: Operational Risk Consultant in San Francisco, CA
pros:
a LOT of vacation time, straight away. and i've been  there for almost 10 years so i have a ton now!  

most people are very socialable and friendly - once you break the ice 

a lot of opportunity

salary increases are pretty regular
cons:
hard to get good training - a coworker left so i was re-orged and made to coordinate a whole program i knew nothing about. typical, and really bad idea. 

opportunity *is* available by you may have to apply to another position within the company to find it

a lot of weirdos. so many that happy hour invites are a very private thing. but find your people and it will be amazing. some of my coworkers were at my wedding.

pros: Great pay, especially if you get the shift differential for working after 5 pm. Benefits are great. The National Business Banking Center as a whole is full of enthusiastic people who genuinely like what they do, because they find ways to make it fun.
cons: The point system is very harsh. The training changes so often because handling money is a sensitive matter. You literally can tell a customer information one day, and the next day, that same information could change. The company is very slow when tracking whether you have too much PTO, and they are not merit based. So you only get SO much time off, and there is no UPTO at all. If you have to call out, it's a point. This job can get really stressful trying to work within the metrics the company has set up. Average call handle time, quality assurance, key driver metrics...all of those factor into your performance and can really be a downer if you're not meeting them. Low metrics can get you fired.

pros: The company really does look out for it's employees. Management has to go through a step by step process through the cooperation if there are any disciplinary measures being made and the human resources are always available to the entire work force. They hold meetings on how to better protect your self both at home and at work in all matters both physical, financial, or emotional. They encourage cross-training and shadowing so that you can develop skills within the company to make your self more valuable, something that is good for both your own self interest and in the interests of the company.
cons: On my side of the company in Operations I don't really see many cons. The only thing critical I would have to say is that the branches are forced to hard to up-sell the costumers which can be a bit off putting.

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Great company for new mortgage loan officers starting out in the mortgage industry. Good leads and great loan programs.
cons: Non engaged leadership, too much lip service, no mortgage loan officer support. Too much free admin check the box work to make  management look good. Ridiculous expectations for 100% comissioned mortgage loan officers.

pros: Benefits were great, good pay
cons: High stress level,  unobtainable goals, micromanagement, upper management onsite had teachers pets

review_title: Aggresive sales environment for inferior products
pros: They offer a decent base salary, considering it is a sales job.  You also have set hours with some overtime required, but you can have a good work life balance and put in the time to be successful.  It is a decent work envieronment.  Most of the people I met at other offices and my own were generally younger.  They recruit a lot of people right out of college, and most of the offices did offer a pretty fun environment, as long as, the office was doing well.
cons: The products offered are not very competitive.  They expect you to sell high rate, high fee products.  It is an aggressive sales environment.  The bonus structure could be better, especially when you look at the kinds of rates and fees you will be forced to sell.  Managers get compensated based on the branches proffittability, so it benefits there bonus.

review_title: Avoid this over-layered mess of a company like the plague!
pros: Steady employment in a wretched economy.  As a legacy Wachovia employee, the health insurance appears to be a small step better.  In addition, the full 6% match on 401k contributions was retained (for now).
cons: The company has too many layers of middle-level management in the Wealth Management division (where I work).  Decision-making in Wells Fargo Wealth and the company overall seems to be based on the "UN Security Council" method, i.e., consensus must be achieved amongst every member of the (very large) group of middle management that has a role in any given decision before any action is taken.  Salaries were kept at the same Wachovia levels, but bonus potential was cut drastically.  The result is that I now have a lower salary than many of my legacy Wells Fargo co-workers, with little potential to make up the gap.

review_title: Good place to work, don't get your hopes too high though
job_title: Operations Specialist in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The benefits are very good, and the 401K will take nice care of you.  There are a ton of opportunities if you can get out of your department.  There is a lot of leadership and professional development offered and encouraged, so you can build your resume here very well.
cons: It may be hard to leave your department as managers do not like replacing people very often.  The atmosphere is very much like high school here at home office.  Many departments are against cell phones being on your desk, and iPods.  The management sometimes seems petty and incompetent about the inner workings of their own departments.  They focus on the overall picture rather than learning what their team members actually do.

pros: They had great benefits! I worked there for several years and had five weeks of PTO, health insurance and 401K.  There is room to move up in the company, IF you can sell...
cons:
Even in an entry level position as a teller, you are expected to do sales.  Be prepared to be under extreme pressure to get more than the minimum required sales quotas.  It doesn't matter if you are an excellent teller (balancing your money, loss prevention, customer service, etc)---if you can't sell to people, your job will be in jeopardy.  You can't even move up in the company if you cannot sell a credit card or savings account to someone with 5 bucks their name. Good luck with that.

In over 5 years of working there, I barely got a dollar raise.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Ventura, CA
pros: Great bonuses can be earned with amazing sales. Pays the bills.
cons: Depending on the branch you work at - It is almost impossible to make the minimum daily goals, making it near impossible to make the quarterly bonuses. Company has a demanding and stressful sales environment that is almost coming to surface with the current allegations as reported recently on the LA Times. Job title no longer means anything. Everyone is being pushed to meet sales goals that are not their qualification. ie: Tellers doing sales (not required or even counting for them) that Business Specialists should be doing.

pros: Very large company and hopefully will have the opportunity to transfer to a management position, which is what I have been doing for over 25 years. I have 5 years experience as Project Manager and team lead in the Wholesale department as a team lead in the Migration Department.
cons: It is hard to work with the current team leads who do not understand migrations and do not know about the Wells Fargo products and services. The team leads do not assist the migration specialists in working with their customers or give ideas on how they can improve their numbers.

pros:
Work environment was ok. There were coworker that I didn't get along with. 
I had no issues with when I needed a day off or to switch days. 
Bonus every quarter based on referrals and customer service
Great benefits.
Match up to 6 percent on retirement.
cons:
Branch manger was all about numbers no matter how he got them.
Took almost a year for me to become full time due to FTE when we were still short. So that didn't add up!!
Starting pay was not all that great. And even worse after taxes and health insurance came out for my family. If I knew what I know now I would have asked for more due to my experience.

review_title: I love working at Wells Fargo!
pros: My job is interesting. I do a variety of different things, so I don't get bored. I love my supervisor. I have monthly 1:1's with her so I know how my performance is. Management is very supportive of growth and helping employees to succeed. My flexible schedule allows me to have a great life work balance. I can work 4 10's as well. Also, can wear casual clothes.
cons: A lot of our recognition money was taken away since we merged with Wachovia. So, we don't get a lot of fun perks like we used to. Not quite as fun, but it is slowly getting a little better.

review_title: Home Mortgage -- Great Atmosphere, Long Hours
job_title: Home Mortgage Processor (Financial Advisers/WFA) in Minneapolis, MN
pros: For a loan mortgage processor (entry-level position), the pay is great and the people are nice to work with. There are a lot of overtime opportunities (required during busy times, but you can really make bank with bonuses and incentives to work 18 hours over the weekend). During busy times, they bring in great food from well-known restaurants.
cons: Overtime is required when the interest rates are low and everyone is refinancing their home loan. There are also very high standards and anything below a "5" on your customer service survey is considered a failure (but you can't tell customers to give you a "5"). Some managers are good, others are terrible, so you get the luck of the draw.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Richmond, VA
pros: Benefits, hours can be good depending on position, exposure to learning is awesome. You will meet a lot of people and learn a lot.
cons: Pay is horrible internally, someone off the street will always make more than you. Getting promoted is the matter of who you know and your good work is sometimes overlooked. Also this is sales. Your success is based on how good you can get accounts. ACCOUNTS ACCOUNTS ACCOUNTS!!! No one cares about anything but accounts here. If you are in a good area and store then accounts will come easy but in a slow town or area this will be a huge problem and you will be required to make at least 30 to 40 dials a day for future appointment setting.

job_title: Personal Banker II in Coralville, IA
pros: Easy sales goals if you actually do your job, easy to be promoted in most cases, great benefits, Team was great to work with for most part. Great and respected training programs. Tuition reimbursement. 401k and discounts on a lot of financial stuff.
cons: VERY Corporate. HR doesn't give a rip about you. Lots of drama in the workplace. Sometimes people who don't deserve to be promoted because of their time at the bank. They push their own ways - and if you don't follow, you can guarantee they will find a reason to fire you somehow.

review_title: Hard sell Senior Citizens or get shown the door
job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Chicago, IL
pros: The resignation process was easy.
cons: Where do I start.  I have never been exposed to actual physical abuse by a Branch Manager.  Ever.  It is a caustic place to work; you are degraded, you are embarrassed in front of customers, and you have to hard sell all day long unless you want the wrath of Management to come down on you.  Lose you ATM card and simply want a replacement?  Well then you need to open a savings account for you and each of your children, take a personal loan at sky high rates, and I will put you in touch with "our" insurance specialist.  You already have a savings account?  Then you need two....just in case.  In case of what?  This is a penny stock company gone mad.  This tiger has not changed it stripes, and you are in for a time share salesman experience every time you walk in the door.  And this is AFTER their mea culpa.

review_title: Choose your career path wisely or you will end up at a dead end.
job_title: Business Banker  in San Diego, CA
pros: Good solid company, that promotes within. Just make sure you choose your career path wisely, you could end up in a dead end job. If you start in a retail branch its very difficult to transfer to another department, with only retail training you dont have to much to choose from outside. They have great training team, and most upper management are very supportive. As long as you do your job and sell you will be fine.
cons: Jumping from retail stores to other departments within wells fargo. Pay is decent but most other banks will pay you more. You can end up in a dead end job or get stuck in retail. They also hire store manager for there sales performance not so much on there leadership.

pros: Fantastic benefits - even a teller that works 17 hours a week gets health insurance and PTO.
cons:
They focus more on quantity. Everybody has these stupid sales goals that don't really matter in the grand scheme of things. For example, if I recruit two customers to open accounts - it does not matter that one customer will put in $250k and the other customer never puts in a dime and long as the accounts were opened. Also - they change the bonus structure every quarter and it's like they are looking for a reason not to give you a bonus. 

My district manager comes in weekly and it does not matter how hard you work how long you've been there. She told us she could easily replace us with people that work at Mcdonalds and she's willing to fire our entire branch if we don't meet the sales goals. That really makes emplyees feel valued.

review_title: It's Sales, it's stressful, if thats ok, your in.
job_title: Personal Banker I in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The people are great, incentive compinsation is pretty good, if you can meet it. Your opportunity to move up in the complany is great, if your number are there.
cons: Sales goals are super strict, your always selling selling selling, i hope that doesn't get old for you, or you won't last. Senior management does not understand with this economy the goals cannot continue to increase, or everyone is going to fail at some point. Be prepared to work long hours and stay late some nights if your sales are not met for the day, week, month etc. It is a very very very stressful work environment once you hit personal banker and beyond.

review_title: Great company to work for, I really enjoyed my time in the Private Bank
job_title: Client Service Consultant II in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
Good management with many years of experience. Pay, benefits, time off is average or slightly above average. Great team environment. 
-100% match on 401k up to 6%
-2 days off a year to volunteer at your choice of charity. 
-3 weeks vacation

Strong company with stable balance sheet.
cons:
Software is outdated and slow. If you mind working one weekend day this may be con, but with time you will get a better schedule. You will run into people that dislike Wells Fargo and have been in there position for a long time, this is due to there lack of motivation not lack of opportunity. Brokerage side of the business may be limited but the bank has many ops. Pay may not be as well though.

-The only reason I left was op to gain additional licenses, increase in pay, and gain experience in different part of the brokerage business that isn't available at Well Fargo; at least not in UT.

review_title: Loan Documentation Specialist IV - OK first job out of college
job_title: Loan Documentation Specialist IV in Bloomington, MN
pros: Good direct supervisors/team managers. Decent pay for an entry-level position. Good company-wide benefits. Good training program at the start, but the continued training seemed to be more around HR protocols, not really how to improve in the day-to-day role.
cons: Large company atmosphere with a large amount of internal red tape. The role specifically could become very monotonous at times but it was well defined at the front end this would be the case. Was part of a larger layoff that was only driven by the fact that interest rates went up 1/2 a point or so - felt like just a number at the end.

pros: Founded 1852. Stable company.  Well known.  Great benefits. Located in 39 states.  Wide product selection for consumers and business customers.
cons: Company Vision and Values says the Customer's financial success comes first. Reality is bankers, tellers, CSSRs are held to aggressive sales goals. Upselling customers and talking them into additional products burns out retail banking staff and turnover is extremely high. End result: Experienced personnel leave and customers get poor advice from newbie employees who are out to make a sales goal.

review_title: Great People, Never needed a bail out
pros: Very qualified and experienced IT and lines of business management and engineers. Lines of business highly focused on the end user experience and conservative where appropriate; creative where needed.
cons:
Slow to change, due to so many silo's of bureaucracy. Faster than most other banks though so the "grass is greener" is all about perspective.
IT achieves progress ever so slowly. Takes a bull in a china shop to drive change on any topic in under a year. Individual directors seem to focus on building empires rather than being more transparent for the greater good. Safe place to work and invest your time, but be prepared for long stalls and extremely slow progress on any front.

pros: Very friendly interviewing process, mine went very well. The interviewers were kind and let me take my time since it was my very first professional interview. I would recommend to just be yourself, be confident in yourself and smile! They want to see your personality that they can present to customers.
cons: Nothing I can think of, my interviewers were very kind, first met a recruiter, had a group interview. Then background and fingerprint screening, then finally with the branch I would work at. The only con is the long process it takes to be hired. Otherwise it went pretty smoothly

review_title: Former Teller at a retail branch
job_title: Bank Teller in Long Branch, NJ
pros: Lots of opportunities to work your way up... if your managers decide that they like you. Incentive program... if you can meet their insane standards. As a teller, received a lot of support from the bankers but that was about it.
cons:
-Deceptive and underhanded sales practices. They basically want you to blindside customers into buying products and opening accounts (I believe there was at least one lawsuit related to this). Environment is very competitive, people get angry when you "steal" sales but will do the same to you without hesitation.  
-Micromanaging employees within an inch of their lives. 
-Training focuses 90% on the same entry-level customer service skills required to get hired and 10% on the actual functions needed to do the job.

pros:
Dedicated, helpful co-workers. This is pretty much all i can think of. While i was happily quitting my slavery at WF, many of the coworkers said they wish they could do the same, but have to stay and support their families, children. Proudly leaving this awful place and finding a great place to work after  was the best part of my time there.  Maybe some of other branches treat their employees like actual human beings, but this wasn't the case.  
you don't want to constantly feel like a hypocrite, and take an advantage of other people in order to benefit rich corporation, avoid the Hells Fargo at all costs if you can.
 You deserve better for yourself!
cons:
-Extreme micro-management to the point of standing behind your back with the check list of things you are obligated to say while helping a customer 
-CONSTANT pressure to sell banking products to customers who don't need them
-Attitude to "take advantage of every customer who walks in" -an exact words from manager's "motivational speech" 
-No life/work balance
- Requiring to sign up your friends and family for the WF b. s. services

pros: 401k was one of the better ones out there with a match dollar for dollar every paycheck, not on an annual basis.  If you worked at Wells Fargo, you could pretty much land a job at any other bank.
cons:
At some point in time you will be ask to sell an unreasonable amount of products to meet quotas.  If you have a customer complaint against you due to product sales due to managers constantly badgering you about sales, you may be FIRED!  Managers constantly asking staff  "How many solutions do you have today?!"  or "Hey, what could you have done better during that last interaction?!  "That was an existing customer with a check card.  Were you able to sell them another 3 check cards?!

Wells Fargo used to be good trying to go for "Gr-Eight" but lost its way with excessive turnover and corporate greed. They have the longest banking hours which is great for customers but bad for employees.

pros: This was by far the best company experience of my professional career. Although the pay is on the lower side of the market in comparison to the other banks my 3 years tenure here was well utilized. I was exposed to a plethora of roles and industries that I got professional experience in. And the business is always growing so you have a wealth of opportunities available to you within the business unit. They offer $5k tutition reimbursement & you are matched up to 6% dollar for dollar in your 401k after 30 days. It's a great place to work. And, I got opportunities to get in to project consulting to make more which is why I ultimately left. But, the door is always open for me to go back. Loved Loved Loved working here.
cons: Increase Pay to be more competitive with other banks

review_title: depends on your branch manager- Lead teller
pros: Great people to work with and usually a laid back great manager
cons: The "higher ups" are ALWAYS putting sales pressure on the branch managers which then the branch managers put pressure on the bankers and tellers for sales. Its fine if you have a manager who can handle that stress from the district manager but you might actually see the district manager yelling at your manager about sales. Your can only control so much if you work at a slow store. If your at a high traffic store its easier to hit your sales goals. But every morning there is a meeting about SALES GOALS and the pressure is on!! Wells destroys you if your not in a high traffic store and hitting your goals.

pros: Great Company if you score a position where there is no or reasonable sales goals - worked at one of their call centers back in the 90's for over 8 years
cons: Position where unrealistic sales and referral goals if not met will get you terminated if not meeting quota.  Customer service comes second which is a shame since 90 percent of inbound calls are from the same 10 % of customer base every month.
