Geez I hate to call knowing associate is going to try and get me to apply for one of their other bank products.  Lot of excellent employees are let go causing tremendous turnover and very costly to hire and train new employees.

pros: vacation time and work schedule are good
cons: Anything and everything else basically.

job_title: Home Equity Specialist in Charlotte, NC
pros: I liked my mgr and all of my teammates. The work itself wasnt difficult. I enjoyed what I did but not the process  it required. We had OT, so we were able make extra money.
cons: The goals werent obtainable, nothing was consistent, we were held accountable (& faced disciplinary action) for things out of our control (wrong info given during the closing at the brach/attorneys being late for the closing etc)  and upper mgt didnt care  about us or our input. The dept had VERY high turnover and was never fully staffed.

pros:
* Freedom to go to store to store.
* Echo sign makes deals a little easier to get signatures. 
* Don't have to work weekends unless you want to. 
* Having Wells on your resume is good.
cons:
* Product is tough to sell.
* Internal system to get your contact / agreements approved is super difficult. Manager needs to approval every agreement even it's the smallest change. If your boss is not around and they didn't give anyone else approval you have to wait and wait. A lot of times you have the Owner or decision maker in front of you and can't do anything. 
* The reimbursement / mileage is very time confusing and extremely difficult.
* Compensation plan kept getting worse. 
* Very very high turnover both sales reps and managers.
* So many pages for RO / Decision maker to sign to join wells fargo credit card processing.
* Lots of lots of competitors in this market.
* High stress
* Lots of negatively when you go to the branches that they hate the job.

review_title: Great place to work, but helps to know someone
pros: Committed to our vision and values and community assistance. Concerned with and recognizes the importance of employee engagement and well being. Great training and development programs. Feel like a valued employee most of the time.
cons: Once in the corporate/executive level, nepotism is strong. Depending upon how you view that, it could be a pro or con. However, while I believe it helps very much to know someone along your career path, I also belive in most leaders are valuable in the company and do what is right. In my particular area, I believe that transparency is lacking and organizational politics are high - however, this might not hold true in other areas.

review_title: If you have a brain and can think for yourself, go somewhere else.
job_title: Personal Banker in Huntington Beach, CA
pros: Great benefits, competitive pay, PTO, and you're given the opportunity to help customers.
cons:
Constant pressure of daily sales goals creates a bad working environment.  Many put sales before service when it should be the other way around.  The constant sales pressure really breaks you down as a human being.  It takes a dedicated individual willing to put up with and sacrifice a lot.  You need not think about the consequences, rather listen to upper management and go full steam ahead.  

The job is centered around sales.  There is no other way to describe it.  It you're a notary, your expected to service the customer and hit your sales goals.  There are many bankers that do not want to get their notary license because they feel that it takes up too much time and will not meet their daily numbers.

review_title: Welcome to the team: let us chew you up and spit you out.
pros:
* Decent salary (at first)
* Decent benefits (at first)
* Decent people (for a while)
cons:
* Increasingly diminishing compensation; raises become impossible to obtain
* Management suffers from "Ivory Tower Syndrome"
* Lack of communication of new policies/procedures
* Inordinate punishment for minor infractions
* Care more about company's profile than actual employees' work or comfort
* Talk about diversity is empty; homophobia, racism, sexism, and favoritism not addressed even when blatant and reported
* Encourages employees to devote entire life to company's mission statement, going so far as to mark down performance reviews for lack of volunteer or advocacy work
* Refuses to make reasonable accommodations for those with disabilities

review_title: Great company depending on your team makeup
pros: Good  pay, nice incentives, many job opportunities
cons: There's some degree of micromanagement.   No matter how great you do or how well your store produces,  it never seems good enough. I  can understand the importance of constantly improving  but you are judged for success by the last thing you do,  even if overall you have been on top. They make you feel guilty about taking time off to take care of family or yourself ( or at least at my branch) and that is wrong because family has to come first.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Wells Fargo has the best banker training in the banking industry, and has the best reputation of promoting internally if you can exceed your goals. Even if you have no prior banking experience, Wells Fargo provides over 3 weeks worth of training you.  They provide great sales training.  There is no other bank that will promote their employees as aggressively as this bank.
cons: Wells Fargo does pay and train their employees well; however, they pay the lowest in the industry in both salary and commission, which is almost impossible to attain.  They set very high goals for all bankers, tellers, and managers. Going to work everyday is like going to"war."  Every banker must hit a certain number of accounts opened, products sold, and profit per day. Also, every banker in the store is fighting each other for the same customers, fighting the Wells Fargo branch across and down the street.  On top of that you have other banks that you are contending against. Regardless of how slow the branch is, you have to hit your numbers. Stress starts at 9 till 6 and never stops.  Be prepared to eat, sleep, and LIVE Wells Fargo!

review_title: Good experience depends entirely on your branch team members and managers.
pros: You can learn a lot about how financial products work and how they are structured. You also learn good sales tactics from team members that will probably benefit you for life. At least for me it did.
cons: Daily quotas are set somewhat high which can lead to unethical selling practices just to meet quotas. Incredible employee turnover rate and terrible management. Sometimes u get a good district manager who pay attention to you help you grow, other times u get terrible ones who don't really care about their responsibilities anymore and just care about keeping their job. I was unfortunate enough to get the latter. So a good work environment really depends on what kind of upper management your stuck with.

job_title: Service Manager II in Livermore, CA
pros: Lots of benefits and discounts. Plenty of locations and jobs to choose from.
cons: As a salary employee,  exempt from over time,  I often need to work 45-55 hours per week.  I have no work/life balance. I need to have perfect customer service scores/meet sales quotas and staff a branch that's open 7 days a week with 6 tellers and 4 bankers.  There are too many balls to keep in the air.  If I drop one I'm looked down upon. I'm always hiring new people due to high turnover which then negatively affects the customer service scores, sales quotas and losses.

job_title: Bank Teller in Carson City, NV
pros: The company as a whole has great goals for helping local communities and wanting customers to succeed financially. They definitely offer good benefits and make it easy to sign up for them. Very comprehensive training and you can usually bond with coworkers by saying how much you hate Wells Fargo.
cons: But the way they train managers is to put too much pressure on the bankers and tellers to make sales, when the managers themselves don't have to do any sales. They push you to meet your goals so they get their bonus which is like $3500 compared to your measly 200 if you even bonus with their ridiculously high sales goals and underhanded tactics of "not giving the customer an option to say no".

pros: I loved working with customers, cash handling experience, and the overall job wasn't too tough. I'm happy I got the experience and loved working for Wells Fargo in the early days before it got bad. I wouldn't recommend to anyone at this point.
cons: I didn't feel that we got paid enough and the sales pressure is extreme. I felt like I had to be dishonest and get customers into products they didn't need in order to keep my job. I honestly didn't do this and nearly lost my job. It didn't start out this way but as time went on the company became more and more aggressive. Luckily I found another job before the quarter ended and didn't lose my job.

review_title: Phone banker for about a year
pros:
-Breaks, Healthcare, PTO, in-house cafeteria, salary/bonuses
-training is lengthy but very thorough, they set you up for success. and they really ease you into your new tasks assigned.
-typical day to day work is demanding but very do-able with the reliable staffing. only reason
-best part of the job is the consistent schedule and flexible hours! they were great with that and they even have a understanding attendance policy that include paid time off for sick days and vacation.
cons:
-Sales, no part-time, stagnant tasks, customers were horrid
-hardest part of the job is the sales(inbound sales). its recorded daily, weekly and monthly so "if youre not meeting you requirement then you arent doing your job." (direct quote from several managers) they are there for all kinds of support but if you dont perform then be prepared to have them on you 24/7

pros: Flexible work hours, great co-workers, lots of potential to move inside the company after a year.
cons: Everything is OK as long as you are a yes person and don’t go against your managers. If you escalate behavior that is unethical the solution for management/hr is to fire you by forcing you to quit(manager says lies about you that you have no way to prove him wrong, manager silently retaliates against you …)  or move to another position or company. Also, lately the bonus are less and the salary increase is less than the inflation rate. Expect your compensation ratio (current salary/ average of your Tier geography) to go down over the years. The health benefits are not as good compared to other companies. The more senior you are in the company the more likely you are to get laid off or forced to move to other companies or company reducing your bonus and salaries

review_title: Overall good experience. Business changes constantly so have to be able to manage and embrace change
pros: The culture on the brokerage side is so different than bank environment - in a really good way! I'm not in a sales role but an administrative role and our office environment tends to be more like a 'family' .
cons: Lack of professional growth opportunity. Needs more opportunities for current employees to grow - professionally and financially. Raises tend to be very low so if folks want to increase earnings they may consider other opportunities within company if they understood what they were. Company involves bank and brokerage and is huge so unless you know what all is available for your talent you could easily get 'stuck' where you are currently.

review_title: Wells Fargo is a great place to work in most cases.
job_title: Premier Banker in Santa Fe, NM
pros: Growth opportunities, training and licensing paid for by company, company moving in great direction as of 7/3/18. Very supportive coaches and team in most cases, good paid time off. I’m at 10+ years with the company and get about 35 days per year
cons: Growth of salary can be slow,  good paying positions open rarely, down sizing branches can make it hard to find position or can have risk of layoff

review_title: Wells Fargo Home Mortgage IS THE LEADING LENDER for financing and for employment!!!
job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Clearwater, FL
pros: It is a great company to work for. The upper management staff is very supportive and they treat us with a great deal of respect. Wells Fargo Home Mortgage is a very diverse company and cares about there employees and their customers. They  are very careful to only do loans that are good for the customer. They have great benefits at a very low cost and they also recongnize all of us all of the time. This is the best company to work for by a long shot!!!
cons: I have yet to find one. It is an awesome company to work for and to work with!

review_title: A good company to work for if you're not in the retail side.
pros: There are a good deal of opportunities to move forward in the company, provided you're willing to be flexible.  Also, the pay is competitive when compared with other banks, and opportunities for raises are available based on quarterly reviews.
cons: At least in the retail side of the company, the pressure of getting sales is too high.  Managers are responsible for their employees sales goals, and their bonuses are based on how well others do, not how well they themselves do.  Provided you get enough sales, you can get away with almost anything, leading to unethical selling practices which is not corrected as it makes managment look good.

review_title: Good work-life balance with opportunity for growth.
pros: Flexibility, opportunity for advancement, strength in a poor global economy.  A company that stands its ground and knows how to gain market share without compromising the business practices it has set forth for its shareholders, customers, and employees.
cons: Lack of communication from middle and senior management when change that affects everyone is coming. Senior management not as forward thinking and prepared for change as they could be.  Make a decision and then stick to it for at least one quarter.  By not giving team members time to introduce clients to change before everything changes again, there was a loss of  confidence even among the most loyal team members.

pros:
*Entry Level - gave you the training you needed
*Very Hands On 
*Realized that there are "down" times when you have off days - don't punish you for something that's out of your control
*Extremely friendly environment
*Everyone -at one time or another- was once a credit manager so they all know the frustrations that go along with the position - are really helpful resources
*Our Branch Manager was extremely nice! Was able to give you the motivation you needed to stay on track but also wasn't there to micromanage you!
cons:
*Warm Calling was included in the position - could get tiring hearing people hang up on you/give objections
*Having off days and not getting appts set was sometimes frustrating

review_title: Customer Service/Hard Sell..goes hand in hand??
job_title: Lead Teller in Saint Petersburg, FL
pros: Nice salary for being a teller (earned over many years)  Good benefits
cons: Management wants you to brown nose customers to get " 5 star shops".  Must ask every customer to buy into some new product or service.  Hard to do when you see the same customers over and over and you have already been sucessful at selling them all Wells Fargo has to offer previously.  Makes it hard to hit goals when you are limited to the number of products you can sell them in a 45 day period and receive credit for.

review_title: A good, solid company to work for.
job_title: Lease-End Sales Consultant in Walnut Creek, CA
pros: Good benefits, solid PTO plan, lots of opportunity for career mobility. As a Lease End Sales Consultant, we were paid a decent annual salary. The real treat was the incentive plan. Even if you were just an average performer, you could make an additional $1500 per month or more. Most of us made enough to essentially double our salary. Times were great, until the financial crisis struck and caused Wells Fargo to pull out of the leasing business. Three years later, we were all laid off when there were no more leases ending.
cons: As with any large company, sometimes you can feel like just another number. Also, sometimes you have to deal with reactive (rather than proactive) middle management, which is cause for sometimes excessive procedural changes. My personal experience with my direct supervisor was essentially ten years of slow, painful death, but I do believe she was the exception and not the rule.

review_title: Decent training at first. Most managers and coworkers lack intellectual understanding of finance outside of their job.
pros: Decent benefits, large bank network to eventually move around to other departments.
cons:
Cheap managers, pay lower than other major banks, and the "meat and potato" style of banking gets old. By that I mean the bank runs its employees and uses them saying that if they exhaust themselves they will be recognized. No frills or concerns what the employees think about it. Those that exhaust themselves are sometimes recognized, but usually not in a meaningful way. 

Bank is also acquiring lots of assets trying to become bigger than JP Morgan. And because of that, has messed up its budget and its paying its employees less than they deserve.

pros: The pros were definitely the paid time off, 401k up to six percent match, and at times obtainable monthly bonus.
cons: Management was obtuse and micromanaging as I have ever experienced. Though I met and surpassed my goals year after year, for nearly a decade I could count on being treated like a new hire, and apparently always in need of instruction.Myself and my co-workers all adults could be counted to be treated like children. Expect to be monitored in a way that would make the N.S.A blush!

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Good benefits and generous co-workers
cons: Underpay, no payment of overtime, shady sales practices - customers misinformed and with excessive amount of accounts and cards never requested, unprepared and under capacitated employees, huge turnover, personal bankers stealing sales from others peers - management and ethic committee nothing did to stop/prevent problem, overkill sales meetings. Feel we are leaving the customer service behind, can't keep soliciting to people to buy bank products if they don't need it, enormous amount of fee is charged for stupid products, relationship with bank is often not taken in consideration when making decision to help customers, managers don't seem to care. With only one month will be contributing to the high turn over statistic myself, completely different than training. Sad.

pros: Management is set up to give you a excellent support team at the branch. Ive found that they do balance your personal and work life well with PTO that increases every few years. They do set a path for you to move up or into another field within Wells Fargo and encourage you to discover what path is right for you.
cons: The compensation isn't the best. There isn't much of a individual rasies (mine was $.08 last year). The only way to increase pay is through promotions. The sales goals for quarterly bonuses are on a tier based system with the lowest tier being the only reasonable one. Some managers encourage unethical behavior to reach higher levels of bonus. This shouldn't be much of a surprise with the recent lawsuits. Seems like managers only care about your success to make themself look better.

pros: I absolutely loved working for Wells in the Retail Services Department. The management is excellent - they truly care and want you to succeed and will help you move up in the company without hesitation. Though call center work can be tedious and frustrating, the company culture and lifelong friendships one builds more than makes up for it.
cons: When I relocated, I had to transfer to a branch as a Personal Banker, as my position was not available in the area. It was a terrible experience from what I was used to... I felt like a used car salesperson. I went into the job hoping to actually help customers, but ended up being constantly pressured to talk customers into accounts and services they truly didn't need. I have heard the branch sales goals have been terminated since my time there, so that is good to hear.

pros: They give you an opportunity to pursue your licenses.
cons: Management/HR are very deceiving when it comes to the licensing program. They tell you they give you a 60 day window (2 months) to study and take the test. They also say be sure not to study on your own time or have any overtime because they will not pay you outside Monday-Friday within operating hours. What they dont tell you is, they dont care for you to pass, they really cut short your time by counting the days by calendar days not by business days. If you don't feel ready or prepared to take the test they will not allow you to extend the time frame, and the PassPerfect program you utilize is mandatory. They will not expense for you to use Kaplan or any other service. Studying for a Series 6,63,65 takes a lot of time to study for and FINRA allows a 90 day window just to prepare and study for one exam.

review_title: Wells Fargo...A great place to be...
job_title: Information Security Manager in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The best reasons to work here are the people and the culture.  Great people and a performance focused, yet laid back, culture.  The compensation as a whole is very good.  Everyone is given a large amount of time off for vacation, sick days or personal days.  The benefits are very comprehensive and are also affordable.  Finally, this is a place that offers opportunity for everyone who seeks it.
cons: It is easy to fade away in a large corporate machine.  Networking is key for building your career.  Each division has it's own quirks and positives.  Some divisions or lines of business tend to be political while others are not.  It really comes down to finding a balance of what you feel you can deal with.  Some areas are very fast paced, and some are not.  Knowing which you thrive in is key.

pros: The best part about WF is the health insurance and PTO.  The training they give is very beneficial.  For sales it is one week and the training for bank procedures, computer programs used, etc is another week.
cons: The sales goals are ridiculous if you work at a slow branch.  If you don't make your sales you get no respect, no raise, nothing.  If you are very strong in sales and can make the minimum 100 sales per quarter (for full time) then WF is a great place to work.  The 1st quarter (Jan-Mar) you are expected to get 4sales a day.  No time off is giving in January (Jump into January they call it).  The sales goals aren't impossible as long as you work in a busy branch.  Also they start out at a lower pay than most banks but think they're making it up to you by giving you quarterly bonuses for making your sales.

review_title: If you want to work in Commercial Banking, this is the Company for you.
job_title: Financial Analyst in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great credit culture. The company is willing to invest in your future. As much training as you would like and people in the Company are eager to help foster your growth.
cons:
The company provides offers a lot of autonomy to its regional commercial banking offices, which can be good or bad depending on your office. Overall, if the Company hires the right people, it's a strength as executives can focus on their macro duties, but if you're working at a weak office, your development will suffer. Try to stick to major cities in competitive markets.

Also, the company is naturally conservative so don't expect too many bells and whistles, but you will be treated well.

review_title: Great opportunity to move up if you don't mind doing what's best for the company over what's right for the customers"
pros: Easy to move up quick, it's more of sales performance over how long you have been there. Good if you don't mind being very pushy.
cons: The sales goals are sometimes so high it forces you be extremely pushy and in most cases not do whats right for your customer.  The management will tell you it's all about the customer and what's best for them, but the employees that are "performing the best" are the ones that could care less about there customers, and get recognition from management.  The stress levels put on you from upper management are sometimes unbearable.

review_title: Money hungry company that does not care about their customers nor their employees...
job_title: Inbound Sales Specialist in Roanoke, VA
pros:
Decent benefits:
Health/Dental Insurance
PTO
Discounts from other companies
cons: Merger with Wachovia went terrible for customers and employees that were with Wachovia.  Salaries were cut, main objective is to sell not on a needs basis to the customers but on products they do not need and are basically transferred from person to person until the customer signs up to add an additional product of service, the fee structures were changed.  Promised customers they would be grandfathered into their specifics accounts however that was untrue and they made customers switch to up to date plans... communication throughout the company was poor and seems that each branch and call center did not work together but more competitive than anything.  There is advancement opportunities however you must be buddies with someone in order to move up it seems they do not look at your education nor tenure.

job_title: Customer Service and Sales Representative in Parkville, MD
pros:
Wells Fargo makes the expectations known and decent the high sales goals can be reached by hard working employees. Sales goals are tough and require an employee who is willing to dig deep every minute of an 8 hour work day and those who aren't afraid of talking to customers
PTO is wonderful at this company and the managers recognize people who work hard. The payouts for completing goals are outstanding
Treating the customers fairly and providing a high level of service is a main focus
cons: To much micro management and the district managers seemed to have lost their vision on the companies customers and focus mainly on the numbers.

pros: The pay is marginal, depending how hard you work to negotiate upon initial hiring. Benefits are good, but incentive is almost unachievable.
cons: The company values are always shifting, but one thing has been constant.  Every training they do is to get you to talk the customer into something they may not even want. If you want to sell your soul for sales, then this company is for you. The company mentality is shifting back to this toxic outlook. Also it is difficult to move up if not convenient for management. If you are excelling in your current role, they will use that despite your personal goals of moving upwards.

pros: Great team member support, super supportive retail team, great managers! WF cared about my career growth, and my manager was constantly talking with me about my career growth within the company and my overall career growth as well. But we had a great store!
cons: Goals can be a little unrealistic, and compensation and bonuses are not worth it. Things are not looking great for the company right now though with all the negative publicity. And unfortunately, retail team members are the ones who will bear the brunt of it.

pros:
Come in a set time, do the same process over and over and over.
I learned a little bit about the back end of mortgage process.
Management was decent
Co workers were nice but everyone was doing their work so didn't communicate much.
Hardest part is doing the same thing over and over can be repetitive.
Most enjoyable part is probably the meetings and events at work. good time to connect with everyone and see where everyone is at.
cons: .When I started as a teller, the management was amazing, they treated you like family, drove you to succeed, and encouraged you to be your best. After a little while, they moved on and a new manager moved in, the attitude changed drastically. And it was well known that our positions were not secure, it became more a matter of making "numbers" and less about taking care of people, being reminded that "HR" has already been spoken to and confirmed that we could be removed for not making "numbers" was a definite drawback.

pros: When I worked there, the comps were pretty good! The environment was really great and the team of people were really good people. WF hires great people.
cons: I've heard that they have gotten rid of incentives for tellers which is a super bummer! I know since the lawsuit things haven't been the same. It sucks, Wells Fargo creates sales goals that are just way too high which I feel is what led to the lawsuit!

review_title: Great company with pros and cons
pros: The culture has shifted in the branch with sales goals being eliminated. There is no pressure to sell which has led to the job to be less stressful. Great benefits and the team member checking account and discounts are awesome. I love the resources and tools we have to ensure we get the job done properly.
cons: With sales goals being gone it has led for complacency amongst team members. When customers come in to open accounts bankers will often avoid them. There is also a lot of politics within the company which can make it difficult for some to move up. I have also noticed segmentation not being practiced to well. Branch managers have a tendency to never be at the branch also.

review_title: Wells Fargo is a great company but be careful in which divison you apply for work.
pros: The benefits are good, and when the economy is good there are lots of little bonuses and parties thrown for employees.
cons: Currently there is no room for growth. The current economy has completed stopped the growth within the Corporate Trust divison of Wells Fargo. The management has made questionable decisions about it's expectations for future business. When there was rapid growth from 2004-2006 the hiring standards were lowered in order to get people in the company to run the new business. This has allowed for a number of employees of questionable quality.

review_title: Have no self esteem? Work at Wells!
job_title: Registered Personal Banker in Los Angeles, CA
pros: If you enjoy being micro managed and constantly being threatened of getting fired, then this is the place for you!
cons: Promotion discrimination. Not knowing your work schedule in advance. Working sometime 15 days straight without a day off. Being cheated on overtime. Yelled at for no reason. Too many reasons to list here.  Sadly the company has no guts to fire an employee so the person gets bounced around to various departments bringing their incompetence to each new department.  Is this such a reputable company that when an employee gives 2 week notice of leaving to the mgr, the next day the employee is escorted out of the building by police officers in front of all employees to see implying that the individual is guilty of a crime. This is how the company respects its employees?

review_title: great company to work for but the sales is very pushy sometime to much of a burden on one.
job_title: Personal Banker I in Vista, CA
pros: great pay for the type for the amount of work done. must be very self motivated to do your own work. and not mind when you have managers telling you to push your sales and push you to work. The benefits you receive with wells are great along with the teams you work with. tellers can start from 10 and have seen up to 14. bankers can make from 30k to 42k depending on how hard you work for your money.
cons: some of the down sides are the pressure you have on you at all times to hit your numbers. not a bad thing but when you dont make the min. easy to be written up and or just verbal to push you to do a better job.

review_title: Some managers have 2 sets of rules: 1 set that's unwritten for a chosen few and the other written set for the rest
pros: benefits, training, oppurtunity to learn and gain experience, good product mix.
cons: Subpar compensation,  high turnover, middle management arrogance, inconsistant processing, unfair treatment by managers to workers, inability to close loans on time

review_title: It's a great place for recent graduates or others looking to gain valuable experience.
pros: The pay is good compared to other companies, you gain a lot of experience in a short period of time, if you have a good team or group that you work with, coming to work in the AM is not so bad.
cons: The company hires during peak times in the mortgage industry and the amount of training you receive is laughable.  If you are ok with on the job learning you'll be fine, but many people just aren't prepared for it and end up quitting very quickly.  Lots of turnover.  If you want to move on or up in the company it is very very very tough.

review_title: Good if you like it slow
job_title: Strategic Planning Consultant III in Minneapolis, MN
pros: If you're in a staff position, you won't have to work too hard after you've been here for a while.  They're very flexible about working from home or remotely.  Vacation benefits are good (and fantastic if you stay 10+ years and get 28 days a year!)  If you perform decently, job security is good.
cons: Pace is very slow and advancement is based on "years in the chair", which is becoming a stricter and stricter rule.  Low performers can be kept around for a long time and if you're a good performer, it won't necessarily be rewarded with pay or promotions.  There's absolutely no career planning (even for high performers), so it's a game of chance as to whether you get ahead.

pros: The people I work with, a flexible Manager who treats me like a human being.  Most of the time, hard work is rewarded.
cons: Little advancement once a certain level is reached.  Pay is not on par with industry peers.  Non-sales specific roles now have morphed into product pushers with annual sales goals.  Retain customers at all costs.  Unhappy, dismal, and overworked employees everywhere you look.     Take those people and ask them to do more.

pros: good benefits such as insurance and paid time off
cons: very high stressful job in sales and the attendance policies has been updated three times i the last 2 years does not give you room to miss if you have emergencies with family or yourself.  The sales process is very high in demand with Wells Fargo they want more yes than no even if the customer does not want anything need to ask why they dont want the service or product.  They let the customer talk ugly to their employees customer are rude that they know that wells fargo is not going to do anything to them.  Even if you get enought paid time off you can not use it when you need too!

pros: Banking hours and holiday's off with pay. Other benefits such as matching 401(k), vacation time/sick pay, tuition reimbursement. In the branch you create a family with both the employees and customers.
cons: People as a competitive advantage used to be something that Wells Fargo strive towards but it has gone more corporate and less caring from upper management outside of the branches. Service managers are the people in the branch running it a majority of the time and the pay is good but they are not fairly compensated for all they do.

review_title: Not bad but also not the greatest
pros: Wells Fargo was a great company for me to get into a more professional environment. I got great exposure learning about IRAs, yield savings, bonds, loans, banking laws, what to do in the event of a robbery, and building relationships with everyone you meet especially the locals and regulars. The company is very diverse and ranges in age. Overall, I made great friendships along the way and built a professional brand.
cons: The amount of time taken in order for you to move up. You have to be in your role for one year until you can move on to the next role. For example, you have to be a teller for one year in order to become a lead teller and so on. Also, the jobs has you standing for a long time depending if it gets ready busy.

review_title: Great benefits and pay, job security not what it once was
pros: The company offers great benefits and fair pay. I was with the company for a very long time and had an overall positive experience. In general I felt well taken care of and had excellent managers and coworkers. I would still be there if my position had not been moved to another state, but unfortunately myself and dozens of other employees at the location were displaced.
cons: It feels as though job security is on the decline at Wells Fargo. In some regards that is due to a lack of demand and thus lack of work for certain positions, but in many cases it is also due to the company looking to save money and turn an even bigger profit, and perhaps make up for fines and penalties. Another downside would be that the company is often in the news for negative reasons and it could sometimes feel embarrassing to be associated with them.

review_title: Rewarding, sales driven, and room to advance
pros: Helping make a difference with customers, great training, leadership encourages advancing within the company which is a strong benefit to working at Wells Fargo, great benefits- including health, dental, vision, 401K, and vacation time. Bonus compensation for meeting sales and customer service goals,. Both sales and customer service driven. Great work environment- good coworkers and great managers. Frequent recognition, praise from peers and management, cooperation between departments.
cons: Focus on sales can be intimidating to people who don't stay internally motivated- even though the sales structure is laid out clearly I see many employees that get overwhelmed, burned out, or really frustrated because they are not meeting goals. Working Saturdays, usually alternating Saturdays, is often a deterrent to retaining good employees.

review_title: overall a pretty good place to work
pros: biggest advantage of working at a big bank like Wells Fargo is the opportunity for advancement.  There are a lot of different ways to branch off from your starting position and the money can be good if you become an expert in your field. WF is a stable and profitable company which is a good bank to invest in (stock sharing plan).
cons: Although you can overcome this disadvantage through working much harder, employees placed in busy areas have a much easier time hitting bonuses and moving up.  Also, customer "shops" are graded unfairly.  If a customer gives an employee just one 4 out of 5 on any question it is received as a "bad shop."  Also, there are a lot of unethical bankers that get away with way too much.

review_title: I loved working for the company.
pros: During my time with Wells Fargo in various positions in Phoenix, AZ spanning over 6 years, I enjoyed working for the company. I did not enjoy working for the managers who elected to be mean, spiteful and hateful for no other reason than them hating their own life. The facilities were clean, great and they offered amazing benefits with paid volunteer time off after. Wells really believes in diversity-if only their managers would buy into it....
cons: This is a for profit company so time is money. Period. Some managers chose to care for their employees to get the best out of them...majority of the ones I had did not. They were money/revenue driven people. I worked in operations/retail and other departments. The problem is once you make it to manager-people stop demanding you to be respectful to others.

pros: Vacation/PTO is very reasonable (1-2 years: 2 weeks; 3-10 years: 3 weeks; 10+ years: 4 weeks; plus sick time was in the PTO bank and could be used for vacation).  The pay is reasonable and fair, plus many departments had a bonus structure.  There is a lot of room for advancement and management will try to make things more relaxed and fun when they can (i.e. employee appreciation days, lunches paid for, etc.)
cons: As with most corporate companies, upper management can sometimes be too far removed to fully understand some of the issues.  Some systems could have been better; often new releases weren't tested well and had a lot of bugs to work out.

pros: You definitely learn a lot. Great teamwork, customer interactions, and solution-based communication skills are developed. Good training provided.
cons: Sales sales sales! That's all it's about. They try to play it off like they look out for what's best for you as an employee but in reality all they care about is keeping up with sales. Also, they script your interactions with customers. There's literally a certain outline you need to follow when helping a customer that obviously leads a service-based need to a sales-based need. Some customers just want to come in get what they expected done and leave, they don't want to be sold to!

pros: Company is a great brand name.  Made me feel proud to wear their badge outside of work.  All supervisors that I had to report to were pretty much good listeners and shows that they care.
cons: Not much training after you get out of the new hire class.  They just give you a piece of paper or send you an email to notify you of and changes.  Most of the time (I mean like 90% of the time) you have to study these changes in between phone calls.

job_title: Trust Team Manager in Clemmons, NC
pros: I haven't managed my career very well, and was mostly comfortable for 16 years in a job that I liked.  We had a low ratio of managers to supervisors and team members, and this balanced the leadership responsibilities in our group.  Our annual business cycle allowed us to take time off, complete training and work 40-hour weeks for most of the year. Your opportunities are limited by your interest in developing and accepting more responsibilities. If you don't want to take responsibility for your growth, don't expect recognition or rewards.
cons: We work in a highly-regulated industry and the necessary compliance work is repeated on a frequent schedule. We put the customer first, but customers have many "asks" to which we cannot say yes.

review_title: Great place to work, exciting time to work there
job_title: E-Business Consultant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Working at Wells Fargo has a variety of benefits, top ones being work-life balance and a team that feels more like a family. Wells offers generous training opportunities, market salary, and an opportunity to work for an organization that most American households know and use. Another top benefit is that the bank really leaves it up to the individual to craft her/his own career path. If you are driven and contribute effectively, you will have a very good opportunity to advance in your career.
cons: Since the acquisition of Wachovia Bank (2008), some organizations within the bank have been adversely affected by internal politics and posturing. The internal frustration continues today (2016). As with many big companies, this leads to internal frustration, half-baked ideas, projects that go through multiple iterations only to be retired, and sub-par delivery of some objectives.

review_title: A Great Place to Work But Ruins by Dysfunctional Management
pros: Wells Fargo has a good reputation. Offer great benefits (PTO, Medical, 401k retirement, etc). I worked with some very smart people who are also some of my closest friends.
cons: Company culture is too focus on "what have you done for me lately". Client retention is irrelevant unless accompanied with strong sales, especially in the Chicago office. As a specialist, even though sales in supposed to be 25% of your scorecard, it's not treated as such. Market Director manages by spreadsheet and has no management skill of staff, and essentially creates revolving door at office. Not many staff members stick around more than 4 years. Too much subtle favoritism, sexism and racism take place.

review_title: Avoid the TMT Group - especially in New York City
job_title: Investment Banking Associate in New York, NY
pros: As you can expect they have some smart analyst, some of the VPs are nice, and Directors were good as well.
cons:
This is one shop you should avoid at all cost if you just got an offer coming out of undergrad or business school. The head of the group uses fear to 'motivate' people and belittles people due to his own insecurities - you won't see that while they try to sell you on the company. 

 Many people have quit or changed groups to avoid him; even his most senior staff need to pretend to get along with him.  There are a couple of people that because they're good at their job, they keep them around but are horrible to work with (Fin-Tech). Run for the hills. This place will give you PTSD if you stay too long.  Experienced some dislike and I assume it's because of my cultural background. They hire lots of wealthy conservative southern white men who haven't had many interactions with people from diverse backgrounds. Take that as you will.

review_title: Contractors are relied upon but treated like trash
pros: If you're able to get a full-time gig, you are, apparently, in for life. Bagels on Fridays. Unlimited soft drinks (if you care about such things).
cons: The "pro" I've described here is a positive if you are the sedentary professional type; a big negative if you must work with these sedentary types and have ambition and skill, and prefer to be rewarded for performance rather than longevity. And, in particular, if you are a contractor. The full-time staff fully relies upon the experience and drive of the contractor fleet, yet very reluctantly offers praise or credit for these individuals. Turnover amongst contractors is very high, and it's obvious why.

review_title: Mix of some good and a lot of bad
pros: Great benefits, great opportunity for advancement for the most part if you work hard. A lot of good people to work with and great opportunity to network yourself. Lot's of vacation time if you stick around long enough. The chance to actually help clients financially the right way.
cons: Very high turnover, unrealistic sales goals, micromanagement, management with no clue. Most of them got to where they are by using unethical sales tactics. The most unethical employees are usually the ones you see get promoted due to their ridiculous sales numbers. Many give the company a bad name by taking advantage of clients and putting them in products that benefit the employee rather than the client.

review_title: It was the best of times, it was the worst of times..
pros: It's INCREDIBLY laid back (at least at my branch). I work in a motorbank branch. We mainly do drive up banking but we also have a small lobby and our main lobby branch is up the hill a parking lot away. Lot's of recognition and appreciation. Good hours.
cons:
The pay is FAR below what they could afford to pay us, since it's the biggest bank in the country.
There are sales incentives but working at a drive up they are impossible to attain. 
I make 500 every 2 weeks working about 35 hours. 
The products we offer are old and boring, and everyone already has at least some form of them.
We have to send 4 ARTS (sales referrals) a day minimum, and if you don't they will nag and nag the hell out of you until you do.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Charlotte, NC
pros: Wells Fargo is sytematically and thoughtfully moving up the league tables in investment banking, capital markets, and sales and trading.  Because of this, the company is hiring while the rest of the street is downsizing.  This provides opportunities to quickly move  up and gain responsibilities faster than at other firms.
cons: The company may seem a little slow to adopt the latest technology.  Additionally, the company is risk adverse (which is good for stability of the firm but bad for short term profit).  This can be aggravating as the corporate bank may not use its balance sheet as much as it could, the investment bank may not seek out some high profile deals, and the traders can't take as much risk.

review_title: Good pay, but a lot of stress, if your branch bankers are garbage your life will be hell
pros: Good hourly pay, and benefits.
cons: Very demanding sales bank, managerial staff can be stressful, push products and services on people that have no use for them. ex. 86 year old woman what business does she have with a credit card. Very young and uneducated managers who are looking to build there own careers, thus not caring about helping there staff advance to leadership roles. NO OVERTIME available.

review_title: Will it let me give them 0 stars??
pros: After five minutes of sitting here trying to think of ANY pro... I came up with nothing.  Literally not one pro.
cons: Where do I begin?  The rumors you have heard of Wells Fargo being a greedy, scandalous and manipulative company are true.  I worked as a Personal Banker but could no longer sell my soul to sell a few credit cards. SELL, SELL, SELL.... Branch Managers and District Managers will pressure you do to do anything you can to sell an extra checking account or credit card or loan or any dang product they can. They tell you it's either your job or sales.  This is what caused Bankers to open authorized accounts.  Just google Wells Fargo lawsuits and you'll see.

pros:
Lot of great people. 
In general, a great company, Nice to work for a company that has a solid business model, relatively conservative which enabled it to stand out during the crisis that hit many other financial institutions in 2008-2010.
Company tries to build a positive culture, cares about its people, big on diversity, etc.
Company is so large, that everyone's experience will be a little different.
cons:
Lot of politics. Probably not very different from most other companies of this size, but having worked for mostly small companies before, I was amazed at the amount of politics.  To get anything done would involve 10-15 teams. Numerous meetings are necessary so everyone can have their say. Folks were always positioning for ways to promote themselves and their group. If anything went wrong, folks were trying to look for someone/group to point the finger at.
Used to small companies where it felt like everyone was on the same team.
Good preparation for a career in politics.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Graham, NC
pros: You have tons of resources available to you to help make sure you can do your job. Get the chance to help people better understand their own finances and their options.
cons: Sales commissions are laughable at the bottom tier. Top tier commissions look good but hard to obtain. Now all of that has changed and not sure what commission is based on at this point.

review_title: Digital and Automated Investing Solutions advisor
pros: If you have no experience in brokerage and you want to get your series 7 66 this is one of the best entry level jobs you can get. I am greatful for the opportunity I was given, I learned so much in this job and met some amazing people.
cons: After about a year you pretty much get what you can out of this job, unless you want to be a senior advisor or management, 40 calls a day, much of your dialogue is scripted, which is great if you've never done advising before but after about 6 months it gets dull. operations is a pain, your requests and forms will get rejected multiple times, lots of red tape.

review_title: Wells Fargo Advisors-Gainey Ranch Scottsdale, Arizona
job_title: Registered Client Associate in Scottsdale, AZ
pros: Free wholesaler breakfasts and lunches on average 3 days per week.
cons: No career advancement and management is only concerned about revenue producing personnel; not those that support them.

review_title: Good company going through a lot of change
job_title: Senior Vice President, Strategic Planning Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good people. Supportive encouraging culture. Good work/life balance. Opportunity to move across different units of the company. Very sad that a few bad apples at senior level have brought so much reputational damage.
cons: Can be slow and difficult to drive decisions, get agreement and get things done. Huge size means too many people want a say in every decision, and hard to find the person who can actually green light decisions. Accountability is not clear.  Massive change both internally driven and regulatory, makes it hard to get things done and hard to see all the initiatives that may influence your projects. Easy to be there a long time and let your network externally slide. A lot of hiring is moving out of the SF Bay Area to MPLS and CLT.

pros: I met wonderful customers and the workers were amazing.
cons: 50 hours 6 days a week open to hour or 2 after close. Absolutely no sitting down unless you're on your 30 min lunch. Other tellers were always getting into my conversations with my customers while they were busy with their own. When team leads didn't know what they were doing and messed up they'd fine a way to blame you in front of a customer.

pros: Wells Fargo has got some great core values.  For example, they believe in making their employees happy because then they will treat the customers well.  They use surveys to help management know how employees are feeling about their work.  They are very active in donating to and helping out local communities.  The employees themselves are dedicated to their work.
cons: Management doesn't always follow their own core values.  Rather than listening to the surveys, they get everyone to answer them correctly.  Some groups are populated predominently by a single sex, so there may be some preferential hiring.  There is no central technical group of any significance, so different departments have their own support with different standards.  Little coordination.  Many of their systems are outdated and their management/employees have no interest in keeping up with current technology and practices.

pros: Usually if you do good they will buy your team lunches, also if you are lucky you can go on all expenses business/training trips. I was a teller and collector and got to go for a weekend training trip.
cons: Rules, policies, procedures CONSTANTLY changing, sales goals are out of this work too high, youare put under amicroscope if you arent doing good even if you are new. stress very high. Wells Fargo is not about the customer, they are about making and saving money. They treat the customers awful, screw them out of money, then turn around a give all their employees personalized bags of wells fargo m&m's. wtf what a waste of money i would rather they not give me this candy and make the customers happy so i dont get yelled at all day.

job_title: Personal Banker I in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Benefits
PTO Time
6% 401k Match After a Year of Employment
Work Hard = Promotion
Awesome Co-Workers & Training
Salary is Competitive
cons:
Constant, Aggressive, Unrealistic Sales Goals (on the contrary, if you are into aggressive sales, then this job is definitely something you should get into—it’s a good company) 
System is Flawed: Success is Focused More So On Number of Accounts/Solutions and Not on New $$
High Turnover Rate

review_title: "Every day I'm happy to go to work"
pros:
Good employees always seem to get good opportunities for advancement. Most of the people I know to complain have been ones that were terrible at their jobs and didn't understand how business works.

Upper management really recognizes hard workers, there are frequent district/region wide Recognition conference calls that all of the stores dial into to listen and get recognized.

REALLY big emphasis on being a "Team" which actually seems to work out pretty well (But there are a couple of places I know that have a bad manager that doesn't exactly contribute to the "team").
cons:
I feel like a lot of information is kept secret the lower you are on the totem pole, I guess that is to be expected with a huge corporation. 
Some of the bad workers some how still have jobs which limits the advancement of hard workers.

Upper management has a report for EVERYTHING, they can sometimes micromanage too much.

review_title: Pb and Pb2 review: If you can survive here you can excel anywhere else!
job_title: Personal Banker and Premier Banker II
pros: You learn to sell like nobody's business. There are a lot of groups within the company in case retail doesn't work out. Quarterly bonuses.
cons: No sense of satisfaction or security. Constant stress and ridiculous sales goals. Unethical practices are encouraged but also punished..its hard to distinguish where the line is. If you find another area of the bank you would like to work for, good luck getting in. Very few people are happy as a retail banker. Even the ones producing the most are just trying to get out.

review_title: The job is still time conducive, however the industry is merging into mainstream retail micro-managing.
pros: Hours and holidays are good. I came from a retail background where we had to shuffle actual product. At least in banking you are providing one service and you dont have to worry about setting up a clearance rack every quarter.
cons: Widget counters. The micro-management places a high level of stress on the entire team. However, it seems we are no longer hiring service professionals but rather people who can ACE an interview. The professionalism in the branches goes from the extreme to the nill.

review_title: Unless you have the golden ticket -- don't apply
pros: The training is comprehensivet.  However...
cons:
(1) The people that are training you to become a financial advisor are people that have failed at the profession.  Your branch manager plays such a huge part in your success or failure and it seems to be by chance whether or not the manager is any good.  My manager is more of an impediment than any help.

(2) Anyone can make it as a financial advisor if they can last five years in the business.  however, the compensation structure is such that most people will be unable to make it past two years.  If you have a giant nest egg, this could be a great choice.  But most of us do not and 4 percent of advisors will last past four years.

review_title: very much a fortune 500 large company
pros: great people, a lot of information to learn, and never a dull moment
cons: You are number to them. Management have they favorites, and if you are not one of them, you are out of luck.  Lower leveled managers and middle management have little to no power to do anything to make changes in the department, often giving you "by the book answers" such as "this is just how it is", or "we are doing this because our peers are doing this" "this is industry standard" . If it is not an idea that they come up with, they like to shoot you down. Management is not caring about real life/work balance life. They only care about statistics so that they can win year awards. They love to spread around how they are breaking yearly sales goals, but can't afford to give better benefits or raises.

review_title: If your manager sucks so will your career at Wells Fargo
job_title: Customer Sales and Service Representative in Tampa, FL
pros: You really get a chance to help people financially and network. My co workers have always been so friendly and I've worked at 3 different branches. You can be promoted very fast if you have the drive!!! I've have 2 promotions in 2 years!!! Very Gay Friendly!!!
cons: High sales goal that change every year once people start reaching them. Management often promoted way too fast, most don't even know what they are doing. They are very much on the good ol' boy system, suck up enough and you will be a store manager in as little as a year. I seen one guy who was there 4 months longer then me get promoted to manger in 1 1/2 year. That was after the other 3 promotions he received. Lots of favoritism in this company!!!

review_title: Great place for people who want to work in one place, never move, and have balance
job_title: Vice President of Product Management in San Francisco, CA
pros: Most areas & managers allow flexible working hours and locations.  Good time off benefits, 50% 401K matching and other small perks.  Lots of "lifers" - people who have been here 10 - 25 years.
cons: Over the last 5 years the company has been whittling away at the perks and benefits - no more subsidized food, less PTO, smaller merit increases, reduced space per employee - it's not as nice a place to work at as it used to be. Because so many people never leave, there's a bit of an incestuousness to the culture; many people are desensitized to the Wells culture because they've never really worked anywhere else.

review_title: Transferring is impossible, company cares about nothing but sales
pros:
Paid Time Off
Worry free on your banking
Decent compensation for sales
401(K)
Okay Pay
CEO who cares
cons:
All the company cares for is sales
Sales sales sales, you dont have sales you don't have a future
Company moving toward more sales focus which changing customer service rating
Company refuses to look at big picture
Extremely difficult to transfer - Management looks at 1 factor, sales. Nothing to do with the situation

review_title: Take a Ride on the Wells Fargo Wagon... not always a smooth ride but it will get you somewhere
job_title: Personal Banker II – Registered in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Growth potential. It is a large bank with a lot of opportunity for growth if you push for it.  I have been really greatful for the lincensing program. Wells Fargo will pay you full time and pay for and provide your financial licensing tests and study materials. You study on company time unlike many other financial institutions that will pay for your materials and tests but you need to study on your own time.
cons: Sometimes the goals can be a bit overwhelming and the "Perfect 5" requirement for customer service surveys just seems a bit unrealistic.  At times the goals and the process can get in the way of real connections with the customers.

review_title: Great company to work for but pay is not the best.
pros: You control your own destiny based on your sales performance. Great to work for a company that encourages career growth. You can move up quickly in the company if you're motivated and hit your sales goals. You are compensated sales and service bonus's when you reach your goals. Great benefits including medical, dental, vision etc. Paid vacation and sick days. Offer 401K plan. Great training. You generally meet and work with great people.
cons: Pay could be better. Pressure to sale can be overwhelming at times. Sales goals can be difficult to obtain. Micro management often occurs. Company over emphasizes providing customer service. Certain managers fail to develop their team members. Work environment can be cut throat at times because of the aggression to achieve sales goals

pros:
Work good hours for the most part 
Stressful 
Online sales pretty much sale the product to em before they sit the customer down 
Being short can be easily done by a small mistake so you got to focused Wells Fargo is really big on customer service like the most important thing then comes solutions we get payed out for having surveys getting all 5s
cons: Not worth it for the pay 12dollars a banker would be easier less stress you still got to meet number as a banker or teller Essenitally at least hit silver I still got a whole month and I hit silver already so if you can sale you'll be fine but I recommend go for banker and just jump in stressful to be a teller cash handling processing these transaction is not like being on a cash register

pros: Great employment role support, latest technology for personal benefits management and for employment role, marketing aids and support, open communication with support staff, and strong benefit menu and offerings.
cons: Growing political dimension to organizational culture affects communication (and employment execution), as it impacts communication between producers and their supervisors.  There is also a strong hierarchical element that impedes communication and serving customers. Protocol demands, impede effectiveness.  Wells does a poor job recognizing the value of people and facilitating their movement for the better of the company.

job_title: Part Time Teller in Houston, TX
pros: They located in many places if need for a transfer.
cons: They don't offer bonuses for employers who reach sale goals but the store itself fail to reach high score. With that being sale after all the hard work a teller put in they want get paid.  Lobby of the bank stay open until six.  During the time change its dark outside and threat bring on a tease with in the bank especially during the holidays.

pros: Decent benefits/PTO, one year contracts mean you can move around to different departments pretty easily - you won't find upward growth in your department but if you look at different departments there's good opportunities to move around/up
cons: Management isn't open with employees. Rules change constantly but it's not company wide - they enact department rules that they'll refuse to put in writing and that means HR can't help you with anything because no one knows what the policies are. Turnover is pretty high - it's really hard to fire underperforming "team members" so there is a constant rotation of department hoppers managing to last a year in their current role and then moving on.

review_title: Depending on location, can be a fairly good employer
pros: Work-life balance, set hours, only had to stay for meetings after work maybe once every two months. Very good group of people in my office, truly fantastic colleagues - but that can depend on the team. I had 3 managers in my 4 years of employment there, which was a bit unusual, each one took a little getting used to, but all three were basically good and decent, I worked in other places where manager were toxic and created a very stressful environment, this was not the case at all. Benefits were good; lots of opportunities for advancement
cons: It's a very hardcore sales driven organization - if you can be OK with that, you'll do well. The pay is not fantastic, and you have to work there long enough to where you get at least an acceptable amount of vacation time.

job_title: Home Preservation Specialist in San Antonio, TX
pros: Due to all new polices changes very little pros. The company has great benefits and advancements after your 1 year. Employee discount are good this is a great company to work for but this department us horrible.
cons: All always on a phone que, you will have to manage files from 80-120. Manager always have attitudes if you have any questions they except you to know everythinh as soon as you come out of training there always new update that they will not cover for you. Your manager will not fight for you if you ever wrong. They will make you feel like crap all the time. All the manager will always go out to eat and take 2-3 lunches on the p-card but never have a budget for us they took away pur monthly bonuses while all the other department lower than us make monthly bonuses. If you like to feel like crap all the time and you want to hate your job this is the one for you.

pros: NOTHING. Save yourself the headache and work at a more respectable bank. This place is a madhouse who has a habit of treating its employees badly.
cons: The sales goals were terrible. Make all the customers open up new accounts so they can't keep track of the fees was essentially the Wells Fargo way. Oh and on top of that you're responsible for a large amount of cash and keeping your customers happy. If you got less than 5 stars on any customer service survey you failed the survey. Even if they left a comment saying, "The teller I worked with was awesome. The scores on this survey are to complain about an interaction I had with another teller at a different branch." Exhausting job and they do not pay for what they want you to do.

review_title: Great benefits and flexible working environment but little opportunity to advance
job_title: Business Systems Consultant in Denver, CO
pros: 401(k), Personal Time Off, tuition reimbursement, work from home 2 days per week, excellent benefits.
cons: There are few opportunities to get a management position or to advance your career. The company has 270K employees and is trying to reduce the workforce. The work environment is negatively impacted by the recent scandals and failure to pass the stress test. They will be closing 1000's of branches in the next few years. Management is unaccountable to anyone. If you have a bad manager or bad senior management in your organization, make a move to somewhere else in the bank because executive management won't do anything about it. The big company environment can be stifling and doesn't create an environment for taking the initiative. Surprisingly, in the IT group that I worked in, they don't use the latest technology or software applications.

review_title: Do you really care about keeping good people?
job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Rancho Cordova, CA
pros: Benefits, Holidays off, PTO and that's it
cons: Executive team only cares about themselves. Will cut anyone anytime to save a buck to increase the stock price and their pay. Everyone feels like it could be their time every day. They also aren't big fans of hiring from within the company across departments, and if it is your department they probably have someone picked so you're out and won't even get an interview. That's if they even list the job when it opens. They'll probably just add it to someone's plate and not pay them more. Seen it happen too many times.

pros: The benefits are very good, 19 days of paid time off are given right away which can be used for vacation, illness, or personal reasons.  Medical, dental, and vision benefits are available after one month of work.  On the retail end, the teller and lead teller job paid more than smaller banks.  They offer tuition reimbursement up to $5,000/year for full time employees and offer up to a 6% match on the 401K after working a year.
cons: The retail jobs are mainly sales-focused and you cannot get promoted unless you make the sales goals, which are hard to achieve for some who do not like to be pushy.  The company policy is to not tolerate gaming but it is hard to prevent when the performance of teller and bankers make managers look good to their management.

pros: I have been at Wells Fargo for 13 years.  I am sure I could have left for another organization for more pay, prestige, etc.  But Wells Fargo is a strong organization that treats it's people well.  The benefits are amazing, so much so that I have not found another employer that can compete.  As you get older you calue these things more.  I am proud of where I work, and barring unforseen circumstances will be here for the long haul.
cons: It's a massive organization, it is easy to get lost in the shuffle and getting even the most simple question answered can be a challenge.  Once you learn how to navigate this becomes less of an issue over time.

review_title: Leadership and accountability should be added to the mission statement (Fort Mill, SC).
job_title: Loan Adjuster/Adjuster in Fort Mill, SC
pros: Sideward mobility if a dept is downsized. So many different positions to apply for. Its a company that has so much more potential only if they can put true leaders in the management roles.
cons:
First and foremost......management! There is such a HUGE disconnect in leadership, process and flow. Just add "specialize in passing the buck" and "majored in deflection and avoidance" to your resume for a sure management role in this company. 
Second- Benefits are subpar.
Last but not least...grammar on phone calls and in emails needs a serious overhaul. I wont have enough room to go into depth, but its time to add hooked on phonics to the employee discount page.

pros: Wells Fargo Home Mortgage is very supportive in theory to its sales personnel.  The problem is that there are some lags in communication between sales and fulfillment.  The fulfillment sites need to recognize that they are there for the sales force - without which they would not have a job - it felt like puling teeth to get anything to closing.
cons: Wells Fargo Home Mortgage is very supportive in theory to its sales personnel.  The problem is that there are some lags in communication between sales and fulfillment.  The fulfillment sites need to recognize that they are there for the sales force - without which they would not have a job - it felt like puling teeth to get anything to closing. Now with government involvement in ridiculous regulations, which Wells is very aggressive in implementing so they have it "down" early, the mortgage industry is becoming very different and difficult.

review_title: I love what I do, but not the company due to sales push
pros:
Career advancement
Decent pay
would be good company if they focused on employee satisfaction and not so much on selling
cons:
Never satisfied, always want more
No JOB SECURITY IF YOU DO NOT SELL SELL SELL
Heavy push on sales and not service
sales, sales, sales, and more sales
Incompetent management
micromanagement
says they focus on service, but that is not the case. all they care about is referrals and sales solutions

pros: They like to hire from within and you don't need a college education to succeed. Great benefit package and insurance. Some of the people you meet are fantastic. The customers you work with are sometimes the best part of the day.
cons: Says they are family friendly, but get VERY angry if you need time off to care for sick child. Hours aren't good if you have family. Very cut throat environment where numbers are looked at and you are analyzed a couple of times throughout the day. If you enjoy being micro-managed then this is the job for you. You are constantly being watched and graded for your interactions.

review_title: A terrible work experience full of ethical problems, poor pay, and micromanagement.
pros: The only positive things worth mentioning are the free bank accounts available to employees. But these same types of accounts can be found for free at other, far better banks.
cons:
- Encouraged to engage in extremely high-pressure sales tactics. The mantra was always "The customers don't know what they need. Show them what they need." We were pressured to sell at least two checking accounts and two savings accounts, among several other products, to each customer who walked in the door. Sales tactics were always skirting the bounds of ethical behavior. 
- Low pay; nearly impossible sales goals meant that the small bonuses were rarely actually available to the majority of bankers who found themselves in slow branches. 
- Very high level of micromanagement; there was no room to stray from the sales model. Regular customers had to be subjected to the same canned sales model every time I met with them, even if they were only there for a routine issue. This kind of forced behavior often prohibited me from developing relationships built on trust and the feeling that I understood the customers' needs.

pros: Excellent Facility..thats the only saving grace
cons: Salaries...In this age of ever increasing prices your salary is very very less..salaries only for IT is good...operations salaries are the worst..peanuts are better than the salaries..Work culture is you butter your higher level you will get anything you want..HR does nothing just listens to you and is back at ignoring your concerns...Employees are treated like bonded labourers

review_title: It was a great place to work when I started but sadly not so much anymore.
job_title: Web Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: They do have good benefits although they continue to degrade a little every year. Good 401k match.
cons: The culture has greatly changed since I started at Wells Fargo. The culture has changed because their are department who's employee's mostly consist of one particular culture. It used to be much more diverse but the scope is getting smaller and smaller.

pros:
Flexible working hours, okay working environment depending the manager management style and leads leadership style.

PTO time are great, increase each mileston! Offers 18 hours of paid volunteer time and paid corporate holiday time = standard holiday plus Veterans day and MLK day
cons:
no room for advancement, you have to applying for other position to be "promoted" to move up the chain and if you do apply, the waiting time to hear something back takes a long time. Achieving production #'s could cause a rift in work relationship.

Sometimes upper management take credit for the ideas/suggestion you put in place for implemented, little to no credit given.

Career development opportunities are slim.. Benefit decrease and cost increase

Compensation does not match up to the level/type of work you have to do. We work on complex loan and don't get commission or bonus like 75% of the company.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Wells Fargo has an amazing culture of professional development. I've worked for WF for about 10 years and have been fortunate enough to get promoted 7 times. All of my manager's have been my advocate and really pushed for my personal and professional development. This is due to the culture that WF has created around team member development. 

WF's commitment to diversity and inclusion is great as well. They promote hiring diverse candidates and have so many outlets for their employees to network with other employees of similar backgrounds and affinities. 

Benefits here are second to none!
cons: The only negative thing I have to say about Wells Fargo is that their salaries are not competitive with today's marketplace. I know banks need to watch their expenses to maximize profits for shareholders. With so many companies like Google and Facebook offering such high salaries I don't feel like WF is missing out on some quality candidates by lowballing the salaries.

review_title: Not the worst, but definitely not the best
pros:
The people I work with are all really good people. Its the best part of my job. 

Also, it seems the company has finally decided to pay employees a competitive wage.
cons:
Though the company has increased many salaries to be compete with other institutions, you can only obtain this higher pay if you are promoted. without being promoted, you'll receive the minimal annual merit increase. 

I've heard it is different at other locations, but the atmosphere is toxic. The unhappy employees easily outnumber happy employees. In my experience, much of lower management, shows little respect for employees. The longer its allowed to happen, the more it spreads and it gradually becomes the norm.

pros: Transport  is free, infrastructure,Hikes (if you are lucky),brand name
cons:
*Office politics,completly Telugu dominated,if ur not from that part,very difficult to get anything here 
*Very minimal exposure of new technologies,all legacy and most of the projects are mainataince.
*Quality of work is not up to the mark,we only get what US people are bored of doing.
*They say u can change ur project within company (IJP) after 18 months ,but it is close to impossible without knowing the manager.
*Attrition rate is high since many good resources are leaving the company 
*Earlier the hikes were transperant without much manager intervention,now it all depends on manager.So Buttering matters a lot.
*Now, Wells Fargo is just like any other service based without Onsite
*Not much work in most of the teams ,you can see people playing carrom,chess,foosball even at 10am in the morning everyday.
