review_title: this is a great company to work for just be very careful with the mistake you do because it can cause you your job.
pros: advancement opportunities, great benefits medical, vision & dental, tuition reimbursement, employee discount, and most importantly sales bonuses. I would recommend this job for college students, they can work with your school schedule, they are very flexible with school schedule.
cons: there is any reason to be fired so be very careful anything can cause you your  job. From being out of balance or "gaming " meaning cheating about the sales you actually made to being terminated from being late to work.

review_title: Great stepping stone, can be a career if you are willing to step over people.
job_title: Commercial Loan Officer in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Name brand recognition.  Looks great on the resume.  If you are a salaried employee...you get a ton of vacation time...though you'd probably take a fraction of it.
cons: Cutthroat competitive at times, the ones that ultimatly succeed are the ones who's moral compass doesn't point in the correct direction, worked there 2 years and didn't get a performance review, very sales centric environment...but company is so conservative that you have divergent interests (book loans, but decline everything in sight?), when you tell people you work here...not many have a really positive impression of this place.

pros: WF offers pleasant work environment, decent benefits package, tuition reimbursement, and advancement opportunities as long as you meet their sales goals. they match 6 percent of your 401K contributions, which is kinda nice, but you'll be able to take their contribution with you (if you decide to leave) only after 5 years with them, which kinda sucks. it seems to be a stable company, so you'd have some kind of work security. i have no heard about anybody being laid off.
cons: sales, sales, sales! seems to be the main concern. of course, they mention customer service and all that, but sales dominate. the commissions seem to be a little low, given the emphasis on sales. and there is little check on sales quality. a lot of customers get screwed with accounts and services that they dont need (but give profit to the bankers)

pros: Set hours & mostly weekends off. Good pay & benefits. Good training. Alot of meetings break up work day. Fun co-workers.
cons: Micro-managed, too much! If have a great sales day, expected to always perform that good or better & then if don't meet these high expectations, have to have meetings on why you didn't perform that well. Often had to fill out sheet on what tactics you were going to use to be able to meet your goals better at beginning of shift. Too many one-on-one performance meetings, like weekly! These meetings were always about how you were going to get even more sales & your areas needing work on. Cold calling, inbound calls, outbound calls, using retention techniques & mostly grumpy customers calling in to complain about their rates or their bill.

pros:
-Good benefits.
-Management was good at the branch I was at.
cons: If you like an enviroment where someone higher than you is always making decisions for you and telling you what to do..,,,Then Wells Fargo Bank is your place.  After being there for 8 months I was fed up with all the red tape and not being allowed to do just the simplest things without having someones approval.  I don't know how many times I was cussed at by a customer because we where waiting for appoval on something from the manager....stuff that other banks just do automatically.  Took the job as a teller in order to advance to a loan officer in the future and after about 7 months was offer that position.  I wound up turning it down after I figured out a "personal banker" is not really a loan officer, but more of a glorified teller.  These guys can't make any decisions either!!!

review_title: Positive learning experience for better industry preparedness
job_title: Personal Banker I in Austin, TX
pros: 401k matching 1 to 1 upto 6%, great people to work around and very little monotony.  Most of the time there is a positive work environment.
cons: The high pressure for sales environment can eclipse the cultivation of a pure customer relationship experience.  The "revolving door" epidemic of employees will prove to be most costly to the bottomline and  ultimately prevent true customer relationship driven banking.  Also, the constant pressures for new accounts inhibits future acqusitions.  The entire month of January is "blacked out" for vacation times which sets a tone for what the company truly feels towards its employees.

review_title: Glad I worked there, glad I left.
pros: A flow of lead, customer base seems decent.    Corporate name.  Access to good size client base if you know how to milk it.  If you can be among the top 10% of loan officers and you can be kind of demanding about what you need, this can be a good gig for you.  With a national base you also can work in many states, and generally have most loan programs available to you
cons: Low BPS per loan relative to other sectors.  Doesn't seem to retain high quality processing and underwriting staff.  Improvements in the LOS seem to take forever - I think they are still not operating 100% with CORE.  Very little true teams:  A lot of individuals vying for their own best interests.

review_title: Game the system until you're promoted
job_title: Personal Banker in Fort Collins, CO
pros: The benefits package is very good, 6% match on the 401(k), good healthcare options.  They do tuition reimbursement and promote from within.
cons: Everything else.  In the Retail Banking world, you're incentivized to be dishonest to the customer by selling on half-truths and out-right lies.  The more you sell, the faster you're promoted.  The faster you're promoted, the faster you lose your soul.  Used car salespeople get a bad rap but they're nothing compared to your local Wells Fargo Personal Banker; especially if they have more than 6 months of tenure.  Don't touch this company with a 10-foot pole!

review_title: One of the big banks where you are inconsequential. Keep your head down and work, you will will never produce enough.
job_title: Loan Document Specialist in Tempe, AZ
pros: Guaranteed paycheck, structured HR policy to protect you from unscrupulous managers.  On average, people were nice, I just happened to have a manager that cared nothing about his employees, he cared about numbers.
cons:
WF hired 900 people and we were told we were going to be trained for our jobs, and although we attended a "training course"....training was quite an impressive spread btw, we were not taught how to do our jobs.   So we are all put on the floor not having a clue how to do our jobs, unless we had experience, which many did not.  Maybe they hired 900 people but they started firing people immediately.  If you are late...you're gone, its only a matter of time.   

You are pressured to produce outrageous numbers.  Opening unnecessary account's, selling unnecessary products in order to increase numbers and achieve goal.

How can we achieve our goals if we don't know how to do our jobs?

job_title: Operations Associate in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Parking is free, so far.
cons: Definately one of the BIG Wall Street Firms.  Profits are siphoned off by upper management in the form of bonuses, high salaries, plush offices and golden parachutes.  Uppermanagement is additionally priviledged to have there own Executive Dining Room for lunch.  The workers in Operations have no such perks.  Salary is at best just above poverty level.  You need a high salary just to have lunch in the caferteria!  Micromanagement is rampent all through the firm.  Two of the buildings on the St. Louis Campus are overcrowded, daily building maintenance is at best minimum, monthly sewer backups are a constant.  Technology has passed the company by.  The company preaches diversity and inclusion, but I have yet too see enviroment on campus.  To get ahead, it is who you know, not what you know.  Favoritisim is rampent all over the campus.

pros: Good salary and incentive compensation upside, and the ability to make goals from many different product sets. Big balance sheet to compete for large loans at below market pricing.
cons: Exceptionally weak regional management in the Silicon Valley hubs completely disinterested in employee empowerment or growing talent. Promotions are based on favoritism with very little accountability enforced other than on micromanaging daily sales on those not considered a favorite. Limited support internally on deals and the skill gap between bankers and their support is immense. Feels like kindergarten a lot of the time. Also, extensive internal competition exists among WF groups with similar product offerings along with less "real" credit appetite to support clients than is broadly known.

review_title: Great customer service across the board.
pros: There is always an emphasis on team work and they do absolutely everything in their power to make sure each team member feels at home at their branch. Team building events and rally's are so much fun! When you do a great job they reward a job well done. You will always feel proud of your accomplishments. You can easily transfer braches in your state or another.
cons: Very hard to move up. I feel that favoritism was always an issue while I worked with the company. Sales environment was very strict and they offered little to no help or direction on how to improve your sales. Quick employee turn over.

review_title: They do not even come close with comparing them to FORD CREDIT!
job_title: Senior Consumer Loan Underwriter III in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Good employees, benefits are good, excellent community involvement.  1 in 3 mortgages are initiated with Wells Fargo?
cons: Uneducated Management has issues.  They don't seem to care about employees, my direct Manager was listed on RIPOFF report for previously ripping off people in a different line of work?  How did she ever get cleared on background is beyond me.   After net quarters back to back of $5 Billion + they lay people off (thousands displaced) they brought on from other companies who had careers use them and disgard them like trash.  Unacceptable practice in my opinion.  Can name multiple examples of this.

review_title: Seems to be a changing atmosphere, like a pendulum
pros: Good benefits, adequate training, many online resources available.
cons: Once you get to store management, it becomes much more difficult to promote. The compensation isn't aligned well with the expectations. The company states they are working towards change, moving away from products, however employee goals do not reflect this change.

pros: Their PTO is the only thing I miss. I had 4 weeks when I left after 5 years.
cons:
When you are hired as a teller, you are expected to meet sales goals that are impossible which makes people do things unethically in fear of losing their job.

No raises after working for 5 years going above and beyond my job description. 

Changed my schedule without notice-- it is basically a retail job now. Soon enough all branches will be open on Sunday, I'm sure. They already took away holidays from the employees and extended Saturday hours. 

Horrible upper management. They have no clue what actually goes on in the branches yet they make all the rules.

I would never recommend anyone to work for this greedy company. The corporation does not care about their employees.

review_title: This bank doesn't care about the clients and doesn't care about the employee..!!!
job_title: Licensed Personal Banker in Foothill Ranch, CA
pros: Great training program, great benefits, mostly good people to work with. If your new to the business world you end up learning a lot about the corporate world which helps you moving forward.
cons:
The pay is horrible, difficult to get promoted. I was a Personal Banker 1 for 3 years and was ranked something
like #3 in the nation for loan volume for over 3 quarters and promised a promotion for a full year which never came. The difference would have been worth and extra $50,000 or so in commissions. It's obvious why they didn't promote me...! Very high pressure to sell to clients. Always pushing to open checking accounts above all else.

pros: Amazing benefits for both part-time and full-time, great flexibility with students and their school schedules, overall a professional work atmosphere supportive of growth within the company if goals are met. I was able to advance to a 30 hour Lead Teller position for nearly a year while going to school full-time with proven experience and a good manager.
cons: The rate of turn-over is high, the sales goals and sales pressure is extremely high and unrealistic considering the low pay and other added responsibilities. The quality of a branch depends a lot of the quality of management and other team members. I would advise going to a bank or credit union that pays higher and has lower sales goals.

job_title: Custoner Service Manager in Concord, CA
pros:
Wells Fargo is very good to its people and goes out of their way to ensure that their team members are taken care of.  They offer a competitive benefits and retirement plan.  
During my time with Wells I have seen the downturn in the markets, and instead of laying everyone off, the company did their best to fit them into other positions within various lines of business to retain the talent. Having worked for other companies, this was a real plus for me.
cons: Working for a bank, you are in a highly regulated environment and with the customer scrutinizing every action the bank makes, it is hard for the bank to provide the incentives that other businesses are able to provide.

pros: Minimal stress for a job in a stressful industry. If you are smart and know how to run a business efficiently, you will do well. If you are lazy and don't take the initiative to improve - especially after you have been coached, you will no be a good fit.
cons: Undertrained industry. The banking industry does not hire many people with technical skills to work in the retail arm of banking. You're going to be dealing with people who were flipping burgers prior to working at the bank and if you aren't patient and/or willing to teach them the skills they need - you will get frustrated.

pros: The benefits are very good. Management is mostly understanding of need for additional time off for personal or family reasons. There's a focus on employee recognition, although a lot of the time it seems like management hands out recognition awards because they have a quota to fill.
cons: There's not really any room for advancement. Managers move between different operational areas all the time, which means that they often have little understanding of or expertise in the areas they're managing. There's two classes of employees: managers, and the rank-and-file. The theory seems to be that rank and file is completely interchangeable with other rank-and-file, and managers are interchangeable with other managers. If you're rank and file, don't bring your brain to work.

pros: Wells Fargo is a big company that has great benefits with mediocre pay. I worked all through college and they provided health benefits and also a tuition reimbursement program that is better and much easier to use than most other companies.
cons: Wells Fargo is a big company with lots of growth potential, that being said, they do not look to promote from within their branches for anything outside of retail. I worked their the entire time I was getting a degree, something that they even paid for but now I cant get a job outside of retail because I don't have the "right" kind of experience.

review_title: Great Benefits but there is a ceiling as to how far up the ladder you can go
pros:
Amazing Benefits
 - A variety of Health plans, dental plans, vision plans
 - 401 (k) with matching 100% up to 6%
 - Employee Counseling
 - Discount website for a variety of products and services
Good early on potential for promotion up to the point of management.
cons:
Once you are a store or service manager you are pretty well stuck. Once you reach that level there are rarely any openings to move up and they typically go to the current senior managements favorites.
Pay is mediocre compared to other companies but is marginally offset by the tremendous benefits.
Expectations are too high and are never adjusted based on traffic or economic conditions.
Senior management is very out of touch with the branch level and it shows in their inflated expectations.

review_title: Wells Fargo values their employees, this is the place to be.
pros: Benefits are excellent, paid time off upon hire date. Room to be promoted or transfer to other jobs within the company are available. Great attendance policy. Nice relaxed corporated environment.
cons: Very sales driven, too much pressure on new hires to sell, not enough focus on ensuring each employee has had proper training. They use the Scare tactic a lot. Not very good start to hopeful trainees. The pressure can be brutal.

pros: Benefits, PTO, flexibility with school
cons:
Poor compensation compared to other banks (about $2 less per hour) 

SALES GOALS. My first two days on the line I was approached and told that I need at least 2 new accounts in 3 days. They got mad when I said I'll try hard, but I'm new. Is it okay if I get only one. Then I needed to refer 2 or more customers to bakers per day for new accounts. Then I needed at least 6 "solutions" on top of that (solutions are credit cards, new accounts (again), bill pay, etc). 

The place is horrible to work in because they will fire you if you don't sell enough for them. I hate working here and am seeking employment elsewhere.

pros: The hours are great, and the benefits are great
cons: They are very pushy, they don't care about their customers, they only care about making the sale, they don't care if the customer is an elder old women if they see a sale outta her they will force her to open up another checking account to even confuse her more, they don't work with their employees they promote people that shouldn't be promoted to just get them out of the teller line, so the people that are the ones that should be promoted they hold back because they don't wanna lose any sales

pros: decent benefits package, better technology than most competitors, easy to advance, good coverage if looking to relocate and stay employed, good coworkers for most part.
cons: terrible balance between work and life mentality, fairly incompetent middle management, lack of communication about why goals are set the way they are, uncompetitive pricing on deposit products, promotions based primarily on solutions performance alone.

pros: The schedule is great, as are the benefits.  Not working evenings ensures I can always be home for dinner with my family. I really enjoyed working with my co-workers.  Since there are relatively few in a branch compared with larger corporations, you really have an opportunity to become like a family.
cons: The focus on sales and referrals takes away the opportunity to give good customer service at times, though I understand it's necessary.  The pressure to get them can make the job more difficult than it should, but you should know that going into it.

review_title: Numbers, Sales, Duplicate Products. Do what's best for the manager, not branch or client.
pros: Competitive pay when compared to some of the smaller banks but about on par with its larger competition.
cons: Asked about numbers on hourly basis by Branch Management and Regional Management.  Only way to hit daily and quarterly bonuses is to have 200% on normal sales goal, clients are opened multiple accounts without their knowledge, instead of upgrading or downgrading, new accounts are opened for client.  Clients told to switch direct deposit, automatic payments.  If you don't hit 150% of your goal daily, you will stay for hours at a time after work without notice in order to cold call.  Management only cares about their hourly numbers, not where they come from, whether they are funded, and definitely not about the best interested of consumer.

review_title: Allows enhancement of valuable skills, but sales tactics are wrong
job_title: Customer Service and Sales Representative in Irvine, CA
pros:
Wells fargo offers a competitive industry salary with bonus potential
Looks good on a resume if you are able to stay for a while
Will develop valuable sales and customer service skills
cons:
Sales expectations are unrealistic and aggressive. Customer's come in wanting to cash a check and you are supposed to open them a "vacation savings account" so your branch can hit its goals
Daily sales goals are to be met and you are checked in on 2-3 times a day to see where you are
They want to you me an ATM machine that sells. You literally have at least 5 "value phrases" to say to customer each time they sit down, or you can be disciplined

review_title: Business Documentation Intern with the Consumer Lending Group
pros: The best thing about Wells Fargo is the people. Nice, nice, nice. I really have not met nicer people than these, and the Vision and Values of Wells Fargo are unparalleled. I am afraid that when I leave i will think that everyone else in the financial services industry is so unkind compared to the caring and considerate nature of every person (from the CEO to the managers to the team members) at Wells Fargo. Even though this was a corporate job, it felt like a genuine, and well-meaning small business with nice, genuine people. 5 stars.
cons: There is huge potential with this company. It's grown massively since 2008 and it's continually growing. Lots of opportunities.

job_title: Full Time Teller in Tampa, FL
pros: There are great benefits for younger adults either finishing school or looking to start a career in banking. Wells Fargo is willing to teach you as much as you will learn to help you move up within 3 years. There is an incentive bonus for those who can reach their sales goals.
cons: All of what you do with regard to the everyday job revolves around the bigger picture of sales. You are required to get at least 3 solutions a day which is difficult depending on the branch you work at. Without at least hitting threshold you will not receive incentive payout. On top of this, staying balanced in your drawer can prove difficult with the never-ending turnover and after a certain amount of outages your job is in jeopardy.

pros: Good 401k, Solid company to own stock in.
cons: Banking at the retail level usually means A LOT of underqualified people who have no business being in finance. The whole retail side of the bank is like a PacSun or a Walmart, you have high turnover, incompetent managers, regional managers, district managers etc. they're all playing the same game, jerking each other off and playing a game of telephone.  "how many sales are you going to get today?" "alright good goals everyone!" you know, fake business, but it looks real because everyone is dressed nicely. Bonuses are insulting and that's if you do well. No profit sharing below mgr level.

pros: I'm a people person so I loved goingband talking with customers and employees. I got attached and it made going to work fun. They reimburse for college, that's a huge plus! They also pay for you to volunteer even if it's during working hours. If your branch meets goals then you get rewarded with breakfast or lunch sometimes. 401k match is also a plus! Pay is decent.
cons: Sales goals are the worst unless you're good at helping 3 customers decide they want new accounts. Most of the time depending on the branch you can get 1 "walk over" to the banker but then you can also get in trouble by not doing the walk overs. You also have to get 3 no's from the customer before it's acceptable to stop asking them to meet with a banker.

review_title: Wells Fargo has great intentions - it's all in the implementation......
job_title: Client Services Manager in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great benefits and job security.  The 'Retain and Retrain' policy is truly believed in from a senior management perspective, and, it's great for the corporate bottom line - if you have a current employee who can do the work and a job that needs doing - why would you lay off a team member?  Unfortunately, when it comes to implementation of the policy, HR is far too deep into middle managements pocket - they will do what ever they're told and good, experience people end up on the street.
cons: As with most corporations - people tend to be promoted to their level of incompetence and then loyalty didctates that they stay where they are.

review_title: Wish we could return to the innovative leadership we once had
job_title: Vice President in San Francisco, CA
pros: There are some small nuggets of areas within Wells Fargo that are still innovative. Additionally, there are a few senior managers that are effective visionary leaders.  and have strong senior management as leaders. The management is allows for time off for personal reasons.
cons: Overall, our senior management are not strong leaders or encourgage/reward their employees to be innovative thinkers. We used to be the pioneers and were the first to introduce new and innovative products and services to our customers. Sad to say that we now tend to sit on the sidelines and let other financial institutions lead the way.

review_title: Great place to launch a career.
pros: In my group I find that opportunities are out there for those who want them and are ambitious. The management casts a wary eye at those who have a sense of entitlement and tends to reward those to really step up and go outside their comfort zone. The company is very large with nearly 80 lines of business so the culture will certainly vary, but overall you get the sense the company is relatively conservative and rooted in sound principles.
cons: While there are certainly plenty of ambitious and successful leadership there are seem a few people with entitlement syndrome milling about as if working for the bank is a government job. These are the same folks who expect a pay raise every year for mediocre performance. Also, with the Wachovia merger now in full swing there is more "uncertainty" in the air these days than normal.

pros: Easy to get in as a Teller and at lest move up as a banker.  If you get into a good branch with good coworkers things will be fine.  If its a slow branch your screwed!  Your able to take PTO when you like with out having to pull hairs.  Good experience and good stuff for your resume.
cons: Sales are a little tuff unless you have some tricks up your sleeve.  Once you hit your goals ask to be promoted!  Ive seen people work there for 5-10-15 yrs and just up and quit!  Don't feel like anyone cares about you unless your helping them get their bonus.  I call it treading water till your fired!

review_title: Good job if you love sales
job_title: Personal Banker I in Dallas, TX
pros: The people are wonderful.  The pay is competitive and management truly seems to respect and value all employees.  They do not tolerate unethical behavior and they seem to genuinely want their people to succeed.
cons: In the personal banker role, you are a salesman.  In my interview, I was told that sales was to be about 20% of my job.  Sales is actually about 90% of my job, and employees are threatened with their jobs if they do not perform.  Sales goals are usually very unrealistic, making it impossible to bonus.  Strong salespeople can succeed, but if you don't like cold calling or knocking on doors to open checking accounts, this is not the job for you.

pros: the pay is average or above average, depending on your postion. Wellsfargo offers great benefits and the general company is a great company, but the branch located in Downers grove, IL is awful.
cons:
-common for individuals to work 12- 14 hours day.
-overwhelm their employees with work and management is out the door by 4:30, leaving employees with no support
-bend to support account executives and do not support internal staff
-very dissorganized and no real training provided
-very difficult to move up in the company, the better you are at your position, the more likely you will not be moved up "we can't find a good replacement", even after three years???
-they do not care if your child is sick and you need time off. You're made to feel guilty when you return, yet if someone leaves for drug problems they are provided assistance.
overall the downers grove location is awful!

pros:
Generally makes a strong investment in its people for training and development
Management truly believes in the company's vision and values - helping our customers reach their financial goals
Gallup poll annually takes a pulse on employee engagement, and action plans are developed in response to the top strength and top opportunity for the team
Generous benefits for medical, 401k, dental, PTO
cons: Revenue opportunities are squeezed, either by political or social pressures - people in general feel entitled to free financial services without any recognition of the cost of providing those services.  So I'm personally concerned about the long-term prospects about the industry as a whole.  Wells Fargo's management is strong and genuinely compassionate, so I know they'll do their best to do right by their customers and employees.

review_title: One of the worse if not THE worse I.T. shop I have ever worked for
pros: The ability to telecommute.  The pay is adequate and in my area not too many employers would be able to match.  The amount of PTO you earn is also a plus.
cons: Too many meetings and conference calls to attend.  Too many process and procedures and not too many people know or understand the process and procedures especially the legacy Wells Fargo employees who can't explain it to new employees.  Just too many inconsistencies within the company.  There are too many mid-to-upper level management.  There is no such thing as work-life balance.  EUC network engineering is a JOKE!!!  to be fair not all of the euc network engineers are a joke, it's those LEGACY EUC NETWORK ENGINEERS who are a joke.  When it comes to using the minds, nope they can't do it!  "It needs to be scripted so I can push a button!!"

review_title: Good place to make a career, if you put in the time
job_title: Level I Underwriter in San Diego, CA
pros: Wells Fargo is a good place to make a career.  The key is to get aboard and then continually expand your usefullneess the company in order to be considered for advancement.  When you're part of the team, there are always job opportunities listed internally.  I was laid off due to the economy but was given a 3 month severance package -- I had been with WF for less than one year, so this was a class move by the company.
cons: Very large and impersonal at times.  Mid management is good but can't affect change.  Upper management can affect change but doesn't always listen to or even hear the rank and file.

job_title: Teller in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Bank hours are very good. 8:15-6:15 on weekdays, 8:45-3:15 on Saturdays. Banking holidays off. Wells Fargo also uses merit pay incentive programs, and Tellers can receive bonuses from finding and filling customer needs (aka "solutions").
cons: The biggest challenge is the pushy managers who feel pressure from their bosses to increase numbers at branches. Managers are always riding the tellers for one reason or another. Also, the branch I work at has been consistently understaffed for the past six months. Some customers can be huge jerks sometimes, but you have to sit there and take it with a smile. Each customer has the possibility of being surveyed, and a teller must receive perfect 5's (on a 1-5 scale concerning 5 different areas of questions) in order to be safe from write ups or warnings. Quite a ridiculous was of measuring teller service performance.

pros: Once one is part of the few elites, his/her job is secured.
cons: Upper management is not aware of how the lower managers treat their employees.  A lot of favoritism taking place, as well as back stabbing.   Hiring inexperience managers to oversee a department who cannot provide a clear guidance, and then holding the team members responsible for failing to meet requirements of the daily tasks.  Also, targeting women over 40 to find reasons to fire them - they use every trick in book to justify terminating older women.

review_title: The worst experience is ever had
job_title: Personal Banker I in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: The company offers excellent benefits.  The bank 401k and options are strong and secure.  It's not worth working here for these though.
cons: They go out of their way to demoralize and demean their retail banking employees.  The employees are encouraged to push products on customers that are in no way in their best interests.  The bank then blames those employees should any complaints be made.  I have never worked in a more emotionally abusive situation.  In the first four months I was at the bank my branch had four different managers, 13 different bankers, 9 different tellers, 3 assistant managers.  Avoid working here.

pros: They have a large footprint and many existing clients so if you are willing to work hard and learn the "Wells Way" you should not have a problem leveraging the enterprise to generate new business.
cons:
Sometimes it feels management was out of touch with being in the field as they constantly had other tasks for us to complete even as a top producing mortgage consultant.  I would have understood these requirements if I wasn't hitting my numbers and didn't need to be micro managed with tasks that I obviously already completed or done in the past to build the business I was generating.  

Also it seemed as if fulfillment (processing and underwriting) ran the show and kept putting additional tasks on the loan officers taking them further out of the field and generating revenue.

pros:
There are very good people/employees scattered throughout the retail segment of this bank that provide new employees sound education about the business to build around.

Bank hours/holidays.
cons:
Middle management truly only cares about the highest numerical performers and will almost always disregard the value of truly exceptional team members that don't jump off the page. They only care about meeting their own incentive quotas, and that means treating the all-stars like superstars.

Sales goals often cause teams to come to work for meetings at the crack of dawn or until sundown.

Pay is SUPER low. Job requirements are astronomical compared to the despicably low comp.

pros: If you are a shark and do not care much about your customers but about your bonus, it's a good place. Some interesting and young coworkers will make work feel pleasant and relieve some of the sales pressure.
cons: Work culture is one of the worst I have seen. The retail banking is filled with extreme pressure to sell products without considering customer needs. Depending on where you are located, this pressure can be so much that using the restroom becomes a rare thing.

review_title: Positive business opportunity & starting over is code
pros: Good people work there from security to the cafeteria. Benefits are decent. Retirement is possible if you work on it. Secured Building. Career Development. Community & Culture Connections. Networking is huge plus. Lateral movement is encouraged.
cons: Negative Publicity. No department can stand alone so all suffer production at the same time at times. Constant change on how to run a department year in to year out. The number of loyal workers being displaced.  Company policy prohibits active employees to give a quality reference for future employment.

job_title: Full Stack Web Developer in Bangalore
pros:
1.Good Work Environment
2. Work from Home facility : 5 in a month : depends on manager to manager
3. Internet Reimbursement : 1180 max
4. Employees with Job role 4 and above is given Iphone and bill reimbursement.
5. Quarterly outings : again depends on manager
6. Flexoble work timing : No criterion to maintain hours
cons:
1. Removed so many benefits like Hot skill bonus, annual bonus.
2. No tranasparency
3. Lot of power has been given to managers.
4. No one to complain if you have problems with supervisor/manager
5. Appraisal depends on the terms with your manager irrespective of what work you do
6. Less learning

review_title: Wells Fargo--Best Company To Work For
pros: It's great to know you're with one of the greatest and most respected companies in the world.  They have great salary potentials, wonderful benefits, amazing opportunity for advancement, and a very knowledgeable and wise leadership.  In an industry that's really taking a beating right now, Wells Fargo is still standing strong.  Many banks and financial institutions are laying off masses of employees, while Wells Fargo is still hiring aggressively.  It's also encouraging to see those who are leading the company now and learn that many of them began in the same position--credit manager.  It shows that if you're willing to put in hard work and be loyal, you will be rewarded!
cons: You may possess all the qualities to make yourself an amazing manager, but if your personal sales numbers don't match up then you'll never get a shot.

review_title: Depends on your management, if you are valued to your potential, so be sharp to read between the lines early.
job_title: Teller/Merchant Teller in La Crescenta, CA
pros: Great customers, they love the bank, and its been around for such a long time that most of them are old and they love just to converse.
cons: If you work in an environment where the staff is short or is lacking a core management professional, beware to be stretched to your maximum, be yelled at even if you are being stressed upon, your balancing is NUMBER ONE, make sure to balance, it doesn't matter, if there are people on your computer looking for sales, or trying to WOW A CUSTOMER, yOU NEED TO ALWAYS ALWAYS BALANCE.

review_title: A Bank that Cares about YOU too
job_title: Quality Assurance Analyst I in San Antonio, TX
pros: Best "for profit bank" I've worked for that shows they care about their employees based off of how you are treated by senior leaders, direct leaders, and team leaders. Many job opportunities everyday on the internal job website.
cons: Compensations seems low compared to other companies in the direct area. A lot of "new" managers with 3 years or less of experience learning to balance how to manage a team and individuals while learning how to be a manager. Although lots of job postings internally, competition is either high or, a posting is amde just for technicality as the hiring manager already has their person of choice waiting. Good tuition reimbursement plan and benefits

review_title: High Pressure, High Stress, Low Morale
pros:
-The benefits are great (healthcare, dental, vision, paid holidays and sick days)
-You get to meet some awesome people and establish great relationships with them.
-You gain a lot of skills that other employers look for (i.e. sales and customer service)
-Opportunities for promotion
cons:
-Extremely sales driven which can cause a very high pressure and high stress work environment
-The pressure leads to unethical sales behavior (screwing over nice customers for your own gain)
-Managers let the stress get to them, and they often do take it out on employees
-Sales goals are often unrealistic to achieve using ethical behavior
-POLITICS, POLITICS, POLITICS!
-Ass-kissing goes a long way
-Company SWEARS they're all about the customers, but trust me - they would screw over any customer to get a sale.  It's just the way it is.

review_title: Day to Day too much stress
pros: Quarterly goals, if you have a weak period you can make it up within  the quarter.  Good benefits and 401(k) match.  Also they have great volunteer opportunities.
cons: Quarterly payout is comprable to Chase's monthly payout.  Capped payout.  Managers freakout on a daily basis if sales aren't made, even if quarterly numbers have been met. Call nights and random extended hours.

review_title: it can be good or bad depending on who your service manager is
pros: good hours, benefits for part time, great incentive if you hit solutions goals. It can be a great place to work if you have a good service manager
cons: I loved it at first until they decided to transfer my service manager to another branch. They brought in a new lady who I do not like at all. I asked her to help me with something and in front of a customer, she said, "do we need to send you back to training?" Everyones hates her, including the branch manager. The only reason she got the job was because she got a lot of solutions when she was a teller. Which is another con. It's all a numbers game here. The people who get the most solutions get promoted regardless of what kind of employee they are.

review_title: Wells Fargo the "Titanic" of the financial world. Too big to change with the times.
job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: Name Recognition is the best in the financial industry. Products are decent but no real niche to set them apart. Work w Bank Branches.
cons: The Managers take all of the good sources of business in the area (bank branches and other line of business referrals). They also re-allign branch assignments to work in their favor.   The mortgage Consultants fight over the scraps.  The manager build teams w Junior MC's and Assistants.  The rest do not get that opportunity.  Managers do not manage or help build your business.  Processing is not good at all.  There are a lot of unhappy people working at Wells Fargo.

pros: Working for Wells Fargo in Southern Californial I was thouroughly impressed with the managment team as well as individual branch success. I had a very supportive team, whom I even became very close with. We worked hard together selling the banks products and as bankers, we were paid well for it.
cons: The Houston Market. Since moving to Houston, I saw the polar opposite of my past experience with the company. It goes to show that lack of good managment and teamwork can make a company fail. The upper managment in the houston area wreak of unproffesionalism, and it shows in their managers as well as other associates. This rapid decline of accountability cause me to look elsewhere for employment. Although I belive the company itself to be a solid one, in houston texas, they are far behind.

job_title: Phone Banker II in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: Health insurance, dental, vision, vacation time
cons:
Sales is all they care about unless you really make a customer mad. 
They push you to refer products with little to no value to the customer, like a 2nd savings account for a customer that usually has less than $50 in there accounts.
People with good sales numbers get away with violating a lot of company policies.
Amazingly high turn over, by 1 month into the job 3 of my training team of 12 were still there, at 1 year it's 2 left(Apparently that's actually high on average)
There is a by large push for getting people to sign up for debit,card overdraft service to allow them to overdraw there accounts to cause them $35 fees.
When a customer would say no to my promise statement(can I tell you about products or services that may benefit you) if my team lead was listening to the call she would just start repeating the phrase "turn and burn" get them off the line as fast as you can they aren't buying anything.

job_title: Personal Banker II – Registered in Miami, FL
pros: If you have a manager that is good, then you are ok. I have gone through so many managers and about 20% of them work with you.  Other than that, the company does offer great benefits and a very decent pay scale compared to other banks.
cons: Sales goals are too high and never equal throughout all branches.  Wells Fargo upper management cleans their hands by laying all the responsibility on you and then when you have an issue which they will not let you know about until it is too late, they fire you.  I was with the bank for 16 years (prior with Wachovia until Wells Fargo took over) and they did not even look at my previous record with zero incidents or issues  and just terminated me on the spot. I am currently appealing it.

job_title: Business On Line Banker in Charlotte, NC
pros: You can enjoy the nice accommodations of two food courts, workout facility (although membership fees are not included), and you will have the opportunity to network and meet people from different departments within the company.
cons: The culture is terrible. Management does not care about the employees and everyone is only a number. Management is constantly changing policies and no one seems to have a definitive answer on key procedures. The performance matrix are designed to keep you from hitting your quarterly bonuses and the opportunity for advancement are very few and far between. The current management team will try to keep you in the department as long as they can if you are  a performer and they will micro manage you to the point that you will leave if you are not meeting the department goals.

pros: Great mission statement and finally focusing their objectives in the right area (wealth), however sometimes the "little guys" feel left out. I work in the wealth area and we offer some great services to our clients.  Clients love having a big bank wih lots of convenience services and accessibilities.
cons: It's taken the bank a while to get where we are despite our initiatives and focus. In the wealth area, it seems to have taken us a while to get where we are and are still behind the 8-ball as to how we should be able to manage our clients

pros: Compensation is the only pro here. Not the best, but it's decent
cons:
Leadership in my department is a joke. They have no idea what leadership means. Unless you have a family member in management, there is no hope for a future here. The supervisors behave like they're in junior high, they allow major big time bullying (I think the supervisors and managers are afraid of the bullies). Policies and procedures are inconsistent. If you have family in management, the policies and procedures are quite lenient. If you are not part of the "family" the supervisors and managers make up their own policies and procedures modeled specific to each employee. It's definitely not a team environment, they treat the non family employees as if they didn't exist and actually target them for mistakes the "family" employees have made. 

Once you work hard and show potential, they block you from moving up or transfers

review_title: Wells Fargo is a good company to grow with, from great customer service to sales you become a stronger employee.
pros: You get so many opertunties to learn and grow. There are many resources from working with Wells Fargo. With proper management and training and hard work you can grow to become anything you want with their company.
cons: You do have a lot of responsibilities which can become stressful. But if you learn how to use them in a timly manner you understand how to function in your position better. You have to be an outgoing person to work for Wells as well, so no shy people!!

review_title: Fantastic benefits, positive work environment, and a progressive culture wrapped up in red tape
pros: Benefits are plentiful and generous, though they have declined since Wells fargo's acquisition of Wachovia.  Still, WF offers some of the best benefits I've seen in a large corporation. Job opportunities are plentiful in this international company, especially in technology, where initial-hire salaries are very competitive.
cons: In-house promotions result in small wage increases.  To earn what you're worth after several years experience, you'll have to look elsewhere.  Being the huge corporation that it is, the scope of most technology jobs is very small.  Most developers, for instance, will spend all their time doing one thing and will have very little opportunity to explore new technologies.

review_title: Great company, not always the greatest branch to work for.
pros: It's a great company overall to work for! I feel you can be proud to be a part of our team, we have been around since 1869ish. We offer so many different products and solutions for our customers. We get great benefits and incentives for doing our job right! Some great district managers and some great people. Also a dedicated HR team ready to give you advice or help!
cons:
Sales. If you don't like them, go to a slower branch area or don't come at all. Sales are very important.
Bad management? You'll be there for the next year.

pros: There are a number of reasons Wells Fargo Advisors is a great place to work for Registered Client associates.  Competitive pay, great hours, flexible schedule.  As a registered associate, your responsibilities are mostly administrative but it is a great learning experience.  The hardest part would be staying organized to complete you tasks in a reasonable time.
cons: I really don't have a lot of complaints about being a Registered Client Associate with Wells Fargo Advisors.  The biggest con to me is that there isn't much in terms of career advancement opportunities from this role.  Really there are two options, become a commission based Financial Advisor or take a couple more exams to work in compliance.

review_title: Work for any other bank than this one
pros: Paid holidays, a lot of vacation time, develop within the company
cons: Updated bonuses since the settlement are a joke, WF is slowly going back to sales goals but are saying they're not and you're not getting compensated for it, promises are not kept. You can go and work for any other bank that you will make more an hour and get paid higher in bonuses and more than likely not have to work on Saturday's.

job_title: Senior Vice President  in San Francisco, CA
pros: Wells Fargo is solvent, has a conservative approach to their business mix and credit evaluation process, maintains a massive retail franchise, is intensely focused on profit, and is likely to stay in business for a very long time.
cons: Wells Fargo is a bloated organization with too many non-producing staff members, large numbers of obstructionist managers focused on self-preservation, and promotes largely adversarial working relationships among its team members.  Infighting is common.  In addition to force feeding the most profitable banking widgets to customers, team members must engage in heavy self-promotion and finally be inducted into "the club" to advance.  With a culture based on hard core sales and a pervasive sweat shop mentality, large numbers of customers are alienated and tend to be ignored unless they are likely buyers of new products.

pros: They have a great 401 k match, 100%! Wells also offers a secondary pension plan, but you have to be there 5 years to vest. Wells offers a very comprehensive product line, so you can sell or refer for almost any financial need
cons:
It seemed that promotion and incentive were mostly based on favoritism and branch. If you were placed in a good branch and made a good impression, you were going to qualify for a lot of incentives and a chance to move up. If you were placed in a branch in a poor sales neighborhood, you had to work twice as hard to get anything.

Secondly, sometimes finding the person to refer to or to ask a question of was almost impossible.

review_title: Post-Mergers, Firm is doing extremely well and now has solid leadership, very professional, Great community involvement
job_title: Marketing Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
- Good work/life balance
- Very professional organization
- Solid and skilled leadership
- Have brought in some great outside talent recently
- Much more passion and heart than most large companies
- Excellent community involvement like United Way, Komen Race, Symphony and Art Fair
- Outstanding St. Louis HQ campus 
- Very fair and honest management
cons:
- Being part of a huge company (the bank) makes things move slow
- Some office space is dated, remodeling is happening, but not near fast enough
- Bank has pushed some odd changes to brokerage
- Bank has changed some benefits that were previously outstanding
- City has unusual 1% earnings tax, and they are located in the city
- While image of the firm is very positive, they could spend more on advertising to get better awareness

pros:
The hours 9-5
The benefitsa are good
cons:
under paid for everything we have to do.
always short staffed and expected  to meet our sales goals if not you get written up for it.Sales goals are high. We get customer shops that evaluate the experience the customer has with us. We are rated from 1-5 which of course 5 means the best. If we get anything other than a 5 its something we did wrong without an explanation of the situation.

pros: If you are great with sales, your bonuses will be great and your chance at promotion is quick.
cons: Terrible Benefits, first off. The only way to get promoted is to have high sales, it doesn't matter at all if you know your job and how to do it well. Tellers are usually there before everyone and leave after everyone. Sales goals are unrealistic, more than double what other banks ask. Most of your customers threaten to leave because they are highly dissatisfied with the change from Wachovia to Wells.

review_title: WAS OKAY - Improved my sales skills
pros:
Bonuses if you made quarterly sales goals
Good pay if hired outside (horribly low within)
Benefits - 401k, insurance, PTO (18days first year)
Free accounts - no fees
cons: For the most part your experience working here will be influenced by your upper management (store and district mngt). I worked under people who had no clue what they were doing, and just because you are a great sales person...DOES NOT mean you are a great MANAGER. Working here is all about SALES SALES SALES. At first it was hard to get used to it, but after awhile it becomes second nature. I did not mind the sales aspect, but eventually had to leave because of the unnecessary added stress from the management every day!

review_title: Strong teamwork, diverse opportunities and customer focus company
pros:
- There is great teamwork in play here. The dynamics within a project team and also among cross-functional teams are great.
 - With solid financial base and great strategy that is proven in both good and bad economy, the job is pretty stable
- Within so many lines of business and growing national and international reach, team members can find opportunities in many different geographic locations.
cons:
- Being such a large bank and conservative in nature, the transition to latest technology usually is a bit slow.  
 - The change management has its own bureaucratic process
 - The visibility of what technology are being used in different parts of the bank seems pretty opaque

review_title: A good place to work. Learned a lot here! Good/Bad experience depends on management
pros: I learned a lot about the financial industry; felt like you're making a difference in many people's lives; if you're good in sales you can make some good extra money. Experience in a professional atmosphere with many avenues to move up.
cons: Scripted customer interaction gets repetitive and annoying. Emphasis on sales goals is intense.  Sales pushing from managers and bankers is constant. Sometimes you feel unappreciated for all the non-sales related work you do. I initially had a great manager that supported me and made a world of difference. New  management with strict rules and fake demeanor rubbed tellers the wrong way (reason for my leaving).

review_title: If you want to have you own personality, not the place for you.
job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Philadelphia, PA
pros: The training is next to none, and if you need referrals, WF has one of the largest referral networks in the world.  Everyone has heard of Wells.
cons: As a loan officer, it will drive you crazy that the bank portion controls the mortgage division.  The thought that a bank manager can control or impact you schedule as a loan officer is insane.  You will never be a person to upper management.  You will just be a line on a spreadsheet.

job_title: Inbound Sales Specialist in Reno, NV
pros: Pay and benefits, that's about it.
cons:
Just about everything else. 
Extremely poor management.

review_title: Favoritism, poor work-life balance in Retirement business unit
pros: Decent banking pay.  Decent health benefits
cons: WF is a company that likes to talk the talk not walk the walk.The policies between business units vary greatly.  The larger Wells Fargo wants you to believe they are competitive, fair, diverse and forward thinking, but there is no consistency with this from one group to the next.  Our business unit just severely cut back its work from home allowance to 2x per month. It's causing lots of low morale and people are already starting to look for other opportunities.  Sr. leadership really needs to stop drinking the pink koolaid.

pros: I loved this job. Lots of fun and lots of motivation to meet quotas. I learned a lot about money and "finding solutions" to problems on people's account setups. I loved that they train you fully before putting you on a teller line and I love that we got to dress professionally for work.
cons: If a boss says you said something they believe her. And then just fire you. At one place I was criticized for the occasional needed break for taking care of a low blood sugar. Made fun of for my religion and even though I consistently made sales goals and had customers that liked me I got transferred because my religion was a problem. It was not something that I ever brought up but was brought up by coworkers.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Good Benefits, PTO and Holidays, Great technology. Okay to be tarty, leave early. Store managers are paid very well for doing nothing.
cons: Low pay, Lots of Politics, you have to know someone (be a favorite) to advance. Sell products to customers they don't need to make unrealistic sales goals. The managers, district managers and higher up only care about the numbers, not the customers or employees. Wells Fargo is about numbers and profits.  District manages have a slogan,  not making your numbers is non-negotiable.  You will be written up, threaten with your job. Banker that make their goal are questionable, but over looked because they are a favorites.

job_title: Personal Banker II (SAFE) in Aurora, CO
pros: Wells Fargo is the best at what they do in many areas, such as home mortgage and auto finance. When you can say you're the best that goes a long way with closing a sale. Lots of potential to move up if you work hard and hit the sales and service goals. Great training, great benefits.
cons: At times, there was a lot of sales pressure when I was there, and the sales pressure often flew in the face of good service and customer experience, because sales tactics and sales ethics started to falter in quality. I hear they are actively trying to increase sales integrity and move away from product-pushing.

pros: Great pay and great benefits. I work in the call Center and I never felt like I was going to lose my job for not making sales goals etc- if I was struggling with something they coached me to help me succeed.
cons: Very busy with little downtime. Come to work. Adherence  (time spent on the phone) goals are unrealistic 92% making people sweat over taking a bathroom break. People get burnt out too quickly causing the high turnover rate. Policies in place for customers are not very flexible because wells Fargo is too worried about lawsuits or complying with federal government whose policies and scripts make this job very inpersonal. Employees endure the brunt of fustrated customers due to this.

pros: The PTO is fantastic- 18 days years 1-2, and add 5 days for every 5 years service after that. 401(k) with matching. Free accounts.
cons: Depending on where you are located, it can be very tough to succeed in this position. Upper management will harp on one area to excel in, and when you do that, they wonder why another area isn't doing as well. The ridiculously high expectations that you are pushed towards can put you in a very awkward position of selling a customer on a product that don't need just to keep management off your back. Don't work here if you have trouble sleeping at night because you sold someone on something they didn't need just to keep your numbers up. you have to have ridiculous output if you expect to move up, otherwise it is very difficult. They say they want customers to succeed financially but every activity is centered around a money grab. And they pay is awful.

review_title: Corporate environment that speaks loudly for customers' benefit but quietly pushes sales numbers hard.
job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in New Bern, NC
pros:
The company has more "lines of business" than any other bank which allows it to have so many different roles and career choices inside the company. 

They spend money on tools to assist in sales, like questionnaires that lead customers to close themselves 

Payouts for bonus are very obtainable.
cons: Understaffed retail branch locations contribute to a lackluster opinion by customers and makes it hard to focus on objectives and sales goals because of so much servicing.

pros: Benefits are great, built long lasting relationships with customers, never bored,  always work to do, great dress code
cons: Too much corruption,  favoritism is out of control, branch management are the main source of the negativity and hostile working environment,  overworking the employees and do not assist, unless you become a brown noser,  you will have no chance of furthering your career, no bonus, no customer service incentive payout, you report your concerns to HR and nothing happens,  and they always side with Management until EEOC gets involved

job_title: Business Initiatives Consultant in London, England
pros:
Really supportive and collaborative colleagues - everyone is happy to help.
Huge organization, lots of opportunity BUT you are expected to self-serve your development and career path (that suits me).
Exciting plans for International development and growth, some great new senior hires.
Support in place (HR, IT etc) people are very happy to help.
I think remuneration is higher here than at other comparable organisations.
Lots of communication, I feel like I always get updated on internal moves / changes or new hires.
Highly inclusive and dedicated to diversity & inclusion - each region across the globe has a D&I council.
Very philanthropic and encouraging of employees to get involved in charity or volunteering activities - everyone in EMEA gets 2 days off a year to volunteer.
cons: Very slow pace of work because the company is risk adverse, you need to get used to managing a number of projects over a fairly long period. Everything always takes longer than originally expected

review_title: Good Benefits, but Company does not care about their employees
pros: The health benefits are pretty good. All the federal holiday are paid off. PTO is great start out at 18 days.
cons: Starting wage is competitive with other companies. Annual increases are a joke, they don't even keep up with inflation rates. Leaders are promoted by who they know and not talent. Use and abuse their employees, running such tight staffing that overtime is constantly required. Claim to be employee focused and everyone is one Wells Fargo when that is a flat out lie.

review_title: They want uniform results and treat you like a dog
job_title: Phone Banker in Des Moines, IA
pros: The pay was more than just about anything else at this level.  The money was directly deposited.  The benefits were pretty sweet.
cons: Everything else was a con.  For every minute you're not clocked into your phone, you were docked 2 minutes.  Then you were graded on how many minutes you were and should have been clocked in.  Anything less than 99% is unacceptable.  So your one 15 minute break over a 5 hours, during supper time, must include any bathroom breaks and food.  With a breakroom about a minute and a half away, it sucked.  They had the strictest set of rules I've ever seen.  They were only concerned with controlling every aspect of your life when you were on the clock so they can churn out uniform results.  There's no thinking or problem solving involved - only reading from a set script.  Just not for everybody I suppose.

review_title: "Where your best is never good enough!"
pros: Good benefit package. Decent amount of PTO. Good place to work for those who do not have a college degree and are looking to move up the corporate ladder.
cons: Sales Sales Sales! Unrealistic sales goals! Managers breathing down your neck to get sales. District managers breathing down their necks and threatening their jobs if they do not micro manage your every move. Tedious offsite events where you solicit the patrons of the community with the "benefits" wells fargo has to offer. What i mean by "benefits" is finding any idiot that is stupid enough to hand over their drivers license in exchange for a Wells Fargo coffee mug!

pros: PTO, Tuition reimbersment, 401k.  Your experience in the retail side really depends on your store manager.  I personally will avoid working for wells fargo at all costs.. Many people love their job outside the retail side within wells, i've heard underwriting is a great department.
cons: Unrealistic sales, management does not have clue what really goes on, extreme gaming to meet goals, employees constantly on the edge about losing their job or being demoted if sales goals arn't met.  It is essientially a revolving door here, always new employees because team members finally call it quits.  Sadly, the people who are promoted within retail are usually those able to game the system the best.  Store Managers/District Managers/Market Presidents will turn a blind eye to ethical issues related to sales because it affects their bonus payout.

review_title: Best company I have worked for out of seven fortune 500 companies in my career
pros: Treat their employees with great respect; a lot of diverse employees that are encouraged to celebrate their diversities: LGBT group, Asian group, Hispanic group, etc.; many clubs within the company to join: running club, cycling team, Weight Watchers, company choir; on-site fitness facility and showers at certain corporate campuses; ability to work remotely is a great option for me; very down to earth CEO
cons: Since merger with Wachovia, certain benefits have been taken away: some company holidays from old Norwest /Wells Fargo, needing to pay to join the 20-year club; some micro-managing managers...seems to hear about them more in the Mortgage business line; culture is changing a bit from the old legacy Wells Fargo; some managers don't follow what the CEO asks for from our culture

job_title: Financial Advisor in New York, NY
pros: Of all the wirehouses, WFA is in my opinion the best for FAs. Management doesn't cram product down your throat, and allows you to operate in the best interests of the client. Though they've been encouraging more partnership with the Private Bank, they have not made it mandatory; and in fact I would argue the PB gives you a greater arsenal to reach more HNW clients than you otherwise might.
cons: At the end of the day it's still a wirehouse, which means you're not as free as you might be as an RIA. As WFA is owned by a bank there's always the risk of "Bank Creep," but I don't see the BOA/Merrill struggles happening to us anytime soon.

review_title: Quick Advancement, Very Challenging Sales Goals
job_title: Personal Banker I in Louisville, CO
pros: Promotions happen very frequently if you prove yourself.  401(k) match up to 6%, good employee benefits.  Good coaching in sales and cross-selling.  Very fun work environment if you have the right team.
cons: Sales goals are very challenging and encourage cheating for employees to reach each level, (Gold, Silver, Bronze).  High pressure sales lead to mistakes and mismanagement of accounts, which leads to up to 50% of your day cleaning up other banker's messes.  Customer satisfaction surveys are based on pass/fail, and "pass" is no less than 100% perfect, making it very difficult to attain.  Salary should be higher as it is known as the highest pressure bank in terms of sales.

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in San Francisco, CA
pros: If you can stomach the culture, the opportunity for career advancement is always available.
cons: Wells Fargo is the personification of evil corporate America. The only value found in an employee is production, at all costs. Devaluation to customer first is so great that the only time the "customer experience" is addressed only when the customer complains or a comp plan metric isn't met. Management compensation plans are  not inline with team member comp plans, so there is a constant struggle in optimizing an overwhelming amount of metrics. As an ex top level national sales exec., I'm truly amazed that this company is still able to churn the bogus amount of business that is does.

job_title: Assistant Vice President, Communications Consultant in Houston, TX
pros:
Wonderful company, great Vision & Values, upper leadership is among the best in the world
Not a lot of opportunity for advancement unless you're based in WF's major hubs
cons: I just got stuck with an inept bully of a boss and HR said he can come in and change important things I negotiated with the company when hired nine years ago.  If it weren't for this twit, I'd planned on retiring with Wells Fargo

job_title: Quantitative Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
Typical banking environment. This is, in principle, not a good thing. It is possible though to sanitize your work environment and become efficient and productive. However, it takes a lot of hard work to convince management to do give you freedom.  If that happens and your way turns out to be better, you will get rewarded generously.  This is not possible in other big banks. Thus WF stands out among its peers.

Great work life balance, except for vacation time.
cons:
IT is a nightmare. It seems they are paid to hold WF hostage to Microsoft, and transfer wealth from WF to Microsoft, while getting very bad products and services in return.  

Vacation time shorter than what WF's peers offer.

pros: Managers are always willing to coach you and help you become better at your job whether your working as a personal banker or teller. This makes career advancement within the company much easier than if you are someone coming from the outside in, unless you have a lot of experience under your belt.
cons: It is a little difficult at times to perform your job function to the best of your ability at all times since they expect you to leave everything at the door when you come in to wok. This makes it especially difficult when customers are rude to you. The best thing to do is not take things personal and stay optimistic.

pros:
Advancement opportunities
OK benefits
Allows 16 hours volunteer time
cons: Upper management, their superiors, and higher are corrupt as heck! The so called change only impacts community banking while other divisions of Wells Fargo operate under the old environment. Partner channels have ridiculous goals and constantly lie to CB partners to achieve SALES and REVENUE. If you want to get micromanaged, ridiculed behind closed doors, and be affiliated with sub par, classless people - join this bank. The things i have witnessed and continue to experience is crazy, unethical, and not aligned with the new core values WF continues to market. ALL BS... and if you are business owner, RUN FAR FAR AWAY FROM THIS COMPANY! And i would not trust any money with any advisors either. WF continues to hire unqualified candidates as no one wants to taint their name working for this company - i'm leaving soon but scared working for WF could have damaged my reputation. And if you are a minority business owner, do not ... DO NOT bank with this company!!!

pros: Competitive Benefits, Competitive 401k match, Decent Vacation Days, Competitive Pay if they like you
cons: BEWARE! MOST OF THE MANAGEMENT IS SUB STANDARD very UNPROFESSIONAL...AND MANAGEMENT,  AS WITH ANY COMPANY, WILL MAKE YOU OR BREAK YOU AT WELLS FARGO. FAVORITES ARE MOST DEFINITELY PLAYED AT THIS COMPANY!! IF THEY LIKE YOU, YOU WILL GET PROMOTED.  YOU DON'T GET PROMOTED BECAUSE YOU ARE DEPENDABLE, HONEST AND DO A GOOD JOB!

review_title: I have had a good experience with Wells Fargo, but the compensation:workload ratio needs some work.
job_title: Project Manager II in San Francisco, CA
pros: Some of the best reasons to work at Wells Fargo are the benefits and the people.  Divisions and groups within the company truly work as a team and it shows in the projects we launch and drive.  The benefits are outstanding with significant PTO accrual and health/dental and vision.
cons: Despite the numerous learning opportunities provided to it's employees, managers (in my experience) do not encourage employees to explore them.  Additionally, trying to get a raise in your current position is nearly impossible.  Merit increases are not always provided due to company cutbacks, which can really decrease motivation to go above and beyond for the Company and/or your product group.

pros: The pay is good. The hours are good, My branch wasn't open on weekends, so I had a good schedule.
cons: They would pop "call night" on you just before leaving for the day. Meaning they told you, you couldn't leave till later and you had to stay and make calls. If you didn't meet your 3 solutions a day, alot of the times they would try and make you stay an additional 2 hours or so and call people to get appointments. I was on maternity leave and was told by the previous manager many times not to worry about my job it will be there when I got back. Well we got a new manager and was told yesterday my position was no longer available. This all happened after I called and gave them my return to work date and someone had told them a different date. So now I have 90 days to find a job within the company or they will terminate me! Way to treat your employees Wells Fargo!!!

job_title: Client Service Consultant in Menomonee Falls, WI
pros:
- Great security license training program. (Series 7 and 66)
- Management is willing to work with you if you are willing to work.
- Excellent place to start after college to gain experience. 
- 401(k)
- Tuition reimbursement. (free MBA anyone??)
- PTO
- Free lunch
cons:
- Not all management is qualified for their position (like most companies)
- Office politics
- Performance is evaluated on a set chart. This makes gaming the system very easy, which rewards laziness not true talent.
- Moving within WFAF is difficult but there are many opportunities within other parts of the company.
- Lower pay. Remember you are working for a bank not a true investments firm!
- Call center job

review_title: Zero merit increase in 2014, individual employee bonus cut in 2013
job_title: Senior Project Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: 28 days of PTO (although so much work on my plate I have to work even while on PTO, I do at least), living and working  in San Francisco is a plus, but why have "recharge your batteries" time if you can't truly use it?
cons: Google "LA Times Wells Fargo" and read for yourself. All of this is my opinion, but I doubled my output of work in 2013 (required for my job) and was given nearly 30% cut in bonus, and zero merit increase. Management told me, "sorry I was given a smaller pool of money and we had nothing to give out". Meanwhile company keeps sending out messages to team members touting record billions in profits. It's time to leave and work for a company that truly cares about it's employees. So sad.

review_title: My verbally abusive manager eliminated my job.
pros: I enjoyed parts of my work and many of the people.
cons: I had a manager who would shout in my face and call me dumb.  I contacted both Human Resources and the Ethics Line, but nothing was done.  To the best of my knowledge, that manager is still in the same job and makes a lot of money.  I'm on unemployment and have not been able to find work.

review_title: Great opportunity with a large local employer
job_title: Consumer Loan Underwriter III in Saint Louis, MO
pros: One of the largest financial services companies in the country with opportunities all over the county.  Great employment package and benefits.
cons: In an effort to keep up with consumer demand for mortgage refinances, the company hired many people whom they probably shouldn't have in terms of lack of experience or whom ended up being disruptions in the workplace and HR issue nightmares.  In this case it really was a few bad apples ruined it for everyone.

job_title: Licensed Personal Banker in Lakeland, FL
pros: Good training and good benefits.  Focus is on selling as a team.  It is easy to collaborate with partners within the company to help make sells goals so inside referral system can be strong.  Many ways to cross-sell and develop financial relationship with clients.  Great starting point to get into the financial services industry.
cons: Pay is a little low for industry standard in some job positions.  In retail banking CSSRs, Unlicensed PBs, and Licensed PBs have to report to branch manager inside the branch vs. outside Sales Leaders; this creates some micro-management.  Company is about sells but should remember to put clients needs above quotas.

pros: As long as you're with FA's that comp you it's great. When you have managers and co-workers who work hard it's even better. Can also be what you make it. You'll soon see that there are plenty of bank employees who are not so happy in their roles. If you get great managers they'll empower you to succeed.
cons: Combination of mis-placement, unhappy people, or brittle bank industry many bank employees aren't happy and the turnover is high. It really is what you make of it. Sell, sell, and sell some more (bank employees). Client associates are at the whim of their advisers. If they pay you extra, great otherwise too bad. The salary isn't great unless you have prior experience. Limited movement available on brokerage side. You're either an FA, CA, or operations.

pros: Decent benefits, and difficult to get fired unless you do something spectacularly bad. The company is large enough that if you are a climber or explorer, you can probably find a role or experience that works for you. Most managers seem to genuinely care about diversity of people.
cons: Given how difficult it is to get fired, there are many incompetent, time-sucking people safely ensconced all over the company.  The firm wastes money on a colossal scale, both on employment of useless people, and on perks, time wasting events, and inefficiencies.

pros:
1. Decent package
2. You can take planned leaves
cons:
1. Racial Discrimination - If you come from North, India and work in South(Hyderabad) you will face racial discrimination. Manager will highlight your mistakes and will hide mistakes of guys of his community.  Very biased managers.

2. In all the Display screens it is mentioned to use English language but despite that even in official meetings they will use Telugu language irrespective of the fact  you are not understanding. You have to point them out to speak in English
 
3. Manger will create a mail trail not to help you with issues but take it as points to fire you.
