4. The HR will have a meeting just for name sake and will support only Manager. They will not listen to you. Only dummies.

review_title: This job for Sales enthusiastic people only, low salary for all positions
job_title: Credit Manager in Long Beach, CA
pros: Good benefits typical of others, strong company with future. Most other lenders in mortgage industry are tightening their lending guidelines. While WFF is the same, they still  have lots of cash left over to lend for the right people that qualify. So this means, if you are performing your job at minimum sales expectations, you have job security. They are willing to work with you when underperforming as long as you have a supportive manager that you quash well with.
cons: The job is 100% sales. They'll turn their back on being late, disrespectful, even dumb, as long as you provide the numbers in real estate loans. No matter how hard you work, or how smart you are, they will only promote based on sales performance. The starting salary is in the 30's which is quite low for market.

review_title: Good first job for Juniors in College seeking a rapid rate of promotion.
pros: Quick promotion rate if you are effective at closing sales through various means.
cons: High pressure to sell, even when you don't necessarily think it is something you "should" set the person up with. I often find myself feeling guilty for talking people into products they shouldn't be using.

review_title: Wells Fargo a great place to work, but it depends on the group.
job_title: Product Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: 5-7 weeks PTO, great benefits and matching 401k, competitive salary.
cons: Very conservative thinking on many issues, disrupts innovation, especially in high tech groups.

review_title: I've enjoyed most of my time at Wells; learned a lot and felt my contributions had value
pros: Large company means many minds; people to bounce ideas off of and share knowledge with; telecommuting/working virtually is very accepted; the work is a good mix of challenging and interesting projects, together with working on things that you already are familiar with, so building on what you know; mostly good work/life balance
cons: Environment that is resistant to change; management asks for input and feedback but either ignores or fails to consider much of what is provided by the employees; too many burnt out and unhappy people in prominent, managerial positions

job_title: Phone Banker in South El Monte, CA
pros: Its a great place if you want a foot in the door for banking. They offer a tuition reimbursement for classes that are taken that directly benefit the company IE business OT is offered all the time.
cons:
Sales goals are insane. We are in a recession and selling credit and DDA accounts is not easy. 
Most people nowadays cannot meet the basic requirements for having a checking account remain free. We take yearly sales integrity courses but even when we feel like sales are not valid or do not directly benefit the customers we still need to sell them something to meet goals and not have a sup/manager down your back.

review_title: Work hard, but it will never be enough
pros: For what is essentially an entry level job (no degree or experience required), the pay is pretty good.  When you aren't being asked to come in Saturday's the m-f 9-5 nature of the hours are also good.
cons: Impossible to reach sales goals without lying to customers or at the very least being deceptive.  Customer service is ALWAYS pushed to the side in favor of harassing the customer for sales.  The training is incredibly long but spent entirely on making the customer happy which is not a priority at the branch level.  If you can keep your head down and leave your morals at the door this is a great job for somebody looking for a paycheck.

review_title: Not a fun job. A means to an end.
pros: Fair pay, interface and work with interesting people, learned a lot about consumer finance, company tries to show that they care about employees in service positions (albeit they do a poor job of doing so).
cons: It's all about numbers. Unrealistic sales goals, extremely unrealistic customer service expectations, interface with a lot of intellectually challenged people, you can always do more no matter what you do, the branch I was at was non-stop busy which created a daily semi-organized chaotic environment.

review_title: Hopeless & Poor skilled People in Middle Management at Hyderbad, India office.
pros:
1) Good Salary.
2) Salary gets credited before month ends.
3) Work Culture.
4) Ambience
cons:
1) Wrong people or Incapable, arrogant, aggressive people in middle management( like Technology manager 2/3/4) spoiling the brand value of Wells Fargo. They mis utilize their position for personal ego satisfaction and they take things personally but not professionally.
2) No Technical growth.
3) While Working with Wells Fargo people usually get technically outdated when compared to outside market.
4) No trainings given.
5) More of Process and less of work.
6) No initiative taken on coordination between different teams, by middle management as they are incapable of handling different situations.
7) Retirement Place for middle management for doing nothing.

pros:
-Decent bonus/compensation opportunity
-Competitive pay for Reno, NV area
-Some of the supervisors and team leads were truly excellent at their jobs
cons:
-Pretends to care about customers to avoid lawsuits but insists on pressing products onto folks even when their accounts are overdrawn or not able to afford additional products
-Does not place employees based on skill. I was informed that I needed to start in the customer care group regardless of my interest in other positions, and was told that that was how the technical department folks got their start.
-Dominated by a strange anti-male culture. It is an understanding that it is almost impossible to receive promotions at the Reno, NV location if you are male, and males seem to be processed out of employment at a far higher rate than females
-Unevenly applied polices, favoritism, and nepotism
-Unwillingness to invest in technology at the call center- network was left to rot on ethernet standards almost 20 years old, resulting in network slowdowns even though the desktops were perfectly serviceable

pros: If you like sales, work at Wells Fargo. They are very aggressive about sales, and the system prompt you to answer whether or not you tried to sell something to a customer.
cons: The ONLY thing they care about is sales. There can be a line out the door, full of the same customers you see every week who are just there to cash their checks. The customers are tired of being harassed about opening new accounts they don't need or want, and what would actually make the customer happy is to get out of the bank quickly, but managers and other tellers are only interested in trying to sell something and then recording what they tried to sell. The emphasis on sales creates a culture of HORRIBLE customer service, and all the customers complain that they miss Wachovia.

pros: Great benefits , 401k match up up to 6%, affordable health insurance and employee discounts ; example phone companies (AT&T 25%off monthly cell bill  etc) , opportunities to do volunteer work in the community with u peers.. It used to be in the past a LOT about selling more and more product to each customers now they are redirecting their focus on asking questions and need assessments on the customers and even the bankers tracking and sales compensations sales changed. That help bankers focus more on the customer .
cons: Banking industry don't pay. Most of the time is about who u know vs how well you perform . Life Balance - salary range 35k-43k ( average after commission and that's selling more than average ) about only 25% of the bankers reach payout based on sales, I will say about aprox 30-35% of bankers receive payout based of the branch total customer satisfaction survey results

review_title: More leads than you can handle great management
pros: The support here is amazing even when upper management leaves Wells Fargo finds a way to make it work for you and your customers. There are so many leads if you are a hard worker more than 50 hours a week and not afraid to make calls to clients you can make well over 125k as a home mortgage consultant and only work 10 months out of the year. Wells Fargo has allowed me to be the master of 3-4 days weekends while still making a great living.They also buy thousands of leads for you to call for new purchase business, trigger leads of current clients and amazing homes for sale leads.
cons: Wells to Wells refinances compensation is not good but also better than most other bank lenders.

review_title: SVP and SR. Business Initiatives Manager
pros: Lots of opportunities, can set your career, and can learn.  The company is willing to grow the team.   It has been a wonderful place to grow.
cons: The company has changed.  There is a lack of transparency.   It is an issue, people are afraid to raise concerns to management.  Management is not interested in hearing about the issues, and will squash someone if issues raised even when solutions are offered as well.  The management team is concerned about what they look like, and want to create a rosy picture

review_title: The company which has lost it's charm because of because of bureaucracy
pros:
1:transport is free
2:very less development work in india.
3: people keep enjoying their lifestyle and please  keep buttering to your manager or onsite manager . every year you will get double digit hike with promotion.But the reality will only you know , when you face  interview outside market.

3:Work life balance is awesome. Keep telling your boss you are great. that is the success mantra in this company.
4:Please join the company if you feel you are not technical sound or do not want to grow in technology path. You become a manger . You enjoy your life.
5:It is a bit of legacy work but it is fine if you do not want to crack your head.
cons:
1:The current management is changing now a days. The company is not performing well in many area. it has lot of technology debt. 
2:only politics work for carrier progression in Hyderabad ofc.

job_title: Personal Banker I in San Diego, CA
pros: PTO is good for a starting position. Large company and thus lots of states to be able to work in if you like to move. Lots of divisions to transfer to after 1 year of work.
cons: rampant unethical sales culture, high pressure, poorly designed products and a system that is ultimately destructive to the customer and employees. Lazy management that put significant pressures on employees to produce while taking no accountability or responsibility themselves. Lowest on the totem poll gets paid very little incentive compensation/bonus. Business model is focused on quantity not quality. There is a significant lack of teamwork between direct coworkers. "Needs based selling" is a sham as if they do not have a need for a product or service it is because the salesman hasn't found a way to justify one for the client yet.

pros:
diversity initiative within the company to hire diverse persons at more senior levels
solid company celebrating 160 years of doing business
located coast to coast
cons:
it is still a relatively conservative bank
internal process of posting for jobs leaves one feeling as if they are in an abyss
still working on getting rid of the fat after the Wachovia merger

review_title: SOLUTIONS SOLUTIONS SOLUTIONS that's all you'll hear as a personal banker
pros: You will love your job if you love your manager. No if and or BUTTS about it. You are required to sales quite a bit which is fine because you're a sales person. However it gets repetitive and annoying... There is GREAT room for advancement. If you don't mind the low pay then you it'll pay off in the end.
cons: Commission is not paid out monthly. As a matter of fact there is no commission it's bonuses that paid out quarterly. You work hard for 3 months to make a very small pay out and that's even if you hit your numbers which are based on a daily performance yea I said a daily performance and not a monthly performance which is so stupid not to mention the goals are so high and extremely hard to hit. But, It can be done...

review_title: Variety of work-type options at your fingertips.
job_title: Business Applications Specialist in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great people to work with, generally open. Leadership is generally receptive, with a few exceptions. Some of the business lines are very cool to work with and have very communal/friendly cultures, with few exceptions.
cons: Watch out for managers who can be domineering and squash true innovation. A lot of them have been around for so long that they think they know everything in the best way it can be done - so much so that they will obliterate steps in a new and excitingly efficient direction simply because they think how it has always been done is the right way and only way.

job_title: Loan Doc Specialist in San Diego, CA
pros: Decent Pay, they did recognize holidays
cons: Unstable, Disorganized..I left a job I wad at for a few years to work for Wells. Seven months later I'm out of a job. Such a large organization and no one takes the time to crunch the numbers up front and determine if they need to do a mass hiring like they did only to have mass layoffs.  The most disturbing thing is this is common practice. I found out later from other employees this is how they operate. On the other hand I saw so much money being wasted it was a crying shame. Office supplies just sitting around, renting sepetate buildings instead of trying to house all employees in one location. The list goes on. If your looking for a career I would look elsewhere.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Seymour, CT
pros: I really enjoyed my job at Wells, I liked helping people. I liked the sales aspect of everything. The days usually went by very quickly. I was getting promoted after 1 year with the company. They want to promote from within, which is great. For lower level tellers and bankers speak up about what you want and you can achieve it.  I would like to go back, however in a different role.
cons: No work life balance, you work six days a week. Forget about making plans or going to see a doctor. They change the hour you must work without warning, making you stay late or come in early for calls. Management is corrupt and do things that are unethical in order to make sales and hit quota.

review_title: This company was a good stepping stone for interacting with customers and the public. Days can be very fast paced.
pros: You get incentives for the hard work you put in when meeting goals. There is always acknowledgment of your work ethics and constant review of job descriptions. There are advancement opportunities available if you are meeting expectations.
cons: One minute you can be on top and WF loves you but soon as you come across an off day/week/month, you are catching heat! When you find interest in a different career path other than what they want you to go in, they have a problem with it. EX: Retail Banking- Corporate Banking.

review_title: Work hard so the executives can play hard
job_title: Registered Client Associate in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great benefits is about it.
cons: Management treats you like you are nothing - my boss shouldn't have been a manager. They would make promises for extras enticing you to work on extra things that you didn't have to and then gave you nothing. Management would release confidential information about other employees around the office, they also give you their work to do along with countless other job duties and say there is no extra pay nor do they say there is a "detailed job description" for you so you can't go back to them on it. Executives talk about all the billions they earn every quarter and it takes so much to squeeze a raise out of these guys. All I saw were managers picking favorites and allowing people to leave the office for hours and get a free paycheck while others didn't get that privilege and stayed to actually do their job. Who do you think got promoted? The ones who left all day to wander around drinking coffee. Best thing I ever did was quit!

job_title: Loan Specialist I in Fort Mill, SC
pros: The Benefits and Vacation time at Wells Fargo are wonderful you need them high percent of team member are on some type of medication for some type of nerve condition. and vacation is your much needed recovery time to find yourself again.
cons: Benefits package at wells Fargo is great but Management does not care about you the pay is very Low 33% less than any other in same business if you bring it up to management you are told be thankful you have a job. I can gladly show you the door if your not happy. At Wells Fargo you will never be told you have done a good job just what can you better. If you are okay being just a number and fearing day to if you will have a job this might be the place for you.

pros: You might get lucky and have an awesome team working with you who all share the pain of reaching the sales quota. I've made good friends with my co-workers.
cons: Ridiculous sales quota, awful manager. They don't see you as humans. I got really sick and landed in the hospital so I called in sick for the week and my manager literally said, "listen, I've got a business to run and you're making this really difficult for me." I was SICK. Did they really expect me to crawl into work pale-faced and attempt to sell clients credit cards? They also created this weird "visions and values" meeting that was mandatory every Friday that basically begged you not to quit. Work/life balance didn't mean a thing because you'd go home stressed out if you didn't make sales for the day.

pros: Maybe you will love The Interview — if you can ever see the movie — as much as some people hate or fear it. But if you're hoping for any cogent political satire here, then the joke's on you.
cons: It lives up to the hype. Critics who say it’s little more than a smutty “bromance” that happens to feature a caricature of Kim Jung Un don’t know what the hell they’re talking about.

review_title: Want to get into Mortgages? Go work for a broker.
pros:
Benefits seemed to be decent when I was there. 401k had a decent match. 
Free checking/savings through the bank.
cons:
Wells Fargo has a bad reputation in the Mortgage Industry. They are known for not getting loans closed in a reasonable amount of time. Some of this falls on the Loan Officer, other times this falls on the bureaucracy of working for a big bank like Wells Fargo.

Pay could be better.

pros: The only pros w/ the company was their PTO and the employees!
cons: Cons: I can write over 5 pages about the cons of working for Wells Fargo. During the banker training that was over a month long. They said how Wells Fargo is so ethic with opening accounts and made it seem like it was easy to get sales, but that wasn't the case at all. Once we came back from training it was a whole different story. We were pressured to open a million accounts just for one member. I decided to write this review with all the news that came out lately with the lawsuits against Wells Fargo.

pros: Great benefits, fairly solid job security, lots of jobs to choose from to make lateral moves as well as moving up in the company.
cons: You're mostly just a number. management rarely cares about you until it's too late to change your mind. Upper management is so far removed from the process that the "little people" suffer when changes are made. Unfair advantage is given to under qualified people because they made buddies with certain people, while others work hard and are left behind wondering why they weren't helped in their career when they ask.  Not to mention the fact that Wells Fargo is a very recognizable brand and when something goes wrong with one portion of the company EVERYONE is quick to point it out to every single entity of wells fargo

pros:
- Wells Fargo does offer the most comprehensive array of products & services, than any other bank... really making it a place where people can truly have all their financial needs/solutions met. 
- Excellent benefits aside from medical and retirement; offered many other professional and personal resources at no cost.
- Overall the bank has a lot to offer to customers, it's big, convenient, and make a good attempt at raising an sustaining employee engagement and morale.
cons:
- Ethical structuring complete violates its own mission and values; they pride themselves in doing what is best for customers, when in reality it's what is best for the company.
- Unscrupulous sales tactics and deceiving approaches towards customers.
- Was hired for one thing, but ended up pushing credit cards, selling unnecessary checking accounts, and begging people at gas stations, and other retail stores to open accounts.

pros: You will have opportunity to expand your skills, and qualities here! The pay is quite well. If you Listen you will learn how to get by in this High Stress environment. You can take an extra load off your shoulders, by being reserved! Too many people come to work making friends, and that don't ever work out. So, be personable, but focused. They will pay you! So, don't question where you will live, healthcare, 401k, family leave, paid time off, benefits kick either a week or so after you enroll. There's too many benefits. You will make it through here. Just remember you'll be part of a family at this point. You can work your way up in no time if you listen.
cons:
Very Stressful 
Demanding 
Timely at first for new hires
Environment can be uncomfortable when you work with snobs, but the people come to clean when you request

review_title: Not a great time to join this company
pros: Historically, good benefits and good pay; however, the current status is uncertain with massive job eliminations and constant changes.
cons: On-going changes within last 5 years to eliminate departments along with scandals from the former CEO and banker bad sales practices have rocked this company. Sr Management is trying to regain losses by getting rid of good/long time employees. Massive and random employee cuts are happening every week and no department is safe.  Anxiety is high in all areas. Changes by Sr Management seem to benefit stakeholders at the cost of employees. One of WF core value statements is: "People are our competitive advantage" , but how can that be true, when they care more about lining the pockets of the CEO and Board of Directors? Working hard and doing your job well, doesn't safeguard you from being eliminated.

pros:
- shift in culture 
- eliminating sales allowing for more meaningful conversations with customers 
- incentive payouts (depending on work ethic and survey scores)

if you want to grow within the company, as long as you stay motivated and push yourself to accomplish your goals, this is very much possible.
cons:
- lack of professionalism
- little to no structure in the work place 
- dependency on others to get things done 
- timeframe it takes to be eligible to do certain things 
- having to constantly remind others of what needs to be done because of lack of structure 

(every workplace is different) 
it really will depend on who’s managing the branch.

pros:
Good pay & benefits
Ability to work from home (depending on your team, there is no consistency throughout the company)
A large variety of jobs
cons:
Very disjointed workplace - indivdual team members are scattered around the country with little to no communication, no team meetings, and no support or guidance.
Management is too preoccupied by their own work to manage their teams or communicate with/get to know their employees. 
A serious lack of formal processes & procedures has caused a number of very preventable mistakes
Technical & analytic teams lack diversity - in age, gender, ethnicity, & background - especially in management positions

review_title: Lack of communication and morally bankrupt
pros: Nice offices, good location, Pay
cons: Poor line management, having been told I had performed excellently throughout my probation period via a performance review and receiving a 100% discretionary bonus my line manager on my last day of my probation released me (second week into the COVID 19 pandemic and one month after my performance review) with no prior warning of "poor performance" and no proof, which suggests that there is no support or transparent guidance/communication from management if they have concerns. Ensure that you have written confirmation of review of your performance each month during your probation period to support your defence. A 6 month probation period allows the business to release you with no supporting evidence.

review_title: You can move up in the company if you can have one good quarter and someone likes you
pros: Its reputation in the financial industry, being AAA rated. The benefits are awesome. The 401k matching is 6% which is also very good.
cons: Advancement is not very likely unless you know someone in upper management that likes you.  The increases in salary are very poor.  The pay for what you do is awful.

job_title: Registered Personal Banker in Irvine, CA
pros: The company is stable and they offer a benefits package.  In the current financial crisis employment at Wells Fargo is pretty secure, however there are rumors of lay off's comming, as we merge with Wachovia.
cons: In order to progress in your carreer in retail banking you have be willing to throw out your morals, pride and common sense and be prepared to do a lot of ass kissing.  Retail managment does not care at all about sales emplyees, their only goal is to squeeze as much out of you as they can. As a banker be prepared to be assigned redundant and inefficient tasks which will only hinder you from achieving overinflated and unrealistic sales goals.

job_title: Personal Banker II in Greensboro, NC
pros: You will get great bank related training and they are the most heavily sales oriented bank anywhere around. Get ready to learn how to cross sale. They try to get all the "sticky" products they can with their customers. Car insurance,credit report, ID protect etc.
cons: They do not respect their customers or their employees. They try to make you force products on customers that you know harm them more than help them. They have consistently adjusted the sales goals upward and nobody hits the profit goal which is beyond unobtainable. You are only as good as the day you are in because they will push sales down your thoat! You must have 5 preset checking act. appoiintments everyday or plan on getting wrote up daily! Also plan on making at least 100 dials a day to stay out of trouble with your boss

review_title: The employee experience was downgraded when Norwest bought Wells and then further down graded when Wells bought Wachovia
pros: Wells Fargo is truly a vast employment opportunity.  It is a large and diversified financial institution with many different  jobs and opportunities at Wells Fargo.  You can truly change careers without changing employers.
cons: As with many companies, Wells Fargo has turned to understaffing as a way of cutting costs.  This has had an impact on the quality of service to customers and the quality of life for employees.  One hopes that when the economy improves, Wells will return to prior staffing levels.

review_title: Stressful, & You are never good enough.
pros: Decent Benefits, was better when Wachovia. 401K with matching. You get 8 hours of paid time off per year to do volunteer work. Diversity is important to the company. Decent training for new hires & existing employees. They do quarterly as well as yearly reviews, and are very clear about job family expectations.
cons: Overly sales focused, with unrealistic expectations. Lots of pressure from upper management which has a negative trickle down effect. Although the company says they want employees to do what's best for the clients, the bottom line (sales) is really all that's important. You may have been extremely sussessful in your job for a long time, but if you have a bad sales week or (shudder to think) a bad month you are no longer considered a value, but as someone who can be replaced.

pros: Great benefits, stable, decent pay
cons: Management is unaware or in denial about the REAL employee experience.  Layers of management create appearances by manipulating dashboards.  Presentations, especially to management,  are completely scripted and rehearsed.  Advisory partners, such as HR and Risk, yield too much power and regularly undermine line managers.  Think long and hard before accepting a tier 1-3 job; you will have multiple masters.

job_title: Customer Sales and Service Representative in Charleston, SC
pros: Management is focused on developing employees into excellent sales people, and most have been bankers within Wells Fargo (or Wachovia depending on where you are). My manager frequently offers immediate feedback on our customer interactions, both positive and negative, to help the team grow and learn. Compensation is reasonable and benefits are excellent.
cons: It seems like Wells Fargo has pretty high turnover, which is to be expected in banking, but employees are moved up and around to different positions within the business very frequently. Also, though the on the job development is excellent, the actual training needs to be organized differently. Classroom sessions either need to be more in depth, or cut out completely.

review_title: 1yr will give you 3yrs job experience anywhere else
pros: its a big company with decent benefits and pay. room for growth if you are willing to move.
cons: the corporate attitude only mimics customer service and requires you to check your morals at the door. they want you to sell every product and solution even it it does not fit the customers needs,. they will charge any fee as long as it can be spun as the customers fault. my office had so much turnover customers thought it was a training branch. the teller line had 400% turnover. we wouldnt learn there names until they had been there at least 1yr.

review_title: A great place to work for 2-5 years
pros: Great Training and Development. Wells Fargo spends a lot of time and money making sure you know what you are doing. Other companies know this and just by working at Wells Fargo you are now more marketable to other financials. It is a company that rewards you for results which means the sky is the limit. Great technologies and programs because it is such a large company.
cons: It is cut throat. If you are not producing you do not survive. Wells Fargo is working for its share holders just as much as it is for its customers. Limited areas to advance on the retail side.

review_title: Flawed but with some fixing could be first class
pros: The company in itself is good. They are conservative and touch one in every three households.  So your well exposed and looked at a little more favorably then other bd
cons: There training program is flawed and inedequate for this market environment, and does not allow you to grow your business the way they want you to.  They are not about you succeeding just looking to churn and burn.  They also are very conservative an do not like people who have a more risk profile they push that client away.  The hoops and hurdles to get things done is slow and time consuming.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Napa, CA
pros: The pay was good for me coming in wih no bank experience. Great team. Co workers were awsome. Since leaving Wells Fargo Ive worked for another bank and the system at Wells is extremely user friendly and easy to use. Traning was great. They paid for commute time and mileage to and from training.
cons: Sales, sales, sales. Really High Sales goals. The pressure was extremely stressful. But if you can take the stress (and not fall into "gaming") then I think its worth it.

pros: Great 401k plan (6%). several weeks of vacation pay.  Monthly bonus structure. Tuition reimbursement. Employee Discounts on several things (phone bill, hotels, rental cars & much more)
cons:
Most supervisors are not qualified for the position. Seems to be a "High School" atmosphere. Coworkers thrive on the drama..management doesn't put a stop to the negativity or drama.. 
Calls are monitored or recorded and QM will fail you for minimal things (example - if u don't verify the customers mailing address twice on the call - really? How annoying for the customer & rep) two fail calls = NO bonus!.. NO communication or consistency between supervisors / management. Very high turnover rates in most departments.

pros: Customers are great, easy job, and great training programs to get you started.
cons:
Wells Fargo does not drug test their employees, which I found odd because of how much money is handled on a day to day basis. I hated working with people that were always high or on some drug. 
Also, sales sales sales. That is all you are there for. You get no compensation unless you get above their "minimum" sales quota. Which was 100 every quarter when I worked there. It was pretty much impossible due to the small town of Roswell and there was two other branches in the town to compete with. Yes, you have to compete with the other branches so your managers can make their bonus. You rarely will get good feedback when you are doing well, but you will hear it every 30 minutes if you haven't made a sale.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Wells Fargo has good health benefits 
Wells Fargo has a variety of positions and they focus on internal promotion
cons:
Promotions turn into politics it is all about who you know vs you performance
The sales culture is sometimes overwhelming and I believe that we are more focused on the sale rather than the customer's needs
They don't pay enough for the stress and lack of work life balance
Micro management--- The bankers are put under pressure to reach sales goals, the store manager is under pressure from the district manager, the district manager is under pressure from the area president (and so on)--- So everyone is to blame

review_title: Would definitely work for them in the future
job_title: Loan Document Specialist in Las Vegas, NV
pros: I worked in the credit department and it was extremely laid back. Casual dress, you can listen to your headphones and eat while you work. There are monthly performance based incentives and bonuses. Maybe twice a month they buy lunch for the office and there's lots of opportunities for overtime.
cons: Most people have to come in as Temps. It took nearly a year for them to hire me. Some people I heard had to wait 2 years. When they hire you isn't based on your performance at all, it's based on when they have the budget. So you work really hard and have amazing stats but still get paid less than a permanent employee who does virtually nothing.

pros: Wells Fargo general culture is very positive. The health insurance and salary are fair but the Paid Time Off has great potential. They also do a great job promoting from within the company.
cons: The retail bank does not have the same positive customer oriented atmosphere that the rest of Wells Fargo does, or how corporate says it should be. They tell us it's not about the sales but then store managers get nasty emails from district managers about production and then that is taken out on the rest of their team.

review_title: Personal Banker for Hells Fargo... I mean Wells
job_title: Personal Banker in Elk Grove, CA
pros: Pros are the hardest thing to think of when wells comes to mind they have none worth while. They act as if they are family and so much activities going on yeah if your management that's it. Try telling you get your sales bound make money! Only one making money is your managers that's why they push you so hard.
cons:
No pay raises 
No life they take over 1110%
Horrible management I worked in CA and TX 
Sexist pieces of crap the harassment I faced was like no Other. Also sales goals are ridiculous I managed to hit them everytime and still got cussed at for not doing more. When I quit after them transferring me twice out of state (wth 10% travel my butt) they closed my credit cards and accounts saying they didn't know my identity pieces of crap try ruining everything even my credit. Number one sued bank out there.

job_title: Loan Servicing Specialist III in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Management was effective but friendly, coworkers had good spirits and a good sense of humor. Pay was decent, training was thorough. The office had big windows and an open floor plan that was fairly comfortable to work in. The desk chairs were nice and you could customize your workspace a bit.
cons: The work as a Loan Servicing Specialist was so mundane it could almost be considered soul crushing. It's cheaper to hire "managed resources" (which I was) than hire full employees so if you get hired on as a full employee, you only get benefits, no pay raise. Most people burned out fairly quickly because filing claims, though it provides a bit of a challenge, can bore you into oblivion.

review_title: WF branching into Black Hole Exploration!
pros:
1. Almost impossible to be fired or disciplined.
2. You’re likely in the top percentile for common sense if you have any when you start.
3. Recently branched into Space Exploration and creation  of Black Holes, they are everywhere at Wells Fargo!
4. Any new opportunity seems amazing after finishing your time at Wells Fargo!
cons:
1. No accountability
2. Terrible management
3. Riddled with Nepotism
4. Promotions of Yes Men only
5. Contrary or conflicting ideas are dismissed
6. Hard work is rewarded with broken promises and nonchalance
7. Management is either non existent (usually when needed) or micro managing, not much in between
8. Your problems/concerns aren’t important , don’t expect any assistance from management. 
9. Shirts are always dirty from the management and associates trying to become management stepping on your back to get ahead.
10. There are black holes everywhere, so many good careers lost...

review_title: Fast growing until you get to branch manager position
job_title: Registered Personal Banker in Wellington, FL
pros:
Pay is good compared to other companies
No sales goals, very customer service oriented 
Bank hours and holidays
Depending on your manager you will have job opportunities
cons:
After you get to branch manager position is really hard to get anywhere else, hard to get out of retail banking
Upper management is full of people that had good numbers when sales goals existed, but don’t have degrees or real leadership training, they do it more based on their personalities and their knowledge of operating the branch.
Staffing is bad sometimes, they said is full staffed but you can tell that’s inaccurate.

job_title: Business Relationship Manager in Portland, OR
pros: Technology is second to none in the banking world. Comprehensive onboarding training and solid benefits.
cons:
Although the pros listed above are pretty attractive, they lose all meaning when the company culture is unequivocally caustic. At all levels the culture is misogynistic, predatory (towards clients and employees), and at times, downright frightening. I have witnessed overt discrimination, harassment and bullying of women and minorities on a consistent basis. Unfortunately while Wells Fargo purports to have an anti-harassment and anti-retaliation policy, it is well known that reporting these incidents is career suicide, even for those not involved. Subsequently it has created an environment so toxic that it has given me no choice but to seek employment elsewhere. 

I came to Wells Fargo from a different bank to work with the elite in Banking and to grow my career. Unfortunately I would not recommend anyone subjecting themselves to this experience.

pros: Good Company with a solid future.  Great environment to work in.  Most teams in Tech are spread out over the nation and world allowing interactions with people from all over.  Most groups have embraced the mobile work force concept giving the flexibility to work from home and/or the office.  The company has done well by me over the many years.  Fabulous Time Off benefits.
cons: Culture has changed after the Wachovia merger from a West Coast-centric style to much more of an East Coast style, particularly in the Tech Group as management is heavily represented in the East.  As the current Gov't whipping-boy in the Financial Sector (and mostly deservedly so), a lot of energy is being consumed responding to those requirements rather than moving forward which is tiring but will one day come to an end.

review_title: High Pressure + Low Pay = High Job Turnover
pros: Wells Fargo offers benefits to all employees who work 20+ hours a week.
cons:
Wells Fargo Bank is not a great place to work because 

1. Ultra stressful. They demand their employees to put on a fake smile 8 hours a day. In addition, tellers and bankers have to push people to open x numbers of accounts per day. Otherwise, warnings will be issued and then termination if they continue to not meet their goals. A few colleagues were canned for failing to meet their goals even though they were very helpful to their customers.

2. Very low pay. An annual pay increase is minuscule. You'll laugh when you see the extra pennies they gave you.

review_title: Things to beware of at Wells Fargo Financial
pros: You truly become a team, and make true friends from working there. It is amazing to see people that started out with you and how far they get on the journey to the top.  But be careful of the people that have been there for a while.  They will tell you to do things that are against company policy, but they will deny it if ever questioned.  Compliance Analyst are assholes in this company.  They did not succeed as managers, so they assume a non competitive role and try to play cops.  They are underpaid miserable assholes.
cons: Upper management will ask you to do things that are against company policy, but they will let you take the fall for it.  They are liars.

review_title: Great training program for recent college graduates. Sales driven culture makes you feel like a used car salesman
pros: The managerial team was very supportive at all times. Training was extremely thorough, and I feel it was beneficial even though I did not ultimately stay in the banking industry. There were employee-initiated sessions to refresh our knowledge and comfort level with both new products and services as well as those that had been offered for some time. Management was always quick to give accolades for sales accomplishments, no matter how small.
cons: Very sales driven culture. Can be very stressful at times. You must sell 8 products to every customer that walks in the door.

pros: Good benefits & pay.  Lots of positions to transfer to.
cons: Sales goals are unreachable and management makes you feel like you will get fired any time you don't reach them.  To many managers that don't know how to manage.  Bankers and managers that don't know how to treat customers.  Lots of people with lack of ethics when it comes to honest sales.  "Coaching" & more "coaching" (coaching means threats of termination or demotion) to achieve sales of products customers don't want or need.

review_title: Great learning experience with eye opening about corporate call center flaws
job_title: Business Online Banking CSR2 in Concord, CA
pros: Great starting pay for entry level positions, good benefits, and various shift picks not based on seniority, very good learning & development department, and provides materials & resources to excell in position.
cons: Management is a bit incompetent, nepotism, favoritism in career growth, poor "work/life" balance in call center, personalized CUSTOMER SERVICE is lacking, lack of "valued sales", stressful environment, lack of flexibility within management & call center operation, doesn't pay ppl correctly according to commission structure, human resources lacks employee support, each department does what it wants, fake "open-door" policy, and lack of promotion opportunity.

review_title: A hopeful career turned into a disappointing abandonment.
pros: Solid training and career paths.  Great benefit package with 18 paid days off per year.  The accessibility of one working for one of the largest banks in the country.  Lots of products and services to offer the customer.
cons: Micromanagement at its finest.  The employee is nearly a number to those making the decisions.  No long term retention apparent. Absolutely no employee support whatsoever. WF pushes "solutions" instead of quality banking like loan production and deposit growth, thus forcing honest employees to resort to unethical behaviors to sell customers products that they do not need.

pros: Looks good on resume but other than that I cannot say anything positive.  There insurance and pay is a joke.  I made 32,000 / year starting out but was paid hourly around $15/hour.  For the stress and anxeity over their unrealistic sales goals, which are unwarrented considering it SHOULD be about doing whats right for the customer, not shoving as many checking accounts down their throat as they can handle.
cons: Lofty sales goals that increase each year and are impossible to attain without gaming, which is not what WF mission is about "to help customers succeed financially".  Horrible experience and I would not recommend banking or working there after learning about how they actually handle customers and employees and what managers allow bankers to do just to make their DM happy and make their bonus.

pros: Work here now to get it out of the way, if you were ever thinking about it.
cons: The micro management where they stand right behind you and nit pick at things that are done within policy and procedure but they personally don't like it. The required use of over 5 mandatory line of script that must to said/read to every customer despite having know and helped some for year and year, thats not good customer service thats robotic behavior that people see thru. Ergonomics are horrendous. Raises are low despite high earrings for the company. Turn over at the branch level is ridiculous, you barley get to know a co-worker an there gone. Years ago this was a great and fun place to work, it has steadily gone down hill in my opinion. That walk all over the little guys and never help you up. In stead of getting a bonus for reaching all time sales goals are a company, that just raise them and ride you min and min, hour after hour to reach them, day after day. Stress, stress, stress for piddly pay.

review_title: Former Wachovia employee and then Wells Fargo bought us. Loved my job until the layoff...
pros: There were chances for advancement while it was Wachovia.  The culture of Wells Fargo wasn't the same and the insurance products offered compared to ours just wasn't as good.  My team was displaced and it was awful to watch.  The severance package was very good but layoff was during a time when the economy tanked and it was very difficult for any of us to find work.
cons: Never sure if job is safe since the merger. Seems you are always hearing on the news about more layoffs when you think things are getting better.  It's difficult to work when you are not sure your position is secure.

review_title: If you're willing to be unethical and lie to customers in order to reach sales goals this is the place for you.
pros: Having paid time off and many holidays are a plus. Hours are not bad and go by pretty fast. Benefits are good and coworkers are good people. Getting to know regular customers and having rapport with them is a huge plus.
cons: Sales, sales, sales. You will be told in a round a bout way to lie to customers in order to get your solution goals. Also be prepared to become a robot and follow a script while you interact with every customer. Pay is dismal at best starting out.

review_title: Great place for recent college grads
pros: Much better environment than most investment banking shops as far as work/life balance and fellow employees, I was calling on my own clients as an analyst within 6 months, but this cannot necessarily be said for the whole investment bank.
cons: Bureacracy/office politics get the best of the job. Working for a bank involves a lot of time spent on compliance work that can be time consuming and non revenue earning. Ive worked way beyond my job title, but since I am a little fish in a big pond, my hard work largely goes unnoticed. "I wanted to give you a 5 star rating, but senior management says we've been giving out too many so I had to give you a 4"

job_title: Financial Crimes Supervisor in Charlotte, NC
pros: Above par health benefits and top 401k; phenomenal culture
cons: Engaging leadership; HR; Robin Hood at face value

review_title: Like an episode of a Oxygen Channel Reality show
pros: Getting to meet new people, helping them through good times and bad.
cons: Well for starters, I feel like I walked on the set of Bad Girls Club, there is literally gossip and back stabbing going on 24/7 here. I have been working for Wells for 3 months and I have seen 3 people quit, and one person be demoted for no discernable reason whatsoever. The bankers are constantly stepping on each other's toes and if you're a newbie, don't plan on getting an opportunity to hit goals in your rookie quarter, the other bankers will take all the opportunities because you "don't count" and they'll leave you with time consuming and fruitless work.

job_title: Sales Supervisor in San Antonio, TX
pros: Responsible for maintaining and balancing a cash drawer 20 + Years experience interacting with customer or Demonstrate skill in use of computers. Reliable attendance good communication skills ability to work a schedule that includes working weekends , Ability to stand for extended periods of time, I have an outstanding diverse team. Positive approach in interactions with customers, have  Pervions experience meeting customers.  Reliable attendance on time.
cons: Teller team members provide fast friendly check out service to quest and assistance in other areas of comprehensive, personalized care for the community.

job_title: Licensed Personal Banker II in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
Good PTO plan
good match on 401k
if you are a minority it is almost impossible to get fired
cons:
Its a "who you know" not "what you do" company. They do not base promotions on merit, more based on how well you know someone in a position of power. 

Benefits are ungodly expensive. They do not care about their customers they only care about what you are selling your customer. They preach ethics and doing things the right way and then you hit the store and it is SELL SELL SELL at all cost.....they don't need one? give them two.....

if you want to move up you better drink the kool aid

pros: Good people to work with.  Great benefits.  Opportunities to grow and move up.  You learn a lot.
cons: If you don't live and breathe sales, this is not the right environment for you.  Lots of favoritism in the workplace especially with management.  If you're not buddies with your manager, you're not getting anywhere.  The company's vision and values contradicts to* what the manager's say to their team everyday.  Lots of unethical practices hushed by management.

review_title: All the negatives of a big company but none of the perks
pros: Brand recognition, lots of offices nationwide
cons: The company is extremely stingy. Employees get very few perks. Day-to-day operations are very inefficient. Lots of unspoken rules, bureaucracy, red tape. Senior management is all white male. Management has a cultlike obsession with the Wells Fargo stagecoach and pony to the point of total creepiness. Normally at big companies you have great resources to balance out the sense of feeling like you're just a number, but at Wells the resources are nonexistent. I was once reprimanded for asking an assistant for an envelope because it would have come out of the wrong departmental expense budget. SO STINGY.

job_title: Senior Vice President, Learning and Development Manager in Orange, CA
pros: I was extremely well taken care of during my 20+ year tenure in Wells Fargo's Wholesale Banking Group.  I worked with many intelligent and wise managers and senior managers and everyone fully dedicated themselves to running a group that we were proud of.  I learned so much and always felt that I was an extremely valued member of the team.  I was always given opportunities to reach and grow.
cons: Senior Management and Human Resources needs to be more respectful to individuals during the reorganization/layoff process.  It is very difficult to be a very highly rated and highly valued employee one day ... and just a "severance package recipient" the next day.  The process is unceremoniously cold, and doesn't need to be that way.

pros: Compensates better than comparable institutions for similar jobs and has higher job security.
cons:
Heavily bureaucratic.
Intellectually stifling.
Dogmatic, unverifiable, and warrantless pressure to (1) sell as many financial products as possible (mostly impossible), (2) conform to dehumanizing standards of communication (i.e. use a script)

Job description: I stand (or sit if I’m lucky) around waiting for the day to end while occasionally helping negative net worth individuals conduct simple financial transactions. Once in a while, I am ordered to comply with random directives such as greeting customers with a script that remains constant or trying to sell “interest bearing checking accounts” with negative real returns almost equal to the rate of inflation in magnitude.

review_title: Great Place to Work and Contribute
job_title: Senior Vice President  in San Francisco, CA
pros: Career opportunities and confidence in management. You are made to feel that nothing is out of your reach but you must take the first step and manage your career. Additionally you are very fairly rewarded for your contributions and you feel equicably treated. Lastly, it is a fun place to work because morale is very high and people are generally very pleasant to work with.
cons: lack of partnering across business areas which can make it challenging to get things done very quickly and/or without having to escalate to the next level. while communication is generally good and regular and you generally feel you have access to any level of management the rumor mill undermines productive communication.

review_title: This firm has the makings to be great but is headed in the wrong direction
pros: Maybe Wells Fargo will tell Wachovia Securities that they are in charge now and things will improve for employees and for clients.
cons: Company uses inefficient decentralized management style where HUB centers full of power control junkies waste time and money creating strife, conflict and chaos.  Small to average sized clients are pushed out the door with fee after fee.  Big bank attitude removes the caring, personal touch that clients and employees want and deserve.  The only reason this firm received the #1 in Client Advocacy Award is A.G. Edwards.  They were consistently ranked number one in client satisfaction.  The Wachovia Securities nor the Wells Fargo Wealth Management ever appeared, even on the bottom of that list.  After the remaining AGE clients and employees leave, so will the recognition award.  This company cares more about making money for the people at the top than anything else.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Melbourne, FL
pros: At there core the company does try and do the correct thing for there customers, the vision and values of Wells Fargo is amazing.
cons: The fact that the vision and values gets ignored by district managers in the drive for sales, yes it's a sales job in banking now but the goals set are not realistic. Service first sales second you can not have the latter without the first. Cross sell works only if there is a need.

pros: It is a serious company with a strong HR backup. In general, they care about their employees but the problem is that a lot of "stores" (that is the way they call branches) are run like mom-and pop stores so a lot goes unnotices. The best part of my experience was the baner's training as well as reimbursement for some of my MBA classes
cons: Very stressful as it heavily quota oriented. That is the reason why a lot of bankers did unethical things, such as opening accounts without proper identification and even taking advantage of the elderly. Some brances are a wonderful place to work, whereas some can be horrible. Make sure if interviewing to check who the branch manager is and whether the person is fair and ethical.

review_title: If You Are Willing to Be Shifty and Underhanded to Get Ahead, You'll Be Fine!
pros:
Good starting pay for a young person just starting out
Benefits of PTO right away when you start
Other Benefits such as health/dental care, 401K, etc... offered
Opportunities for extra monetary benefits (if you are willing to do whatever it takes to get customers to sign up for more junk they don't need)
cons:
Management always demanding results of more "contribution" (DON'T BE DECEIVED, THIS IS A SALES POSITION....SELLING PRODUCT IS YOUR NUMBER ONE PRIORITY EVEN OVER SERVICE TO THE CUSTOMER!)
Have daily goals to met and if you don't met they you are reprimanded
You are judged by your results no matter what circumstances might affect your daily sales results
Hours are long some days and  breaks are short

pros: I was a teller for 6 months. I loved my coworkers and my service manager was the best boss I've ever had. If you love to convince people to sign up for products, this is the job for you. Tellers are well-compensated for referring customers to bankers. I was only there for 6 months but I saw a lot of people move up.
cons:
Lots of sales pressure. There are check-ins every three hours to see how much we've sold.
Some bankers and tellers do things that are downright unethical in the pursuit of getting "solutions."
If it's slow, it is mind-numbingly boring, if it's busy, you had better be cool under pressure because people are not understanding when you make a mistake with their money.

review_title: Great job, sales goals ruin it though.
pros: My regular customers know me and trust me with their finances. My service manager supports me and my career development. They match your 401k contribution after you've been there a year and offer tuition reimbursement if you choose a career involved with banking.
cons: Employees are constantly pressured to push products and services on the customers even if the customer doesn't need said products/services. Sales goals are insanely high and compensation is not that impressive. Upper management can be extremely lazy and underqualified and tends to use negative reinforcement with employees.

review_title: Senior Vice President and Creative Director
job_title: Senior Vice President, Creative Director in San Francisco, CA
pros: I can confidently say that in the two roles I had Wells Fargo in corporate (not customer facing) departments they do play nice. They mean well, have good manners, and genuinely care about it's employees. They don't move too quickly so there is plenty of time to prepare for change. They try hard to communicate whats going on in the industry, the company and at a department level. I would work for Wells in again in a heart beat. Good, nice people with solid ethics.
cons: They can be extremely slow. They lack innovative passion. I don't know of too many other company's that size that don't have an internal innovation lab. This would help attract younger employees, more creatives, and help retention

review_title: What the company is meant to stand for is great...
job_title: Personal Banker II – Registered in Fergus Falls, MN
pros: The companies vision and values is amazing. What the company stands for and does for the community is great.
cons: They hire people with no experience at more pay than the people who have worked at the company longer/have made their numbers for years. The commissions are very low for the amount of work you have to do to make them. Only get them quarterly. There is also ever changing rules that make it harder to do your job and help the customer because everything is micro managed. The manager experience I have seen in my store and another is that they hire friends or someone they "know" instead of someone who has done well with the company.

job_title: Personal Banker in Old Bridge, NJ
pros: Wells has an excellent on boarding and training program for incoming tellers and bankers. I made a lot of new friends in the program and i felt that by the end of the program i had ample knowledge of the wells fargo systems. They offer a competitive and negotiable starting salary. (Higher than most banks)
cons: Long work hours depending on your branch and district. You Are constantly mic managed, and coached in front of clients. You are constantly asked to sell products to customers that they do not want. However as i understand, following the recent scandal the bank has eliminated all sales goals and this should begin a change in the sales culture.

job_title: Asset Manager in Des Moines, IA
pros: The work life balance is good, with many paid days off.  Matching 401K, health insurance is affordable, 1% profit sharing the last two years.
cons: Your salary upon entry will dictate what you make for many years to come.  Yearly raises are often capped at 2% with many people receiving less than that. There is not a lot of respect for employees in my experience.  Any suggestions or complaints are met with indifference by management.  If you bring up disappointment in compensation you are told you are more than welcome to look for a new position inside or outside of WF.  This is the same for people who have been with the company 15+ years.

review_title: Steer clear; unless you like bad management and typing/sorting papers with insane quotas with low pay
job_title: Data Entry Clerk in Columbia, MD
pros: None except for maybe pay, which was low. Maybe meeting good people.
cons: I worked at one of two locations in Columbia. If you receive this title, you will be flipping around envelopes or typing in a boring environment fast-paced for hours. They don't care about you, they care about how much you can either type or sort within 8 hours. I was let go almost immediately for not making a difficult quota without a warning. Management sucks. Boring repetitive work, you barely can advance without doing it for a year. The woman showing me how to do work was skipping tons of things and not using quality. Then when management sees you doing it, they get upset. It may seem good to work at a bank, but it really is deceiving.

review_title: Great place to get your first job
job_title: Phone Banker in Saint Paul, MN
pros: There are countless opportunities in the company. If you want to completely change your career path you don't have to leave the company and the supervisors are very enthusiastic about helping you with your career path and coaching you individually to help you get there.
cons: The pay is slightly less than what other companies offer for the same position and the hours are often not standard. Because the company is so big you often don't find out about major changes in procedure or other significant information until after they have taken effect. Many times you never get official notification and only become aware of the changes through water cooler conversation.

review_title: Wells Fargo; Take it or Leave It
job_title: Marketing Database Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: Large, well established company with many opportunities to try different jobs within the financial industry.  Benefits and PTO are generous, and are very comparable, if not better, than most companies.
cons: Long standing, established business means processes and people who are inflexible. Each business unit is its own entity, and leads to turf wars, and the inability to communicate between divisions. This leads to redundant work, and horrible customer relations management. Management leads with a cavalier attitude, and manages from the top down. New ideas or dissent is frowned upon.

pros: Wells Fargo is a place that really believes in work life balance.  The benefits package is one of the best I've heard of and they offer many opportunities for growth.
cons: New hires are asked to and must remain in their first position for a minimum  of one full year.  The cons to this are that you can't really move around, unless they agree to a transfer of location.  It's understandable from their perspective but not necessarily too convenient for their employees.

review_title: Good Place to Launch a Career
pros: Benefits are good - generous PTO, lots of insurance choices, 401(k) match + discretionary profit sharing, education assistance. Employees get good deals on financial products. Work/life balance is important, some departments have flexibility for work from home. I've had lots of professional growth at Wells.
cons: Since the Wachovia merger, teams are more fragmented and don't communicate/interact as well. Atmosphere feels more isolated. Difficult to move up or laterally to other positions/teams. Management is less connected, partly due to geographic separation. Lots of uncertainty about future job security, leading to low morale in places.

pros: Great opportunity to build customer service and sales skills. Great way to build your resume and great way to establish relationships and networking. They pay for your school but you must stay with the bank for a one year commitment.
cons: Not enough tellers. Tellers are not allowed to stand. I think this is ridiculous because stand for 5 to 8 hours straight is not fair while the managers and banker are sitting down. It is only fair if they stand. I think if one should suffer the rest should as well equality needs to enforced.

review_title: Stressful.  Really miss feeling valued.  Really miss Wachovia.
job_title: Loan Documentation Specialist V in Charlotte, NC
pros: I enjoy my team.  There are lots of good people that works at Wells.
cons: No family care time.  Micro management runs rampant.  There is definitely a culture difference between west and east coast.  More about numbers than quality customer service.  Management set goal are too often unattainable.  Expectations are not realistic.  Technology is lacking and systems and processes are antiquated.  Bonuses were taken away from many tiers of staff and merit increases have been reduced to almost nothing.  It is disappointing to read about all the earnings but never see it in your pay.

review_title: Great work environment but corporate is too pushy.
job_title: Part Time Teller in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Good compensation. 
Awesome tools for learning.
Great benefits. (Even for part time employee's)
Lots of room for growth.
Bonuses quaterly. 
Lots and lots of pto.
cons:
THIS IS A SALES POSITION. So, you must be able to sell the banker to customers so that the banker can sell product. With that said, corporate is just too pushy with how things a run in Store. Unnecessary scripted interactions with customers. After a while the customer feel like they are just another number because the script is so robotic. 

The intense pressure, for unrealistic sales numbers, from corporate, trickles down the command chain and we are all left in a panic at all times. At times to "motivate" sales it is hinted that you may loose your job other wise. That-- I find very distasteful. 

So if you are not ready to sell like crazy; I would suggest another job.

review_title: The title fit the job but working in a call center was not something I enjoy, I did extremely well at it however.
pros: Good teammates. Fun rewards for working there and doing well.
cons: No interaction with customers face to face. Having to follow a script created by people who have no idea the best way to sell. QA was not consistent. Pay was a joke. In 2 years I reached the maximum in my pay grade and was unable to get transferred for some reason.

pros: You will get paid less than your competition. Managment will also default to the highest producer, regardless of what guidelines or rules were broken. If you drink the kool aid and pretend like everything is okay when it’s not, you could move up if you’re not in a sales position. You will have to relocate to do it. Not many opportunities to stay in the same region to move up.
cons: Completely unethical. Management bullies advisors to cross sell, even when it’s unwarranted. They push advisors to bring clients into the Private Bank even though clients don’t want to. Management does nothing when people break rules, encourage people to stay quiet. I anticipate there will be more WF negative news for years to come. Managment lies to recruits to get them to come. I watched they say anything they needed to and never followed up. They are so big, they just trust you won’t be able to do anything anyways. They want revenue first.

review_title: Wells Fargo is a great place to work if you like getting yelled at constantly.
job_title: Business Relationship Manager in Bluffton, IN
pros: The benefits are truly great and cannot be beaten by anyone in the industry.
cons: Regional management that is imcompetent at best.  They have huge egos and really are clueless when it comes to dealing with employees.  Beating people up for working hard, yelling at people when they are hitting their goals, and not approving any credit requests typically does not lead to happy employees.  You would think they would look at their retention problems and realize this, but their arrogance does not allow for introspection.

review_title: Flexible, Big Company with tons of perks, and benefits.  Fantastic place to work.
job_title: Marketing Consultant in San Francisco, CA
pros: At wells fargo there are many reasons to work here.  For one, the diversity here is the best in the industry, the shear amounts of diversity and openness is unsurpassed.  Also, depending on what group you are in, the dress code is VERY laxed for a bank (Jeans, T-shirt is acceptable).  Also, some offices have fooseball tables/pool tables for the people (wholesale side).  as with any big company, thsi could vary group to group, however except from the finance heavy areas, many workers work remotely, as well as get very lenient PTO.  Speaking of PTO....25 days + 1 day at home a week is fantastic.
cons: Big company, and everything that comes with it

review_title: Management communication to staff is severely lacking.
job_title: Application Systems Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good benefits and "large company stability" (for what that is worth). There is always some chance of being able to move from one department to another to continue a WF career. Some very innovative and rewarding projects, but hard to know if you will be able to stay on such a project. Co-workers tend to be upbeat and helpful within each department. Educational opportunities are plentiful if you fight for them. If you align yourself well with your immediate manager and his/her manager, then you are most likely to succeed. You must ask for feedback and act on it, even if it goes against your personal beliefs.
cons: Very poor communication from all layers of upper management. All management communication is upward facing (i.e., managers suck up to their superiors and look down upon their staff).

review_title: Merger has taken it's toll on my group.
pros: While it lasted, my group made large sums of money and grew for decades.  In general, Wells is a huge bureaucracy and as long as you find a good niche to fill you can end up staying employed with them for years.
cons: Lots of inefficiencies.  You have to ask for approval to do anything meaningful in most groups.  Try and get into a group with management that is "in the club" with the higher ups and you should be fine.  None of my advice applies to retail banking jobs.  The people who work in this part of the bank are usually removed from any decision making part of the WF behemoth by dozens of levels.

review_title: It can be heaven or hell - depends on you.
job_title: Personal Banker I in Nashville, TN
pros: If you work HARD (like never before) - you get a lot of opportunities to grow, good compensations, inventives and benefits. I have work for 3 different banks and this has been the best by far - best benefits and grow opportunities. What is best about Wells Fargo is the people you are surrounded by. They care about you and they always encourage you.
cons: After working on 3 different banks, I can say that this have been by far the bank that pushes you the most. Your goals are higher than any other bank I have seen - sales sales sales. Its hard to get a loan, but they push that product a lot (just to put an example). The pressure is on all the time - so if you don't like to work under pressure, this is not a place for you

review_title: The merger between Wachovia and Wells Fargo has been a tough transition
pros: Promotion from within.  The people that I work with in the branch are great.  Wells Fargo is nationwide now with the merger so there is lots of opportunity if you need to relocate.
cons: Goals are way too high, especially on the East Coast.  Incentive is nearly impossible to make and morale is way down among most employees.  Turnover is high and it's hard to motivate and encourage your employees when they aren't able to reach their personal or branch goals.  Promotion is done from within, but if you aren't hitting your numbers or if your service is not high, then it is very tough to move out of your role.

pros: Benefits-good insurance /401 K /retirement /vacation
cons:
Management unprofessional, eager to criticize rather than commend employees for a job well done (when applicable)
Stronger focus on upselling financial products than providing good customer service for customer's financial needs

review_title: Great place to start a banking career, but soon will find not many doors open within the company
job_title: Personal Banker in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great benefits, many locations, easy to transfer. Have many options into management roles, Loans Underwriting, Operations, Business Banking.
cons: Most jobs, even management, does not require a degree. Its a sales job. ALOT of product pushing. Be ready to sell things that people don't need. After a few quick position changes you can get stuck pretty fast. Job openings depend on others leaving, being fired, moving. Just because your good in one position does not mean you will be promoted into another.

review_title: Overwhelming incredible amazing amounts of micro-management.
job_title: Personal Banker I in Tampa, FL
pros: Decent schedule, only one Saturday a month. Lots of room for movement, drink the kool-aid though.
cons: I work for a district that micro manages EVERYTHING! My manager cannot approve our own PTO, the DM does it. DM every Wednesday reviews every interaction we had with every customer with our manager. I am then nit picked for not wording my contact events just right, or plugging the wrong number into the CNA''s. Nothing is ever good enough. To the critics who would state I am just a slacker I am second in my districts for sales! Doesn't matter scrutiny comes to all.

job_title: Loan Document Specialist in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The benefits were very good.   I was able to succeed because I worked very hard for every raise and promotion within the scope of my job title.  The hours were flexible and my manager was very nice and easy to talk to.
cons: Upper management was very poor.  The site manager played favorites with promotions whether they were qualified for the job or not.  The technology at my site was extremely antiquated.  The desks were entirely too close together so as to make talking to customers extremely difficult.

review_title: A real sneak peek at the large-scale banking business - all that matters is $$$$ (customers come in last)
pros: They were really concerned about overtime so at least you never had to work extra hours? If you are into sales and are willing to climb the corporate ladder this might be a great fit for you. Some minimal sales incentives and ability to move up if you stick with it and schmooze.
cons: I found it hard to work for a company that puts a customer's actual needs last in the desire for profit. We were being asked to sell everyone overdraft protection and I just felt like we were being asked to trick people who are not as great at financial management into additional fees that will only make their situation worse.

job_title: Senior Underwriter in Saint Louis, MO
pros: It was a great pleasure working for Wells Fargo, the environment was comfortable and all staff worked at the same level of respect. My direct manager was very understanding, straight to the point with directions and encouraging most of the time. Salary, Insurance and life benefits were all good.
cons: At the time this company was shifting our jobs to different state. A new manager was hired and began doing serious changes. We were left out wondering for a period of time what's going on and with no clues they cut off our PC's applications and files. Then they lay-off around 200 people at the same time without warning. That was very disappointing since most of us needed that job and we were so good at it.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Irvine, CA
pros: You'll escalate your profession in retail banking quickly if you're optimistic. With the right branch, you'll enjoy working with your team to achieve a goal. They provide excellent customer service training and basic sales training.
cons: They extremely  micromanage their staff at the branch. Sales metrics need to be met or else you'll have a bad day. Although the managers tell you to focus on customer service, they really just want you to script word-for-word towards every customer to get a perfect survey. For 2014, you'll be making 20-30% less starting compared to the existing bankers and managers.

pros: You are given great tools for coaching your team to success. Training is the art of dealing with employees in various situations is very good.
cons: Work life balance is non existent.  You are expected to work long hours on a regular basis without compensation of any kind.  It is not unusual to be told to keep your team after hours calling customers to meet sales goals and then expected to have no overtime for hourly team members.  Retaining good people is difficult without a steady work schedule.

review_title: You're Not an Employee to them, you're just a robot that generates sales.
pros: You start off with 18 days of paid time off for the year (3.5 weeks), starting pay is fair.
cons: The title says it all, if you want to work at Wells Fargo then expect to be pressured about sales, coached ONLY about sales, talked about SALES. Yes, it is a retail position and I understand sales are a big part of the job, but being an efficient banker is providing customer service as well, after all you're dealing with peoples money, money that they busted their behinds to get. Wells Fargo doesnt understand that, I've been told over and over again by 10 different managers that they expect a sale out of EVERYBODY that sits at my desk, even if the customer is only requesting a pin change. I lasted as long as I did because I'm good at sales, but after a while I saw that my sales werent benefiting any customer financially. Wells Fargo just wants humans who act like robots and go about the same script.
