review_title: Although Wells Fargo is a very large company, if you prove you can add value and be dependable, you will get noticed.
pros:
-Strong reputation within the industry as well as from an external perspective when compared to other financial services firms
-Quality benefits including a range of health insurance options that allow you to choose an optimal plan, great company match policy for 401(k), and a range of internal resources for career development
-Nationwide footprint offers potential opportunities in almost any region one desires
-Company culture, diversification, and community involvement are promoted through actions, not just words
cons:
-Compensation seems marginally below the competition, which possibly is a result of the quality benefits
-Lack of cutting edge technology and almost seemingly focused on short-term costs vs. long-term benefits in regards to technology

job_title: Loan Document Specialist III in Homewood, AL
pros: Great experience. PTO above average. Can be a decent job if your team is motivated to do well. Decent incentive checks from time to time.
cons: ALWAYS look for opportunities to advance within and outside of the company. Layoffs can happen at anytime and leave you displaced. A large part of work performance is "luck of the draw" and upper management is not very understanding about it. The job grew drastically in responsibility near the final months. Work on files seemed to overlap and too heavily contingent on the responsiveness and receptiveness of underwriters. A successful or failing file was oftentimes left up to the "discretion" of the underwriting department which was hardly ever consistent.

pros: The career growth is great. It offers employee recognition and management will sit down and talk to you to really figure out what you want. There are some positive side to the fact that it is a sales driven job. Everyone are professional and its just a great environment to work at.
cons: Sporadic daily goals, sometimes they want you to focus on sales and sometimes they want you to focus on key driver metrics. They want you to do prompt service and there is only one way to do it, there is no other way! Management will really be on you if you do not follow rules and regulations. When there is large volume of customer and they want you to do all things or else you will be evaluated.

job_title: Regional Bank Private Banker in San Francisco, CA
pros: Very competitive base pay, great benefits. Great bonus for Private Bankers. Wells Fargo will send you to get licensed (Series 7 & 66) these are crucial licenses if you want to expand your career and become a financial advisor.
cons: Sale Pressure is over the top and it makes the job more stressful than it has to be.  As has been reported in the news, the company almost encourages employees to do unethical things to succeed. I would be much more successful if I chose to fall into this loop, but the unethical employees are the ones who excel and somehow get promoted. Also, branch managers have no idea what most Private Bankers do, so new private bankers are in their own.

pros:
Great program software to navigate through customer interactions. 

Consumer lending products are great comparatively... A lot of the products sell themselves

Incentive program was good.
cons:
Middle Management. I've never been managed by more two-faced, talk out of the side of their mouth managers than at Wells Fargo.

Micromanaged but then told you're not being micromanaged... Just own it people!

Promotions take forever and they low ball you with the offer... Never accept a lower salary than you deserve "just to get your foot in the door" with Wells Fargo, you will shoot yourself in the foot.

review_title: Some Areas are like a Sweat Shop
pros: Your co-workers(middle management and below) are smart, kind and helpful people
cons:
Benefits are not that great. Vacation Time is less than most smaller banks 3 weeks. 
Leadership lacking at upper levels
Punitive Environment- will have actions taken if you make a mistake
Very long hours and very little resources  in areas,  you will work multiple roles even though you are paid for one. 
HR can't be trusted
Trust in leadership is lacking
Work life balance is non existent in many areas.

review_title: Don't work here - Plenty of other options in the Bay Area!
job_title: Quality Assurance Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: I met some of the best people who have strong ethics and are hard working.  They have become life long friends.
cons: They slowly start taking benefits away from employees.  Management was allowed to say and do what they wanted and employees were left with no support from HR.  They didn't have a HR rep in the building so it was tough for them to see what was really going on in person.  Discrimination from management occurred and raised to HR however no action was taken.  A manager made her team complete a test on financial products but you were not allowed to study during work hours.  This test was not a prerequisite for the position and the topic of the test was not required in order to complete the job.  There was no consistency in management or performance reviews.

pros: Great company to be an employee of. Great benefits and PTO. lower mangemant has always been excellent and reasonable. Our business line has good intentions and a genuine approach to sales. Unfortunately a few bad apples have damaged its reputation.
cons: Business processes are highly questionable. Quality assurance guidelines are erratic and some of your pay is based on someone else's objective opinion of how you sound on the phone(soft skills) It used to be a career now it's more like a job or introduction into sales. Communication from upper management needs to improve, business processes are constantly changing (sometimes without lower level employees knowing). It can be tough selling for this company givin the environment and spotlight it's in right now.

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Mortgage origination system is the best I have ever seen in the industry, Underwriters will actually call you to review the loan, Jumbo pricing is by far the best in the industry. Unless you compete with another bank all Jumbo loans are yours. Very relaxed environment, no micro managing. You will be running you own business.
cons:
Bank referrals are gone
You are to bring in your own business, dont count on enterprise to give you anything
managers are just lazy, and well protected, company will fire you before questioning them. 
Jumbo Self employed income calculation is very conservative, some loans will end up funding at other banks
be ready for office POLITICS!!!! O yeah, lots of Drama and Politics
Conforming pricing sucks
FHA? hah
very restrictive on kind of marketing you can do (this is a large bank after all)

pros:
1.Less work and job pressure. 

2. Decent work life balance
cons:
1. Used to give good hikes till 2017. Stopped IJPs in times. 

2. South Indian crowd and management. I barely seen lot of diverse people in a group. My manager was Telugu and i was only north indian from that 10/12 people team which is claustrophobic in times.

3. Stopped confirmation hikes since 2017 

4. Technologies used are legacy mostly. Not counting analytics. Java dev is old school regular workers. No work for big data developers

review_title: I loved working in Wells Fargo. I can say the best place to work.
job_title: Operations Analyst in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good benefits and atmosphere. Free coffee for the employees
cons: Recruiting Process is not good at all. Company does say that they care for their employees but with exceptional performance, I never got a chance to grow my career within the company.

pros:
+Coworkers are great and everyone in the office works hard
+large company so there's some security
+processes are established so you just do things their way.
+pay and benefits aren't the best compared to other banks but still solid.
cons:
-long hours, easily 50-60+ hour work weeks, no time for social life. There have been times where people have worked through the night!
-low morale. It feels like they're just using us up and waiting for us to burnout. A coworker said the best part about the job is it's better than working at the branch. Another said they were feeling guilty because they had to decide whether to work, sleep, or spend time with family.
-work is unrelenting and assignments aren't flexible
-stuck at desk most of the day. 
-investigators at other offices don't seem to be as thorough

job_title: VP, Product Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Wells Fargo encourages a good mix of work/life balance.  Obviously it depends on the group and management, but I have never had a problem taking days off or even large blocks of vacation (e.g., 3 weeks) at a time.  Having 5 weeks of PTO is outstanding, and I work from home 2x per week.  The senior management is very competent - proven by 20 years of results through various economic cycles. Overall a good company to work for.
cons: Obviously it's big, and it's a bank, so red tape is inevitable.  There's a lot of process and procedure, but I think that's inevitable with the size of company and in financial services.

pros: Best reasons to work for Wells Fargo are that you will have a great support from your fellow team members, especially your managers. Great opportunity for advancement in your career. Great bonus that you get every three months just for doing your job. Lastly its a great company to work for because you get to help other succeed financially; knowing that you just helped someone financially really makes you proud of what your doing!
cons: There are not many downsides of working at wells fargo! If i had to choose one though, it would be the fact that they don't recognize a college degree for raises and promotions. Some one can have a undergraduate degree in business and get paid as much as someone who doesn't have a degree. I think something has to be changed about this!

pros: It is a great place to start a career in finance. They pay a good minimum salary and the company pays tuition reimbursement.
cons: There are significant moral and ethical challenges. There is extreme stress related to production. The leads are used, reused, and ultimately overused. Management is not based on ability to lead but sales production so sometimes there will be managers who will power trip and are just unfit to lead. It gets really boring sitting in an office starring at a computer screen all day. The products are inferior and people are more knowledgeable about the subprime market now. Lastly, you are only worth the money you can consistently bring to the company.

review_title: Wells Fargo is stable, well run company
job_title: Product Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Different divisions can have different cultures, but overall I would say that Wells is a really well run company with a good culture and very solid ethics. They do a lot of great community and charity work. Generally employees are treated well and many employees stay with the company for a very long time because they have the ability to grow and move around the company.
cons: Culture can vary by division, so a lot depends on what you're dong and who your working with. In my group and role, I find I am constantly on the phone for back to back conference calls and that can be very draining and not always as productive as all that.

review_title: Never work for Wells Fargo, if you don't want to be fired from a job.
pros: Any company that has benefits is a plus when you have a family. Some of your co-workers are fun to work with. Make good friends with customers.
cons: Sales expectations are too high!!!!! the compensation for being the top sales person is not worth the agrevation and headaches. There are conference calls three times a day with the District Manager to see if you are selling. If not they call you out and put stress on the manager in turn the manager goes crazy and makes for an unpleasant atmosphere. The manager consistantly pressures you for sales until the day is over. If you don't open new accounts everyday, you will be fired. Not enough compensation to put up with the BS!!!!

review_title: Good job.  Great learning opportunity, but a dead end
job_title: Business Banking Specialist in Denver, CO
pros: Fun, challenging, and the clients are really interesting.  You're always learning something new, both about the industries your clients work in and about loans and financial instruments they want.
cons: You need experience to do well at this, but it's a dead end.  If you don't have the experience, you can do a marginal job.  If you do, you logically want to move on to work with bigger and more complex clients.  However, that is on the business banking side and this is a personal banking role, reporting to a branch manager, so it's hard to make the cross-over.

review_title: Wells Fargo - a good place to start a career in business banking.
job_title: Business Deposit Consultant in Napa, CA
pros: Wells is a great place to learn general business banking skills such as credit underwriting, treasury management, FX, etc...  You really don't need any banking skills just business-to-business sales experience.
cons: Wells is a trillion dollar business and as such they have to managed to the lowest common denominator which is sales, sales, sales.  The pressure is enormous and you are only as good as your last quarter.  This is not uncommon to many corporate businesses, but in Wells' case it leads to some very questionable behaviour.

pros: Good experience and good for your resume.  Wells Fargo has a very efficient hiring process and lots of openings, so it was easy to get hired.
cons: Extremely high pressure.  Often times coworkers agreed that anything you do at Wells Fargo is never good enough.  Some people have trouble with cash balancing, some people have trouble multi-tasking with all the duties assigned, some people have trouble in diffusing situations where a customer is unhappy (which happens a lot).  Virtually all employees are unable to meet sales expectations.  And they let you know this every single day.

pros: Good benefits. Just about ends there.
cons: Widget sales. Micro management. Punishment for not meeting goals. Treated like you are dumb. Unreasonable sales goals. Absolutely ridiculous sales plan. Terrible rates on loans and savings items. All hands on deck Saturdays on a whim. Management does not care about employees or customers. Terrible customer service.  Please leave your brain at the door and follow our scripts way of doing things.

pros:
The ability to gain a wide base of knowledge regarding banking and financial business.   
Large company that provides several different career paths.  
The potential to earn good bonuses.
cons:
The company's culture is completely contradictory to the companies Mission Statement.
High stress sales environment.
Ethically questionable work environment.  You will be expected to push products that may not be in the best financial interests of the client.
Management will turn a cheek to unethical sales and sales manipulation tactics because it benefits them.
The incentive goals are extremely difficult to hit.
Low pay in general.
The only recognition you receive is regarding sales. Any other work is irrelevant.

pros: on the bright side it does provide you with good experience with a nationally known company. Much more responsibility than just a ticket punching cashier.
cons: Where to begin. Huge company so everything is approved from someone above yourself. High turnover which stresses the operations heavily. Within 5 months of working at one location I had climbed to most experienced teller. Should be a good thing right. Nope, most people quit or bail out on a branch to follow someone they previously worked with. Lastly, I have no problem with sales at all when it is a needs basis. But setting unrealistic goals spills over onto our customers and forces us to sell an 80 year old person a debit card just to swipe in at the counter so we can reach our goals. Come one Wells stick your vision and values.

review_title: Wells Fargo Teller Position is a Sales Job
pros: Great work environment since I had a great Boss.  I was able to work a flexible schedule and really enjoyed my co-workers.
cons: Sales, Sales, Sales.  We had to offer something to every customer at our window even when you could tell you were annoying them.  Some people I saw on a regular basis and each time It was expected for me to "sell-offer" them a product that we make money on.  Forget customer service this is all about selling.  The quota's are high and hard to meet unless you are incrediably dillegent or if you are at a larger bank with lots of customers.

job_title: Collector in West Des Moines, IA
pros: Thorough training, excellent benefits for part time including paid time off, incentive program, other rewards programs. Lots of room for advancement in Wells Fargo. Collections is kind of a bottom feeder job, but if you start in collections you can work your way up to higher management positions within Wells Fargo.
cons: Hours are not the greatest in call-center environment. Expected to work weekends. Management not always helpful, or knowledgeable about company policy. One day they will give you advice about how to improve job, then the next day they will act like they never told you something. Sometimes management seems to purposefully leave out important information like not explaining that overtime is required.

pros: 401k is matched by the company. Health care is provided. Room for growth. Good for people who like to meet and interact with people on a day to day basis.
cons: Depending on the region, growth opportunity maybe limited do to bias management. To much gossiping in South Florida region and jealous that may negatively affect your career. Long work hours cause imbalance in personal life that will leave you no time for anything. Extremely sales driven, to the point where customer service is no longer top priority. As a banker, I wasn't provided a desk to see customers and was still expected to meet high daily goals. Was only allowed to assist in fellow team member in obtaining their daily goals. Some management and team members perform unethical behavior to meet sales goals, such as opening accounts without customers consent.

job_title: Customer Service and Sales Representative in Atlantic Highlands, NJ
pros: Benefits and salary combined with sales incentives make for very good compensation. Sales goals are pretty achievable when given the right tools and placed in a good market. Products are simple and we have Banker Connection which is a very good support phone service that can be a lifesaver. Very easy to move up if you have a good head on your shoulders.
cons: Too much stress from the top as it trickles down to us. If you're stuck with a boss who's too numbers-driven, then you will never enjoy a day on the job. Sales goals are achievable, but if you don't achieve them, you will never hear the end of it.

pros: Opportunities for growth, pretty good quarterly bonuses if your store performs well.
cons: Very competitive, lots of sales pressure. You are expected to say whatever you need to say to make the sale regardless of what is best for the customer. There are lots of bankers talking out of their a** to make sales numbers. Management is incompetent. Upper management is never happy with performance. Very poor work-life balance. As a teller, the job is not worth the stress. Your customers are randomly surveyed about their experience and if they don't give you  5 out of 5 on all questions it is considered a bad survey and counts against the whole store. That means a customer can give a 4 out of 5 on one question and a 5 out of 5 on the rest and the whole survey is considered "bad".

job_title: Loan Document Specialist in Charlotte, NC
pros: Great people to work with
cons: Wells Fargo puts up an image as a great employer, I was involved in the mortgage industry and was diagnosed with an Incurable heart disease, when I returned back to work voluntarily after being out for a couple months to deal with my medical issues, Wells Fargo laid me off due to performance. I was out for 3-4 months and was laid off due to performance, this was absurd to me because my absence did not account for what I had done in the past, now I have moved on and have actively looked for better for reliable employment. Wells Fargo seemed like a great company with promised opportunity that was never seen, if you are in the right department it might be different but my experience was awful.

pros: Great company ethics when it comes to employers, great pay, diverse company and many opportunities for promotion
cons: The Daily sales goals will have you contemplating quitting every single day. No one lasts as long as upper management says you will. Turnover rate is insane. Managers put crazy pressure on you to produce to the point to do unethical things just to hit numbers. Managers will have you solicit random people and companies on a daily basis to get checking accounts. It extremely embarrassing and uncomfortable. There is no work/life balance. Be prepared to never see your family. Oh, and if you live in an area that can get harsh winters...be prepared to go in and stay all day even when its dangerous outside (i.e. snow, hail, hurricanes, etc. )

pros: Good opportunities for advancement. Pretty flexible for college students. Really fun people to work with and often fun customers as well. Managers want you to move up. Awesome vacation time/paid holidays.
cons: SALES. SALES. SALES. or should I say solutions...this is THE most important aspect of the job and it sucks. Pressuring customers, and non-customers to open accounts, credit cards and so on. Company tries to claim that it is all for the person's benefit but it's hard to see that most of the time. Constant micro managing and almost a nagging-like form of sales follow ups. Goals and plan are the same everyday, yet we are asked what our goals and our plan is every morning. Tellers are responsible for WAY more than probably anyone in the branch, yet are paid the least (bankers and mangers have agreed).

job_title: Mortgage Loan Officer in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great leads, resources, book of business, huge market share. Great place to get started as a mortgage officer
cons: too many levels of management makes it very difficult to get things approved and loans done. 100% commission with a draw, if you have a bad month of two, makes it very difficult to get back on track.

review_title: Every worker only cares for themselves.
job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in West Palm Beach, FL
pros: Looks good on your resume when you leave the company to go somewhere else
cons: You get micromanaged throughout the day and are constantly reminded that your quarterly sales quota is not looking good for your review. Customers are fed up due to the fact that the banker they were recently dealing with is no longer at the company because they were let go due to poor sales.

review_title: Pay doesn't seem to be in line with other banks
job_title: Licensed Personal Banker in Highlands Ranch, CO
pros: 401k match at 6%.  They promote from within so moving up/promotions can be frequent. Choices in health insurance. Term life insurance and accidental death and dismemberment coverage
cons: pay is lower than other banks in area. Only way to be paid more is to threaten to leave or be promoted and then shortly later step down. If management is not your career path you will find that they will put off promoting you to keep you around but will promise it is coming soon

pros: Extremely diverse, diversity is included during training.  Great benefits.  Very supportive company if you are an ethnic minority, LGBT or and any other class protected or not, Wells Fargo is an all inclusive employer.   The culture of caring is amazing
cons: For me, too much scripting (Though necessary for consistency) too much knit picky crap on monitoring phone calls.

review_title: Not a bad place for older folks who want some stability & looking to retire
job_title: Technical Project Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Quite stable despite recent layoffs. If you deliver everything expected of you, you a likely to keep your job.
I know what is expected of me at work.
2 days telecommute.
cons:
Very profitable bank staffed like a poor startup
Very little work life balance - poor work load balancing by manager. No prioritization - every thing has to be done by regardless of how few employees are in your team.
Zero employee input - Managers (in fact every body) needs to say "Yes" to higher up to keep their job - I think this is bank culture
Lots of outside business hour work, although it is to be expected since this is a 24x7 a website
So much process & paperwork, surprised anything ever gets done

review_title: I will be looking for a new job
pros: I am currently employed by WF the best things about working for this company are the Benefits, PTO, and very competitive salary.
cons: Its very true what all the reviews say, everything about this company is sales! Upper management makes it seem like sales is not all that matters but they will pressure you until you break. I will never recommend working in this company to anyone!  My manager verbally abuses and insults all of his employees including myself because of pressure put on him to meet overall goals. I am scared to call HR for fear of losing my job or being branded as a "HR Rat" because gossip travels fast within the market. Ive trained with more than 20 people in 2 different markets and they all say the same. Shame on John Sumpf for pretending that this does not happen. I stay for call night until almost 8pm 4 or 5 days a week. The work/life balance is awful! STAY AWAY WHILE YOU CAN!!

job_title: Lockbox Operational Clerk I Associate in Chester, SC
pros: To grow with the company would be of great pleasure to grown within the company..
cons: I wasnt giving a fair opportunity as a team member. As a 30 hr who to meet the same standards as a 40 hr team memeber .overall I wanted to grow within the company itself..

pros: They have shifted the focus from sales and widgets to actually caring what the customer is talking about and what they trully need.
cons: Pay is worst now. Since sales have been cut the opportunity for bonus is drastically reduced. They cut the bonuses all up and only gave raises to tellers

review_title: Worst Supervisor and line manager in Cards collection experience
pros: The aminity, ambiance are great. Also team mates in US are great only in my line of business which are my supervisor and line manager who treated their people very unprofessional manner
cons: Working with unprofessional sup is the hardest part because you will be the one to adjust.

pros: Regular (f/t) hours, paid holidays, easy daily duties, can be a very enjoyable job depending on manager.
cons: Poor management, unrealistic sales goals, favortism, company pretended they didn't know CA was cheating the system for over a decade.

pros: Value their workers, 15 an hour full-time with 6 weeks paid training, volunteer opportunities, gradual training they don't throw you to the wolves, opportunities to grow
cons: phone banker position is a little boring for me. you take calls and stare at a computer all day, even after 6 weeks of training the calls can still be confusing and you don't know exactly where to go for help once you make it to your team, you dont get to move around in the company until after youve been on the phones for an entire year

job_title: Mortgage Loan Officer in San Diego, CA
pros: The WF brand is recognized worldwide. Lots of marketing materials, user-friendly origination system that interacts with clients well, good medical/dental benefits, 401k, etc.
cons: The brand is tarnished which makes it very difficult to establish new relationships with referrals sources. (Realtors HATE WF.) Extreme preferential treatment with a small handful of Mortgage Loan Officers which makes for a toxic and resentful environment. A few loan officers are allowed to take large price hits and make crazy loan exceptions which enable them to fund $100+ million/year. This allows WF to have a few LOs on the Scotsman Guide each year. Your base hourly rate becomes a recoverable draw (which is illegal) and if you have a small funding month, you will actually OWE the company money the following month to reimburse them your hourly wage. If you are a Mortgage LO, run. You will actually hurt your career.

review_title: Wells Fargo Employee to Employer Feedback
job_title: Client Service Associate in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
-401K Match Program
-PTO
-My Co-workers were my family
-Senior Management seemed to care for all employees
cons:
-My division was closed as were a lot of divisions within Wells Fargo after the banking scandal
-A former manager (immediate) became very disrespectful and unprofessional - they were reported to HR by other team members which ultimately led to a hostile work environment,
Health Insurance used to be affordable and fair but they have switched between companies in prior years and the cost to employees has risen in not only our premiums but also our out of pocket expenses when receiving health care.

review_title: Great fresh grad job - you will learn a lot.
job_title: Personal Banker in San Jose, CA
pros: Awesome Training program for sales individuals. Looking back - the systems that Wells Fargo uses are by far the most advanced and user friendly than any other institutions I have worked with since then.
cons: Sales pressure is intense. If you can meet your numbers, great - if not start looking out before you are "coached out".

pros: There are many career advancement opportunities within Wells Fargo.  You can easily start off as a teller and then work your way to lead teller, banker, and then service manager in two or three years.  After that, you can become branch manager.  In my case, I'm currently looking for opportunities in the IT area, and there are countless opportunities there once I graduate.
cons: On the retail banking side, Wells Fargo seems to focus too much on sales.  That puts a lot of pressure on the employees to sell their products and services, and advancement is often dependent too much on how well you can sell.  For example, if you are a teller and want to advance to a service manager position eventually, you'd better be selling well.

review_title: My time here has been like rafting a river, tumultuous at times and calm at other times.
pros: The Benefits were great until 2012 when they changed their medical plans. The Time off earned is a really nice benefit.
cons: I have seen many instances where somone is hired based on friendships or other reasons and not based on skill or knowledge. In time I see this hurting the company in the long run.

review_title: Company culture is excellent however, opportunities for advancement are difficult to come by.
pros: Many opportunities to be recognized for hard work.  Clear communication about organizational changes.  Intranet site is inclusive, interactive, informative, and exciting.  Senior managers are long established and have deep knowledge of the industry the are in.
cons: There has been constant organizational change in the past three years with companies being acquired, divisions merging/splitting/going away.  This causes some uncertainty about where your department is headed and how your responsibilities are affected.  Little opportunity for advancement in support departments since managers tend to remain established for a long time.  In the past year Retail has been expanding rapidly so there is more opportunities for promotions especially with new offices opening up.

review_title: Large and primarily a retail driven financial institution, it has it's ups and downs.
pros: A good number and variety of lines of businesses to choose from to move around within the company.
cons:
- Lofty (recent newspaper articles say "aggressive") sales goals, micro-management, and a very process driven company that can give you the impression it's run by business consultants.  (ex: Office Space, an exaggeration but does come to mind)
- pay/commission - The company i tight and would rather spread a little (really small) incentive/commission to everyone vs. rewarding the producers.  
- Stay away from the retail banking line of business unless your young and have no expectations.

pros: the money, but it's not worth it! the half-time workers get half the payout for the same amount of work.
cons: Bad (HORRIBLE) management, everyone is stuffed in one room for. 9-10+ hrs a day, social security/disability checks every month WILL be the death of you. Did I mention solutions don't sound like a big deal but THEY ARE TO MANAGERS AND DISTRICT! literally I felt threatened to preform, and put down constantly by my immature know-nothing bank manager. Had no manager managing the tellers which they are supposed to have one called the service manager, was never accurately trained and I was left to fend for myself and fell victim to co-workers and managers blaming me.

review_title: Overall I enjoyed working for this company
pros: I enjoyed working for Wells Fargo for the past year and a half. It's a great company to work for especially while in college. The company's hire within program is excellent; I've seen many of my colleagues move up and become bankers and store managers. The opportunity to grow is all the motivation needed to exceed sales and service goals.
cons: While working as a teller for Wells Fargo, I personally found their sales goals obtainable, however, over the course of my time there, I've witnessed several changes that made it harder and harder for tellers to make their numbers and receive a quarterly incentive.

pros: Well-known company so they offer decent benefits especially to students with tuition reimbursements. The company itself has pretty high goals for success.
cons: Management isn't well-trained for their employees. Very sales-based rather than customer-based although in a bank I feel customer service should be top priority, especially when they don't even need more accounts or more credit cards. Training is lacking throughout the branch and nothing is ever consistent.

review_title: stressed, negative and cut throat work environment
pros: stability of the company and wells is present in roughly 30 states
cons: no work/life balance, uncaring and cut throat style of management, very much a churn and burn mentality when it comes to filling positions...the turnover rate is well over 50%. Very micro managing and it doesn't matter what you did yesterday...it only matters what you are doing for them today and what you plan on doing tomorrow.  Meeting sales goals is the main focus above delivering great customer service...this intense sales focus has created a very unethical work environment in that people will do anything to meet that sales goal..ethically or unethically.  If you don't meet sales goals then you are required to stay after hours to make cold calls.  They use a threatening style of management to get people to meet the goals...instead of coaching and helping them.

review_title: Personal Banker role - means to an end.
job_title: Personal Banker I in Dunwoody, GA
pros: I enjoyed the customer interaction, the standard hours, and helping people reach financial goals. Usually the tellers were very nice, and the customers and I built up a good relationship.
cons: Corporate sales structure is crushing, pay is very low, no customer loyalty, dead with customer complaints, wear a full suit everyday.  Other personal bankers try to steal your accounts since that is how bonuses are earned.  It is always a competition to try to get new business.

review_title: I have to make a paycheck to support my family.
job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Dothan, AL
pros: Pays the highest in its category.
cons: They don't care about you as a employee or about the client.  Completely consumed with numbers. The people who do things scamming and have numbers over goal r rewarded and praised those who meet expectations and gain loyal customers are criticize and wrote up for not pushing for more. U r required for late hours calling and long days of soliciting whether you have numbers or not. Not possible to have a real home life.

review_title: Decent pay, structured environment, excellent training
pros: Most training I've received at any position, great trainers and good learning environment. Name recognition is good for business. Great opportunity for growth and advancement. If you work hard, it will be recognized. Great hours.
cons: Pay is mediocre to decent and there is a lot of turnover but some of that is due to very high standards and the average employee may not measure up. If you don't want to work hard and ethically, you won't last, if you have strong ethics and appreciate a structured environment, you'll do well.

review_title: Relentless hounding for horrible compensation, but good opportunities for advancement if you hit bonus goals.
pros: Good opportunities for advancement and excellent benefits. Many top executives started as tellers. Company lives and operates their core values, not just superficially. All training is set up so you learn to act ethically in banking and not to cram things down people's throat.
cons: Terrible pay for what is expected of you. Constant hounding by managers that are not trained enough to give you proper coaching so the result is just them aggravating everyone. Values and ethics are clear but that doesn't mean much when incentive plans are so high you can't hit them without selling to people who doesn't need anything.

pros: There are tons of advancement opportunities. I initially started in a position that didn't end up being the best fit for me, and I was able to move around to a different department after a year. I enjoy what I do, and I work with a great team. I thoroughly believe Wells Fargo wants to do right by its customers.  The benefits are also better than many other places.
cons: The pay is on the lower side. Additionally, the company is so big that it can make processes inefficient. There are work sites all over the country, and some other sites have very poor work ethics and the better ones end up having to pick up the slack.

review_title: Great spot for Financial Advisor Trainee
job_title: Financial Advisor in San Jose, CA
pros: Wells Fargo Advisors has great tools for newer people coming in to the industry.  The training is very good and the salary is competitive.
cons:
Starting your career outside of a branch is really tough.  The Private Client Group, where I worked, has more upside potential, but also significantly more downside risk.  In the branch, you're going to meet people who have money and are looking for direction.  Outside the branch, you've got a much bigger challenge to hunt down leads.    

If I were to do it all over again, I would start in a brick and mortar location.  Much easier to make the contacts needed to be successful.

review_title: This company gives to those who work hard...
pros:
-Benefits (PTO, tuition reimbursement, & insurances)
-Decent pay
-"Culture of caring"- at least in the phone bank, I've seen so many occasions of this company working for it's employees who then work for the customers
-Amazing job opportunities- if you work your butt off- you will be rewarded! (I have worked here for 3 years and have gotten 3 promotions and 6 raises within those jobs)
-Flexibility when life happens (moved across the country for a job transfer within WF and had to come back within a week due to a family member getting ill- there was no problems in coming back to my old position. No questions asked.
cons: Long hours when you start out- obviously as a salaried employee it can become taxing. But once you get a hang of things- you are right back to a 40 hour work week.

review_title: Sales driven, customer satisfaction is a must.
job_title: Service MANAGER I in Austin, TX
pros: Help customers grow financially & develop the teammates around me. The money is decent and you get out of the office to build business relationships.
cons: Forcing sales down your throat; wanting you to badger every customer. Lack of pay increase during a promotion. Negotiate your money on your initial hire because you won't get it later- trust me!

review_title: Retail Banking for Sales Driven Giant
job_title: Personal Banker I in Austin, TX
pros: Wells Fargo had  a great training program. Their benefits are also great. There was a lot of opportunity for growth - with the understanding that you had to make your sales goals. It looks like they have been trying to make some changes that may positively impact their employees.
cons: Unrealistic expectations in a rigorous sales environment. Although, in light of the bad press, sales goals have been taken away - I'm sure it's a matter of time before something similar, or worse, takes it's place. I don't see their rigorous sales mentality going anywhere. In the banking world, that's what they have always been known for.

job_title: Senior Quality Analyst in Austin, TX
pros: Flexible work timings .  Friendly work environment .Not much work pressure
cons:
Technology/  process/ applications are age old.
 Avg hike not more than 10% . 
Your promotion depends on how good your terms are with your higher management rather than your work . 
Horrible place to work as contractor . Work is  redundant  .
 Pedestals not provided so carry your headset, charger  etc etc every day and yes if you leave it on your desk it will be stolen even though there are cameras every corner .
You don't have flexibility to cummute as you like . Either you book parking for 2 wheeler or 4 wheeler or opt for public transport or company cab .
No perks on birthdays or anniversary or long service

review_title: Pretty good for a teller job
pros:
Starting pay is higher than min wage for entry level teller position. 
Wells is a lot more lax than other banks- there's not sales goals or pressure to meet numbers. (ever since the news a few years back, theyre all about being ethical and what's right for the customer.) 
The company is overall pretty inclusive and diverse 
They are all about your next career step and how to get you there, and promoting within
cons:
Judged on how you talk to people, you're always being watched and your manager has to do "observations" on your interactions. There's not a pressure to sell but there is a relaxed goal to get customers to sit with bankers if there is a need for it
Being a teller is like being a cashier and there's not really much to do other than take transactions which gets boring

pros: Talented people with tons of potential • There are lots of opportunities • A decent employer as far as pay and benefits go • Fairly flexible when it comes to work-life balance
cons: A BIG company with lots of red tape • Conservative and risk averse • Slow to react to new opportunities • Actions don't reflect what's being said • They say they want digital-first and cutting edge creative, but little of the work actually is that • Favoritism runs rampant – you're either in the clique or you're out in the cold • Meetings – lots of meetings

review_title: Comfortable with a little room to branch out.
pros: Wells is supportive of a great work life balance, investment research does great work, benefits are excellent.  There are gennerally very good and supportive people that join the team.  The C-Suite has done an astounding job of managing through the most challenging time in several generations.  Kudos.
cons: Wells is a very large company and they run a very tight ship when it comes to expenses so back office technology is far from the cutting edge.  There are a lot of systems and they are not integrated.  Some days it seems like most of my time is remembering user names and creating new passwords.

pros: Very stable company with opportunities to grow.  Benefits were among the best I've ever seen, and for banking, great use of and investment in technology.
cons: Banking doesn't pay as much as other industries.  Federal regulations and audits make "in house" innovation hard because all code, macros, and procedures must be approved before using.  Rarely does one get to use their own use of macros for efficiency because of these guidelines.

review_title: Do not work for Wells Fargo, it is the worst job ever
job_title: Personal Banker II – Registered in San Francisco, CA
pros: The pay is good, and the benefit is also good. Training is great, office is good. The co-workers are fine, not bad. Sometimes you can have a good manager if you are lucky.
cons: The sales goal is extremely high, they set up the goal for you which is next to impossible to reach, and even you can reach your goal, not means you can be paid, because they also add other numbers to your plate. If in the quarter, your store did not meet their goal, your personal goal will be tanked as well. How unfair it is!! Everyday is sale, is "jump start", from morning to evening, you will be called and e-mailed every 15 minutes, "keep you up date with your goal". Wells Fargo pays you not bad, but they suck blood out from you and your family.

review_title: It isn't what it used to be - most unfortunate
pros: I drank the kool-aid back in the days of Norwest. I'm a senior level manager who has had nothing but GREAT experiences with Wells Fargo - up until 2 years ago. I worked hard, and they rewarded me with promotions, recognition and increased compensation. Unfortunately, I'm located in Minneapolis. Now with the merger of WF and Wachovia, the senior level positions are being positioned in Charlotte rather than Minneapolis.
cons: There will be dramatic centralization efforts done over the next few years. This will likely mean even less jobs in Minneapolis.

review_title: Very diverse company, but at times there is very little room for progression out of an entry-level position.
job_title: Collateral Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
Team Leaders are very supportive and insightful when it comes to learning new things.
Company Website provides a variety of different training sessions and reading materials.  
Overall, Its a 'safe' job. if you do what your'e supposed to, you'll probably continue having a job.
cons: Promotions aren't very "above the board" and favoratism plays a role. I used to think that it was just the NY office, but I think its more of a everywhere in Wells thing.

review_title: Can be great depending on your branch and manager.
job_title: Personal Banker I in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great co-workers. Up to date technology compared to other banks. My branch manager is very supportive. Wells Fargo brand has prestige.
cons: Wells Fargo brand also has a lot of baggage. If you are in a branch with low walk-in volume you will spend a lot of time on the phone trying to get existing customers to open more accounts in order to make your daily sales volume. Very difficult to provide good customer service and make sales goals. Gallup surveys of customers require a perfect 5 out of 5 in 5 different metrics to pass. One 4 and the survey is failed. Some managers encourage sleazy tactics in order to meet sales goals. New account pricing making it more expensive for people with low account balances to bank. Cross-selling of insurance products like renter's and homeowner's insurance now mandatory.

pros: Wells Fargo is a good company to work for if you want need  flexibility with your schedule.  Great benefits.  You like to advance fast this is the place to work.
cons: The managers in Florida were not trained properly so they can train their staff while merger was taking place.  Wells Fargo hires employees from the outside and because the branches are not always fully staffed the managers do not get to shadow people in their position and their employees get very frustrated from not being trained properly.

review_title: I have too much integrity to be successful here.
job_title: Inbound Sales Specialist in Lubbock, TX
pros: Great benefits. Pretty good salary.
cons: You have to be OK with looking the other way at unethical practices and sales techniques.

pros: Time off was good and management was generally nice. I remain friends with my former coworkers, they were the best part!
cons: They say that they are a moral and ethical company, but they expected you to push sales and accounts on people that were not good. Also, if they were giving you sales credits and suddenly it looked too easy, they would stop giving credit for that item...but they still expected you to sell it.

job_title: Inbound Sales Specialist in Westlake, TX
pros: This job offers great experience for those who want to get their foot in the door with banking. You don't take work home with you. Bonus opportunities are $20,000 a year (but almost impossible).
cons: Being on the phones helping people wouldn't be so difficult if you could actually help them. The problem is management wants you to ignore the bad calls and focus on the good calls. When 50% of your calls are not opportunities, how can you be at a expected 75% referral rate? Its things like this that you WILL get tired of. Your voice will be heard but NOTHING will happen.

review_title: Steady paycheck but they could care less about employees and their sucess
job_title: Securities Operations Specialist in Glen Allen, VA
pros: Steady paycheck. Full benefits package.
cons: The company could care less about the success of the employees.  Turn over is high and they don't care.  Inexperienced management with power complexes.  They have some unethical practices to make money because they feel the gain outweighs the risk.  Anyone with a moral compass and who is looking for a company that is supportive in the growth of their employees should steer clear.

review_title: They know how to treat their employees!
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Fargo, ND
pros: Wells Fargo offers 401k matching, stock options, bonuses and more. They have a positive atmosphere and excellent OJT in a very comfortable office setting. Supervisors encourage you to work to your potential and offer any assistance they can to help you grow in your career and even as a person. They don't let you give up on yourself even when it gets tough.
cons: The actual job is somewhat high stress, but it's the nature of banking. There are always downsides to a job, so most of the cons at Wells Fargo are mostly unavoidable in any work setting.

pros: I'm currently an operations analyst for Wells Fargo's wholesale customer database (WCIS). The culture is great, half of the team is comprised of new college grads, the other half is made up of people in their late 30's. It is a great start for college grads to understand how systems communicate and to learn basic banking tech lingo if you're on route to be a BA.
cons: The ceilings for career and salary growth on the team are very low. The WCIS team is isolated on an island, in the back office of 3 Wells, making it very hard to meet front/mid office professionals unless you make networking an extracurricular activity.

pros:
-Good place to start your career id interested in banking/finance
-Experience of not only banking and products, but back end activities, such as check fraud
-Culture
cons: As a teller, you may be required to meet a referral goal or at least assist the branch in meeting it’s goals each month. This means you not only have to carry out each transaction quickly and accurately, you also must inform the customer of the bank’s products and try to encourage them to open other accounts or look into a loan. This is not easy and will irritate most people. However, if you do not make your goals you may face termination and even if you aren’t personally responsible for goals your branch manager will not appreciate a teller who refuses to cross- sell.

pros: You have a paycheck every other week.  Benefits and perks (that you have no time to take advantage of because you're working all the time).
cons: Unpredictable work hours.  You have a set start time, but never a set end time ('work until completion").  The less work your department has, the longer your hours are guaranteed to be for that day because people want to squeeze as much OT as they can from the company.  VERY unprofessional "team leaders" who talk to you as if they were in a street corner gang and incompetent management that refuses to do anything to address ongoing problems within a department.  The hours are so long and unpredictable that one couldn't possibly have time to do anything other than go straight home and fall asleep.

pros: My coworkers are the only thing that made this place bearable.
cons: Be prepared to trick people into getting services that they don't need because you and your branch need to reach your quota by the end of the month. If you didn't make any "sells" (didn't get any people to agree to enroll in a new credit card or another checking/savings account, debit cards etc.) you would be lectured and would be told that there would be "serious consequences" aka would be fired. There was serious favoritism and the managers are very sneaky. My manager used to give customers free services and refund their fees in exchange for free merchandise, concert tickets, sport tickets, pretty much whatever the people offered that he thought he could get use out of. Eventually they fired all the management and replaced everyone. Overall just a terrible experience working here.

pros: Great teamwork, autonomy, support from managers, training opportunities, flexibility, excellent benefits, good communication.
cons: No cons, this is a great place to work for those who are reliable, hardworking professionals and are willing to work as part of a team where everyone relies on each other to do the right thing and get the job done without cutting corners.

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The 401k plan has been very good for me.  They match 6% and have a wide variety of investment options.
cons: The company is huge and therefore it is very difficult to feel valued or that your views or opinions count.  The upper management (especially in the mortgage division) don't seem to understand what it's like on the front lines so some of the decisions they make don't seem to make sense.

pros:
- Bank job, you can enjoy A.C. 
- Not really a stressful job after no Sales Goal 
- Compared to other bank is much more easy to get a promotion chance
cons:
- Ridiculous management 
- Different branch different manager in charge; If you are luckily,  you got a good manger, then you will be fine.
- They don't know how to enhance teammates relationship 
- horrible working environment 
- I worked so many jobs before; This is the most drama job in my life ,and the useless service manager acting as BM who doesn't care. 
- Reward the lazy employee who shouldn't be rewarded 
- unfair working environment

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Raleigh, NC
pros: Good benefits package, medical coverage is comprehensive, 401-k match is healthy.
cons: They are the biggest, so with that comes all the red tape, as the scrutiny on them is the highest. Latest scandals don't make them look good as a brand. Commission structure is not competitive, especially if the loan is a refinance of a current wells fargo mortgage. Similar to other big banks commission package. If you want to earn more money, you need to work at a smaller company, broker banker etc. who will pay you more basis points for self sourced business. Wells Fargo provides a fair amount of leads, but pays you significantly less because of this. You could make as much money or more on one or two loan closings somewhere else, as you could with four or five at Wells Fargo.

review_title: Great benefits, terrible culture and corporate politics
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great benefits including health, dental, 401K matching, employee discounts. Generous and flexible PTO policy, which can be hard to find with other employers.
cons: Toxic, "watch-your-back" culture. Corporate politics at its worst here. Hard work and results aren't rewarded. It is very much who you know, who likes you, and if you are in the right club, and not what you know or how much you do/deliver. For this reason, the wrong people often get ahead and the good hard-working, results driven folks are overlooked, so they leave, or constantly look to leave. Heavy workload, unrealistic expectations and long hours make for poor work/life balance.

review_title: Great place to start your career
pros: The audit team is great at developing you into a good staff auditor.  They offer plenty of training to help you learn. They have several offices throughout the country, so you can choose where you want to work and live. Wells Fargo overall has great benefits compared to previous employers. Insurance is reasonably priced, plenty of time off, and great 401k.
cons: Audit is not allowed to work from home even though it would be easy to do so. They seem to over look internal candidates for promotions and it can be hard to get the opportunity to move up. Trying to move to another department can be hard also because they have very high standards for their required qualification.

pros: Benefits almost immediately, they do try to allow for work/life balance (at least my boss has been great with this), outlook on diversity and volunteering
cons: Hiring salary/raise amount could use work to be on par with other call centers/banks. Some favoritism when it comes to promoting. My position could be better crafted to allow for more career development into leadership. Mostly understaffed at all times. This position can be quite stressful and more could be done to make changes to allow this position to be more leadership within the site versus just back to back escalations all day.

review_title: not a bad job for those with customer service experience and little schooling
job_title: Account Resolution Specialist in Des Moines, IA
pros:
has a good culture I believe but is dependent on your team and manager and division
they would allow you to flex your time and it had a lot of PTO but the schedules weren't the most ideal
cons:
the job itself was a little soul-sucking but that's what you get when you deal with finances and people who can't control their own and it happens to us all
coworkers tend to be unprofessional
managers don't to much one on ones due to production needs and lack of development since it's supposed to be done on ones own time which fine and all but it would be encouraging to have management look out for you when they know where you stand

review_title: Do you know what pressure is??
pros: wells fargo offers a base salary for a sales job, with great benefits. no overtime cap, can, and will work plenty of overtime. lots of down time to play on the computer.
cons: high high high sales pressure, lack of respect. can be on top of the world one month, but see what happens when you have down month. constantly driven into the ground on a daily means about how bad you are doing. constantly pointing out all the negatives about being on the infamous "zero list". all about calling the same people cycled every week but still trying to force outrageous loans on prime customers. because they are the only ones who will be approved.

review_title: Wells Fargo, A great place to work!
pros: Wells Fargo supports their employees in everything they do.  They are major supporters of Diversity, and have great visions and values.  I must say that they are the best company I have ever worked for.  I know that I'll be a lifer here, because they treat their people well, and sincerely want them to succeed.
cons: The only downside I see is that there is not enough growth opportunity where I live.  They need to expand the jobs available in my area to encourage professional growth.

review_title: WF hires too many Underwriters and then has to let them go. Not a stable environment.
pros: The pay is good and co-workers are great.  Most managers are very supportive, but a few are feared by most people there.  When the volume is up, lots of overtime available.
cons: When the loan volume is high, they overhire underwriters and then have to let lots of them go once the volume subsides, so you never feel secure.  Also, QC auditors look for any little thing to ding you on and you get conflicting answers as to how Wells Fargo wants the file so you can get a write up from one QC auditor for overconditioning and a write up from a different QC auditor for excuding the same condition you were told was an overcondition.

review_title: Great - if you can get hired
pros: If you're an employee, you are golden.  Bonuses, perks, trips, etc
cons: if you're a contractor, they force you to only work 18 months and then you have to go on a mandatory 6 month layoff.  Not worth it. They don't keep their word about hiring contractors.   Too many contractors means constantly changing -turnover in departments every 18 months.  They don't pay contractors overtime.  They ask you to not bill the extra hours.  They work you 12-15 hour days.  No life outside of work.  Sitting on a beach checking your blackberry.

review_title: If you are good at sales, then this is the right place for you.
pros: They have really good benefits and an awesome training program. I enjoyed working with my customers, however, it is a customer service job so you get the good ones and the bad ones. What makes the job is the people you work with.
cons: Very sales orientated. You can get fired for not making sales. Where I work , there is no way for us to make our sales so there is a lot of turn over in that aspect. And they keep increasing sales goals each year which lowers moral for the employees.

pros:
Pay is decent for someone just out of school.  
Good vacation time.
Medical benefits start after 30 days.
cons:
-high stress and sales pressure for everyone down to the tellers
-Incentive pay is low and paid quarterly.  You recieve your incentive pay 6 weeks after the end of the previous quarter.  According to policy, you must be in your position at time of pay out to guarantee payment.   There are also maximum pay out caps per referral and per quarter.
-Training is not very comprehensive.  When you have a question baking support is often unhelpful and occasionally rude.

review_title: The branch manager is the scapecoat
job_title: Store/Branch Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great 401k company match up to 6%
cons: You are only as good as what you do every day. If you ever have a day that is not 100% in sales you will be publicly ridiculed on conference calls.

pros: Professional company.  Professional training, management, time-keeping, scheduling.  Treat employees great. Offer quarterly awards and benefits.  Orthodontia for kids (even for part-time employees).  If you're flexible to move, are motivated and work hard, you could move up in the company.
cons: Big time sales job.  I was surprised how much a teller is more of a sales person.  They really try to get you to sell accounts, add accounts, credit cards, over-draft protection, etc.  There are cash rewards for meeting set goals, but you are really trying to get people to sign up for something new, every customer, every time, every transaction.

review_title: Good place to work since you need the money but everything is all about sales sales sales sales!!
pros: You get compensation for meeting sales goals and for customer service essays but only if your whole team contributes. Promote from within. Everybody works as a team to meet each and everyone's sales goals by the end of the quarter. Having the right supervisor is EVERYTHING! The whole attitude of the team if based on the supervisors attitude. Everyone is a Valued Customer =)
cons: Too many sales to meet, over 300 per quarter. Kind of forces employees to force a new item on a customer although they don't need it. You can move up in the company but only if you brown nose the right behind, or else it turns where a qualified teller is teaching a recently promoted lead teller how to do their job.

review_title: TO GET AHEAD IT'S WHO YOU KNOW, NOT WHAT YOU KNOW, THAT COUNTS
job_title: Operations Analyst in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Work is close to where I live
cons: A publicly traded company, profits come first, then customer service.  Profits are unequally distributed throughout the company, with upper management taking the most profits, the front line employee is luck to see a couple of pennies for raises.  The average joe employee earns just enough to keep them above the poverty line.  There are layers and layers of management scrambling and meeting all day long to come up with idea's on how things can be "simpler" and "more efficient".  Technology has passed this company by, most everything at the Home Office is a very manual process.  The office culture moral is generally low, there is discrimination at most levels.

review_title: Not a rewarding place to work!
job_title: Personal Banker in Colorado Springs, CO
pros:
Coworkers are friendly
Good benefits
Lots of Locations
Gives good people skills
Gives good cash management skills
cons:
Can be long hours
Sales Pressure
Unreachable Sales Goals
Forced to do unethical things

review_title: Great Company overall but as with any corporation you may be a bit limited / restricted
job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great people to work with, excellent benefits, the resources of a large company, 401k match is excellent, numerous business lines to learn from and refer to.
cons: They want the ad services department to review my linked in account or shut it down.  Lots of audits / paperwork of a large company. Can be restrictive as far as marketing / advertising.

review_title: Unscrupulous managers and impossible sales goals
job_title: Lead Teller in Fort Collins, CO
pros: The benefits were the only upside.  Upon being hired as a teller I got 3 weeks of paid vacation and they match 401K contributions up to 6%.
cons: The sales goals were impossible to reach and management would often pressure tellers and bankers to find sneaky ways of tricking customers into opening accounts and credit cards that they did not need.  On several occasions we knew of bankers putting in HELOC applications without consent.  However, if someone brought it up to our store and district leadership that person would be ridiculed and publicly humiliated by management.  The company values are really at odds with most people's morality and it was a struggle to go in to work every day.

review_title: Ok, but the aggressive sales were beyond ridiculous!
pros: Lots of room for advancement if you excel in sales. A solid 98% of their best sellers utilized shady tactics, lies, and tricks at the customers expense. If you have morals and don't like to deceive or purposefully confuse, no luck here!
cons: The sales goals!! So aggressive! It truly doesn't matter how amazing you are at all other aspects of the job if you struggle with sales. And they WILL be on you! They rejoice in public shaming and will talk in your ear telling you what to sell your customer all the while you're attempting to concentrate and answer customer questions.

job_title: Contact Center Representative in Homewood, AL
pros: Good benefits: You get Paid Time Off (PTO) during your first year. Insurance, 401K, etc. The company is diversity focused. Casual attire because you don't have face to face contact with customers.
cons: More focused on selling new products rather than focusing on customer's immediate need. This results in errors, numerous call backs from customers. The most important Con is representatives have 282 seconds to complete the call from a customer and during this time the rep. has to disclose various scripts,resolve the issue, sell products, and transfer with a hold time to a sales agent. If reps don't consistently 282 sec. time, they are fired.

review_title: I appreciated the flexibility and support of management and the atmosphere was relaxed but still professional.
pros: You will be rewarded based on your performance with incentive bonuses and sometimes gift cards. Usually start with 3 weeks vacation and in addition,a set number of total hours for personal or sick days. Opportunities to advance.
cons: If working an entry level job such as Phone Bank or Online Customer Service, then there is strict time management, micromanagement, and matrix (goals) management. If you fail any matrix standard, then you will not make incentive and you will be warned. If after warned and still don't meet goals, then you will be placed on probation and could lose your job after several consecutive months of not meeting matrix standard. Probation will prevent you from posting out to another job in the company.

job_title: Loan Administration Manager II in Frederick, MD
pros: Large company, plenty of opportunities if you make/take them.  Good 401K Match up to 6 percent.  Decent PTO.
cons: Mortgage Servicing is experiencing mass budget cuts resulting in many lost jobs or should I say "displaced" team members.  The little bit of perks you did have - dept. picnics, pizza for the team working OT, etc. have gone away.  Constant talks about budget as if we aren't a megabank.

review_title: Good company with some bad areas
pros: Benefits are good though the cost goes up every year, 401K plan, other discounts the company offers also very good. You can post out for other positions within the company for better opportunities and/or to gain more knowledge-just need to be mindful of minimum requirements of potential job as this basically needs to match your resume.
cons: All areas/business lines/departments are not managed the same so work/life balance may vary.  The business line I worked in had many micro-managers who exhibited unprofessional behavior.  Complaints from the staff were not addressed or you were confronted by the person as to why you had an issue.  Also the longer you stay in a department, the harder it may be to post to another opportunity.

job_title: Retirement Service Representative in Roseville, MN
pros: The paychecks we're some of the most beautiful things I've ever seen. Clean, comfortable,quiet, fancy and professional environment. Free food all the time.
cons: Where do I start? First of all, the job is tough. We get screamed at and swore at on a daily basis. And on top of that, management freaks out if you even go to the bathroom when its not your scheduled break time. Management was "new" and was so busy proving his undying loyalty to the company that he neglected his employees.  You end up sacrificing your breaks, just to keep your numbers up, which creates an extremely hostile work environment Employees are just temporary scapegoats to this company. People get fired constantly.

pros: It was generally a fairly relaxed atmosphere.  They provided plenty of volunteer opportunities and some matching charity contributions.  Benefits were good.  Insurance options included legal and long term disability, as well as normal health/dental/life/vision choices.  PTO instead of vacation/sick time.  They provided around 20 days within the first year.
cons: Pay raises became very poor.  There's not much hope to make money if you're hired at a low salary, unless you move to a totally different position.  When I worked there there was a lot of consolidation, and it wasn't always done wisely.  Also a lot of turnover/movement within the company.  I had a direct boss for about 7 years and I think his boss changed 6 times in that period.

pros: Wells Fargo offers 401(k) and matches up to 6 percent after your first year along with tuition assistance for school relevant to business. Offers great flexibility with hours to be able to go to school, a lot of room for improvement they have many different positions in Wells Fargo that isn't limited to just retail banking. Not to mention they offer great health insurances and lots of holiday pays and paid time off.
cons: Can be very stressful at times, you pick up many extra responsibilities that aren't on your job description.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Reno, NV
pros: Its a good company, worked there for 7 1/2 years and went through up and downs, but the people that I worked with were mostly wonderful, when I mean people I mean co-workers .  Pay is competitive and benefits are excellent, overall I was satisfied with my time there financially speaking.
cons: Management and leadership is out of touch, they have been there forever and they do not seem to care about the workers, they have a different view, they always look at your from their perspective, never from your shoes, if they were to take calls from customers for a single day they would probably quit.

review_title: With no real metrics, favoritism runs rampant
pros: 6% 401k match, good benefits (three months for adoption and new parents, tuition reimbursement, discount mortgage and loan rates.
cons:
Management is entirely incompetent. With so many years of deceptive sales practices the very people who were doing shady things are now managing teams, not because they're experienced, but because sales. The bank pushes employee recognition to an extreme, it's forced. We are required to send 5 e-cards weekly. The area in which I work also happens to consist entirely of management from another town nearby who were all high school friends with their direct manager (coincidence?)
Management is petty with all of the team. Documents unnecessary items to keep in employee files as leverage against employees, not discreet about it whatsoever. There is no exaggeration when I say petty things. Toxic environment, forced culture, fake management, no clear path to promotion, no real coaching. Vile.

review_title: Not bad for a large institution focused solely on the street
pros: If you don't like your current job, wait 1 year, interview for another one within the company. If you are lucky enough to come in at a senior level, comp and benefits are quite good. If you're in the top 15% during review time, merit increases aren't that far below average for the industry.
cons: Lots of bad managers who sneak by making their leadership "comfortable." Anyone who wants to make a real difference slowly has the passion and conviction strangled out of them.  Many experienced, hardworking and loyal employees are taken for granted and under compensated in favor of bright new talent.

review_title: Mediocre -- at best -- in most respects
job_title: Marketing Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Opportunity to move around and up -- although it's getting harder since the Wachovia merger and due to cost cutting. Slightly easier  if you are a sought-after Millennial.
Good benefits, and fairly generous PTO... although they've been pulling back on the latter to save money.
Work/life balance
cons:
More interested in optics that the true toxic culture.
Poor leadership/weak management mean lots of lifers who phone it in.  (The other face of work/life balance.) There's a lot of mediocrity hiding in plain sight.
Cronyism is the norm, enabling many team members to coast.

review_title: Good place to start, then leave
pros: Wells offers more training than most banks, has a well articulated corporate values & mission statement.  Wells also offers some good potential to move up if you are willing to move around.
cons: Wells is very gimicky and slow to increase pay.  They will promise a lot but steadily and consistently undermine the value of your pay package with "adjustments" to bonus programs.  Wells also suffers from a huge amount of cronieism.  Being a chear leader is much more important than results as everyone lines up to look their best by stroking each and every promotion or idea that comes through.
